webTitle: Famous five for the heart of Eriksson's new England

fields.headline: Famous five for the heart of Eriksson's new England
fields.trailText: Every good team in history has had a strong, established nucleus: David Beckham, Paul Scholes, Steven Gerrard, Emile Heskey and Sol Campbell are the ones for Sven.
fields.body:
When Sven-Goran Eriksson picks his first England squad this afternoon he will have more in mind than just the Spain game or trying to qualify for the World Cup. He will already be thinking towards Euro 2004 in Portugal and the World Cup in Germany in 2006, and I feel there are five players he should build his side around.

Every good team in history has had a strong, established nucleus. England in 1966 were a prime example and France have had a core who have been together for three or four years. Eriksson's main men should be David Beckham, Paul Scholes, Steven Gerrard, Emile Heskey and Sol Campbell.

Starting at the back with Campbell, his experience is important with Tony Adams missing. He plays better in international football than for Spurs. The extra motivation may bring out the best in him but internationals are not so much of a hurly-burly as club matches and, although Sol is big and strong, he prefers a thinking game to total blood and guts.

Ahead of him Gerrard has to be a prime thought if he can stay fit. He is doubtful for the Spain game and that nagging injury situation is the only reservation you would put against someone who has the lot. He can tackle, pass, do the holding job and also support and get his shots in.

The hope has to be that, as he gets older and stronger, the injuries disappear because I can see Eriksson wanting him in a five-man midfield in a lot of games, with Heskey as a lone striker. In international football you have to control the middle of the park, and in any case people coming from deep can be more difficult to mark, as Pablo Aimar showed for Valencia.

Beckham would be my playmaker from the centre of midfield but I wouldn't want him to be a deep playmaker, constantly playing five yards off the defenders. I'd like him to be getting the ball higher up the field and making the play from there.

What really sticks in mind is the goal he scored for United in the 3-2 defeat by Real Madrid last season, when he picked up the ball in the last third, sidestepped two defenders and unleashed a rocket shot. I would like to see him do that more often.

Beckham's best value is in the top half. People say that against Valencia he did not do well but he was stuck on the right wing. He is not a winger and, if he gets pinned down, he is fairly easy to mark. He can go at people but he is not Ryan Giggs. He is better at beating people with passing and movement off the ball.

When he plays in central areas he has the quality to play good balls into the front and then support on the outside. In a way I would like to see him fill the sort of role Bobby Charlton did for England. Bobby could come deep but he made sure he got forward enough times.

It is important that the midfield players are encouraged to do that, and that is Scholes's natural game. If you took a poll among football people, an awful lot would have Scholes as the country's most valuable player. He has that priceless asset from midfield of being able to do a lot of the busy, ugly work and be an expert finisher when he gets in the box.

He may not be the best defensively but he is trying to improve on that and, if England are to play with just one striker in a lot of games, midfield players who can support the strikers, get into scoring positions and finish are vital.

To be that lone striker you need a physical presence and Heskey has it. He is developing more and more into a player who can protect the ball from defenders if it is played into him and he has the pace to go it alone.

The thing that convinced me - and I hope it was not a flash in the pan - was his performance against Italy when he was up against Alessandro Nesta and Fabio Cannavaro, two of the most dogmatic, natural defenders in the world. They were very respectful of him.

If he continues the progress he is making at Liverpool and carries on learning about movement and making runs, he can be the man for England. He could still do with scoring a few ugly goals, going in for sliding tap-ins, but he has got more headers in this season and there has been an improvement in his finishing.

Of course he could also play in a pair with Michael Owen or Robbie Fowler but I would start him alone against Spain in this side: Seaman; Gary Neville, Brown, Campbell, Ashley Cole; Dyer, Beckham, Gerrard or Ince, Scholes, McManaman; Heskey.

webTitle: Jackson tribute show breaches charity law

fields.headline: Jackson tribute show breaches charity law
fields.trailText: Exclusive: Popstar Michael Jackson's official visit to the UK next month has been plunged into controversy after it emerged that a special Jackson tribute fundraising event at which the singer is to appear is in breach of charity law, a SocietyGuardian investigation has revealed.
fields.body:
Popstar Michael Jackson's official visit to the UK next month has been plunged into controversy after it emerged that a special Jackson tribute fundraising event at which the singer is to appear is in breach of charity law, a SocietyGuardian investigation has revealed.

Publicity for the event on one of the singer's approved fan clubs' websites says the Sargent Cancer Care for Children charity will share around £100,000 expected to be raised by the annual event - called Michael Jackson day - in London on March 7.

The website also publishes what appears to be a personal signed letter from Mr Jackson in which the singer states that the event will benefit Sargent cancer care and his own Heal the Kids charity.

But Sargent cancer care today said it "will not benefit financially from the proceeds of the event". It asked for its name to be removed from all publicity for the event, on the grounds that this could mislead the public, on February 21.

Commercial promoters are obliged by law to enter into a written contract with a charity if they wish to use its name to sell a product or service - but Sargent said it had not signed any contract with the promoter of the event, Adrian Grant.

Sargent Cancer Care for Children's spokeswoman Zena Fernandes said: "We have asked the Michael Jackson fan club to remove information about the charity from their web page because it could be misleading."

Mr Grant told SocietyGuardian that he had a "verbal agreement" with Sargent, that he had exchanged emails with Sargent about the event, and that he expected a contract to be signed soon. "I am waiting for Sargent to come to us with a written agreement," he said.

He said he had issued Sargent Cancer Care for Children 500 free tickets, which the charity could sell to make a profit. Mr Grant added: "If they don't want to be named as a beneficiary, they will have to give the tickets back."

But a Sargent spokeswoman denied that it had been in discussions with Mr Grant about endorsing the event: "He was not in negotiations with the charity. I was in negotiations with our volunteers. I can't comment on what his impressions (of the latter negotiations) were."

She said supporters of the charity had bought the tickets and the proceeds would go to the promoter: "Generous supporters of Sargent are proposing to buy some of the tickets to enable children with cancer and some of their families to attend the concert.

"The price of the tickets paid for by our supporters will go directly to the promoter."

Although the link to the charity's website was removed from the mjworld site during the SocietyGuardian investigation, the claim that the event was benefiting Sargent had last night not been amended.

The fan club website mjworld.net claims: "Another very special reason to attend this event is to help us, and Michael, raise over £100,000 for Heal the Kids and Sargent Cancer Care for Children, an organisation ... that is very close to Michael's heart."

Ticket agency Tickets Direct said on Thursday that more than 1,000 tickets had already been sold and confirmed that "all profits from the tickets would go to the two charities".

A spokesperson for the Charity Commission, the government regulator of charities, said: "Any promotion of this type would require the permission of the charity concerned and the promoters would have to have a written agreement with them.

"It is for the charity to ensure that either an agreement is reached or that their name is removed from all publicity."

The Charity Commission said it would "give it a bit of time" before taking any action.

A charity lawyer, Rosamund Smith, said it is a criminal offence for a commercial promoter not to have a written contract with a charity when it is using the charity's name to sell a product or service.

The legislation has been in force since 1992 as part of the Charities Act but there have been very few prosecutions.

Ms Smith, of law firm Bates, Wells and Braithwaite, said: "It is very difficult for charities to enforce as they have very little bargaining power. Some charities don't want to make a fuss if they are going to receive money, but it is a major concern when unauthorised fundraising takes place and the charity doesn't want the relationship."

Mr Jackson plans to launch Heal the Kids at the Oxford Union on March 6 but the Charity Commission has confirmed it has not received an application for registration.

Heal the Kids is being co-launched with Rabbi Shmuley Boteach, author of the Jewish marriage guide Kosher Sex, and a close adviser of Mr Jackson.

Other members of the charity's board include former Israeli prime minister Shimon Peres, Dr Stanley Greenspan, a professor of psychiatry and paediatrics, and actress Elizabeth Taylor.

The website promoting the Heal the Kids charity says the idea came from major studies which show "that children who experience no tactility, no tenderness or hugging in their formative years, bear emotional scars that will not heal later in life".

fields.headline: The questions we asked
fields.trailText:
Two years on from the Macpherson report, the Guardian is conducting a survey of the
                                                                  43 forces in England and Wales to find
                                                                  out what progress has been made. We conducted a similar survey last year. We
                                                                  have taken our questions from data Her
                                                                  Majesty's Inspector of Constabulary
                                                                  asked forces to keep, as set out in
                                                                  Winning the Race, and recommendations
                                                                  by Sir William Macpherson himself.
fields.body:
Two years on from the Macpherson report, the Guardian is conducting a survey of the 43 forces in England and Wales to find out what progress has been made. We conducted a similar survey last year. We have taken our questions from data Her Majesty's Inspector of Constabulary asked forces to keep, as set out in Winning the Race, and recommendations by Sir William Macpherson himself.

The questions we asked included:

1. How many ethnic minority officers do you have now? And as a percentage of the total number of officers?

2. What is the latest figure you have for the clear up rate of racist crimes and incidents?

fields.headline: Touts, temples and tourists
fields.standfirst: Newly arrived in Indonesia, Sue wonders whether the touts can smell her approaching, grapples with her excess baggage and tours Bali, where possible away from the tourists
fields.trailText: Week 13: Singapore to Bali Newly arrived in Indonesia, Sue wonders whether the touts can smell her approaching, grapples with her excess baggage and tours Bali, where possible away from the tourists
fields.body:
So at last I have left Malaysia. I re-entered Singapore to fly to Bali through the 'back door' - by train from Kuala Lumpur. Anyone who has been in Singapore airport will know that it epitomises the country, flash, efficient, air-con, expensive shops. By contrast the railway station is scruffy, not many facilities and a roadside-type canteen. This puzzled me until I was told that all Singaporeans fly and in fact the station belongs to Malaysia.

I returned briefly to my nephew's to pick up a few things. I had bought a sports bag for those times when I go off for just a few days, and somehow this has become full as well. I haven't bought much - only another pair of shorts, two T-shirts, a pair of flip flops, a second novel, and a few toilet rolls - this was a mistake as I asked for one in a market and was sold one pack of 12. I've taken the middles out and did abandon some. . . perhaps I am beginning to see how I have filled another bag. Oh and I forgot the dozen hotel soaps.

With all my bags I arrived in Bali at 1am. Despite all the warnings from emailers I stayed in Kuta that night as it was so near. Having had a few late nights and not getting to bed that night until after 2am, I got the shock of my life when I woke the next day to find it was 2pm. The staff were polite enough to laugh when I asked if it was too late for breakfast. A wander through Kuta, crowded with touts, bronzed surfers, and pink Europeans led me straight to the travel office to book a ticket to Ubud, where I am now.

Still fairly touristy, Ubud is much more laid back than Kuta with far fewer touts. Wandering around the shops full of paintings, wood carvings, batik and knick-knacks can fill many an hour. There is a dance show every evening and I went to see the Larong dance, the more formal court dancing with wonderful costumes. It was great. I met up with American Ed, my neighbour in the lovely homestay where I am lodging, and James and Dominique, from NZ and France, all with years of being on the road around the world with lots of stories and tips. We hired a car at a ridiculous price (times are not good in Bali) and went up to the rim of the volcano, Mt. Batur and the lake beside. We were just in time to admire the view before the clouds came over and it rained. The touts here were terrible, pulling at your arm and even shouting through the door of the restaurant.

We found a deserted road that skirted the lake through a layer of solidified lava. Feeling free of sellers we got out of the car to enjoy the views at leisure. Out of nowhere came a motorbike, complete with driver and collection of paintings. How do they do it? - radar, short wave radios, acute sense of the smell of tourists?

We carried on to some hot springs. Here an entrepreneur had built a luxury hotel, lovely swimming pool and a complex of discrete thatched jacuzzis - all except the swimming pool now abandoned and gradually decaying - perhaps a reflection of how Bali has been hit by the recent political and economic troubles of the region. A few desperate locals tried to sell us some shorts, crisps or a massage, but were good humoured enough when we declined. Driving back off the main roads you begin to see the appeal of Bali, with the rice fields, forests and little villages.

On Tuesday I rented a rather dubious mountain bike and headed off. I couldn't seem to find a way off the scary main road and found myself by accident at the Neka museum, a beautifully laid out art gallery showing the development of Balinese art. I loved the traditional paintings but was also impressed by the work of new young artists, retaining a distinct Balinese style despite European influences. I did then manage to find some back roads, often walking down as well as up the very steep hills, even finding a little cafe where they did not speak English (fortunately Coke is universal). An enjoyable, if hot and tiring day. I wonder if anyone at home has repaired my bike, immobile for three years.

Thinking of home, I am increasingly struck by how much poorer and yet much happier the people seem in Asia. Everywhere I have been the people all smile and say hello, the youngsters career about joyfully on their scooters and motorbikes with no sign of disaffection, even the babies and toddlers, always up very late, rarely seem to cry. It seems such a contrast to the stress and rush of people in England, with road rage and Friday night drunken brawls. Maybe it is the sunshine, or maybe the knowledge that Western wealth is virtually unattainable makes them more content with their lot. I do not know. I only know it is a pleasure to be among them.

On Thursday poor Ed was struck down with 'Bali belly'. I think he must have eaten the same as Bruce who has been poorly this week and would not have his photo taken when not looking his best. Typical male - they are much vainer than us women.

Leaving Ed with stocks of bottled water, sweet tea and aspirin, I went on the 'sunset tour' of west Bali. This was a visit to a rice terrace, the Royal Family Temple at Mengwi, a batik studio, where I was sorely tempted to spend lots of money, and the Holy Monkey forest, swarming with greedy monkeys, bats and tourists. I decided I had taken enough monkey photos and went for the bats. The last stop was the Tanah Lot temples, perched on the cliffs above volcanic rocks and sand, battered by huge rollers. Hundreds of tourists jockeyed for positions to take photographs of the stunning sunset - me included.

At last I feel I am getting to grips with Bali. Initially the crowds and touts, umpteen rows of bamboo wind chimes and wooden cats made it disappointing, but as the week has gone on and you see the ordinary Balinese at work in the countryside, notice the little rice offerings outside every shop and house, see the wonderful art still vibrant, you come to appreciate that there is more to Bali than tourism. It is still a beautiful place and its native culture still very much alive.

Having recharged my batteries in Ubud these last few days, I may round it off with a massage this afternoon, if I can find somewhere that looks OK. Tomorrow I am setting off to the east and north of the island, following email advice - thanks everyone.

All you emailers who promised advice on Australia, now is the time. I fly to Darwin next Friday. I am going to try and change the next flight which is from Darwin to Sydney two weeks later. If I can't, I need a two-week trip from Darwin that allows me to see as much as possible. Any suggestions - should I go east, west or south?

I hope spring has arrived back home - I will miss the daffodils.

Sue

webTitle: Right to roam plans leave farmers angry and campaigners wary

fields.headline: Right to roam plans leave farmers angry and campaigners wary
fields.trailText: Proposals to open access to the countryside and give rural communities the right to buy surrounding land were yesterday unveiled by the Scottish executive to a chorus of criticism.
fields.body:
Proposals to open access to the countryside and give rural communities the right to buy surrounding land were yesterday unveiled by the Scottish executive to a chorus of criticism.

The draft bill outlaws Keep Out and No Trespassing signs, and enables communities to register their interest in land important to them. Farmers' leaders claimed it would open land to a rambling free for all, while ramblers said the bill would actually restrict access.

Land reform is an emotive issue. Scotland has 343 people or bodies owning more than half of private rural land, the highest concentration in the world. There has been anger at the sale of estates and beauty spots like the Cuillin mountain range, recently on the open market at £10m. There has also been confusion surrounding the law of access.

It is proposed to create a right of responsible access to land, including inland waters, for recreation. Access can be limited on grounds of health and safety, security or privacy, and when crops are growing, but landowners will have to take down any permanent signs barring entry and give reasons for any restriction.

The bill would also give rural communities a legal right to buy land when it goes on sale. They will be able to register an interest, and will have a 30 day space to decide whether to exercise the right-to-buy, which could be funded by a new Scottish land fund set up with nearly £11m of lottery funding.

Crofting communities will be able to buy the land on which they live and work at any time.

The proposals now go to pub lic consultation. The deputy first minister, Jim Wallace, said: "I believe this legislation will provide responsible enjoyment of the countryside and provide opportunities for rural and crofting communities."

Campaigners welcomed the proposals but Andy Wightman said: "It is not going to achieve a massive shake-up in ownership." Cameron McNeish, president of the Ramblers Association in Scotland said: "The legislation, rather than improving access opportunities, would restrict our cherished freedom to walk on land."

The National Farmers' Union has withdrawn from the forum to discuss the legislation.

webTitle: Blair to extend ties with EU and America

fields.headline: UK to extend ties with EU and America, says Blair
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair staked out his general election foreign policy stance against the Tories yesterday, claiming that Britain could have "the best of both worlds" as a trusted North American ally and as a committed part of the EU.
fields.body:
Tony Blair staked out his general election foreign policy stance against the Tories yesterday, claiming that Britain could have "the best of both worlds" as a trusted North American ally and as a committed part of the EU, and calling for renewed free trade links across the Atlantic.

In an address to both houses of the Canadian parliament in Ottawa, Mr Blair said he rejected "point blank" the claim among some Tories that the UK had to make a choice between Europe and America.

But Mr Blair also pinched one of William Hague's favourite lines by proposing closer links between the EU and the North Atlantic free trade association (Nafta) in a fresh drive towards global free trade.

Mr Blair will face the toughest test of his self-appointed role as transatlantic foreign policy middle man when he flies to Camp David today for his first meeting with President George Bush. The controversial US national missile defence project will be top of his agenda.

As the prime minister left Ottawa last night for Washington, aides to the Canadian prime minister, Jean Chrétien, sought to calm speculation that Mr Bush may be ready to back off on NMD in the face of EU, Russian and Chinese concern.

Mr Chrétien told the Cana dian House of Commons on Wednesday that the Bush administration had "decided they will not proceed if it will cause a lot of problems for Nato and if they cannot find an arrangement with the Chinese and the Russians".

But Mr Chrétien stepped back from those remarks yesterday at a press conference with Mr Blair, saying NMD was a military decision which would be taken by Washington. Mr Chrétien's aides said it would "absolutely wrong" to claim the Canadian leader had received any kind of a promise from Washington that the US might not proceed with NMD.

Mr Blair prepared for today's Camp David summit with Mr Bush by burnishing his credentials as an Atlanticist and by taking a calculated pre-election swipe at Tory party and rightwing press claims that Britain faced a choice of alliances between Europe and North America.

"We will have the best of both worlds. We will give up neither relationship. We will make them both work," Mr Blair said in his speech.

The prime minister said he was "a committed Atlanticist" but also a European, "unshakeable in my view that Britain's future is as a leading player in Europe, a force for good, and a force for reform inside the EU".

"There are those in my country who say it is not possible to be all those things. You can have Europe, or you can have North America, but you cannot have both and that Britain has to choose," Mr Blair told the Canadian MPs. "It is an article of my political faith that I refuse point blank to do so."

His audience cheered as Mr Blair twice dipped into French as part of his address to the bilingual parliament.

Though Mr Blair's speech contained a robust defence of the European defence initiative, an issue which is likely to cause rocky passages when he gets to Camp David, Downing Street was keen to draw attention to the section on Nafta, in which Mr Blair appeared to pull off a classic New Labour manoeuvre by adopting a Tory issue as his own.

Mr Blair said Europe should make new efforts to strengthen the EU-Nafta relationship by aiming to end a series of transatlantic disputes "over issues like beef and bananas" before the June EU summit in Gothenberg, Sweden.

He said the two sides should agree a "political declaration of intent" on trade and aim for "duty free and quota free access for everything but arms".

"It's time we started to argue vigorously and clearly for free trade," Mr Blair said. "The case against it is misguided and, worse, unfair. However sincere the protests, they cannot be allowed to stand in the way of rational argument."

webTitle: Tories hope 180 swing seats will confound pollsters

fields.headline: Tories hope 180 swing seats will confound pollsters
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Despite the polls William Hague's aides insist that he is convinced he can pull off a surprise victory.
fields.body:
Despite the polls William Hague's aides insist that he is convinced he can pull off a surprise victory.

While virtually the entire shadow cabinet have resigned themselves to a Labour victory, the Tory leader has adopted a Panglossian optimism regardless of the circumstances.

He and the party chairman, Michael Ancram, the only two senior Tories who believe they are heading for Downing Street, pin their hopes on 2.5m swing voters in 180 seats they believe could deliver them victory. Three factors will convince the so called middle income "pebbledash" voters to embrace the Tories.

First, the opinion polls disguise widespread anger with the government for being arrogant and out of touch. Second, Michael Portillo's tax cuts, carefully aimed at middle income earners, will appeal on the doorstep. Third, the Keep the Pound campaign will play well with the majority of voters who are opposed to the single currency.

So the theory goes. By the time the election is called, the Tories will have delivered their message to more than half of their target voters through a call centre at Central Office. So far, 1.25m voters have been contacted, and all 2.5m voters in the target seats have been sent a mailshot.

The 180 seats have been graded to avoid wasting resources in seats where the Tories already stand a good chance or in seats where they will struggle.

John Flack, the amiable rightwinger who hopes to win back Mr Portillo's old seat of Enfield Southgate in north London, admits that he is likely to be left to his own devices. His seat, 23rd on the list, would return to the Tory fold on a swing of 1.55%. A little further down the list, Michael Simpson can expect shadow cabinet visits in Putney in south London, where he needs a swing of 3.4%.

One Tory MP said yesterday that he could not understand the polls, because the hostile reception he received on the doorsteps in 1997 had been replaced by a genuine warmth. The MP, who asked to remain anonymous, said: "No one believes that we will win the election - Tony Blair would have to commit a serious crime for that to happen. But today's polls, which I believed in 1997, do not reflect the view on the streets. People who abandoned us in 1997 are coming back."

Another Tory said that a rural/urban split could explain the dire polls. "We are in real trouble in urban areas - I see no signs of a recovery in London," the source said. "But we could do well in rural seats where on paper we do not stand a chance."

Once the election is called an efficient "war room" at Central Office, staffed by 60 press officers and researchers, starts work. However, on the ground the Tories are dangerously short of activists. In 1979, when Margaret Thatcher first won, they had more than 12,000 councillors, the backbone of a campaign. This figure has nearly halved.

webTitle: History only hope as polls demolish Hague

fields.headline: History only hope as polls demolish Hague
fields.standfirst:
As the election approaches, he is fast becoming the Michael Foot of the Conservative party - but could he be the next Edward Heath?

Special report: election countdown
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Faced by the devastating opinion polls this week, William Hague and mission control, as Central Office likes to call itself, will be searching for salvation in history.
fields.body:
Faced by the devastating opinion polls this week, William Hague and mission control, as Central Office likes to call itself, will be searching for salvation in history.

This is difficult since the polls are so unprecedentedly ghastly for the Tories. No political party has been so far behind in the polls so close to an election and won. The Conservatives are facing the psychic shock of being out of power for as long as nine years - the first time the Tories have been so completely excluded from power for nearly a century. They did not win an election in their own right between 1900 and 1922 after the collapse of the Lloyd George coalition.

The Guardian's ICM poll on Monday showed Labour's lead in February rising to 15%, an increase of five points on the previous poll, and larger than the 13 points by which Labour won the 1997 election. The findings caused a particular shiver since the Tories rely on ICM for their own poll findings.

ICM also makes more effort than any other pollster to weigh its results to take account of the so-called shy Tory spiral of silence, the greater tendency of Conservative supporters to deny their voting intention.

The Times poll, conducted by Mori and published on Wednesday, showed Labour with a 20 point lead, with, for the first time since March 2000, more Tory supporters dissatisfied than satisfied with Hague's performance as party leader.

This is made more grim as most pollsters claim voters have made up their minds well before polling day.

Mr Hague is in danger of becoming the Michael Foot of the Conservative party, the man who dragged the Conservatives to a bigger defeat than necessary. And even Mr Foot enjoyed a poll lead over the Tories in the mid-term of the Thatcher administration.

At the very least, Mr Hague must have hoped to be the Tory Neil Kinnock, the man who rebuilt the party's shattered foundations, but did not put the roof on. Mr Hague, who is calmly self-assured, sees himself instead as the next Sir Edward Heath.

Hagueites tend to cite Heath's unexpected 1970 election victory as proof that the polls can be horribly wrong.

Indeed, in 1970 only one polling organisation got the result right. At one point the bookies had Labour at 20 to one to win. Following Harold Wilson's ejection from office, some chastened political correspondents ("Harold's got it in the bag" was one famous headline) were asked to write front page mea culpas, explaining to readers how they got the result so badly wrong.

In his memoirs, Sir Edward recalled how he at least was always sure he would win.

He wrote: "Our private polls told us that our message was getting through. At the start of the campaign, voters thought Labour would be better at dealing with an economic crisis, but by polling day we were nearly 10 points ahead on that issue, despite Labour's attempts to portray our restrained criticisms as scare tactics."

By legend, a bad trade deficit for May, announced on June 15 and dismissed as "a couple of Jumbo jet orders", contradicted Labour's claims to have solved the balance of payments problem. On polling day itself, the worst unemployment figures for 30 years were announced. But if Mr Hague draws comfort from this, it is difficult to see what comparable bad economic news is lying in wait to trap Gordon Brown. Unemployment, inflation and interest rates seem to be set fair - and falling. The March jobless figures may drop below 1m for the first time since 1975.

The Conservatives need a 7.3% swing to ensure that Labour loses 90 seats, and its overall majority. The next important landmark comes with a 7.6% swing. If the Tories achieve this across the country, giving them a 2.2% lead in votes and allowing them to capture Erewash in Derbyshire, they would hold 265 seats in England, a majority of the English seats.

In search of the silver lining for Mr Hague, pollsters tend to point to three factors. Voters are nowadays more volatile. Mr Blair's personal ratings rose by 6% on the weekend his son Leo was born. Voters are also less loyal to class or party. The sudden fuel crisis last Autumn culminated with Labour trailing the Tories in two polls.

But this turn-around evaporated, as rapidly as it appeared, something that still confuses Labour as much as the Tories.

Frustratingly for Mr Hague, polls also repeatedly show voters stubbornly do not blame Mr Blair for many public ills. He has been undamaged by floods, rail disasters, the dome or the loss of Peter Mandelson. The Guardian-ICM poll showed a small fall in Labour voters certain to vote. By contrast, the Mori poll showed no difference between Labour and Conservative "likelihood to vote". Both polls have recently been showing "likelihood-to-vote figures" are lower than at equivalent stages in the previous parliament.

Mr Hague can draw comfort from the fall in turn-out in 1997, partly because the result was seen as a foregone conclusion. But many 1997 election studies also show the Labour working class did not turn out in 1997. This was, however, counter-balanced by a greater willingness of the Labour-supporting middle classes in marginal seats to turn out.

fields.headline: Pop's university challenge - round two
fields.trailText: It certainly got you all going. We've had a tremendous amount of feedback on our graduate pop chart. What's more, your replies have caused quite a bit of movement in the table, with a number of new entries and a new number one.
fields.body:
It certainly got you all going. We've had a tremendous amount of feedback on our graduate pop chart. What's more, your replies have caused quite a bit of movement in the table, with a number of new entries and a new number one.

But first, an apology. It seems we were wrong to state that the missing member of the Manic Street Preachers, Richey Edwards, went to Cardiff University. According to quite a number of you, he was most definitely at Swansea - the 'proof' coming from Dr Jemma Hine who claimed to have shared a house with him at Swansea while he was learning to play guitar. The definitive answer could only really come from Richey himself, but so far, he's not been in touch. Swansea get the points, including the extra 'cred' points for being a mysteriously missing Manic - Cardiff lose out.

Many of you were keen to point to our mistakes, but a note of defiance might be in order here in the face of some of the more brutal criticisms. For one, how do we define 'star'? We feel we've been generous, but even we couldn't bring ourselves to include 'Rockin' Louie' or various members of, frankly, quite obscure hardcore punk bands from the early eighties. So they don't count in our revised table. Sorry.

Misinformation abounded. Either Suede and Pulp and Judge Jules are serial graduates or a number of institutions are laying false claim to their talents. Where there is serious doubt, we had to discount the votes. Our best piece of inside information came from a member of Van Der Graaf Generator who gave us a full account of the band's links to Manchester University. Extra points there.

One or two glaring omissions came to light. John Lennon's period at the Liverpool Art School (now part of Liverpool John Moore's), the plethora of talent to emerge from St Martins, Liverpoo; and Goldsmiths and the mysteriously popular band The Higsons. If as many of you bought Higsons records as pointed out that Charlie 'Fast Show" Higson went to UEA, then his career might have taken a whole different turn.

The final table puts Manchester at the top - not a big surprise given the city's musical reputation. A late burst from Goldsmiths secured second spot. Oxford's association with Ugly Rumours keeps them routed to the bottom, despite claims surrounding cutting edge dance music.

The allocation of cred points and deductions for what we decide is naff make it all a dubious electoral process, but you can keep the feedback, and the votes, coming in to jimmy.leach@theguardian.com

webTitle: Universities issue warning over tuition fees

fields.headline: Universities issue warning over tuition fees
fields.trailText: University heads yesterday warned the government it would have to consider raising student fees to fund a £900m a year shortfall if it wants to meet its targets.
fields.body:
University heads yesterday warned the government it would have to consider raising student fees to fund a £900m a year shortfall if it wants to meet its targets.

In a direct challenge to education secretary David Blunkett, who has ruled out top-up fees during a second Labour term, university vice-chancellors have refused to discard them as a future option and remain convinced that a future government will allow universities to charge extra.

The introduction of market fees allowing prestigious universities - or popular courses like law and medicine - to increase tuition charges to students is one of four options outlined by Universities UK in a paper published today.

Sir Howard Newby, president of Universities UK, formerly the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals, refused to rule out a post-election change of heart by the government on the matter. "Ministers come and go. Economic and political circumstances change and we have to keep this option on the table."

"Governments have been known to change their minds. One looks with interest at videos of speeches by present cabinet ministers before the last election. We still feel it is very important that it remains on the table as a feasible option and one which still needs examining carefully. It is quite likely there will be another comprehensive spending review after the election. We regard this as all to play for," said Sir Howard, vice-chancellor of Southampton University.

The vice-chancellors insist the status quo is not an option and the government's targets of 50% of young people participating in higher education and widening access to poor families cannot be met unless more money is pumped into the system.

The Labour government has eased the squeeze on funding but spending per student has still fallen by 38% since 1989, said Roderick Floud, vice-chancellor of London Guildhall.

The three other main options examined by the report are increased public spending; graduate contributions similar to the system introduced in Scotland after the Cubie report; and the Conservatives' plan to endow universities with windfall profits from the sale of radio bandwidth for mobile phones.

The vice-chancellors meet in Newcastle next week to discuss the report but are unlikely to plump for one option. Sir Howard said each option had strengths and weaknesses and the government might well want to combine elements of public and private funding.

Tuition fees would have to rise by £700 per head on top of the current £1050 limit to generate the additional funds vice-chancellors are seeking. And they would have to be even higher if universities wanted to fund bursaries for students from poor families. Only half of all students will pay fees under current rules, estimates the Department for Education and Employment.

A spokeswoman for the department said: "Tuition fees are uprated annually in line with inflation and the government is putting a record £1.7bn into higher education."

A Cubie-style graduate contribution scheme would have the advantage of not deterring students but the weakness that additional public funding would be needed to replace fees in the short term and that universities could suffer cuts in the meantime.

More details of the Tory plan to endow universities were needed but it would give them increased autonomy if the right terms were agreed, said the report. It would cost an estimated £24bn to endow 12 leading institutions and £101bn for all universities.

 The final report on New Directions For Higher Education Funding is available from Universities UK Woburn House, 20 Tavistock Square, London WC1H 9HQ
Enquiries: publications@UniversitiesUK.ac.uk

fields.headline: Where the weird things are
fields.standfirst:
Jess Cartner-Morley on London's eccentric, exciting shows.
Special report: London Fashion Week 2001
fields.trailText: Jess Cartner-Morley on London's eccentric, exciting shows.
fields.body:
After "How was the Versace party?" the question most people want to ask about London Fashion Week is "Why are the clothes so weird?" You might well ask. No other city has sent down the catwalk quite so many dresses that bare at least one breast. No other city would have embraced with such abandon a trend as profit-destroyingly unflattering as drainpipe trousers. Why, indeed.

In fact, London has done contrarily well out of cornering the niche market in Weird Clothes. In 1994 there were 15 shows on the London fashion week schedule; now there are 52. Apart from Burberry, very few British brands command power in the marketplace with their advertising spend; instead, they have to rely on grabbing the audience's attention by any means necessary. And if the industry has an inbuilt lean towards an art-school mentality, it may have something to do with the fact that out of the 52 designers on the schedule, 26 are graduates of one particular, highly experimental college: St Martins.

However, while London's creativity attracts attention and acclaim, this doesn't always translate into healthy businesses, as Hussein Chalayan's problems demonstrate. But maybe, just maybe, things are about to change. The first signs of a new spirit of maturity seemed to be emerging during this London fashion week. The most exciting designers are those who have a broad enough intelligence both to express their creativity and to take up the challenge of producing pieces that work as clothes - and their number seems to be increasing.

Alexander McQueen has all the trappings of an experimental designer. Vivid, theatrical storytelling on the catwalk, showpiece accessories such as feather headdresses and gold dog skeletons, and a penchant for undiplomatic plain-speaking in public. But the clothes that will be on the rails come September are far from clownish. Instead, they have a subtle kind of drama: a double-breasted avocado green trouser suit has a waist seam curving in a gentle spiral around the body; a belted leather coat is detailed with scalloped layers, like fishscales; a halterneck evening dress in black satin has a wide neck cuff with long, trailing ties.

Elegant tailoring with a sense of theatre was also the mood at another highlight of the week, the Markus Lupfer show. Softer than last season but still with bite, the collection featured shell pink leather separates, elegant trouser suits and airbrushed printed silk in painterly colours of egg yolk yellow, scarlet, electric blue and emerald green.

Matthew Williamson's "Wonderland" had some magic moments: gently curved skirts in panelled opaque and sheer glittering ivory lace, and feather straps on a pale column dress. Elspeth Gibson's collection was also delicious: try a tartan mini with rose-pink lace petticoats (yes, minis are definitely back), a cream cashmere cardigan with diamanté-sprinkled net, or a cocktail dress in black spotted net over a nude slip. The return of the Proper Cocktail Frock was a theme of the week. At Boyd, where the tone was more sophisticated than last season, a stunning black lace dress had asymmetric straps - one spaghetti-thin, one thick ribbon - and an aubergine slip beneath.

Tracey Boyd also showed some of the season's best coats: tailored and neat in glittered lilac tweed (tweed has gone luxe for next season), or long and luscious in raspberry sheepskin. Even Julien Macdonald, king of teeny-tiny spangly frocks, showed hints of the new maturity: Helena Christiansen looked absurdly gorgeous in a black satin dress with slices of sheer black lace at the hip.

Clements Ribeiro revived one of their best-loved themes with polka-dot charcoal sweater dresses (sweater dresses look set for a revival) and sweet pale chiffon dresses with uneven, raggedy hems, reminiscent of a ballet school fallen on hard times. Scott Henshall was impressive, with crossword-printed silk separates and elegant, cruise-style pale knitwear. Sheila Maloney developed her distinctive, quirky style with trademark curving skirt hems, dresses decorated with outsize sequins in the shape of deer, and intricate glitter pouches giving movement and shimmer. Marcus Constable also featured dip-and-soar hems, in skirts of layered gold-and-silver taffeta.

Mulligan's was a strong collection, with black crepe tailoring lined with rose pink silk, sparkle-sprinkled tweed coats, and spraypaint squiggles (a summer trend that looks set to carry through) in pistachio on a chocolate leather skirt. Preen was impressive, with charming Elizabethan-esque puffed and pointed shoulder shapes, and wing-shaped pocket flaps on very nicely cut trousers.

Talented newcomer Hamish Morrow showcased his ability to make sculptural shapes work on the body, with tailored and frothed glitter wool column dresses and black lace. Jeans were daubed and splashed Jackson Pollock-style with liberal quantities of pink and turquoise paint.

With a mighty international fashion business up and running, Paul Smith doesn't need to prove to anyone that he is a grown-up. Instead he had some fun with tongue-in-cheek Aspen glamour: coffee lace cocktail dresses, scarf-print shirt dresses and gorgeous sweetie-coloured coats.

Nicole Farhi's restrained elegance was perfectly aimed at her loyal customer base: understated soft leather tailoring for day, tuxedo-style bugle-beaded black separates for evening. John Rocha made interesting shapes wearable, with the tiniest of puff sleeves and softly gathered demi-puffball skirts, while Betty Jackson's sharp patchwork separates of bright silks and ribbon-cut coffee skirt were upbeat and eye-catching.

Ben de Lisi, as always, excelled in long, fluid evening dresses, this season in raspberry satin and liquid-soft white sequins. And there were also some wonderful collections that had little to do with selling clothes. In particular Russell Sage, reworking antique table linens and vintage pieces and mixing these with new fabric, gave an imaginative and thought-provoking show, while Jessica Ogden's blend of kimono dressing and old-fashioned English prints, enthusiastically staged as a mini one-room play, was original and hugely enjoyable.

Which is as it should be: this is London, fashion's capital of ideas, and we want to keep it that way. We just don't want everyone to go bankrupt, that's all.

Even Julien Macdonald, king of teeny-tiny spangly frocks, showed hints of the new maturity: Helena Christiansen looked absurdly gorgeous in a black satin dress with slices of sheer black lace at the hip. Clements Ribeiro revived one of their best-loved themes with polka-dot charcoal sweater dresses (sweater dresses look set for a revival) and sweet pale chiffon dresses with uneven, raggedy hems, reminiscent of a ballet school fallen on hard times. Scott Henshall was impressive, with crossword-printed silk separates and elegant, cruise-style pale knitwear. Sheila Maloney developed her distinctive, quirky style with trademark curving skirt hems, dresses decorated with outsize sequins in the shape of deer, and intricate glitter pouches giving movement and shimmer. Marcus Constable also featured dip-and-soar hems, in skirts of layered gold-and-silver taffeta. Mulligan's was a strong collection, with black crepe tailoring lined with rose pink silk, sparkle-sprinkled tweed coats, and spraypaint squiggles (a summer trend that looks set to carry through) in pistachio on a chocolate leather skirt. Preen was impressive, with charming Elizabethan-esque puffed and pointed shoulder shapes, and wing-shaped pocket flaps on very nicely cut trousers. Talented newcomer Hamish Morrow showcased his ability to make sculptural shapes work on the body, with tailored and frothed glitter wool column dresses and black lace. Jeans were daubed and splashed Jackson Pollock-style with liberal quantities of pink and turquoise paint. With a mighty international fashion business up and running, Paul Smith doesn't need to prove to anyone that he is a grown-up. Instead he had some fun with tongue-in-cheek Aspen glamour: coffee lace cocktail dresses, scarf-print shirt dresses and gorgeous sweetie-coloured coats. Nicole Farhi's restrained elegance was perfectly aimed at her loyal customer base: understated soft leather tailoring for day, tuxedo-style bugle-beaded black separates for evening. John Rocha made interesting shapes wearable, with the tiniest of puff sleeves and softly gathered demi-puffball skirts, while Betty Jackson's sharp patchwork separates of bright silks and ribbon-cut coffee skirt were upbeat and eye-catching. Ben de Lisi, as always, excelled in long, fluid evening dresses, this season in raspberry satin and liquid-soft white sequins. And there were also some wonderful collections that had little to do with selling clothes. In particular Russell Sage, reworking antique table linens and vintage pieces and mixing these with new fabric, gave an imaginative and thought-provoking show, while Jessica Ogden's blend of kimono dressing and old-fashioned English prints, enthusiastically staged as a mini one-room play, was original and hugely enjoyable. Which is as it should be: this is London, fashion's capital of ideas, and we want to keep it that way. We just don't want everyone to go bankrupt, that's all. fields.headline: Getting a selective education
fields.standfirst:
Taken to the governess, we were from local important families

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: This government's close interest in school education has madeLeanda de Lisle think again of her own.
fields.body:
This government's close interest in school education has made me think again about my own. It was private and therefore a great privilege, I'm told. Perhaps I should make it a little more public and you can judge for yourself. This is not the way the other half lived 30 years ago, but half a per cent - or possibly half a per cent of half a per cent.

I didn't go to school until I was eight years old. I had my father's old governess instead. However, since I shared her with 10 or 11 other children, "Miss Scott's", as her home was called, had something of the feeling of a school.

From the age of four-and-a-half I was taken by taxi every day from my parents' country house to a semi-detached home in the nearby market town. The driver would sit me on his lap. I remember something rather gross about it, but let's just say I think he may have taken unnatural pleasure in the experience of having me at the wheel.

I always felt rather embarrassed and uncomfortable as I peered out of the windscreen from his lap and when I was dropped off at Miss Scott's gates I would run (my father often said he couldn't stand little girls that skipped) to the front door.

There was no uniform, but little girls were instructed to wear dresses. My favourite was a mint green colour in satin cotton with smocking across the chest. I'm not sure what the boys were asked to wear. The only sartorial detail that I recall are the slippers that Edwin's mother would deliver him in. They insured that Edwin was utterly despised by all the girls. The boys made no comment. I fear they were all rather wet.

We varied in age from four to 10 and were neither sat in grammar school-type rows or comprehensive circles. Instead we were placed in twos at individual trestle tables covered in bold gingham cloths. We worked in pencil. When Miss Scott passed by she would smack my hand with her ruler because I held mine "like a lamp post". It was humiliating but it made no difference to the way I worked. My pencil stayed upright, digging into the paper and my handwriting was irredeemably bad.

We were taught to read and spell with the aid of boxes of paper letters that must have been 40 years old (my father's governess was probably giving us an entirely pre-war education). You had to copy out sentences from a book in letters on your table. I liked the stories about scarecrows and biscuits and would sneak a glance at the pages ahead. Edwin, who was always having nosebleeds, would be lying on the floor beside me with a damp cloth on his forehead.

For lunch we would walk into the centre of town for overcooked beef and jelly trifle at the local cafe, or stay in the house and have a picnic. My nanny sent orange squash in one of my father's hip flasks. There was no playing that I recall. After lunch we would say the Our Father. Catholics and Protestants were clearly differentiated by whether they were allowed to add: "For thine is the kingdom the power and the glory", at the end of the prayer. Then we would lie down on a rug on the floor and sleep or read.

I read the Roy Rogers Annual as often as I could. I hit Edwin with it once on the top of his head. I sometimes wonder who he was and what happened to him. The children all came from important or aristocratic local families and their fate was often curiously grim. At least four became heroin addicts. As a percentage, this must rank with the grimmest inner-city sink estates.

One was the prettiest girl in the school. Her dancing teacher used to put stars on the bottom of her ballet shoes because she could skip higher than anyone else. Everyone wanted to hold her hand on the walk to lunch - save me who knew that skipping was not to be admired. She cleaned up eventually. Those of you who read glossy magazines and gossip columns would recognise her name.

However, the titled boy who developed a habit shot himself in his twenties. My best friend from Miss Scott's had been engaged to him. She lives in a castle now, although she will be divorcing its owner later in the year. Another boy, known as Duncan the Dribbler (for obvious reasons) was killed in a motorcycle accident. I'm not sure that he made his twenties. We also had a teenage bride and a girl who was gang raped on the London underground shortly after leaving school. That doesn't leave many does it?

Miss Scott's chief concern when I left school was that my handwriting shouldn't blacken her reputation locally. Happily for her I was sent on to an enormous French school in London. I looked back on Miss Scott with fond nostalgia, but being fed our ABCs with a silver spoon never proved a magic dose for any of us.

webTitle: Quake-hit pupils find solace in Chekhov and maths

fields.headline: Quake-hit pupils find solace in Chekhov and maths
fields.standfirst:
The disaster which left thousands of schools damaged or in ruins has failed to dampen the passion for learning

Special report: natural disasters
Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The disaster which left thousands of schools damaged or in ruins has failed to dampen the passion for learning.
fields.body:
In a green tent in the grounds of what was once a school, a crayon drawing has been pinned to the wall. It shows a small girl with her arms thrown up in the air. She is running - running away from a shaking house and a row of wobbling green trees. The girl is smiling and yet her actions convey an absolute and Munch-like sense of horror.

The picture is one of many done by pupils at Kendriya Vidayala school in Bhuj, the town flattened by last month's devastating earthquake in India's western state of Gujarat, in which 30,000 people - many of them children - died.

In relative terms the school did not emerge too badly from the disaster. The building is still standing, though a complete write-off. The classrooms are cracked, the roll of honour hangs wonkily from the wall, and the glass trophy cabinet next to the head's office is full of toppled shields and prize cups.

But most of the 641 children who used to come here for lessons survived. They were not, as elsewhere, buried along with their teachers beneath an enfolding torrent of rubble.

"It is very necessary to divert the students' minds. They have witnessed so many horrible scenes," the school's head, K N Mishra, said yesterday, speaking from the tent which is now his temporary office. "Education is the only means to do this."

And so two weeks after the catastrophe on January 26, a group of soldiers began erecting a series of khaki tents along the driveway that leads to the school's entrance, inside an army cantonment.

Gradually, the children came trickling back. At the end of last week 116 had returned for classes on plastic sheets strewn with leaves. Desks have been salvaged. New parents are even seeking to enrol their five-year-olds after an advert for the school appeared in the local paper.

The younger children are still doing drawings of the quake, while the older ones wrestle with maths exams and English comprehension. Yesterday they were working on a translation of Chekhov.

"It isn't hard for me to study. But it is hard for students who have lost their parents or are mentally disturbed. They are not mentally ready," 15-year-old Hitesh Soni said. "My uncle died in the earthquake. So did my sister's brother-in-law and my aunt's porter," he added.

Other students recall the moment the tremors started. "We were on stage in front of the school singing the national anthem. Everyone ran away," Shahed Sumra, also 15, said.

Of all the imperatives that have emerged from the aftermath of the earthquake - medicines, shelter and warm clothing, for example - one of the greatest, perhaps, is the need for education.

Across the barren province of Kutch, which was almost completely destroyed, some 15,000 schools have been affected. Some have suffered only cracks; others have disappeared.

"We are talking about 1.8m children who have lost the two safe places in their lives - schools and homes," Maria Calivis, Unicef's head in India, said. "Their future is filled with uncertainty and fear. The lesson from other earthquakes is that the best way of establishing normality is to get kids back to school."

Getting children back to school is, however, an unsure business. In Bhuj, only two schools have so far reopened - Kendriya Vidayala and the Army School are both run by the military, one of India's most dependable institutions.

In the shattered villages in Kutch's interior, a handful of other "tent" schools started last week, some made out of little more than old bedsheets and bamboo poles. But the problems lying ahead are immense.

Many teachers were killed in the earthquake or have since fled. In one of the worst affected towns, Anjar, an entire school of 300 children and staff was wiped out. In Bhachau, which was also obliterated, 78 girls died when they were buried inside their school building.

And in the village of Adhoi a parade of girls celebrating India's Republic Day were entombed in the main street. Many of those who died were simply too slow to flee - a category that includes the enfeebled old and the very young.

Officials in Gujarat have set a date of April 1 for schools to be reopened, but they recognise that the process of rebuilding will take years.

Already, though, there is a determination that education should continue - and a recognition that without it there can be no development.

"We are getting them rehearsed for their exams. We are giving them trial papers," Ravi Bhatt, the army officer in Bhuj in charge of education, said of the older children who had come back to school. "We can't allow them to keep mourning. You have to start somewhere."

At Bhuj's Army School the noticeboard has not been changed since the morning of the earthquake. "Army School celebrates 51st Republic Day in high spirits," it reads.

The school building still stands but is dangerous and will have to be demolished. Lessons are being carried out here, as elsewhere, in the school grounds in an ever-multiplying series of tents.

"One of our boys has lost his father," the headteacher, Geeta Soni, said yesterday. "We are trying to find out what happened. Otherwise we have been very fortunate. All our teachers are safe.

Youthful resilience

"The problem is not with the teenage children but with the small kids who have the feeling that it [the earthquake] might happen again," she added.

On the surface, at least, most of the children seem remarkably resilient. In one corner of the grounds, a 13-year-old boy is busy sawing wooden poles in half. Another boy is hitting the ground with a pickaxe, while a third is holding on to some blue plastic sheeting. It takes a while to work out that they are, in fact, building their own classroom.

"They are learning about pitching tents. It is part of their education. Generally they are very happy. It is a change of scene for them. They are enjoying being at school rather than at home," their teacher, Devila Gor, explained.

Inside the ruined and deserted school building, the classroom walls are still adorned with a series of moral slogans. In earlier days they might have seemed banal. Now, though, they appear apt.

"The good we do today," one reads, above a room of fallen masonry, "becomes the happiness of tomorrow."

fields.headline: Litmanen in doubt for final
fields.trailText: Bradford City v West Ham
fields.body:
Bradford City v West Ham

Harry Redknapp is upset to have lost Shaka Hislop, who is due to play for Trinidad against Jamaica in a World Cup qualifier next week. Frederic Kanoute is also missing with a bruised foot; he could be replaced by fit-again Davor Suker. Bradford can recall David Wetherall, who has missed 14 weeks with a groin injury, Gunnar Halle and David Hopkin.

Coventry City v Charlton Athletic

Coventry will be without Mustapha Hadji, who is on World Cup duty with Morocco against Senegal. Youssef Chippo will fill in for his compatriot, as he is suspended for the Senegal game. Charlton will also be without an international - Shaun Bartlett plays for South Africa in Malawi - but they can bring back Jonatan Johansson and Mark Kinsella, who have recovered from knee surgery. Scott Parker is suspended.

Derby County v Aston Villa

Derby will be without Horacio Carbonari (suspended), Malcolm Christie (suspended), Brian O'Neil (hamstring) and Stefano Eranio (hamstring), but Seth Johnson and Rory Delap return to the squad after recovering from knee injuries. Villa will be without Gareth Southgate (knee) and Darius Vassell (suspended).

Ipswich Town v Everton

Ipswich will be without Marcus Stewart, who starts a three-match suspension, but they have prepared even for this contingency by signing the 20-year-old Scottish international striker Mark Birchill on a three-month loan from Celtic. The Iceland international defender Hermann Hreidarsson misses out with hamstring trouble, but the central defender John McGreal and the right-back Fabian Wilnis both return. Everton may be missing Richard Gough (chest infection) and Abel Xavier (knee), so the 19-year-old central defender Peter Clarke could make his first start.

Leicester City v Sunderland

Leicester will be back to virtually full strength, with Gerry Taggart and Andrew Impey now recovered from groin injuries. Tim Flowers is the only notable absentee with a muscle injury in his leg that restricts his kicking, and Simon Royce will again deputise in goal. Sunderland include Ben Clark, George McCartney and Thomas Butler in their squad. Kevin Phillips joins Michael Gray, Alex Rae and Don Hutchison on the suspended list. Stanislav Varga has failed to recover from a groin injury but Jody Craddock will replace him in central defence. Danny Dichio is favoured to partner Niall Quinn up front but the Ireland international winger Kevin Kilbane is also in the frame.

Middlesbrough v Southampton

Middlesbrough will be without Colin Cooper and Keith O'Neill (both suspended) and are also likely to be missing Christian Karembeu (eye and hamstring), Steve Vickers (abdominal muscle) and Phil Stamp (hamstring). Noel Whelan (back) and Paul Okon (groin) should return. Southampton will have to do without Tahar El Khalej (World Cup duty with Morocco) while Hassan Kachloul, Marian Pahars, Jason Dodd and Matt Oakley need fitness tests. Dan Petrescu and Kevin Davies are available again and Glenn Hoddle has called up Gary Monk, a defender who has been on loan with Oxford.

Newcastle United v Manchester City

Alan Shearer will go straight into the Newcastle starting line-up only two months after undergoing knee surgery. But the midfield could again look makeshift: Christian Bassedas is suspended and Gary Speed is a major doubt with a calf strain. Manchester City bring back Jeff Whitley after suspension and could recall Steve Howey, who has a broken toe, to the centre of defence.

Tottenham Hotspur v Leeds United

Spurs have Chris Perry, Darren Anderton, Stephen Carr, Mauricio Taricco, Ben Thatcher, Chris Armstrong and Oyvind Leonhardsen sidelined by injury. Steffen Iversen, whose return from a knee injury was delayed by a throat infection last week, could be among the substitutes. Andy Booth may be on the bench in his last game before returning to Sheffield Wednesday next week at the end of his month's loan spell. Leeds have Lucas Radebe and Alan Smith suspended. Danny Mills is likely to play alongside Rio Ferdinand at the heart of the back four, with Alan Maybury coming in for his first game in three years at right-back.

Sunday

Manchester United v Arsenal

United are without Andy Cole (suspended) and Ryan Giggs (hamstring). Nicky Butt could start in midfield along with Paul Scholes. The Arsenal captain Tony Adams is rated only a 50-50 chance to recover from a back injury in time, so Arsene Wenger looks certain to recall Igor Stepanovs. Lauren Etame Mayer is on World Cup duty with Cameroon against Zambia. Silvinho is fit again after a calf injury but may not displace Ashley Cole from the left-back spot.

Worthington Cup final

Birmingham City v Liverpool

Apart from the new signings Curtis Woodhouse and Peter Atherton, who are both cup-tied, Birmingham City are pretty much at full strength. Geoff Horsfield, Jon McCarthy and Stan Lazaridis should be ready to play after recovering from injuries. Liverpool will wait for late fitness tests on Jari Litmanen, Steven Gerrard and Danny Murphy before naming their side.

Birmingham City (from): Bennett, Poole, Eaden, Gill, Grainger, Burrows, Purse, Holdsworth, M Johnson, Hughes, Lazaridis, McCarthy, O'Connor (captain), Sonner, Adebola, Horsfield, Marcelo, A Johnson.

fields.headline: Behind the scenes at the museum
fields.standfirst:
In a tent outside the Natural History Museum, a transformation is taking place: model Vivien Solari is being painstakingly prepared for the Clements Ribeiro show. Charlie Porter tracks her backstage

Special report: London Fashion Week 2001
fields.trailText: In a tent outside the Natural History Museum, a transformation is taking place: model Vivien Solari is being painstakingly prepared for the Clements Ribeiro show. Charlie Porter tracks her backstage
fields.body:
At 9.30 in the morning, it isn't that unusual to be sorting out your hair and make-up, and so Vivien Solari, a 22-year-old from Manchester, is currently covered in grips and foundation. But Solari isn't doing any of this herself - she has two people for the hair, one for the make-up, someone else for her nails. It is something she will do a lot during the day - stay completely still while others dress her in their imagined ideal. Here, she is being prepared for her first job of the day, a prime role on the catwalk of British label Boyd.

Solari, a Vogue covergirl who has modelled since she was 19, is at the epicentre of a tiny room in Fulham Town Hall, the venue for today's show. Around her circle onion-like layers: make-up people, photographers and, on the outskirts, the designer, Tracey Boyd, scurrying in bags as she gets the clothes ready. Solari is oblivious to all this, not because she's precious but because she knows she must keep still so the make-up can be done as quickly and immaculately as possible.

Thirty minutes late, once the backstage monitor has been fixed, the show runs without a hitch. The models walk demurely in view of the audience, but behind the scenes it is controlled chaos as they tear around, unzipping their clothes to make it into the next outfit in time. After the final procession, they cheer, clap, strip and leave.

Solari is in the midst of a tough few weeks. After eight shows in New York, including Helmut Lang ("All the girls like his show because he does clothes you might actually want to wear"), she is in London for a couple of days before the heavyweights in Milan and Paris. Today are shows by Boyd and Clements Ribeiro, designers with similarly accessible collections; yesterday was the entertaining but tiring high glamour of Julien Macdonald; the day before that, the hectic Robert Cary-Williams, whose clothes weren't finished two hours before the show.

It has gone midday, but because of a mix-up with her agency's cars, Solari is travelling to her next appointment on the tube. She is made up like a lady of the night, with two beauty spots and highly-styled, tight-curled hair from the Boyd show. "I think I'm getting some looks," she says.

She is heading for the Nicole Farhi headquarters off Carnaby Street. Earlier in the week she went for a fitting (the designer tries all the outfits on the model to make sure the clothes match the girl) but Farhi wasn't happy with one of the outfits, so back Solari has to go. She puts on the brown leather jacket that is causing the problem and stands stock still as Farhi and two assistants pull and push at the jacket, talking over her as they do so.

They still aren't satisfied, so, even though it will mean visiting the studios a third time for one jacket, Solari agrees to return after Clements Ribeiro. In New York, models are paid by the hour, so designers are more de termined to get the clothes right in one fitting. In London, most shows are done for the prestige, on little or no money, so there are few constraints on what a designer can ask.

Are the fittings always that weird? "You stand there for hours," Solari says, "as they decide how long a sock should be, or if you should wear gloves." It seems so impersonal. Does she ever get a say? "Very rarely. Once, Stella McCartney couldn't work out which outfit to put me in, so she asked what I thought, which was good."

Solari is going to the fitting for Clements Ribiero via her accountant - she has recently become a limited company to ensure she invests her money wisely. She became a model after dropping out of a psychology degree at Leicester University, but doesn't plan to stay in the industry forever. For the time being, she is having fun and earning enough money to make it worth worrying about.

Slowly she is transformed, ending up like someone from The 1940s House. Over on the make-up side of the room, her eyebrows are turned into huge slashes of blue.

Then the clothes - David Bowie crossed with 20s-style geometrics - and the designers, Suzanne Clements and Inacio Ribeiro, arrive. Solari is briefed on her outfits and struggles into black, studded Manolo Blahnik stilettos, holding on to a rail as if she is trying them on in the middle of a discount sale. It seems the designers are ready to take a risk with the rest. "They don't want me to try on the clothes, which is a first," Solari says.

She is grabbed again by the hairdressers, who want to colour her hair with pink powder. An MTV cameraman shoves a microphone in her face and all around photographers come and take more pictures of the girl they had photographed only eight hours before. Throughout it all, Solari looks impassive.

When they eventually appear, the clothes in the show are a success and Solari looks great in a leopardprint riding coat and a cute military bomber. But the show is running an hour late and the audience is twitchy to get to the British Fashion Awards.

Solari, too, has another engagement, back at Nicole Farhi, devoting yet more of her life to the jacket that, at the next day's show, will be on the catwalk for precisely 30 seconds. Not that this bothers her; as a model, it's just not her problem.
