fields.headline: 'We can't go on like this...'
fields.standfirst: Donald MacLeod outlines today's funding report from Universities UK
fields.trailText: Donald MacLeod outlines today's funding report from Universities UK
fields.body:
Whatever David Blunkett may insist about no top-up fees under a second Labour government, it is clear that university heads have by no means abandoned the introduction of market fees as a possible - indeed probable - outcome to fill the funding gap. A four year parliament would not be a long preparation for this kind of change, pointed out Sir Howard Newby, president of Universities UK (formerly the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals).

Their report, hopefully entitled New Directions For Higher Education Funding, sets out the "significant damage" done by many years of underfunded expansion. Since 1989 resources per student have fallen by 38%, following a decrease of 20% between 1976 and 1989.

Staff-student ratios declined to an average of 1 to 17 (1 to 23 if funding for research which is included in the average unit of funding is excluded), libraries and lecture halls were run down and drop-out rates increased, especially among universities offering access to the disadvantaged.

They argue for minimum additional funding of at least £620m a year.

Maintaining funding per student in real terms at 2000-01 levels - £75m;
Selective improvements in pay and conditions to recruit and retain staff and to provide for improved staff development - £195m;
Improved funding premium for disadvantaged students - which could cost up to an additional £100m if the suggestion of an increase in the premium to 20% is implemented.

This takes no account of the further costs of meeting the requirements of the disability discrimination act or the costs of expansion. Nor does it include funding for the additional costs of meeting the equal pay for equal work by women which would bring the total to £900m per annum.

Option 1: increased public spending

Strengths
Additions to funding through increased block grants are readily identifiable. The government would be keen to acknowledge what additional funding it had provided. Notwithstanding the policy changes in Scotland and the commitment by the Liberal Democrats to abolish fee contributions, they appear in practice to have been accepted at their present level, even if grudgingly, by a majority of electors, parents and students.
Fees at their present level make a modest contribution to equity by charging most to those best able to pay.

Weaknesses
This option is wholly dependent on how favourably the government of the day is prepared to look upon the funding needs of higher education. There can be no guarantee, if additional funding is secured in the short-term, that it will not be subsequently eroded as economic circumstances become less favourable or following a change of government to one less favourably disposed to higher education.
The option increases the dependency of institutions on public funds and is therefore likely to add to rather than decrease the demands for scrutiny and accountability.

Option 2: market fees
Fees could be charged according to the cost of providing courses (engineering more expensive than business studies, for instance), or by the return to graduates - higher fees for law and medicine and lower fees for history, as the Australians have attempted to do. They could also be differentiated by subject and institution on the basis of market forces.

Strengths
Fee deregulation would in principle allow institutions to set their fees at levels that, subject to the pressures of market forces, more nearly reflected the costs of providing teaching. To meet the level of funding need of some £620m identified in Section 2 would require average fees per person to increase by about £700 per annum before taking into account the need to fund scholarships for the poorest students.
Deregulation of fees would also encourage diversity amongst institutions and potentially offer greater choice to students. Higher average fees could also be expected to increase the pressure on institutions from individuals and their families to meet their expectations about levels of support and feedback from staff and quality of resources more generally, and thus could improve value for money in the provision of teaching and learning.

Weaknesses
On the assumption that scholarship schemes would be in place to enable the poorest students to pay their fees, there would be substantial consequences for students from families with intermediate incomes.
There is already evidence from the DfEE study that many parents in 1998-99 were not making their contribution to fees.
The financial implications for different institutions and subjects would also be very uncertain and potentially damaging. Those institutions that have been most successful in attracting students from the poorest families would be least well placed to charge substantially higher fees and might also be under the most pressure to reduce fees in certain subjects. They would then find it even more difficult to provide for the additional needs of those students from the poorest backgrounds.

Option 3: income-contingent graduate contributions

Strengths
With a graduate contribution at the level proposed in Scotland of £2,000 this option could generate some £600m a year for an endowment fund with current annual numbers of graduates across the UK. Much of this would, however, come from publicly funded income-contingent loans.
There would be less of a barrier to participation because there would be no up-front fees and money could be steered to institutions opening up access. This option could also provide an incentive to employers to pay the graduate contribution as a form of "golden hello", especially in fields where competition for graduates is strongest.

Weaknesses
This option would require additional public funds to replace the current private contributions to fees. This would put institutions at greater risk of further reductions in the level of funding per student. It is more likely that over time that public funding will be reduced as funds flow from an endowment fund and this source of funds will cease to be truly additional.

Option 4: institutional endowment

Strengths
This is one of the few schemes that could give universities increased autonomy and independence of action if the right terms are agreed. It would enable the most competitive and popular institutions and maybe also those specialist institutions operating in a niche market fully to exploit their comparative advantage, and facilitate the further development of world class universities and specialist institutions. It could facilitate the development of a 'culture of giving' such as exists in the USA.

Weaknesses
Given the sums involved, it would be many years before the whole sector could be endowed, and in the meantime there would be a return to an explicit dividing line between institutions.
It also has to be asked if any government would be willing to give universities the degree of freedom that, theoretically at least, this option entails. Indeed, as we have seen, the Conservatives have already stated that even endowed universities would not be free to determine their own undergraduate fees. It must be uncertain how many universities, if any, would seek to opt out if deregulation stopped short of fees.
Such a scheme might have a negative impact on widening participation.

webTitle: Wake up to Popstars live debut

fields.headline: Wake up to Popstars live debut
fields.trailText:
5.30pm: Popstars band Hear'Say will break their silence at a time when teenagers are still bleary-eyed, writes Dan Milmo.
Feb 23: Hear'Say prove they've got the white stuff
fields.body:
After the months of hype, they might have been expected to make their live debut on a primetime television show such as Top of The Pops.

But today it emerged that Popstars band Hear'Say will break their silence at a time when teenagers are still bleary-eyed.

The manufactured fivesome were mocked earlier this week for miming their single Pure and Simple on Channel 5's Pepsi chart show.

But Hear'Say, who were chosen from thousands of hopefuls because they had genuine singing talent, will perform their record live at 7.30am on Kiss 100's Bam Bam breakfast show.

Kiss secured its exclusive thanks to the antics of breakfast show prankster Street Boy, who dressed up as a courier to get into the Popstars' top-secret safe house.

The programme's producers persuaded Kiss to keep the location of the house secret by offering the station the first live performance of Hear'Say's single.

"It's a real coup. It shows that Kiss is really in touch with what's going on," said Mark Storey, managing director at Kiss FM.

Popstars boss Nigel Lythgoe would doubtless have preferred to give the band its live debut on primetime TV.

Their performance on a London-only dance station is likely to raise more eyebrows in the national press.

fields.trailText: "This has come as a total surprise to me. I'm proud, delighted and still a little bit stunned. It is a huge honour and I hope it reflects well on everyone at the club. We've had a great season and this has made it even more special."
fields.body:
"This has come as a total surprise to me. I'm proud, delighted and still a little bit stunned. It is a huge honour and I hope it reflects well on everyone at the club. We've had a great season and this has made it even more special."

Chris Powell

"All the supporters keep going on about 1966 and three West Ham players in the midfield and for all of us to be playing together in the same midfield and gelling and working together, this will be a great experience for all of us. I'm always keen to fulfil my England ambitions and Spain are a great side to get involved against. It's great to be involved in a fresh start and hopefully we'll all do well."

Frank Lampard

"This is really nice news for all three youngsters," he said. "They have all worked hard this season and deserve it. I am sure they will be able to make the step-up, it won't bother them at all."

fields.headline: Ethnic minorities grow to 1 in 10
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Next year's census is expected to show that minority ethnic communities total more than 5m people, or 10% of Britain's population, Jack Straw said yesterday.
fields.body:
Next year's census is expected to show that minority ethnic communities total more than 5m people, or 10% of Britain's population, Jack Straw said yesterday.

The home secretary's "best guess" of the growth in the black and Asian communities came as he confirmed the introduction of a race equality law directed against "institutional racism" across the public sector, including schools, hospitals and broadcasting organisations such as the BBC.

The last census in 1991 estimated that Britain's minority ethnic population accounted for 7% of the population, at about 3.5m. Mr Straw said that in London the proportion probably now stood at around 20%; in some boroughs, and in his constituency of Blackburn in Lancashire, it was more than 50%.

Publishing the second annual report on progress in tackling racism since publication of the Macpherson inquiry into the murder of Stephen Lawrence, the home secretary said that the new figures would underline the scale to which Britain was a multiracial society.

Mr Straw said the report on 70 recommendations put forward by Macpherson showed "encouraging progress in key areas, but we cannot afford to be complacent". He said that, after two years, the "breadth and depth of the change" required had become clear, and much more needed to be done within the police and elsewhere to ensure the reforms would stand the test of time. fields.bodyText: Next year's census is expected to show that minority ethnic communities total more than 5m people, or 10% of Britain's population, Jack Straw said yesterday. The home secretary's "best guess" of the growth in the black and Asian communities came as he confirmed the introduction of a race equality law directed against "institutional racism" across the public sector, including schools, hospitals and broadcasting organisations such as the BBC. The last census in 1991 estimated that Britain's minority ethnic population accounted for 7% of the population, at about 3.5m. webTitle: Wronged officer may spurn payoff to stay with Met

fields.headline: Wronged officer may spurn payoff to stay with Met
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: An Asian officer wrongly accused of sending racist hate mail to colleagues is considering forgoing a £350,000 compensation package to continue working in the Metropolitan police, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
An Asian officer wrongly accused of sending racist hate mail to colleagues is considering forgoing a £350,000 compensation package to continue working in the Metropolitan police, it emerged yesterday.

Sergeant Gurpal Virdi, 42, told the Guardian he has had second thoughts about leaving the force, despite the treatment he has received over the past three years and the prospect of a settlement which was agreed by lawyers from both sides last week.

He withheld his signature from the deal - which would include a full apology - following an informal meeting with the Met commissioner, Sir John Stevens. The two agreed Mr Virdi should spend a fortnight considering his position.

"There were no lawyers, no barristers, just us," Mr Virdi said yesterday. "I have always said that I joined the Met because I wanted to make a difference. That is still the case. Before all this happened, I loved my job, I loved working in the community. I feel like my career was robbed from me."

Though Mr Virdi is still angry the Met refused to settle the case at an earlier stage, he thinks it is wrong for taxpayers to pay the penalty for its obstinacy.

"The amount of money that has been talked about, and the amount of money spent on the case, is huge," Mr Virdi said.

"Why should taxpayers pay for it? I told the commissioner I would seriously think about coming back but I haven't made up my mind yet."

Mr Virdi praised Sir John, saying he had shown "a lot of guts" in his conduct, but said he was fearful some other officers refused to accept that he was not behind the hate mail campaign.

"These people should put up or shut up. My concern is this: how can I go on being a really good policeman if I am always looking over my shoulder, if people haven't been brought to account?"

If Mr Virdi decides to stay in the Met, he will keep the £150,000 awarded to him last year by an employment tribunal for being discriminated against on grounds of race.

But he will have to renegotiate the £200,000 compensation offered to him last week for the loss of his career and injury to his feelings.

Mr Virdi, who had 16 years of unblemished service, was wrongly accused of sending racist hate mail to himself and other black and Asian staff at Ealing and Hanwell police stations, west London, in December 1997 and January 1998.

Sir John said yesterday: "He could walk away with the money, couldn't he? My view is that he wants to remain in the organisation. He was found not guilty and he is entitled to stay. I'd be happy to have him back."

fields.headline: Red face for Fischer's friend
fields.standfirst: Some unpleasant ghosts have returned to haunt former 60s revolutionary Dany Cohn-Bendit, writes Jon Henley
fields.trailText: Some unpleasant ghosts have returned to haunt former 60s revolutionary Dany Cohn-Bendit, writes Jon Henley.
fields.body:
The ghosts of a radical past have already caught up with Germany's embattled foreign minister, Joschka Fischer.

Now it's the turn of his good friend, the flame-haired former student revolutionary Dany Cohn-Bendit - and with him, a number of France's leading intellectuals - to confront some decidedly ugly demons from the swinging 60s and 70s.

Cohn-Bendit, who was known as "Dany le rouge" in the far-off days when he led the May 1968 French student uprising but is now a senior and almost-respectable Euro-MP for the French Green party, has been acutely embarrassed by the sudden resurfacing of an article he wrote in 1975.

The story, an extract from his book Le Grand Bazar, is based on his experiences in the early 1970s in an alternative, independently-run kindergarten in Frankfurt, where he lived after being unceremoniously kicked out of France.

It describes in disturbing detail how his flirtation with some of the young children in his care had taken on "an erotic character". He was, he wrote, often "disarmed" by the playful little girls under his charge.

"I really felt that the little girls, from the age of five, had already learned how to lead me on, to flirt. It was incredible. Most of the time I was disarmed by it," he wrote.

"Several times certain children opened the flies of my trousers and started to tickle me. I reacted differently each time, according to the circumstances... But when they insisted on it, I then caressed them."

Questioned about the article on French television last night, Cohn-Bendit, a hugely popular figure in France, declared furiously: "I will not allow myself to be assassinated in public. I am not a paedophile, and I never have been."

He described the passages as "unbearably flippant" and insisted they bore no relation whatsoever to reality. "No, I never had sexual relations with children," he said. "There was never the slightest suspicion of paedophilia or of sexual relations at the time."

Cohn-Bendit added that some 20 parents of children in his care at the day centre, and many of the children themselves - now in their 30s - had written an open letter in his support.

He told l'Express, a French newsmagazine which this week published parts of the article after its existence was revealed in The Observer, that the remarks had been a taunt.

"I said all that to provoke, to shock the bourgeoisie," he said. "Knowing what I know today about sexual abuse, I regret having written all that."

The passages are indeed disturbing. Some French right-wing MPs have called for Cohn-Bendit's resignation, but Frankfurt prosecutors said yesterday there was no case to answer and that if Cohn-Bendit had genuinely had a paedophile past, "it would have been known long ago".

Cohn-Bendit claims, apparently with some justification, that the article re-emerged as part of a smear campaign mounted by Bettina Röhl, the daughter of the German terrorist Ulrike Meinhof, in a bid to dicredit Fischer by association.

Frankfurt prosecutors started proceedings last week to investigate whether Fischer, who himself has been seriously embarrassed by a 1970s photograph of him attacking a policeman, had lied in court about his ties with a guerrilla suspect in the 1970s.

But Cohn-Bendit also points out that Le Grand Bazar was greeted with considerable critical accalim at the time, that he was invited on French television several times to discuss it - and that no questions were ever asked at the time about child sex abuse.

"I am not trying to justify myself," he said. "But this was the debate of the time. It addresses all the leftist debates of the day - on communism, violence, education, sexuality. It is a book that springs from our spirit of anti-authoritarianism."

In a growing debate about the permissive excesses of the May '68 generation, French media have noted that in 1977, such celebrated left-wing intellectuals as Jean-Paul Sartre and Simone de Beauvoir even signed a petition calling for paedophilia to be decrimininalised.

"The era was naive," said Roland Castro, an architect who was one of the leading lights of 68.

"We said everything and its opposite, hastily, without reflection. In trying to break out of the old barriers, we ended up pulling them down altogether."

fields.headline: Nike
fields.standfirst: This week the company refused a customer's request to sew the word 'sweatshop' on his trainers. Here's our online guide to why they took it seriously
fields.trailText: This week the company refused a customer's request to sew the word 'sweatshop' on his trainers. Here's our online guide to why they took it seriously.
fields.body:
1. Workers at nine Nike plants in Indonesia have been found to suffer from sexual and verbal abuse, lack of medical attention and compulsory overtime.

2. According to the report from the Global Alliance for Workers and Communities, female workers gained jobs through sexual "favours", employees were coerced to work overtime in violation of Indonesian law, and medical facilities were inadequate.

3. The report was funded by a £5.4m contribution from Nike to the Global Alliance, whose members include Gap, Nike and the World Bank.

4. The company has issued a remediation plan to placate its critics.

5. Nike's healthy corporate image has been battered in recent years by allegations that it employs underage workers in its Asian factories and asks all employees to work long hours for low pay in conditions that would never pass US inspections.

6. Sites such as Nike Sweatshop Olympics - tagline:"It's not just 20 cents an hour, it's an athletic adventure" - and Nike Watch have drawn attention to working conditions in factories that produce one of the world's most popular labels.

7. A recent addition to the Nike pantheon of designer gear is iD, products that will provide extra work for textile labourers as they are emblazoned with a personalised logo.

8. But Nike turned down graduate student Jonah Peretti's attempt to have "sweatshop" sewn onto his trainers.

9. Obviously some people do very well by Nike. Sports stars like tennis player Andre Agassi, sprinter Marion Jones and golfer Tiger Woods have signed multimillion dollar contracts to have the infamous swoosh plastered over their bodies.

10. Basketball god Michael Jordan even has his own Air Jordan brand.

webTitle: Europe sees Britain as home of tainted food

fields.headline: Europe sees Britain as home of tainted food
fields.standfirst: The UK's reputation as a meat producer - already stained by BSE - is looking  positively tainted after this week's outbreak of foot and mouth disease. As Andrew Osborn reports from Brussels, European consumers will be even more reluctant to buy British
fields.trailText: The UK's reputation as a meat producer - already stained by BSE - is looking positively tainted after this week's outbreak of foot and mouth disease. As Andrew Osborn reports from Brussels, European consumers will be even more reluctant to buy British.
fields.body:
For Europe's already traumatised army of consumers the outbreak of foot and mouth disease in the UK will confirm what they have suspected all along - that Britain is a country where the food tastes bad and is tainted by disease.

It doesn't matter that foot and mouth cannot be passed to humans via infected meat like mad cow disease for in the minds of consumers perception and fear is everything.

Britain, for many on the continent, is rapidly acquiring a reputation as a country which acts as an incubator for some of the world's nastiest animal diseases, and its agricultural credentials have now hit rock bottom.

As if to illustrate the point a brave band of souls from the British Meat and Livestock Commission were in France this week for its annual agricultural fair.

But they had made the mistake of taking a few sheep along with them to liven up their stand and swiftly found themselves in the embarrassing situation of having to test the animals for foot and mouth disease antibodies. Distrust of the UK's already battered farming industry is at an all time low.

First there was BSE, which is now spreading across Europe leaving a trail of fear and paranoia in its wake, and then last summer Britain's pigs were struck down by swine fever forcing the European Commission to slap an export ban on the UK which was only lifted after thousands of animals had been slaughtered.

European consumers have been reading about export bans on British meat products for the past five years and the outbreak of foot and mouth disease could be the final nail in the coffin. Dangerous, tainted and diseased are words which, rightly or wrongly, are increasingly associated with British food products and it could take years to dispel the many myths and misunderstandings which live on in people's minds.

The UK may have chosen to unilaterally impose its own export ban on animal products after it discovered foot and mouth in Essex but the government also has to contend with an EU-wide export ban from Brussels and many European countries will need firm assurances before they agree to lift it.

When the EU's food safety spokeswoman briefed the international press corps on the issue earlier this week she was faced with a barrage of alarmist questions from journalists all over the world demanding cast iron assurances that Britain's problems will not become their problems.

"Can it affect humans?" asked one Italian journalist. The answer - 'not really' - obviously failed to satisfy many and when the EC admitted that there was a tiny risk of viral infection through close contact between infected animals and older people, children and pregnant women, the alarm bells began to ring. "Can you catch it by drinking milk?" asked another and so it went on.

One of Britain's most lucrative export markets for animal products - the EU itself - is at stake and the government and the UK farming industry must do everything they can to reassure our European partners that the outbreak is under control.

If it does turn out that the source of the infection lies beyond Britain's shores it will undoubtedly be a useful tool in persuading our trading partners that there is nothing endemically tainted about UK food production techniques.

But the nightmare scenario, and one which the government must be dreading, is that the highly contagious disease will be carried on the wind, on the soles of tourists' shoes or on the wheels of cars, to continental Europe.

If that happened it would be hard to imagine how Britain could ever hope to rebuild its export markets for meat. The challenge facing Britain's beleaguered farmers is tough enough as it is already.

fields.headline: The Insider
fields.standfirst:
(she goes to the parties so you don't have to)
Special report: London Fashion Week 2001
fields.trailText: (she goes to the parties so you don't have to)
fields.body:
Barely had I recovered from the whiplash-inducing, celebrity-spotting party that was the In Style launch ("Looking great, Vanessa! Love the leather outfit, Nigella!") than it was time for London fashion week party-hopping.

Declined Arkadius's on the grounds that it was being held in the SW hell of the Sloaney Ponies and conserved energy instead for Monday's Versace party. The shiny, swirly invite stated the dress code as, simply, Versace. But there's really no point: at a Versace party, no one is going to be looking at us mere civilians.

How does Donatella do it? A Monday night party in London and alongside the inevitable (Appletons, Hervey, Goldie etc), there are some proper, glossy celebs, including Oscar nominee Kate Hudson, managing to look adorable in a really stupid hat. Kate Moss, sporting newly cropped hair, was holding court, while Kate H clapped and wrinkled her nose in delight, just like she does in the pictures. It was all Fabulous with a capital F: half-empty champagne glasses were whisked out of one's hand and tossed away, replaced by fresh supplies. Once everyone had clocked who was invited to which bit of the party - 8pm (chichi dinner), 10pm (champagne and lounging) or 12pm (trying to squeeze in the door) - the favourite party game became Are You VIP Enough (to be allowed to dance near the Kates)? An unofficial VIP area, guarded by security men, was breached by one British journalist who then stood looking anxious as it dawned on her she didn't actually know these people, so had no one to talk to. After valiant attempts to look engrossed in a glass of champagne, she was asked to leave.

No EastEnders on Tuesday, what with three parties in the diary. First the Bloomberg party for Maria Grachvogel, where Victoria Hervey miraculously wasn't, then on to the British Fashion Awards, where of course she was. Then it was a midnight dash across town to the Chanel and Pop magazine party... where we were greeted by the sight of Victoria Hervey quaffing champagne, barely wearing a dress. Does this girl have a body double?

First the Bloomberg party for Maria Grachvogel, where Victoria Hervey miraculously wasn't, then on to the British Fashion Awards, where of course she was. Then it was a midnight dash across town to the Chanel and Pop magazine party... where we were greeted by the sight of Victoria Hervey quaffing champagne, barely wearing a dress. Does this girl have a body double?

webTitle: How to stop the virus spreading

fields.headline: How to stop the virus spreading
fields.standfirst:
Foot and mouth disease is a quick-spreading virus that can be spread great distances by car tyres, infected animals, or even the wind. Here are some ways to contain it.
Special report: foot and mouth disease
Map of the infected area in Essex
fields.trailText:
Transport
• All livestock movement suspended for seven days.
• Vehicles entering and leaving Cheltenham race course are being disinfected to prevent the virus contaminating preparations for the national hunt festival.
fields.body:
Transport
 All livestock movement suspended for seven days.
 Vehicles entering and leaving Cheltenham race course are being disinfected to prevent the virus contaminating preparations for the national hunt festival.

On the farms
 Five mile quarantine zones around outbreaks of the virus.
 Farmers and their families on the affected sites forbidden to travel.
 Postmen delivering to infected farms are told to hand over mail at the gate.

Animals
 Dogs in the infected areas must be kept under control - either in a kennel or tied to a secure object with a collar and chain. Police are authorised to treat free-running dogs as strays.
 All hunting by harriers, beagles, foxhounds and staghounds is cancelled for a week.
 Horse riders are advised to keep to the roads and off bridleways and farmland.

People
 Ramblers advised to cancel all walks in affected areas and stay away from farmland throughout Britain.

Towns and cities
 The London mayor, Ken Livingstone, has called for a Countryside Alliance march in the capital to be cancelled in case cross-contamination leads to transmission of the virus across the country.
 Zoos told to keep an eye on animals such as elephants that could contract the disease.

Leisure
 Public banned from deer sanctuary at Epping Forest, Essex. All vehicles entering the forest will be disinfected.
 Whipsnade wild animal park in Bedfordshire is banning cars until further notice.
 The National Trust has closed all land containing livestock to the public.

fields.headline: Red faces at Tory-backed website
fields.trailText:
4pm: A site campaigning against over-regulation has been forced into an embarrassing climb-down, reports Wale Azeez.
2pm: Labour joins text messaging frenzy
fields.body:
A Tory-backed website set up to campaign against over-regulation of UK businesses has been forced into an embarrassing climb-down, after publishing the logo of a "supporting" organisation without permission.

The Ministry of Silly Regulations website was launched by William Hague yesterday.

It included the logo of the British Chamber of Commerce in a list of supporters that includes the Conservative party, the Institute of Directors and the Confederation of British Industry.

However, the site had not secured permission to use the logo from the British Chamber of Commerce and was ordered promptly to remove it.

"We have to act quickly and surely on unauthorised uses of our brand," said a BCC spokesman.

Now the Ministry of Silly Regulations has published a disclaimer saying, "the organisations shown do not necessarily endorse the views expressed on the Ministry of Silly Regulations".

The website is the brainchild of Sir Paul Judge, former owner of the Premier Brands food business and chairman of the Conservative party's new deregulation group.

Sir Paul is also the former boss of Cadbury-Schweppes.

The Tory Central Office spokesman would not confirm whether Sir Paul was a member of the Conservative party.

webTitle: Powell but no Barry in Eriksson's bumper squad

fields.headline: Powell but no Barry in Eriksson's bumper squad
fields.trailText: Sven-Goran Eriksson today named three Coles in his first England squad and no Gareth Barry.
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson today named three Coles in his first England squad and no Gareth Barry.

The new England coach named a 31-strong squad for the friendly against Spain at Villa Park next Wednesday. He included four uncapped players - the 19-year-old Arsenal full-back Ashley Cole, the 19-year-old West Ham midfielder Michael Carrick, the 22-year-old Sunderland midfielder Gavin McCann and the 31-year-old Charlton left-back Chris Powell - but still found room for the 34-year-old Teddy Sheringham.

Eriksson indicated that he would use an orthodox zonal back four and promised plenty of substitutions. "We are going to make a lot of changes on Wednesday against Spain after 45 minutes," he said. "It is important to know that four English teams have played in Europe this week and will be playing again the week after the England game so we don't want to force them too much."

There are four candidates for the problem left-back spot: Liverpool's Jamie Carragher, Everton's Michael Ball, Ashley Cole and Powell.

"I have seen Chris Powell of Charlton two or three times," Eriksson said. "He is left-footed, a left defender, so why not see him?

Barry, the left-sided Aston Villa defender who has played in all four England games this season, will also be given an opportunity. "I talked to [England Under-21 coach] Howard Wilkinson and I decided that Gareth Barry will play for the Under-21s on Tuesday night. I want to see him play."

"I have not met the players, just said hello to one or two of them. This is one reason why he we chose so many.

"Tord [Grip] and I are quite new to this situation but we have seen a lot of games. Tord has been here almost three months; I have been here five weeks. I am sure we don't know everything about every English player. That is why we chose to take a lot of players - 31 - to see them, to know them."

webTitle: Animal movements stopped for a week

fields.headline: Animal movements stopped for a week
fields.standfirst:
Special report: foot and mouth disease
Special report: the countryside in crisis
Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Agriculture minister Nick Brown today banned all livestock movement for a week as officials confirmed that animals from the opposite ends of England are infected with foot and mouth disease.
fields.body:
Agriculture minister Nick Brown today banned all livestock movement for a week as officials confirmed that animals from the opposite ends of England are infected with foot and mouth disease.

A farm in Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland, joined four in Essex struck by the virus. Investigators said that the northern farm is the initial source of the outbreak that may have started 14 days ago.

"There is going to be a complete standstill for the next seven days in the movement of livestock in Great Britain," said Mr Brown. "The purpose is to prevent the spread of foot and mouth disease while we are trying to extinguish it."

Foot and mouth was first confirmed at the Cheale Meats abattoir in Little Warley, Essex, on Tuesday. It later spread to an adjacent farm on the same complex before reaching another farm at nearby Great Warley. The fourth Essex farm, Canewdon, was confirmed today.

A second outbreak in Northumberland - the first affecting cattle - was announced this afternoon by chief veterinary officer Jim Scudamore. It happened in Ponteland, just four miles away from the first in Heddon-on-the-Wall.

"We have had active disease in the country for longer than we had thought, and that could have been spreading," said Mr Scudamore.

Heddon-on-the-Wall is now ringed by a five-mile animal exclusion zone and all the pigs are to be slaughtered.

Investigations are continuing at an estimated 600 farms that are believed to have supplied the Essex abattoir with live animals in recent weeks.

Livestock traders said they supported the ban even though it would cause significant difficulties. Peter Kingwill, chairman of the livestock auctioneers' association, said: "Our business is selling livestock and if we can't do that it is obviously going to cause problems.

"If this can be sorted out in a week then it would not be too much of a disaster."

Britain's livestock market is worth almost £25 million-a-week. Traders buy and sell 14m sheep, 2m cattle, 500,000 calves and 750,000 pigs every year.

Officials warned that it may still be some time before the outbreak is contained.

"We are not just looking for the source but for other cases as well," said a ministry of agriculture spokesman.

fields.standfirst: If you want the very latest, most up-to-date-est, news on the announcement, keep hitting refresh like a loon.
fields.trailText: 2.25pm No sign of Sven-Goran Eriksson yet, just a few empty chairs. But that hasn't stopped the journos from the nationals taking their usual place on the front row. They are ready. We are ready. But is Svennis ready?
fields.body:
2.25pm No sign of Sven-Goran Eriksson yet, just a few empty chairs. But that hasn't stopped the journos from the nationals taking their usual place on the front row. They are ready. We are ready. But is Svennis ready?

2.30pm 2.30pm and no sign of Sven. The man is late....

2.31pm Journalists are handed a piece of paper with the England squad on it. It is...

Seaman (Arsenal), Martyn (Leeds), James (Aston Villa), Wright (Ipswich), G Neville (Man Utd) P Neville (Man Utd), Brown (Man Utd), Ferdinand (Leeds), Campbell (Tottenham), Ball (Everton), Carragher (Liverpool), Ashley Cole (Arsenal), Ehiogu (Middlesbrough), Powell (Charlton), Dyer (Newcastle), Beckham (Man Utd), Scholes (Man Utd), McManaman (Real Madrid), Carrick (West Ham), J Cole (West Ham), Lampard (West Ham), Parlour (Arsenal), Butt (Man Utd), McCann (Sunderland), Barmby (Liverpool), Heskey (Liverpool), Owen (Liverpool), Fowler (Liverpool), Andy Cole (Man Utd), Sheringham (Man Utd), Phillips (Sunderland).

2.32pm Sven arrives. The first question is about why he picked Chris Powell. Sven says he saw him twice and was impressed with him. "I have seen Chris Powell of Charlton two or three times. He is a natural left-sided defender so why not see him?" he says.

2.33pm Sven is asked why he has not picked Gareth Barry. Sven says he wants to see him play for the U-21's instead.

2.35pm Sven confirms he will make a lot of changes during the Spain game. "We are going to make a lot of changes on Wednesday against Spain after 45 minutes," he tells the media. "It is important to know that four English teams have played in Europe this week and will be playing again the week after the England game so we don't want to force them too much."

2.36pm Sven is asked about the absence of Dennis Wise and Paul Ince. He denies their international careers are over.

2.38pm "Do you know your captain?" he is asked. "Yes, but I'm not telling you" Sven tells the journalists.

2.40pm But Sven does confirm he will play either 4-4-2 or 4-3-3 against Spain. "I have a starting line-up and formation in mind but we have to wait for Saturday and Sunday to see who is fit. We will work on that on Monday," he adds.

2.42pm Sven is asked the obligatory question about the standard of English football. "I have been surprised by the standard on and off the pitch in England. Every player I have seen is extremely hard working. You can never complain about that. The speed, the mentality, I have been impressed," he says.

2.45pm A few mundane questions follow. Sven confirms that Villa Park is a "super stadium." He also will be guest of honour during Sunday's Worthington Cup final. Before then he will see Bolton v Blackburn tonight and Aston Villa v Derby tomorrow. My what a busy man he is!

2.46pm No more questions. Sven leaves the press conference. Journalists gabble excitedly.

fields.headline: E-grocery sales soar in Britain
fields.standfirst:
Tesco.com leads the way as shoppers decide cyberpower eases the burden

More net news
fields.trailText: Tesco.com leads the way as shoppers decide cyberpower eases the burden
fields.body:
There is little more stressful than a supermarket on a Saturday. Parents pilot overloaded trollies through heaving aisles while bored children create chaos. The staff are in overdrive to keep shelves stacked and quick-shop singles huff and puff with indignation.

By comparison, hooking up to the internet, sending a shopping list across cyberspace and sitting back waiting for a happy chappy to deliver the lot, professionally packed, to the front door, seems like heaven.

This is the world of online grocery shopping, where you let your fingers do the walking and use your modem, not your muscles.

It is also a business where Britain is leading the world. A higher proportion of British food shoppers have converted to the net than in any other country and Tesco.com is now the world's biggest internet grocery business.

According to market research group Datamonitor, British grocery shoppers spent £395m online last year - with more than half of that ending up in Tesco's tills.

But in terms of the £95bn UK grocery market, it is still a tiny business - accounting for just 0.4% of the market.

Datamonitor believes online shopping will account for 5.4% of the British grocery market by 2005. Across Europe, they calculate, the market share is likely to be only about 3%.

Investment bank Goldman Sachs estimates that e-tailing groceries is likely to grow to 7-10% of the European market in the same period. The Institute of Grocery Distribution, however, believes that 23-27% of the grocery market will be online by 2008.

The variations are huge, but the market for groceries is so vast that even the most conservative estimates would create a substantial business.

So far e-grocery firms come in two forms: pureplays, which are new businesses set up specifically to deliver groceries to the customer's door, and traditional supermarkets exploiting a new sales channel.

Pureplays have dominated in the US, where for a while they were among the brightest stars of the dot.com share boom. Webvan launched on the US stock market in 1999 backed by an impressive list of blue-chip investors and banks.

Its shares have crashed so low, however, that the company could be thrown off the Nasdaq - and it has ceded important markets to US grocers.

Earlier this week, Webvan pulled out of Dallas saying it had trouble competing with GroceryWorks.com, a small online grocer owned by Safeway, and with other brick-and-mortar companies such as Wal-Mart that offered unbeatable prices.

In Britain - and now in the United States - it is traditional supermarkets that are setting the pace, led by Tesco.com. Online grocers have used two distinct business models - either using warehouse "picking centres" to fulfil orders or simply sending staff up and down the aisles of existing stores. The pureplays, together with Sainsburys and Asda in Britain, set about building specialist low-cost picking centres, while Tesco based its service on its stores.

It was a smart move by Tesco. It may not be the most efficient model in the long term, but using existing stores and staff meant Tesco was able to roll out its service cheaply and rapidly - and steal a march on its rivals.

In the five years since Tesco.com was launched it has grown from a pilot project in 11 stores to a service available in nearly 250 of its outlets. It covers 90% of the population and has 750,000 registered users who place 60,000 orders a week.

Tesco has invested £60m in the service, buying hundreds of vans and installing computer systems - and claims its new way to do the weekly shop has also created 8,500 jobs.

Left behind in the race to win customers, Sainsbury's and Asda have been forced into a rethink and are playing catch-up by rolling out store-based services to supplement their picking centres.

"The store operation allows us to roll out rapidly, to assess and build demand in new areas without the greater investment of picking centres," Sainsbury now says, belatedly. Even so, Sainsbury's still only covers about half the country while Asda can only service web shoppers inside the M25 plus a few more outlying home counties towns.

Iceland - which changed its name to Iceland.co.uk to reflect its online creden tials - is also sizeable player in the market, although several others, such as Somerfield and Budgen, have recently logged off, having failed to build a big enough customer base.

About 65% of online grocery shoppers are women - but the key to running a successful online grocer is size. To be profitable they need a lot of big-ticket, busy family shoppers, who regularly spend more than in-store shoppers.

The average Tesco.com basket size is £85, four times the in-store average. But the grocer needs to ensure that shoppers are buying the full range of goods. According to one supermarket executive, shoppers buy more low-margin bulk and commodity items online, such as toilet rolls and tinned beans. Tesco is addressing that problem by offering more non-food lines, including furnishings, electrical goods, videos and clothing on its website.

The grocers must also generate regular business. With 60,000 orders a week, most of Tesco's 750,000 "registered users" are not regular users. Webvan in the US has the same problem, but magnified. In San Francisco - its longest established market - its shoppers order only 1.8 times a quarter.

Datamonitor believes that online grocery shopping "is set to become the largest business-to-consumer sector given that expenditure on food, drink and household products is still the most important element of consumer expenditure after housing costs". They calculate that the market is worth $3.5bn (£2.6bn), but will be worth $55bn within five years - a compound growth rate of more than 77%.

Britain, they say, is leading the field because British shoppers are much more relaxed about giving out their credit card details to make purchases on the phone - and are therefore less concerned about security risks when making purchases.

Elsewhere in Europe, e-tailing is most advanced in the Netherlands, where the Ahold chain last year bailed out the struggling US web grocer Peapod.

fields.bodyText: There is little more stressful than a supermarket on a Saturday. Parents pilot overloaded trollies through heaving aisles while bored children create chaos. The staff are in overdrive to keep shelves stacked and quick-shop singles huff and puff with indignation. By comparison, hooking up to the internet, sending a shopping list across cyberspace and sitting back waiting for a happy chappy to deliver the lot, professionally packed, to the front door, seems like heaven. This is the world of online grocery shopping, where you let your fingers do the walking and use your modem, not your muscles. It is also a business where Britain is leading the world. A higher proportion of British food shoppers have converted to the net than in any other country and Tesco.com is now the world's biggest internet grocery business. According to market research group Datamonitor, British grocery shoppers spent £395m online last year - with more than half of that ending up in Tesco's tills. But in terms of the £95bn UK grocery market, it is still a tiny business - accounting for just 0.4% of the market. Datamonitor believes online shopping will account for 5.4% of the British grocery market by 2005. Across Europe, they calculate, the market share is likely to be only about 3%. Investment bank Goldman Sachs estimates that e-tailing groceries is likely to grow to 7-10% of the European market in the same period. The Institute of Grocery Distribution, however, believes that 23-27% of the grocery market will be online by 2008. The variations are huge, but the market for groceries is so vast that even the most conservative estimates would create a substantial business. So far e-grocery firms come in two forms: pureplays, which are new businesses set up specifically to deliver groceries to the customer's door, and traditional supermarkets exploiting a new sales channel. Pureplays have dominated in the US, where for a while they were among the brightest stars of the dot.com share boom. Webvan launched on the US stock market in 1999 backed by an impressive list of blue-chip investors and banks. Its shares have crashed so low, however, that the company could be thrown off the Nasdaq - and it has ceded important markets to US grocers. Earlier this week, Webvan pulled out of Dallas saying it had trouble competing with GroceryWorks.com, a small online grocer owned by Safeway, and with other brick-and-mortar companies such as Wal-Mart that offered unbeatable prices. In Britain - and now in the United States - it is traditional supermarkets that are setting the pace, led by Tesco.com. Online grocers have used two distinct business models - either using warehouse "picking centres" to fulfil orders or simply sending staff up and down the aisles of existing stores. The pureplays, together with Sainsburys and Asda in Britain, set about building specialist low-cost picking centres, while Tesco based its service on its stores. It was a smart move by Tesco. It may not be the most efficient model in the long term, but using existing stores and staff meant Tesco was able to roll out its service cheaply and rapidly - and steal a march on its rivals. In the five years since Tesco.com was launched it has grown from a pilot project in 11 stores to a service available in nearly 250 of its outlets. It covers 90% of the population and has 750,000 registered users who place 60,000 orders a week. Tesco has invested £60m in the service, buying hundreds of vans and installing computer systems - and claims its new way to do the weekly shop has also created 8,500 jobs. Left behind in the race to win customers, Sainsbury's and Asda have been forced into a rethink and are playing catch-up by rolling out store-based services to supplement their picking centres. "The store operation allows us to roll out rapidly, to assess and build demand in new areas without the greater investment of picking centres," Sainsbury now says, belatedly. Even so, Sainsbury's still only covers about half the country while Asda can only service web shoppers inside the M25 plus a few more outlying home counties towns. Iceland - which changed its name to Iceland.co.uk to reflect its online creden tials - is also sizeable player in the market, although several others, such as Somerfield and Budgen, have recently logged off, having failed to build a big enough customer base. About 65% of online grocery shoppers are women - but the key to running a successful online grocer is size. To be profitable they need a lot of big-ticket, busy family shoppers, who regularly spend more than in-store shoppers. The average Tesco.com basket size is £85, four times the in-store average. But the grocer needs to ensure that shoppers are buying the full range of goods. According to one supermarket executive, shoppers buy more low-margin bulk and commodity items online, such as toilet rolls and tinned beans. Tesco is addressing that problem by offering more non-food lines, including furnishings, electrical goods, videos and clothing on its website. The grocers must also generate regular business. With 60,000 orders a week, most of Tesco's 750,000 "registered users" are not regular users. Webvan in the US has the same problem, but magnified. In San Francisco - its longest established market - its shoppers order only 1.8 times a quarter. Datamonitor believes that online grocery shopping "is set to become the largest business-to-consumer sector given that expenditure on food, drink and household products is still the most important element of consumer expenditure after housing costs". They calculate that the market is worth $3.5bn (£2.6bn), but will be worth $55bn within five years - a compound growth rate of more than 77%. Britain, they say, is leading the field because British shoppers are much more relaxed about giving out their credit card details to make purchases on the phone - and are therefore less concerned about security risks when making purchases. Elsewhere in Europe, e-tailing is most advanced in the Netherlands, where the Ahold chain last year bailed out the struggling US web grocer Peapod. fields.headline: Barry relegated to U-21 squad
fields.trailText: Gareth Barry has been given an unwanted 20th birthday present - a place in the England U-21 squad for Tuesday's friendly international with Spain. He will be joined by Leeds duo Alan Smith and Paul Robinson and Derby County's Seth Johnson, who have all been relegated to the U-21 squad, even though they were part of caretaker coach Peter Taylor's team that faced Italy in November.
fields.body:
Gareth Barry has been given an unwanted 20th birthday present - a place in the England U-21 squad for Tuesday's friendly international with Spain. He will be joined by Leeds duo Alan Smith and Paul Robinson and Derby County's Seth Johnson, who have all been relegated to the U-21 squad, even though they were part of caretaker coach Peter Taylor's team that faced Italy in November.

Coach Howard Wilkinson has included three new caps in the squad; Tottenham defender Alton Thelwell, Manchester United midfielder Mark Wilson and Newcastle striker Shola Ameobi.

Thelwell enjoyed an eight-game run in the Spurs first team at the end of last year although in recent weeks he has been on the substitute's bench. Wilson was reported to recently be the subject of a £2m bid from Ipswich manager George Burley although he has not played for Manchester United first team.

Nigerian-born Ameobi has had a run in the Newcastle side since Alan Shearer was sidelined through injury. He is also eligible for his native country and his call-up at under-21 level is an indication that England want him to commit himself to their plans.

fields.headline: Cosla wins some breathing space
fields.trailText: The beleaguered Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (Cosla) appears to have won itself some breathing space after council leaders agreed today to continue its funding and to carry out a "root and branch" review of its entire operation. David Mitchell reports
fields.body:
The beleaguered Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (Cosla) appears to have won itself some breathing space after council leaders agreed today to continue its funding and to carry out a "root and branch" review of its entire operation.

Cosla's future had been under threat after four councils - including Glasgow city council - had decided to pull out and three others had announced they were considering the move.

But at today's meeting, it was agreed to fund Cosla at its current level plus 3% from 1 April and to carry out the wide-ranging review of its operations by the end of June.

Cosla president Norman Murray said afterwards: "The leaders' meeting gave clear support for Cosla's long-term future but recognised there are some concerns about our role which is why we have agreed a fundamental review.

"That review will be undertaken by a wide-ranging group of people who will be talking to member councils about their views of the organisation as it exists and how it should be shaped in the future. I am very confident that at the end of that process we will have an organisation that will take us at least 10 years into the future."

Mr Murray said he was heartened that a number of councils who had indicated that they might leave Cosla had said they would reconsider their decision in the light of today's agreement.

"I have told them all that I am happy to go and talk to them further about what this decision means for the organisation and its future at any time. I am also pleased that today's decision means some measure of security for Cosla staff who have suffered enormous uncertainty over the last few weeks," he said.

Afterwards, a Cosla spokeswoman said there was no question of redundancies among the organisation's 50 full-time staff at the moment. But she added: "Once the review group has established what councils want for the organisation and how best to achieve it, we will have to model our staffing structure around that."

One of the councils understood to be reconsidering its decision to leave Cosla is Clackmannanshire, which is controlled by the Scottish national party.

Meanwhile, South Lanarkshire - one of the councils that had been threatening to pull out - now seems likely to renew its membership after its demands for a wholesale review of Cosla's core functions appear to have been met.

South Lanarkshire wants Cosla to concentrate on the key roles of a national employers' organisation, local government finance and coordinating local government responses to the Scottish executive, and to review what it describes as "non-core activities", such as its office in Brussels.

South Lanarkshire's ruling Labour group is calling a special meeting early next week to discuss the issue but a council spokesman said: "The early indications are that we will be able to stay as Cosla is moving towards what we were looking for. Any decision not to renew our membership has been suspended."

webTitle: New police force faces uphill struggle

fields.headline: New police force faces uphill struggle
fields.standfirst:
With essential reforms in the Northern Ireland police force still in their early stages, the police recruitment drive launched today may well be premature, writes Derek Brown
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText:
With essential reforms in the Northern Ireland police force still in their early stages, the police recruitment drive launched today may well be premature, writes Derek Brown.
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.body:
The first cautious steps towards the establishment of a reformed police force in Northern Ireland are being taken today, with the launch of a recruiting drive which aims to enlist Catholics and Protestants on a 50-50 basis.

Though it is early days, the signals are not encouraging. Unionist politicians remain bitterly opposed to the reforms, while nationalists and republicans insist they do not go nearly far enough.

Random interviews in the local and national media offer a bleak picture of a police service still viewed as partisan and sectarian. In strongly republican areas, the new Police Service of Northern Ireland is widely seen as the Royal Ulster Constabulary under another name.

The RUC has been criticised for launching the recruitment drive in advance of a political agreement on the constitution of the new force. But chief constable Ronnie Flanagan is adamant that he needs new officers now, to fill gaps in his seriously stretched force.

The recruiting drive is being conducted by an independent agency. It hopes to sign up some 250 applicants. Training will begin in September, and the new recruits could be patrolling the streets next spring. In two years, they will be fully-fledged officers.

The problem is that neither they nor anyone else knows what the force will look like then - physically or figuratively.

The reform process is an essential component of the 1998 Good Friday peace accord. Former Tory minister and Hong Kong governor Chris Patten produced his wide-ranging proposals in September 1999, since when they have been the subject of bitter discord in the province.

Unionists believe that the Patton proposals involve the destruction of the RUC. They say the force has been a bulwark against terror, having had 302 officers killed and nearly 10,000 wounded in the course of the current Troubles.

Catholic politicians, on the other hand, believe that many of the Patton proposals are cosmetic, and that the new PSNI will remain an instrument of continued British rule. They wanted the RUC to be disbanded, and the new force set up from scratch.

The wrangle has become meshed with other festering disagreements over paramilitary disarmament and the withdrawal of British soldiers. It has prevented the establishment of the new independent Police Board, which is supposed to implement the more detailed reforms - including apparently petty but symbolically explosive issues like police uniforms and badges.

Some progress has been made, including the appointment of a reform Oversight Commissioner in June last year. A new police ombudsman began work in November, and a complex severance procedure will lead to more than 1000 officers leaving the existing force by the spring of next year.

That is what makes the current recruiting drive so important, both to plug the gaps in the policing of the province, and as a tangible sign of change.

But with unionists still holding out for the reforms to be watered down, and republicans angrily accusing the RUC of perpetuating itself, the new recruits are likely to be facing as many old problems as new challenges.

fields.headline: BBC in cricket row
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: World Sports Group asked BBC reporters to pay an entrance fee to attend this week's Sri Lankan test match, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The BBC has asked the English Cricket Board to negotiate on its behalf after being told it had to pay extra to enter the venue where this week's Sri Lankan test match is being staged.

Commentator Jonathan Agnew, producer Peter Baxter and reporter Pat Murphy were barred from entering the grounds after the rights holder, the World Sports Group, demanded an entrance fee.

The journalists were finally allowed to re-enter the grounds after talks between British and Sri Lankan officials.

A spokeswoman for BBC Radio 5 Live said the journalists were eventually allowed in without paying the fee.

"We had our access sorted out and we are in negotiations to make sure access is resolved for the next test," she said.

The BBC is allowed to report, but not commentate, on the matches for eight minutes an hour.

This is part of a reciprocal agreement with TalkSport, which has the rights to cover international test matches.

But the rights owner, World Sports Group, was not told of a "gentleman's agreement" between the BBC and TalkSport, say insiders.

"There was a gentleman's agreement but no-one stopped to think that there was a third party involved," said a source in Sri Lanka.

"I think they just wanted to make as much money out of it as possible."

Now the English Cricket Board has been roped into the discussion, in a drive to iron out the problems in time for the next test match, to be held in Kandi on March 6

TalkSport says it will co-operate with the BBC and the ECB to help smooth the negotiations.

fields.headline: Labour joins text message frenzy
fields.standfirst: Click here if you're up4it
fields.trailText: 2pm: Labour is inviting activists with mobile phones to write a text message attacking the Tories, reports Wale Azeez.BR> Click here if you're up4it
fields.body:
The Labour Party has launched the first hi-tech salvo against the Tories in the run up to the election with an extraordinary text messaging competition attacking the Conservative Party.

Cashing in on the explosion in text messaging, Tony Blair has launched Txt For Labour in a bid to win the propaganda war against the Tories and recruit supporters.

And young activists can win the princely sum of £100 if they come up with the winning slogan.

The strategy raises the prospect of voters with mobile phones being bombarded with election slogans from all parties.

The competition's entry form, which was posted up on the internet today, reads:

"This is a competition to design a text message either attacking the Tories or with a vision for Labour.

"It can be humorous or inspirational, a game or a slogan, it's up to you.

"Just enter your message into the box provided and you could win £100!"

The Tories dismissed the initiative, branding it a sign of desperation.

"The Labour party is so bereft of ideas it is having to resort to competitions to come up with campaign ideas," said a spokesman.

But Labour hit back saying it didn't have a monopoly on good ideas and hoped young activists could enliven the election campaign through clever use of mobile phones.

The winning slogan will be distributed to up to 30,000 members of Young Labour.

However, a spokesman for the party said only those who had specifically signed up for text messaging would receive any communication.

He said he hoped the drive would spread beyond the party faithful and into the hearts and minds of the populace by word of mouth.

"We are targeting young activists and those who use texting in their day-to-day lives," he said.

He also acknowledged the strategy was being used to "gather contacts on a permission basis".

The spokesman was quick to emphasise Labour was observing the code of conduct drawn up by the Wireless Marketing Association this week.

The Labour party is not a member of the organisation and so its mobile marketing activities do not fall under its control.

However, the spokesman said it will contact the body before any text messages are sent out.

Young Labour has already devised its own slogan: "Action, together we achieve more."

The group's website features the Young Labour logo - a pink rectangle emblazoned with a letter A, which opens up like a filmmaker's clapperboard.

webTitle: Ford rolls out voice activated services

fields.headline: Ford rolls out voice activated services
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Ford drivers will soon be able to access personalised internet services by talking to their cars, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
It sounds like something from a James Bond movie but Ford drivers will soon be able to access personalised internet sites by talking to their cars.

In a tie-up with Vodafone, Ford is to install voice-activated services in its cars.

The first in-car telematic services will be offered as an option in the Ford Focus model.

But Ford intends to install the systems in all of its cars within five years.

The systems operate via Vodafone's mobile telephone network.

Initial services include connections to emergency and roadside services, location positioning and rerouting, traffic information and the ability to make phone calls using voice recognition technology.

The system will be extended to offer personalised news, stock quotes, weather and messaging.

Drivers will be linked to a customisable home page that can be accessed via the internet, enabling drivers to personalise the information and contacts they wish to access in-car.

A first range of services will be available in Germany on March 1 followed by a UK launch and a roll out to other countries.

The services can be accessed by four buttons on the front panel of the stereo system in the Ford Focus.

"Telematics offer a whole new way to satisfy customers," said David Thursfield, president and chief executive of Ford, Europe.

"We are delighted the Focus is the first European Ford to be available with telematic technology.

"We anticipate that, within five years, nearly all new Ford vehicles will be fitted with some type of telematics system," said Mr Thursfield.

"Telematics is an integral part of our strategy, delivering information and assistance to our customers wherever they are, even in-car," said Thomas Geitner, Vodafone Group chief executive, group products and services.

A first range of services will be available in Germany on March 1 followed by a UK launch and a roll out to other countries. The services can be accessed by four buttons on the front panel of the stereo system in the Ford Focus. "Telematics offer a whole new way to satisfy customers," said David Thursfield, president and chief executive of Ford, Europe. "We are delighted the Focus is the first European Ford to be available with telematic technology. "We anticipate that, within five years, nearly all new Ford vehicles will be fitted with some type of telematics system," said Mr Thursfield. "Telematics is an integral part of our strategy, delivering information and assistance to our customers wherever they are, even in-car," said Thomas Geitner, Vodafone Group chief executive, group products and services.

fields.trailText:

Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £185.54
Sean Ingle = £41.82
Paul MacInnes = £34.90
The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £24.08

Scott Murray: Leicester v Sunderland: 0 or 1 goals scored - £10 @ 9/4

The reason? Append any of the following words - Akinbiyi, Benjamin, Dichio, Kilbane - to the following phrase - "The finishing of" - and consider.

Sean Ingle: Udinese to win at Internazionale - £7 @ 7/2

There's so much value on this weekend's coupon, my betting hand is twitching like alcoholic who's been off the sauce for a few hours. For some reason I'm convinced - well, as much as any failed gambler can be - that Liverpool to beat Birmingham in extra-time offers good value at 13/2. And surely in-form Perugia (forget last week's unfortunate reversal against Lazio) are way overpriced at 9/2 to beat a Parma side who are tired and miserable after crashing out of the Uefa Cup last night.

But surely the daddy of all value bets this weekend is the 7/2 on offer for Udinese to beat Internazionale at the San Siro. Udinese are sixth in Serie A, Inter are 11th. Last night Inter lost 2-0 at home to mid-table Spanish side Alaves, while Udinese spent the evening with their feet up.

And it gets better: Udinese have won two of their past three away, while Inter have lost their last two games - and when the two sides met at the start of the season Udinese beat Inter 3-0. In fact, the only dampener on this bet is that Inter's home record in Serie A is actually OK (four wins, four draws, one defeat to Lecce). But considering their poor form and the recent turmoil at the club (passport scandals, prostitutes, Marco Tardelli calling his team "strange"), the 7/2 on offer at Blue Square is an excellent price.

The Prince of Punts: Derby v Aston Villa, half-time/full-time, Villa/draw - £4.89 @ 14/1

Hummm, Prince of Punts angry. Prince of Punts mocked by Blue Square's Patrick Murray. Prince of Punts called "flippant". What is flippant? Prince of Punts not care. Prince of Punts smash betting orthodoxy! Prince of Punts destroy!

Aston Villa and Derby never score goal. Aston Villa and Derby never win match. But odds on draw very pants. Must find value, must find value! Aston Villa score first in 14 games this season. Aston Villa take early lead! But Derby smash and bash. Derby get equaliser. Prince of Punts swim in cash!

Thomas Keegan of the Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective: QPR to win at Wimbledon @ 10/3. Liverpool to beat Birmingham City @ 4/9. Hartlepool to beat Mansfield @ 8/15. £5 treble (pays about 8.6/1).

QPR have found themselves battling against relegation, with the hopes raised by last season's top-ten finish fading fast. Such is their predicament that Gerry Francis feels he has no option but to step down after this game. However, things are not all doom and gloom down at Loftus Road given that, since Gerry's announcement, Rangers have been stung into life and recorded two successive victories - including their first away win of the campaign in their last match.

Wimbledon, however, find themselves facing demons of their own, with the midweek FA cup defeat to old Crazy Gang member Lawrie Sanchez and his ten-man Wycombe team bringing back memories of better times. The Dons have recorded only three home wins to their name, and given the off-field circumstances QPR may triumph in an emotion-soaked Selhurst Park (if that isn't a contradiction when Wimbledon are playing). Throw in the fact of this being a derby game and odds of 10/3 surely represent decent value.

In order to circumnavigate the lower league singles rule, I also include Liverpool to beat Birmingham in a game where class - and a squad the twice the size of most Premiership clubs, never mind First Division - should tell, along with Hartlepool to beat Mansfield, 'Pool being in an outstanding run of form.

fields.headline: Philip Morris strengthens Ferrari ties
fields.trailText:
2pm: Tobacco giant Philip Morris has signed a five-year deal for Marlboro to sponsor Ferrari's Formula One team, reports Julia Day.
Feb 13: Philip Morris denies F1 reports
fields.body:
Tobacco giant Philip Morris has poured cold water on speculation it is pulling out of Formula One racing by signing a five-year deal for Marlboro to sponsor Ferrari.

The declaration means Ferrari will be in a much better position to negotiate a new contract with superstar racing driver Michael Schumacher, when it comes up for renewal in 2002.

Ferrari's sponsorship money helps to pay Schumacher's £20m annual salary.

Ferrari confirmed it is to continue its relationship with Marlboro, which dates back to the start of 1984.

Marlboro will continue to plaster Ferrarri's racing cars and drivers with the brand's red-and-white livery until the end of the 2006 season.

The sponsorship will not be permissible under the EC clampdown on tobacco advertising after 2006.

After that date, cigarette advertising will be banned from sport.

Reports that Philip Morris was to pull out of its £45m-a-year Marlboro sponsorship deal with Ferrari - in order to release funds for fighting compensation claims from smokers around the world - were slammed by the company.

Feb 13: Philip Morris denies F1 reports

webTitle: Councils to improve housing in a bid to beat fuel poverty

fields.headline: Councils to improve housing in a bid to beat fuel poverty
fields.trailText: Local authorities are being ordered to launch huge council housing improvement programmes as part of a government bid to help the millions of people who cannot afford to heat their homes in winter.
fields.body:
Local authorities are being ordered to launch huge council housing improvement programmes as part of a government bid to help the millions of people who cannot afford to heat their homes in winter.

The government today unveiled its strategy to eradicate fuel poverty among pensioners, families with young children, people with disabilities and those suffering long-term illness.

About 50,000 pensioners die every year due to cold-related illnesses and many others need hospital treatment.

The government aims to end fuel poverty by 2010 with its £1.5bn annual initiative, which will benefit around 3m households, or 4.5m people. It hopes the strategy will also ease pressure on the NHS, which spends around £1bn a year on illnesses linked to fuel poverty.

A household is considered to be suffering fuel poverty when more than 10% of disposable income needs to be spent on energy to keep heating at satisfactory levels.

Launching the programme, the environment minister, Michael Meacher, said: "It is totally unacceptable that people should ever not have enough money to keep warm and be forced to choose between paying for food or heating their home.

"This problem wears people down and more likely to fall ill, and once makes it harder to recover."

The measures were a "win-win" situation, said Mr Meacher, as they would create jobs through insulation improvement work, while also saving the poor money.

The strategy includes:

 Removing 800,000 English households in the private sector from fuel poverty by 2004 through better heating and insulation;

 Bringing a further 400,000 homes in the public sector in England up to decent standards;

 Ensuring Scotland's 140,000 pensioner households and social sector tenants have centrally heated and well insulated homes by 2006;

 Delivering help to 37,000 households in Wales by 2003;

 Targeting 40,000 households in Northern Ireland by 2006.

Existing energy efficiency schemes run by central government, local authorities and devolved assemblies will also be coordinated to ensure help is properly targeted at vulnerable people.

But the announcement sparked a political row with the Liberal Democrat environment spokesman, Don Foster, claiming the government had underestimated the number of vulnerable households - saying the figure should be around 5.3m, rather than the government's 4.5m.

And environment group Friends of the Earth accused the government of breaking a pledge to help more people.

Spokesman Martyn Williams said the strategy "failed to live up to" Labour promises.

"It doesn't even seem to do what is required by law, which is a target for eradicating fuel poverty everywhere, not just vulnerable households," he said.

"It looks like the Treasury has forced ministers to do the bare minimum they can get away with but this will leave an awful lot of people still shivering in winter."

fields.headline: BBC1 overturns ITV news lead
fields.trailText: 12.45pm TV overnights: A national crisis helped BBC1's 10pm news achieve higher ratings than News at Ten, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
BBC1 pulled in marginally more viewers to its 10pm news bulletin than ITV last night, proving the old adage about the BBC playing an important role in times of national crisis.

The foot and mouth outbreak helped the BBC pull in 5.8m viewers and a 28% audience share compared with 5.7m and 27% for ITV's News at Ten.

But At Home with the Braithwaites and Who Wants to be a Millionaire? helped ITV to an earlier peaktime victory.

Family trouble among the lottery-winning Braithwaites, played by Peter Davidson and Amanda Redman, secured 8.5m viewers and 34% share at 9 o'clock.

Before that, Chris Tarrant's quiz show gained a 10.3m audience and a 43% share.

Money proved more popular than football last night.

ITV's figures trounced the BBC's Match of the Day at 9pm.

Roma's 1-0 victory over Liverpool opened with 7.8m viewers and a 31% audience share.

The audience peaked at 9m, which the BBC claims is the highest viewing figure for a Uefa cup match.

But the match failed to reap the full benefit of its lead in from EastEnders, where the 11th-hour reunion between Pat and Roy gave the soap 55% of eyeballs.
