fields.headline: The British patient
fields.standfirst:
In the final extract from their book auditing the performance of the Blair government, Guardian writers anatomise the health service
Extract one: Well, did things get better?
Extract two: social justice
Extract three: environment
Extract four: crime
Polly Toynbee and David Walker pick their top 10 politics books
fields.trailText: In the final extract from their book auditing the performance of the Blair government, Guardian writers anatomise the health service.
fields.body:
The existence of the NHS does relatively little for the nation's health: just as sewers not doctors cured cholera, so creating a better off, better educated population does more for heart attacks than building extra coronary care units. But the political health of successive governments has depended on perceptions of the NHS. Unless it is drip-fed above-inflation increases every year, there is hell to pay. Parsimony always results in winter crises, soaring waiting lists and patients on trolleys plastered all over the front pages. It was a lesson of post war political history Labour should not have ignored.

For the first two years spending bumped along at the bottom. This followed a thin time under John Major, when annual increases in NHS spending averaged 2.6%, compared with a post-war average of 3.4%. Since the founding of the NHS was Labour's proudest boast, people expected to see real improvements and fast, however hard the party tried to damp down expectations. They did not happen. The pledge to cut waiting lists by 100,000 was modest - but even that proved perilously hard to achieve. To compensate, a flurry of hospitals were built at once on the never-never. Thanks to the private finance initiative, capital spending was taken off Treasury accounts. The government reckoned patients seeing gleaming new hospitals would not bother to question dubious 30-year debts to the private sector.

Labour's NHS crisis broke in late 1999, personified in Mavis Skeet whose cancer operation was cancelled four times in five weeks because of bed shortages, until her condition became inoperable. Political reaction to her story triggered the biggest spending promise the NHS has ever had. After Lord Winston, the nation's most famous doctor, said the NHS was the worst in Europe and Labour policy "deceitful", Tony Blair dashed to the studios to calm nerves.

He promised the UK would henceforth match the European Union average in health spending, expressed as a proportion of GDP. That meant a guaranteed 6.1% year on year increase, 35% more by March 2005. When the chancellor confirmed it in the budget, the British Medical Association tore up the usual grumbling press release it had prepared and spoke unequivocally of its delight. The good news only goes so far, however, as the graph shows. New calculations by the King's Fund show the gap between the UK and the rest of Europe remains and may even grow.

Besides, for voters mammoth figures signify little. Most NHS cash goes on staff who are hard to find and long to train. Official waiting lists did come down thanks to much pushing - and longer waiting times for first appointments. Demand rose and so did total volume of treatment, as it has steadily since 1948. After a bad first two years, pay for doctors and nurses did rise, but not enough to stem shortages - 22,000 unfilled nursing vacancies at the end of 2000.

With the money came a new NHS plan. It embraced the already launched National Institute for Clinical Excellence which seeks to identify the most effective drugs and treatments, spreading best practice everywhere. The new commission for health improvement acts as a medical Ofsted, examining hospital performance. Tony Blair envisioned a consumer-friendly health service so the first available new money went to the most visible places - accident and emergency departments and 25 high street walk-in clinics for people too busy to take half a day off to see a GP. The plan promised abolition of hospital waiting lists by 2005 and shorter waiting for GP appointments. To the prime minister the danger was that the middle classes would abandon the NHS if it failed to compete with the glossy brochures of the private clinics.

The national plan of July 2000 offered a long menu: 7,000 more beds, 7,500 more consultants, 2,000 more GPs and 20,000 more nurses, with targets for everything from cleaner hospitals and prescribing powers for chemists and nurses. But since none of this has happened yet, it has made no impact with the public. It has, however, stuffed the mouths of the medical professions for the time being: there is a lull in the usual grumbling from the wards.

Before the big promise to match EU funding, speculation was growing that the NHS could not survive on the current basis. The Tories and rightwing think-tanks claimed that only private insurance would raise standards. Even Labour ministers were floating the need for a hypothecated tax - an ear-marked extra tax for the NHS. The big spending promise stilled these voices. But we may now be witnessing the NHS's last chance, at least as a service paid for out of general taxation. If even this great increase fails to deliver standards that match public expectations, many more may turn to private practice, leaving the NHS as a poor service for poor people. But the NHS is recognised internationally for its efficiency in getting value for the low sums spent. If total health outlays in the UK were to come near to what the French and Germans spend, it ought to improve markedly. But that is for the future. For the Blair government 1997-2001, the outcome so far is poor.

Extracted from Did Things Get Better? by Polly Toynbee and David Walker published by Penguin Books on 22 February at £6.99.

fields.headline: A museum fit for martyrs
fields.standfirst: The mundane possessions of Palestinians who have died in the uprising have been collected and turned into a memorial-cum-exhibition, writes Suzanne Goldenberg
fields.trailText: The mundane possessions of Palestinians who have died in the uprising have been collected and turned into a memorial-cum-exhibition, writes Suzanne Goldenberg.
fields.body:
Samer Eweissi's catapult shot its last rock at an Israeli soldier on October 20, when the 15-year-old from the West Bank town of Qalqiliya was killed by a bullet to the lung.

It was back in action this week as art: wrapped like a present in a raffia bow, and encased in a plexiglass cube with Samer's photograph in a stately old stone mansion in Ramallah.

The transformation of Samer's carefully whittled block of wood, and the other homely artifacts on display - a child's bicycle, a Gameboy, work tools and jeans, schoolbags and copy books, and a single sock - is part of an exhibit on the five-month Palestinian uprising called '100 Shaheed (martyrs) - 100 Lives'.

"The objects in themselves have no value except that they belonged to a martyr," said Samir Salameh, the Paris-based artist who is curator of the exhibition at Ramallah's Khalil Sakakini cultural centre. "But now they have become precious objects; that is why I wanted to honour them."

The contrast between the care with which Mr Salameh arranged the mundane artifacts and the bloody chaos in which their owners died, is hugely dislocating. Each totem is bound up in pale cord, and then placed in a cube with the name and spare mono-coloured photograph of the owner, before being arranged in a gallery space dimly lit by tiny candles placed on the floor.

Israeli critics would argue that the exhibit glorifies violent death, and promotes a cult of martyrdom. The Palestinian curators say that while the dead of this intifada have been laid to rest as heros, with thousands trailing their flag-draped shrouds to their graveyards, their families are often left to grieve alone.

The toll in the uprising climbed above 400 this week. The Sakakini Centre's Adila Laïdi argues that the loss of each family is subsumed by the collective suffering of the Palestinians.

Despite the tributes delivered over the graves of the dead, the deceased are soon reduced to numbers and statistics. But although Ms Laïdi said she wanted to immortalise the owners of the 100 objects on display here, she and the others involved in mounting the exhibit were soon overwhelmed by the stories of their truncated lives.

They have also been besieged by the relatives of the other dead in the uprising, who want their loved ones included.

"We got to know them so, so well," says Ms Laïdi. "I wanted to do something for everybody, but people kept dying every day and now I am always feeling guilty: 'what about the others?''

Field workers visited the families of the deceased in person to collect the objects, circumventing an Israeli siege that has severed the West Bank from Gaza, and made travel between Palestinian-ruled cities a nightmare.

At times, the results are pitiable. Some of the dead are represented by their work tools - a measuring tape or a drill. Sami Balawneh is represented by the identity card that allowed him to work inside Israel. The magnetic ID card expires on May 19 2001; Sami was killed in the West Bank city of Tulkarem on October 11.

The family of Yazan Halayqa, aged 14 and from Hebron, donated his blue bicyle with a heart-shaped pillow on the handlebars that reads: "I love you this much".

Many of the men and boys remembered here had so few belongings, their families simply donated a piece of clothing. Bilal Affaneh, who was one of the first to die in the uprising last September, is represented by a single sock.

Alaa Bani Nimrah, from the West Bank town of Salfit, was so poor that he had never had his photograph taken during his 15 years' in existence.

"The picture is of what it is to be a Palestinian. It is a condition that is more important than your name," Ms Laïdi said. "The time of death and the circumstances of their death were dictated by the fact that they were Palestinians living under the occupation."

fields.headline: Hollywood infuriates Russian veterans
fields.trailText: Survivors of a Soviet nuclear submarine disaster are campaigning to block the filming of a Hollywood disaster-movie version of their experiences - enraged by a screenplay that portrays them as incompetent drunkards.
fields.body:
Survivors of a Soviet nuclear submarine disaster are campaigning to block the filming of a Hollywood disaster-movie version of their experiences - enraged by a screenplay that portrays them as incompetent drunkards.

Initial support for the venture, due to star Harrison Ford and Liam Neeson, soured when a group of veterans obtained a draft of the script.

"Everyone is drinking - the officers and the sailors," scene-setting directions note. "They drink heavily and they drink constantly. The only activity which distracts them from this is fighting ... The submarine is leaking. The sailors are covering the holes with paint."

A group of veterans in St Petersburg had been assisting the Canadian production company to research the 1961 disaster, in which 28 sailors died from radiation poisoning after a malfunction on a nuclear reactor in the K-19 submarine.

They say they were assured the film, Widowmaker, would focus on the courage of the men on board, especially those who sacrificed their lives to avert a nuclear catastrophe.

The arrival of the script triggered outrage. "It is very insulting," said retired Captain Yury Mukhin, one of 90 survivors. "It portrays us as ill-educated, ill-disciplined and impolite, when in reality K-19 was the most advanced submarine in the Soviet Union, and the navy recruited its best men to serve on board."

Survivors are dismayed by the portrayal of K-19 as a lump of faulty technology and horrified by the suggestion that crew members would have drunk vodka or played cards on duty. A panic scene after the alarm is sounded, with crew members reaching for the instruction book, made them particularly furious.

"We suspect that the film's idea is to show that Russian submariners were incompetent 40 years ago - and to imply that this is how they are now, in the wake of the Kursk tragedy," said Igor Kurdin, head of the St Petersburg Sailors and Submariners Club.

A letter has been sent to Russian naval chiefs demanding an end to cooperation with the K-19 Productions film company. An assistant at K-19 Productions said the script had been substantially revised and that the veterans' concerns were groundless.

"Revising it won't help. The film needs to be totally rewritten," Capt Kurdin said.

fields.headline: Lord Cledwyn of Penrhos
fields.standfirst: Senior Labour politician who rose to be secretary of state for his beloved Wales and an early advocate of devolution
fields.trailText: Senior Labour politician who rose to be secretary of state for his beloved Wales and an early advocate of devolution.
fields.body:
Lord Cledwyn of Penrhos, who has died aged 84, was Labour leader in the House of Lords from 1982 to 1992. Earlier, as plain Cledwyn Hughes, he served as a senior figure in the Commons under three Labour leaders - as an opposition spokesman under Hugh Gaitskell, and as a cabinet minister under both Harold Wilson and James Callaghan, most notably as secretary of state for his beloved Wales.

Widely popular for his shrewdness and warm personality, he had an unending store of anecdotes, which were imparted with relish in the corridors of Westminster and to audiences in Wales, whether in his native Welsh language or in English.

The stories derived from his climb up the political ladder, from Anglesey county council (1946-52) to the Commons backbenches in 1951, through his government posts as minister of state for commonwealth relations, Welsh secretary and minister for agriculture, to his leadership of Labour peers for the decade that ended with the 1992 general election. One of his oft-repeated classics concerned James Callaghan's retort in 1976, when Cledwyn told him the parliamentary Labour party had elected him leader and prime minister: "And I never even went to university!"

Cledwyn's confidence - and the quality of his anecdotes - grew steadily from the time he arrived at Westminster as a small-town solicitor and the new Labour MP for Anglesey, who had just ousted Lady Megan Lloyd George, daughter of the last Liberal prime minister. His shy clannishness initially only allowed him to eat at the Commons Welsh table and speak, preferably in Welsh, to fellow countrymen from north Wales. More aggressive solicitor-MPs from the bigger practices of south Wales tended to ridicule his parochial timidity.

Cledwyn's feelings about north Wales were so strong that, in 1959, he and his wife Jean decided that they did not want their two children brought up as Anglo-Welsh mongrels in London's English-language culture. Jean returned to north Wales, converting Cledwyn into a train-wearied weekend husband.

His initial timidity derived partly from the large red birthmark on his face, and partly from the womb of Welsh culture - that combination of chapel and north Wales Liberalism - into which he was born in Holyhead, on the isle of Anglesey. He was doubly embedded as the son of a respected Presbyterian minister and leader of the local Liberals, the Rev David Hughes, himself the son of a Snowdonia quarryman.

But young Cledwyn did well at Holyhead grammar school and went on to read law at the University of Wales at Aberystwyth, which then had only 750 students, almost all of them Welsh. He became president of the university Liberal society.

In 1937, he returned to Holyhead to be articled to a local solicitor. As local unemployment deepened, and the Czechoslovak crisis intensified, he listened to local Independent Labour party speakers - and joined the Labour party in 1938.

Called up in 1940, he served in the Royal Air Force Volunteer Reserve until 1945, doing administrative, legal and intelligence jobs, and was commissioned as a flight lieutenant, without being able to fly. In 1944, local Labour stalwarts urged him to stand in the impending general election against Lady Megan, but his father resisted. Cledwyn fought the 1945 election almost on his own, making 50 speeches - 45 of them in Welsh. Nonetheless, he came within 1,000 votes of victory.

Back in Holyhead after demobilisation, he opened his own legal practice. In court, he defended clients with unexpected fierceness and, by 1949, his position had improved enough for him to marry the lovely Jean Hughes, who had the same surname, the same religion and the same politics.

Cledwyn's political advance looked less hopeful. In 1946, he had been elected to Anglesey county council, but when he challenged Lady Megan again in 1950, she beat him by 2,000 votes, largely because, although a Liberal, she had identified with Labour. In 1951, however, when Labour was receding nationally, he ousted the crown princess of the Lloyd George Liberals by 595 votes.

Cledwyn made a diffident start, unsure that he would survive beyond one term at Westminster. Initially, he left Jean behind in Holyhead with their infant daughter, Ann. In the Commons, he became a fringe Bevanite, largely because he liked Aneurin Bevan (though not his wife, Jennie Lee). In 1955, with a number of other Welsh-speaking Labour MPs, he urged devolution for Wales. The following year, they started a petition for a Welsh parliament, for which rebelliousness Cledwyn was reported to the Labour national executive by the south-Wales-dominated Welsh Council of Labour.

Thanks to his battle to bring jobs to the constituency, in 1955 he was returned by a comfortable 4,568 votes, and brought Jean, Ann and son Harri down to London. He helped to bring the Wylfa nuclear power station to Anglesey, and subsequently get an aluminium smelter project in the area. He knew unemployment forced Welsh-speaking locals to emigrate and lose their Welsh culture.

Cledwyn began his rise in 1959, when Gaitskell made him an assistant spokesman on housing and local government. When Harold Wilson led Labour to victory in 1964, he became minister of state for commonwealth relations, with African troubles on his plate. In 1966, he became secretary of state for Wales.

A firm believer in Wales as a nation entitled to its own parliament, he faced the problem that four-fifths of Welshmen lived in non-Welsh-speaking south Wales and did not share his aspirations. His two years in the job were spent in building Wales's economic base and civil service, disappointing nationalists and Welsh-language fanatics. "Language is a thing you cannot push down people's throats," he told those who shouted "Traitor! traitor!" at him at the eisteddfod.

In 1968, Wilson made him minister for agriculture, partly to get rid of Fred Peart, who was a fanatically anti-common marketeer, partly to promote another Wilson loyalist, George Thomas (later Viscount Tonypandy) to the cabinet, thus giving south Wales its due voice in the Welsh Office. At agriculture, Cledwyn could not compete with Peart as a trencherman. But he became a moderate pro-marketeer and a great admirer of Roy Jenkins, an uprooted South Walian - although he stopped short of following Roy into the Social Democratic party.

As a capable administrator, Cledwyn did not enjoy Labour's period in opposition from 1970 to 1974. When the party returned to power, he became chairman of the parliamentary Labour party 1974-79, a job well suited to his ability to nudge most people into loyalty. As Jim Callaghan's envoy to southern Africa at the end of 1978, he tried, unsuccessfully, to accelerate the handover of power in Rhodesia. In 1979, he stepped down from the Anglesey seat, and was made a life peer.

His greatest test was his decade as Labour leader in the Lords, which began by ousting a disintegrating Peart. He had 120-130 ageing peers, only two-thirds well enough to vote regularly. It was an arduous task to put up a creditable show against at least three times as many Tories, both declared and undeclared, backed by the civil service. It was a disappointment that his time was not capped by a Labour victory in 1992, which would have allowed him to reform the institution. He had the compensation, however, of handing over to another Welshman, Lord (Ivor) Richard, even if he was from south Wales.

Lord Cledwyn is survived by his wife and two children.

Lord Callaghan of Cardiff writes

I am deeply sad to learn of Cledwyn's passing. As secretary of state for Wales, he was an outstanding leader. His concern was for all aspects of Welsh life - its political and economic advancement, its culture, the language, and the progress of the university of which he was so proud to be pro-chancellor.

In international affairs, he was a true statesman; as a member of a small nation, he had an instinctive understanding of the small nations of the Commonwealth. As minister for commonwealth affairs, he earned a wide reputation in Britain's overseas territories for his interest, his creative mind and his humanity. As Labour leader in the Lords, despite depleted numbers, he organised a most effective opposition and won the respect of all parties in the House.

He was an unfailing counsellor to me throughout my political life, and especially during my time as prime minister. Wales has lost a great man, and I mourn a true friend.

 Cledwyn Hughes, Lord Cledwyn of Penrhos, Baron of Holyhead in the Isle of Anglesey, politician, born September 14 1916; died February 22 2001.

fields.headline: 44,000 homeless in Mozambique floods
fields.standfirst: <A HREF="http://www.guardian.co.uk/Mozambique/">Special report: Mozambique floods
fields.trailText:
Riot police are helping to evacuate some of an estimated 400,000 Mozambicans affected by flooding which has killed at least 41 people and left more than 44,000 homeless.
<A HREF="http://www.theguardian.com/Mozambique/">Special report: Mozambique floods
fields.body:
Riot police are helping to evacuate some of an estimated 400,000 Mozambicans affected by flooding which has killed at least 41 people and left more than 44,000 homeless.

Despite the presence of police, many residents are unwilling to leave their homes, fearing that they might lose any possessions and animals they leave behind.

The town of Marromeu on the banks of the Zambezi river in the central province of Sofala has been put on a state of maximum alert because the river is continuing to rise, the newspaper Noticias reported. Earlier this week the Zambezi was 1.86 metres higher than its critical level of six metres at the town of Caia, about 50 miles upstream from Marromeu.

The authorities had already evacuated hundreds of Marromeu residents who live on islands in the river, and efforts to evacuate others were under way, Antonio Chicumbe, the province's delegate at the National Disaster Management Institute, said.

The government has issued an appeal for £20.7m in flood aid. Yesterday, the German foreign ministry said it was giving £320,000 in emergency aid.

Devastating flooding last year killed more than 700 people and inflicted widespread damage in the impoverished country. International donors pledged more than £276m to help the former Portuguese colony recover from those floods in central and southern regions.

fields.bodyText: Riot police are helping to evacuate some of an estimated 400,000 Mozambicans affected by flooding which has killed at least 41 people and left more than 44,000 homeless. Despite the presence of police, many residents are unwilling to leave their homes, fearing that they might lose any possessions and animals they leave behind. The town of Marromeu on the banks of the Zambezi river in the central province of Sofala has been put on a state of maximum alert because the river is continuing to rise, the newspaper Noticias reported. Earlier this week the Zambezi was 1.86 metres higher than its critical level of six metres at the town of Caia, about 50 miles upstream from Marromeu. The authorities had already evacuated hundreds of Marromeu residents who live on islands in the river, and efforts to evacuate others were under way, Antonio Chicumbe, the province's delegate at the National Disaster Management Institute, said. The government has issued an appeal for £20.7m in flood aid. Yesterday, the German foreign ministry said it was giving £320,000 in emergency aid. Devastating flooding last year killed more than 700 people and inflicted widespread damage in the impoverished country. International donors pledged more than £276m to help the former Portuguese colony recover from those floods in central and southern regions. fields.headline: Scared of being scared
fields.standfirst:
A new international crime study places England and Wales at the top of the crime league - but the list is based entirely on people's 'experiences' of crime. Crime correspondent Nick Hopkins reports.
Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: A new international crime study places England and Wales at the top of the crime league - but the list is based entirely on people's 'experiences' of crime. Nick Hopkins reports.
fields.body:
Confused? You should be. Last September the government was hailing a 10 per cent drop in crime with overall figures, as counted in the British Crime Survey, at their lowest for almost a decade.

Fear of crime, the statisticians told us, was much more of a problem than crime itself. The less than subliminal message was - we worry too much. But we're not fussing nearly enough, if an international study published today is to be believed.

It suggests crime rates in England and Wales are the highest in the industrialised world, and that we're at the very top of the international crime league table for burglary, car offences, sex and violent assaults.

The study, which relied on questioning people about their experiences rather than jotting up offences recorded by the police, may reflect a nation's obsession with crime - as an issue, it is on a par with the weather.

But a sounder conclusion is that other countries are faring much better in the areas of prevention and deterrence. The reasons are probably myriad.

Here is some food for thought: the results of another survey this week revealed that 50 per cent of violent crime and 33,000 deaths a year in England and Wales are linked to alcohol.

The Alcohol and Health Research Centre study also showed teenagers from the UK are more likely than most of their European counterparts to have taken drugs, drunk alcohol or smoked. Teenagers are responsible for the majority of minor offences.

At a briefing at Scotland Yard yesterday, Sir John Stevens, the commissioner, told reporters some of the difficulties facing his force. The Met is about 3,000 officers under strength at the moment. His aim is to have filled the vacant posts within three years, but it won't happen without massive funding for recruitment campaigns. Progress is painfully slow. Morale is rock bottom.

This time last year, 25,400 officers worked at the Met. Today, the figure has risen to 25,422 - a measly increase. His officers are spread thinly across a whole range of departments - community service units, murder squads, anti-Yardie inquiries etc - at a time when his most experienced detectives are leaving in droves. Why?

When officers reach the age of 50, they are positively encouraged to find employment in other fields by antiquated "police regulations". Penalised financially if they stay on - especially in terms of pension - they are snapped up by security businesses which pay much higher salaries.

"We've got to find some way of keeping them," said Sir John.

Meanwhile, the government is considering making judges visit prisoners they convicted when they are in jail to help "break the cycle of reoffending and develop a culture of rehabilitation".

Just how this will help inmates - and judges - is not entirely clear.

webTitle: Domestic goddess to plug World Book Day

fields.headline: Domestic goddess to plug World Book Day
fields.trailText: 11am: Unesco has chosen food writer Nigella Lawson to front World Book Day 2001, reports Wale Azeez.
fields.body:
Confirmation for Nigella Lawson fans that the domestic goddess can do no wrong arrived this morning, when she was chosen to front a campaign to encourage people to read books.

Ms Lawson was named author of the year at the British Book Awards 2000's last night for her bestseller How to be a Domestic Goddess.

However, she has now been engaged by Unesco and the book publishing industry to promote World Book Day 2001.

Posters featuring celebrities and their favourite books will appear across the country, supported by a radio advertising campaign designed to whip up interest ahead of World Book Day on March 1.

The campaign was inspired by a similar initiative in the US that featured stars such as Whoopi Goldberg and Rosie O'Donnell.

Ms Lawson named the Raymond Chandler Papers, edited by Tom Hiney and Frank MacShane, her favourite book.

Her fellow TV chef and cookery writer Jamie Oliver opted for Sue Townsend's Adrian Mole: the Cappuccino Years.

Actor Ioan Gruffudd, who played TV's Hornblower, chose Omega by Geraint Jones.

Olympic boxing champion Audley Harrison, another of the featured stars, went for Fight the Power by Colin McMillan, the story of the former British featherweight champion.

World Book Day is being sponsored by the Booksellers Association of the UK and Ireland, the Publishers Association, Book Tokens and Securicor Omega Express.

webTitle: In brief: Costner's sideburns too weird for the school run

fields.headline: Costner's sideburns too weird for the school run
fields.standfirst: Plus: Liz Hurley insists on the real thing; Russell Crowe's not just a beautiful body
fields.trailText: Plus: Liz Hurley insists on the real thing; Russell Crowe's not just a beautiful body
fields.body:
 Kevin Costner has apparently been mistaken for a drug dealer after growing huge sideburns for his new film 3,000 Miles to Graceland. The 46-year-old actor grew the extra facial hair for his role as a bank robber who disguises himself as Elvis. According to ananova, he said parents at his children's school thought he'd "turned a little weird." The star of the forthcoming Thirteen Days continued: "I showed up and the rest of the parents thought I was some kind of dealer."

 Elizabeth Hurley surprised workers on the set of her new film, Servicing Sara, by refusing to be associated with any fakery. According to peoplenews, the woman known principally for that dress, was involved in a scene where she had to wear a Rolex watch but immediately realised that the one she had been given was a fake. Hurley then refused to wear it because, she said, audiences would be able to tell it wasn't real. Despite concerns about money, Hurley was subsequently granted a £6,000 genuine top-of-the-range, diamond-encrusted Rolex.

 The ubiquitous Russell Crowe is to start shooting his new film, A Beautiful Mind, on Monday. The film, which also stars Crowe's fellow Best Actor Oscar nominee Ed Harris, is based on the real-life story of John Forbes Nash, a man who won the Nobel Prize in spite of suffering from paranoid schizophrenia. According to ananova, Crowe plays Nash, while Harris is cast as an intelligence officer.

webTitle: Car ads do not deliver says RAC

fields.headline: Car ads do not deliver says RAC
fields.trailText: 12pm: An RAC survey reveals car ads are ignoring their target audience by not giving consumers what they want, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Images of cars ripping across an African desert, hurtling through fields of flames or snaking around hair-pin mountain bends are advertising staples.

But car advertising is not giving consumers what they want.

Motor marketeers and their advertising agencies are committing the sin of ignoring the needs of their target audience, according to Edmund King, RAC Foundation chief executive.

And car manufacturers are losing sales as a result.

In a new survey, the independent body has found just 3% of car ads in newspapers and magazines concentrate on safety features.

In contrast, 8% of press ads focused on safety 18 months ago.

"Consumers are always most concerned about the safety of cars but manufacturers are not selling it," explained Mr King.

"A new European crash-test programme is now in place but most manufacturers do not make use of the results in their ads.

"There are some exceptions - Renault, for example - but we feel ads are not giving consumers what they want, which is weird when you're trying to sell a product," he added.

He called for simpler ads containing the basic information about safety, efficiency and economic viability.

The survey revealed ads have shifted to focus on finance deals - with 29% of press ads promoting special offers.

Some 26% of ads focused on gadgets, 14% concentrated on speed, 12% promoted cheap insurance and breakdown cover and 8% tried to sell a lifestyle concept.

In a bizarre reversal of the old advertising adage "sex sells", only 6% of ads highlighted the sexiness of the cars.

Although far removed from the "bikini-clad babes languishing on bonnets" approach prevalent in the 60s and 70s, Mr King said the last 12 months have witnessed an increase in the use of sex to sell cars.

He pointed to a Mercedes-Benz advert in this week's press.

It uses the line: "She takes my breath away... the way she moves... sleekly turns the road to silk... the way she purrs..." and ends: "She's worth it."

fields.headline: Tat's all, folks
fields.standfirst: What am I bid for an eight-foot model hamster? Or a plastic brain complete with perspex case? At the end of this month everything in the Dome will be sold off in 'one amazing auction sale'. But is this stuff worth anything? And who's going to want it?  Emma Brockes took design connoisseur Tommy Roberts there to cast an expert eye
fields.trailText: What am I bid for an eight-foot model hamster? Or a plastic brain complete with perspex case? At the end of this month everything in the Dome will be sold off in 'one amazing auction sale'. But is this stuff worth anything? And who's going to want it? Emma Brockes took design connoisseur Tommy Roberts there to cast an expert eye
fields.body:
Lot 100: the 8ft hamster

Roberts approaches the fibreglass rodent and confidently dodging the "is it a mouse/is it a hamster?" debate, simply identifies it as a "monument to bad taste". The rodent once stood in the Work Zone. To the right of its paw is a block of yellow, fibreglass cheese. "It's a mouse, with some cheese," says Roberts slowly, turning it over in his mind. Within seconds, he has identified a possible buyer. "A theme pub will buy that and hang it out of their first-floor window because they've got a cheese board," he says. Roberts thinks they'll pay in the region of £350, although is at pains to point out that with two tasteless bidders in the room, you never know how high these things will go.

Lot 103: the central nervous system

Roberts's eye is caught by a sliver of brain, pancreas and two dismembered feet suspended, Damien Hirst-style, within a block of Perspex. Beside them hangs a human nervous system. "They're plastic, I think," says Roberts, suddenly doubtful of how far into tastelessness the organisers have strayed. He picks up a model of a human eye, the size of a hub cap. "This would make a wonderful mirror in someone's big loft apartment." Two prospective buyers can later be overheard discussing the merits of "body-part art", while a nearby dome steward sniggers into her neon vest.

Lot 650: the oversized clock and other miscellany

Getting into his stride now, Roberts considers a table of assorted tat - boardgames, shuttlecocks, a rubber chicken - and reflects on life's ironies. "It's common," he says, waving an arm to take in the spread, "but without the common touch. That's where the dome went wrong."

A giant clockface stands before him, imprinted with the legend: "the average person works 100,000 hours during their lifetime." It used to stand in the Work Zone. After observing what a shame it is that more hours weren't put into finding an imaginative way to deliver the statistic, Roberts says that the clock will find a home in the atrium of a big accountancy firm and could go for anything up to £300.

Lot 91: the mannequin

"God," says Roberts, "he'll never make it in window dressing." We are standing before a life-size doll, a man in a boilersuit grimacing as if he knows where he is. Roberts is quite taken and moves in closer. "The Beamish Museum might be interested in him. They could use him as an engineer on the Flying Scotsman." He puts its value between £160 and £220.

A dummy of a disconsolate England supporter is less well received. "He looks more of a heroin addict than a football fan," sniffs Roberts. "In fact, he doesn't look like a fan of anything." He declines to put a price on him.

Lot 84: the sculpture

Warming to his disgruntlement, Roberts rounds on a collection of Tony Hart/Womble style sculptures made from things other folk have thrown away. There is a bicycle built from bits of old sports equipment and a harp cobbled together from instruments. It is the model of a three-piece suit fashioned from old magazines, however, that provokes Roberts's outrage.

"It could go for £20, it could go for £200," he says, shrugging helplessly at the vast irresponsibility of people with too much disposable income. "It's Hannibal Lecter stuff," he rails. "I mean, was the person who made this in an asylum? Your aunty might call it surrealism, but we both know what I would call it." I usher him into the nearest side room, realising too late that it's bare but for a row of hamster wheels, each occupied by a stuffed rodent.

Lot 236: the rodents

Unexpectedly, Roberts goes for the rodents. "Nicholas Serota stuff, this," he says happily. "I mean, you'll get pet owners bidding for the cages - I'd say £200 for a row of 20 - but the best place for this lot is Tate Modern." It is unclear whether Roberts is praising the rat installation or condemning modern art.

Lot 957: the costumes

Second-hand fleeces, nurses uniforms, air steward outfits - it is like the BBC wardrobe department in here, but Roberts thinks the Work Zone's costumes have wider potential. "A club will open up in nine years time called the Millennium Experience and all this stuff will be at the cutting edge of fashion." He pulls at the corner of a sludge-green dress. "You'll have to keep it in the cupboard until then, of course."

The serious business of the auction, and the items that Roberts finds genuinely exciting, will be generated from the dismantled huge industrial kitchen - the chrome fridges and marble-topped tables, the hobs and trolleys - all of which he imagines will be snapped up by restaurants at a fraction of their usual price. A chrome fridge, usually £2,500, might go for nearer £800. "The best thing here is the catering equipment," says Roberts, "and the stainless-steel ware." Lot 2989 is the first thing Roberts would himself consider bidding for. It is a multi-level storage rack. "I'd pay £70 for that and be happy.

"You could stand your TV and hi-fi on it, use it as a bookcase. It's got that 70s hi-tech look about it. If you robbed the wheels of the other one, you could make it portable."

Roberts is momentarily excited by a big, old-fashioned radiator. "I would pay £500 for this," he says and slaps it, before jumping back. A fibre-glass fake, of course.

Lot 5047: the cleaning cone

"Beware, slippery surface." Yes, even the yellow safety cones are for sale. Roberts thinks they'd make good objets d'art , if you were so inclined.

Lot 1653: the seaside resort

Here, I'm afraid, Roberts starts to wilt. The tat-attack of the dome's fake British coastal resort penetrates even his thick skin. "That might be considered art in Tunbridge Wells," he spits, bitterly, surveying a brightly coloured picture of palm trees and beach huts. "Someone buying props for a pantomime in Margate might go for this, but what a tacky, tacky thing. These people had no imagination. This is dated 90s design stuff. The best thing about this whole place is the riverside view. When it's been stripped, they should let the kids come in and dodge about on their BMXs for £1 a day."

Roberts takes off his glasses and rubs his eyes, before resting them on a picture of a pizza, framed by a red-and-white striped lifebuoy. A shudder moves through him. "Gruesome," he says.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.trailText: Shanghai Noon | Earth | L'Humanité
fields.body:
Shanghai Noon ****
Rental and DVD rental Buena Vista Cert 12

A light-hearted buddy-buddy east-meets-west comedy that is hugely amiable and works a treat. It gives Jackie Chan a far better role than his other Hollywood vehicle, Rush Hour (now filming a sequel), and surely elevates Owen Wilson to a new level of celebrity. Already the co-writer of the eccentrically brilliant Rushmore, he looks a bit of a Sundance Kid here and pulls the same trick of playing a contemporary character in the old west, performed with superb timing and reams of laconic, drawled philosophy, charm and deviousness. Chan and Wilson makes a real team and the exuberance of their interplay suggests both actors were having a ball (compare and contrast particularly with Will Smith and Kevin Kline's disconnected duo in Wild Wild West, the last, disastrous attempt at frontier comedy). Debutant director Tom Dey makes the camera almost as acrobatic as Chan, whose English is clearly improving; and, like its title, Shanghai Noon pulls some neat twists on the old west. There's some sloppy plotting, but it's a small price to pay for such an engaging movie with some superb set-pieces.

Earth ***
Retail (£15.99) Fox Pathé Cert 15

Part two of Deepa Mehta's controversial trilogy, Earth concentrates on the 1947 partition of India, when independence was combined with widespread carnage. In the foreground, the estimable Nandita Das (from Fire) is being wooed and considering a union. In the background, a country is breaking into warring tribal and religious groupings. A mood of foreboding sets in, despite the beautiful settings. There are moments of quiet contemplation and comedy, largely seen through a child's eyes, but it leads to a shocking ending.

Retail (£15) Artificial Eye Cert 18

webTitle: Pop CD of the week: Fun Lovin' Criminals: Loco

fields.headline: Felonious funk
fields.standfirst: Caroline Sullivan enjoys the wiseguy Lotharios of New York
fields.trailText: Caroline Sullivan enjoys Fun Lovin' Criminals, the wiseguy Lotharios of New York
fields.body:
Fun Lovin' Criminals Loco
(Chrysalis)
****
£14.99

To quote the jazz-rappy Microphone Fiend, which pops up halfway through the Fun Lovin' Criminals' third album (fourth if you count 1999's novelty lounge project, Mimosa), these 15 tunes are "tales from the dark side". Sure - and the Ramones are really "bruddas". It's not surprising that most of this Manhattan trio's success has been outside their home country: Americans would never swallow their wise-guy personae, especially since the seedy New York they depict ceased to exist 50 years ago.

Growler-in-chief Huey, who refuses to divulge his surname, seems to have come straight from the pages of Damon Runyon's 1930s "Broadway" stories, and his facial fur from Willy Deville of long-defunct Lower East Side punks Mink DeVille. Then there are the songs - Where the Bums Go, Swashbucklin' in Brooklyn - which purport to be about illicit urban dealings, except that no self-respecting criminal would use terminology like "swashbucklin'".

The one genuine thing about Huey, ludicrously titled bassist Fast and drummer Maxwell is their love of smooth Latin and funk rhythms, zazzed up with turntable silliness and scratchy rock guitar. The recent top-five single Loco shows them at the height of their powers, finding an unlikely middle ground between Santana and the Beastie Boys. The focal point is Huey, shamelessly playing up the Latin-lothario schtick that also serves him admirably on the drowsy Half a Block and Bump. On the latter he rakishly recalls the Sunday he met "the finest girl I've ever seen" at a club on gay night. But is she a lady or a ladyboy? The Crims leave it to your imagination, although they don't on the incongruous rockabilly thumper Dickholder. They close on the equally unexpected note of Little Song, which proves that Huey can play a rather fine pedal-steel guitar.

It's great fun, this fantasy Manhattan of bad cops and good criminals, and you've got to smile at their temerity - which is what Huey and the boys are counting on.

webTitle: Hip-hop CD of the week: Rae and Christian: Sleepwalking

fields.headline: Tracks of my dreams
fields.standfirst: Alexis Petridis  welcomes back the kings of British hip-hop
fields.trailText: Alexis Petridis welcomes back Rae and Christian, the kings of British hip-hop
fields.body:
Rae and Christian Sleepwalking
(K7/Grand Central)
****
£13.99

If, as twinkle-eyed 1970s Northern comic Mike Harding once sang, it's hard being a cowboy from Rochdale, then being a hip-hop production duo from Manchester is a job Sisyphus would consider a bit of a schlep. The problem faced by Rae and Christian, just such a Mancunian duo, is the same for all British hip-hoppers: gaining respect, especially from hip-hop's founding fathers in the US.

The stronger the American hip-hop scene is, the less likely it is that anywhere else in the world will get a look in, and right now, US hip-hop and R&B is going through one of its regular periods of thrilling, unpredictable reinvention thanks to producers Timbaland and the Neptunes and Atlanta rap duo Outkast. What chance do a pair of bespectacled Lancastrian knob-twiddlers have in the world of b-boys and bling-bling?

In fact, for the past five years Rae and Christian have been doing quite nicely, thank you. After founding Manchester's celebrated record store Fat City and the equally regarded label Grand Central, Mark Rae and Steve Christian have performed a remarkable balancing act. Their production style - soft keyboards and muted orchestral samples, influenced by US soul but shot through with a distinctly English strain of melancholy - has proved original and inventive enough to win that elusive Stateside respect: their records are packed with guest appearances by rap stars such as Jeru tha Damager and the Jungle Brothers. It's also proved palatable enough to allow the duo a lucrative parallel career as remixers of choice to Magic FM stalwarts such as Texas, Simply Red and Natalie Imbruglia. The one fly in the ointment was the failure of their excellent 1999 debut album, Northern Sulphuric Soul, to translate critical acclaim into crossover success.

Two years on, Sleepwalking pools together a similar collection of taut, funky instrumentals, heavyweight guest rappers (this time, Californians the Pharcyde collaborate on two sparkling tracks) and moody ballads. They've even got an actual soul legend on board: 56-year-old Bobby Womack, who contributes to two tracks. Unfortunately, on Get a Life, Rae and Christian appear to have been so overawed by Womack's considerable presence they forgot to write a song, but the stirring voice that powered Across 110th Street saves the day. Wake Up Everybody, which boasts semi-improvised vocals and a darkly portentous backdrop, is a highlight.

Better still is Vai Viver a Vida, the collaboration with Brazilian singer Tania Maria. A guest appearance by a Latin-American vocalist is usually an excuse for dance producers to make records riddled with cliches: they get the maracas out, hire a samba band, dress up like Carmen Miranda and start singing "They've got an awful lot of coffee in Brazil" in Speedy Gonzales accents. Thankfully, cultural tourism isn't on Rae and Christian's itinerary. Instead, Tania Maria's voice floats sexily around swelling strings and simple acoustic guitar.

Only one collaboration falls entirely flat. There's no excuse for marooning the impassioned falsetto voices of roots reggae legends the Congos on the sort of anodyne funk that provides suburban clothes shops with background muzak. On Hold Us Down, lead Congo Cedric Mynton sounds like he's trying to chant down Babylon in a branch of Miss Selfridge.

While they may wisely eschew working with British MCs, Rae and Christian have a knack for discovering home-grown singers. On Northern Sulphuric Soul they introduced the Mancunian Veba; here it's Rae's cousin, Kate Rogers, who provides Sleepwalking's stand-out track, Not Just Anybody. Her gorgeously drowsy voice is perfectly matched to shimmering, twilight atmospherics.

Will Sleepwalking make mainstream stars of Rae and Christian? It seems unlikely: the album is defiantly out of step with current R&B and hip-hop trends. There's no attempt to ape the vogueish, stuttering beats you hear on Destiny's Child or Aliyah hits. When the Pharcyde rap here, it's over propulsive breakbeats and muted jazz keyboards rather than the hook-laden, sample-heavy chart sound. But if it avoids current trends, it also avoids British hip-hop's fatal flaw: sounding like a clod-hopping pastiche. Sleepwalking boasts a style, and a charm, entirely its own.

fields.headline: Such sweet sorrows
fields.standfirst: Arab Strap weave beautiful soundtracks to heartbreak, plus township hoe-downs, faux geeks and Afro blues
fields.trailText: Arab Strap weave beautiful soundtracks to heartbreak, plus township hoe-downs, faux geeks and Afro blues
fields.body:
Arab Strap The Red Thread
(Chemikal Underground)
****
£12.99

We've been here before - the rows, the drunkenness, the cheating and dreams; the guitars that skulk in the corner before screaming, the drums that throb quietly, fists clenched and ready to throw punches. The Red Thread is the latest addition to that rich tapestry Aidan Moffat and Malcolm Middleton have been stitching since their debut in 1995: on the surface no different from the three albums preceeding it, yet as dissimilar from them as a new girlfriend is from an ex. Moffat's lyrics have a blush-inducing frankness ("At least we know we're fuckable/ At least we're sated and we're tired", "My mind wonders what my hands would do/ To make sure that you came"), and his mumbly voice sometimes drifts into the sleazy drawl you'd expect from a crooner in a late-night bar in the red-light district. But there is sweetness too, lines as simply sorrowful as "We could pretend that this never started/ That you're still shy and I'm still broken-hearted", that capture at once all the joy and awfulness of relationships. And the humanity of his writing is beautifully reflected in Middleton's majestic arrangements, from the curiously sprightly Love Detective to the icy slashes of guitar that rise up at the end of Demon Tips and the swooningly romantic strings on Haunt Me (reminiscent of the orchestration on label-owners the Delgados' Great Eastern album). Upliftingly depressing, these are songs to remind you why you fall in love. (MC)

Mahotella Queens Sebai Bai
(Indigo)
****
£15.99

A rousing, utterly joyous set from three elderly South African women who were stars in the 1960s and 1970s and are now enjoying yet another revival. Hilda Tloubatla, Mildred Mangxola and Nobesuthu Mbada were among the finest female exponents of Mbaqanga, the home-grown mixture of R&B, gospel and traditional styles that for years dominated the South African townships. There was a fashion for a male, deep-voiced ultra-bass singer - "a groaner" - to be joined by a female backing chorus, and the Mahotella Queens provided the backing for that greatest of groaners, Simon "Mahlathini" Nkabinde. His death two years ago should have marked the end of an era, but the Queens are back, and sound fresher and more confident than ever. They have even expanded their repertoire, now switching from gutsy, rolling and tuneful R&B and pop songs through to delicate, unaccompanied close-harmony work. There are sections where they match Ladysmith Black Mambazo for their gently thrilling, delicate treatment of gospel and traditional songs, but then they switch to tight, rhythmic songs such as the catchy and slinky Umona, or to chugging, guitar-and-accordion-backed dance tunes that sound like the township answer to a country hoe-down. Great stuff. (RD)

Life Without Buildings Any Other City
(Tugboat Records)
***
£12.99

Remember 1979? Life Without Buildings do, and with such affection that they've resurrected the sound of the Slits as a kind of artistic statement, adding nice tunes behind seemingly freeform yet stylised vocals. But although the guitars - slow and sweet or fast as a speeding heartbeat - work hard behind the lyrical hop-scotching, the songs' success depends on the vocal delivery of Sue Tompkins, spitting words like bullets or trilling like a Tellytubby on acid. Words are posed as questions and repetition is key, a sentence spoken over and over until it leads to an unrelated idea. Syllables are pronounced and usually followed by a yelp. "Dar-ling, how come you so pret-ty?" Tompkins asks in Philip, all Estuary vowels and attitude, her randomness either punk poetry or the inner workings of an anxious mind. Sorrow, with its spoken-word sadness, is great, and when Tompkins announces "it's like the new past", she's right. (BC)

Clem Snide Your Favorite Music
(Cooking Vinyl)
***
£13.99

There is something rather too knowing about Boston quartet Clem Snide: from the way they stand ankle-deep in water and the faux-geekiness of their sky-blue dress-suits alleviated by MTV-friendly haircuts, to the song 1989, which limply parodies Prince's 1999. As with the Bobs, Barenaked Ladies and Big Daddy before them, it is as if Clem Snide cannot bear to be seen to take their chosen genre seriously. They excel at gentle but non-hickey country-tinged fare, made their own by singer and sole-songwriter Eef Barzelay's way with a wan lyric (when he elects not to take a stroll down Smug Avenue) and art-school graduate Jason Glasser's cello and violin. Best comes first with the lovely, cello-led My Dairy Queen, which swoons along at funereal pace and displays a richness of sound they never quite repeat. The brisk single, I Love the Unknown, is not too far behind, and a thoughtful cover of Ritchie Valens's Donna suggests their intentions are far from dishonourable, but they will have to lose the air of contrivance and twee nonsense such as Exercise if they are to progress. (JA)

15.60.75 Jimmy Bell's Still in Town
(Glitterhouse)
****
£13.99

This is a live album from a Cleveland septet, recorded in 1975 on the evening they somehow came to support Bob Marley on their home turf, featuring nobody who went onto greater things. Released shortly afterwards by the appositely elusive Water Brothers records, it should have passed into obscurity almost instantly. In fact, it did pass into obscurity until Pere Ubu's David Thomas pronounced it "the only good album ever recorded by anyone". Obviously Thomas is wrong, in the way that everyone is always wrong about their favourite album, but he has done the world a mini-favour by bullying his current label to re-release it. As with John Coltrane circling around and then tearing through My Favourite Things or the entire output of Laughing Clowns, 15.60.75 (AKA Numbers Band) possessed an overwhelming sense of watertight, driving urgency. Songwriter Robert Kidney's crisp vocals bring a Kevin Rowland-esque dramatic tension to Narrow Road and Animal Speaks, and when the three saxophones tootle in unison on Jimmy Bell and Thief, it's clear that Bob Marley had quite an act to follow that evening. (JA)

Leonard Cohen Field Commander Cohen - Tour of 1979
(CBS)
***
£11.99

A live Leonard Cohen album recorded on a British tour in December 1979? Released in February 2001? Since Cohen's last album of new songs, The Future, came out nearly 10 years ago, presumably this is a last-gasp effort to remind listeners that yes, there really was a bloke called Leonard Cohen who used to make rather good albums. Here, he sounds relaxed and philosophical, backed by a sympathetic band who pluck and massage a variety of Eastern-sounding stringed instruments. Though he sings Bird on a Wire and So Long, Marianne, much of the material is from the lesser-known reaches of Len's catalogue, so if you crave elderly live recordings of the obscure Cohen, this one's for you. Bizarre. Nice to hear the old boy again, nonetheless. (AS)

Ty Awkward
(Big Dada)
***
£12.99

From the same label as Roots Manuva comes this debut album of British hip-hop from the London-born, Nigerian Ben Chijioke, alias Ty. Compared to his "conscious rap" counterparts in the US, Ty's music is less dark and intense, his delivery pacific not hectoring. He raises issues such as bullying and sexual politics in a moderate way, just as the musical backdrop is a pleasant collage of soul, guitar and piano samples. While the sound is smooth enough to be American, the lyrics are very British: bizarre references to strongman Geoff Capes and Grifter bicycles make Awkward a CD adjunct to the sort of nostalgia peddled by Saturday night TV shows on BBC2. The production is crisp and DJ Pogo's turntable skills dextrous, creating a layered PM Dawn-ish effect on Trippin' Over Words and lending a haunting quality to The Nonsense. By She's Not Feeling Me at the Moment - a series of answerphone messages from an offended ex-girlfriend replayed by sensitive new man Ty - Awkward's relentless Anglocentricity has become quite appealing. In his spare time, Ty lectures schoolkids on the merits of enlightened behaviour and the evils of MTV - so well-meaning; the anti-Eminem. Awkward is the acceptable face of hip-hop, but really, the best hip-hop is always unacceptable. (PL)

Olu Dara Neighbourhoods
(Warner ESP)
****
£13.99

It's a surprise that more of us haven't heard of Mississippi's Olu Dara, a cornettist/ guitarist/singer who has won US awards for his work in contemporary dance and theatre, and has worked with the likes of Art Blakey, Cassandra Wilson and Brian Eno. But then, it's also a surprise that this atmospheric and spontaneously alive fusion of Afrobeat, gospel, jazz and blues is only the 60-year-old's second album. Dara's Afro-blues - reminiscent in parts of Fela Kuti, Jimi Hendrix, Beefheart and Dr John, who guests on Hammond B3 on four tracks here - is not a nostalgist's appropriation of roots forms; it's shot through with an unsentimental 21st-century urban grit. The balance of feelgood charm and sharp wit is played out in the contrast between the lullaby-like Out on the Rolling Sea (a traditional sailors' song from the Bahamas) and Red Ant (Nature), a wry allegory involving racial metaphor ("I saw the red ant cryin'/ 'Cause the black ant was walking on his hill/ I saw the black ant cryin'/ 'Cause the white ant was trying to steal") and ecological satire. What all the tracks share is Dara's light (and oddly youthful) touch, which makes Neighbourhood's vibrant meditation on the African diaspora a friendly creature with a sting in its tail. (GM)

Songwriter Robert Kidney's crisp vocals bring a Kevin Rowland-esque dramatic tension to Narrow Road and Animal Speaks, and when the three saxophones tootle in unison on Jimmy Bell and Thief, it's clear that Bob Marley had quite an act to follow that evening. (JA) Leonard Cohen Field Commander Cohen - Tour of 1979 (CBS) *** £11.99 A live Leonard Cohen album recorded on a British tour in December 1979? Released in February 2001? Since Cohen's last album of new songs, The Future, came out nearly 10 years ago, presumably this is a last-gasp effort to remind listeners that yes, there really was a bloke called Leonard Cohen who used to make rather good albums. Here, he sounds relaxed and philosophical, backed by a sympathetic band who pluck and massage a variety of Eastern-sounding stringed instruments. Though he sings Bird on a Wire and So Long, Marianne, much of the material is from the lesser-known reaches of Len's catalogue, so if you crave elderly live recordings of the obscure Cohen, this one's for you. Bizarre. Nice to hear the old boy again, nonetheless. (AS) Ty Awkward (Big Dada) *** £12.99 From the same label as Roots Manuva comes this debut album of British hip-hop from the London-born, Nigerian Ben Chijioke, alias Ty. Compared to his "conscious rap" counterparts in the US, Ty's music is less dark and intense, his delivery pacific not hectoring. He raises issues such as bullying and sexual politics in a moderate way, just as the musical backdrop is a pleasant collage of soul, guitar and piano samples. While the sound is smooth enough to be American, the lyrics are very British: bizarre references to strongman Geoff Capes and Grifter bicycles make Awkward a CD adjunct to the sort of nostalgia peddled by Saturday night TV shows on BBC2. The production is crisp and DJ Pogo's turntable skills dextrous, creating a layered PM Dawn-ish effect on Trippin' Over Words and lending a haunting quality to The Nonsense. By She's Not Feeling Me at the Moment - a series of answerphone messages from an offended ex-girlfriend replayed by sensitive new man Ty - Awkward's relentless Anglocentricity has become quite appealing. In his spare time, Ty lectures schoolkids on the merits of enlightened behaviour and the evils of MTV - so well-meaning; the anti-Eminem. Awkward is the acceptable face of hip-hop, but really, the best hip-hop is always unacceptable. (PL) Olu Dara Neighbourhoods (Warner ESP) **** £13.99 It's a surprise that more of us haven't heard of Mississippi's Olu Dara, a cornettist/ guitarist/singer who has won US awards for his work in contemporary dance and theatre, and has worked with the likes of Art Blakey, Cassandra Wilson and Brian Eno. But then, it's also a surprise that this atmospheric and spontaneously alive fusion of Afrobeat, gospel, jazz and blues is only the 60-year-old's second album. Dara's Afro-blues - reminiscent in parts of Fela Kuti, Jimi Hendrix, Beefheart and Dr John, who guests on Hammond B3 on four tracks here - is not a nostalgist's appropriation of roots forms; it's shot through with an unsentimental 21st-century urban grit. The balance of feelgood charm and sharp wit is played out in the contrast between the lullaby-like Out on the Rolling Sea (a traditional sailors' song from the Bahamas) and Red Ant (Nature), a wry allegory involving racial metaphor ("I saw the red ant cryin'/ 'Cause the black ant was walking on his hill/ I saw the black ant cryin'/ 'Cause the white ant was trying to steal") and ecological satire. What all the tracks share is Dara's light (and oddly youthful) touch, which makes Neighbourhood's vibrant meditation on the African diaspora a friendly creature with a sting in its tail. (GM) Reviews by Maddy Costa, Robin Denselow, Betty Clarke, John Aizlewood, Adam Sweeting, Paul Lester and Garry Mulholland.

fields.headline: Jazz CD releases
fields.trailText: Henri Texier: Remparts D'Argile | Louis Sclavis: L'affrontement des Prétendants | Perfect Houseplants: New Folk Song
fields.body:
Henri Texier Remparts D'Argile
(Label Bleu)
****
£14.99

This is a remarkable improvised soundtrack to film-maker Jean-Louis Bertucelli's originally scoreless 1968 movie of the same name, with Henri Texier on bass, Sebastien Texier on saxes and clarinet, and Tony Rabeson on drums. Rabeson's playing is a very powerful element in this dramatic and darkly intense music; in the early sections his bumpy tom-tom pulse underpins long stretches of fast and feverish free-bop alto playing. As the sax stretches further and further out into multiphonic yelps and wails, Rabeson ups the ante with a hissing cymbal beat reminiscent of Sunny Murray and snare offbeats like the effect of a journey on a rutted road. Henri Texier displays an astonishing virtuosity on the bass: his mix of flying uptempo runs, furious strumming, sliding chords and deep, throbbing resonances sounds like Charles Mingus, Charlie Haden and Jimmy Garrison rolled into one. But he is just one apex of a superbly balanced triangle of collective improvisation. Fascinatingly, the prevailing musical atmosphere often strongly recalls the free jazz of the period in which the movie was made, particularly John Surman's white-hot but shortlived trio. Cheriba Courage has a folksy lilt: didgeridoo sounds mix with tambourine-like clatters while military pipe-melodies step sideways into dark melodic alleys. Vent Poussière (Dust Wind) is exquisitely suggested by Sebastien Texier's quiet clarinet over Rabeson's rustling, barely touched cymbal patterns. This is a real beauty, and you don't have to be a free-jazzer to hear that.

Louis Sclavis L'affrontement des Prétendants
(ECM)
***
£14.99

Another one from the premier league of the sharp-end French jazz scene. Henri Texier and multi-reed player Louis Sclavis have often been partners in bold and imaginative projects, but this set is for Sclavis's current quintet, adding trumpet, cello, bass and drums to the leader's hurtling virtuosity, particularly on clarinet. The leader has been preoccupied with a search for a southern European and north African-influenced new jazz over the past 15 years, and this set is full of scalding improvisations and wild sonic tumblings hitched to ecstatic, dancing melodies. Some of it is very jazzy, notably the episodes featuring the agile and inventive trumpeter Jean-Luc Cappozzo; some of it is tranquil and ruminative, with the ensemble sounds taking on chamber-music textures in their sustained cello lines and airy clarinet. Sclavis and Cappozzo duck and swerve in intimate unison on the eccentrically boppish theme of Hors les Murs, before Sclavis takes it on in winding, tinkling isolation, like water finding its way downhill over pebbles. Bassist Bruno Chevillon flickers at the top of the range in his unaccompanied solo and swings hard in his deft, running-on-tiptoe forays over the whole instrument. Sclavis's slow clarinet playing, classical in its sober poise, is very atmospheric, and if the set isn't as seamlessly powerful as his 1992 Duke Ellington album, or the remarkable 1996 study of Rameau's music, it's certainly up to the leader's determinedly original standards.

Perfect Houseplants New Folk Songs
(Linn)
***
£14.99

Perfect Houseplants is ex-Loose Tubes saxophonist Mark Lockheart's sparky quartet including the excellent pianist Huw Warren. Both Lockheart and Warren have followed folk muses as much as jazz ones (the pair have worked extensively with singer June Tabor), so the focus of this set is familiar territory for them and their regular listeners. But you still hear plenty of rugged jazz-blowing and a good deal of the nervily sardonic, fidgety melodic concepts that recall old Frank Zappa discs. The latter quality is prominent in the opening Lockheart composition Pageant, with its circling piano figure, blurted sax lines and clattery drumming; on Warren's gentle Holding Back, however, the groove is more Latin-tinged and sunnily Pat Metheny-like. The Barford Angel (another component of Lockheart's East Anglian suite) is a reminder of the close idiomatic links between this band and the aural landscape of Django Bates; here the instruments swim lazily around each other. The relaxed theme of Bubbles highlights Dudley Phillips's graceful, Steve Swallow-like bass guitar. A pretty agreeable mix on the whole, and with some inventive improvising, though the compositions in this corner of British folk-influenced jazz can sometimes merge into each other a little.

webTitle: Kirch closes in on formula one

fields.headline: Kirch closes in on formula one
fields.trailText:
11.45am: Kirch is close to securing the finance to buy a stake in F1 from struggling rival EM.TV, writes Dan Milmo.
Feb 16: EM.TV/Kirch rescue deal
Feb 16: EM.TV chief quits
Feb 15: EM.TV bailed out by Kirch
fields.body:
German media group Kirch is close to securing the finance to buy a stake in formula one from struggling rival EM.TV.

The £700m rescue package was reported to be in jeopardy because four major banks had rejected Kirch's approaches.

However, the company today denied reports it was pulling out of the deal and said it was close to securing the finance.

Kirch has agreed to buy half EM.TV's 50% interest in formula-one holding company SLEC.

Banks had originally balked at supporting the deal because SLEC owner Bernie Ecclestone is threatening to block it.

Mr Ecclestone wields a veto over any change of control in SLEC and he is backed by FIA, the formula one governing body.

If the deal goes through, control of formula one will pass into German hands, as Kirch has also agreed to finance a shareholding option that would give EM.TV a further 25% of SLEC.

EM.TV has been forced to sell its SLEC holding after piling up debts of £650m.

Chief executive Thomas Haffa is under investigation for possible fraud and insider trading.

fields.headline: Ethnic minorities grow to 1 in 10
fields.trailText: Next year's census is expected to show that minority ethnic communities total more than 5m people, or 10% of Britain's population, Jack Straw said yesterday. Alan Travis reports
fields.body:
Next year's census is expected to show that minority ethnic communities total more than 5m people, or 10% of Britain's population, Jack Straw said yesterday.

The home secretary's "best guess" of the growth in the black and Asian communities came as he confirmed the introduction of a race equality law directed against "institutional racism" across the public sector, including schools, hospitals and broadcasting organisations such as the BBC.

The last census in 1991 estimated that Britain's minority ethnic population accounted for 7% of the population, at about 3.5m. Mr Straw said that in London the proportion probably now stood at around 20%; in some boroughs, and in his constituency of Blackburn in Lancashire, it was more than 50%.

Publishing the second annual report on progress in tackling racism since publication of the Macpherson inquiry into the murder of Stephen Lawrence, the home secretary said that the new figures would underline the scale to which Britain was a multiracial society.

Mr Straw said the report on 70 recommendations put forward by Macpherson showed "encouraging progress in key areas, but we cannot afford to be complacent". He said that, after two years, the "breadth and depth of the change" required had become clear, and much more needed to be done within the police and elsewhere to ensure the reforms would stand the test of time. He acknowledged that the big four police forces - London, Manchester, the West Midlands and West Yorkshire - were falling short.

A consultation paper on the equality law, which comes into effect from April, confirms that major central and local government bodies will have to ensure their workforce reflects their communities, and policies and practices do not indirectly discriminate. The commission for racial equality is to be given powers to secure court orders where needed.

fields.headline: HarperCollins launches ebook imprint
fields.trailText: The Chinese-born author who won last year's Nobel prize for literature is spearheading HarperCollins' big push into e-publishing, writes John Ezard.
fields.body:
Gao Xingjian, the Chinese-born author who won the Nobel prize for literature last year only to hear that his main novel was unpublished in many countries, had the most handsome and risky of amends made to him yesterday.

His story Soul Mountain was chosen by HarperCollins to spearhead its first big push into the risky and untried domain of e-publishing. Downloadable versions went on sale for £8.17 - £1.73 less than the printed paperback - at online retailers including Waterstone's.

Soul Mountain is the first of 100 e-titles due out by Christmas. Others include titles by the fantasy author Raymond E Feist, the novelist and short story writer Joyce Carol Oates, the naval storyteller Bernard Cornwell and the bestselling US children's horror writer RL Stinewith.

HarperCollins UK is the first big British publisher to bring out an e-book and its parent company the first to mount a global e-publishing operation.

But its initial market is small and uncertain. At present the books can be read only on PCs, Apples or laptops. Print-outs are barred because of piracy fears. And concern over the security of encryptions means that so far computers cannot download them on to palmtops or other handheld personal digital assistants, though these are a large part of their natural market.

No purpose-built e-book reader is on the UK market. To import one from the US would cost about £150. Acknowledging these drawbacks, Leo Hollis, HarperCollins's editorial director of e-books, said: "This is a first step and a brave one."

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapskate | Quick bites | On the menu | On the net | Just out
fields.body:
Cheapskate
Where to eat out for under £15

Wee Curry Shop 7 Buccleuch Street, Glasgow Tel: 0141 353 0777

A little bit of back-street Calcutta or Bombay - tiny restaurant, rickety tables, functional oilskin tablecloths, with the odd choice touch of tartan curtains, halogen spots, and prints of Indian ladies in opulent saris. The proximity of the open-plan kitchen means you watch your food being cooked before you eat, cookery demo and lunch rolled in to one. The basics are properly looked to - grade A rice; top-hole puris; ace parathas, and no industrial curry pot here. Also keep room for karahis and chilli garlic chicken of the less explosive variety. Veggies are more variable and puddings should be avoided. But as the bills are on a par with the space, and the food comes flying to the table, who cares?

Quick bites
Where to eat out in 15 minutes

Café Gandolphi at Habitat, Buchanan Galleries, Glasgow Tel: 0141 331 1254

You know the phrase "As pants the heart for cooling stream when heated in the shopping"? The Café Gandoplhi is Glasgow's cooling stream bit, assuming you don't mind queuing. Modern, airy, spacey; cool, cream steel. The menu is aimed at the light luncher rather than the dedicated diner, with loads of dishes in kid's portions for the family that shops together. Part Italian, part Asian, part British (puds) and part fused; salads, soups, pasta, fancy Focaccias and bulky baguettes, for the most part produced to an impressive standard, puds excepted. Service brisk and prices reasonable. And so, refreshed, you're ready for the fray again...

On the menu

Flour 00

A flour by any other name?
Certainly not. A specific flour for specific purposes.

Licensed to bake?
Not exactly.

For what, then?
Making your own pasta.

Are we talking fresca or asciutta here?
Fresca, assuredly.

So what's with the doppio zero, then?
No self-respecting pasta-maker would use anything else for making fresh pasta or pizza, come to that.

What's so special about it?
It's ultra fine, and very hard.

Hard?
The hardest of the hard. It has very strong gluten, the protein that gives pasta and pizza dough their tensile qualities.

As opposed to?
Tipo 0.

Which is?
Just for bread.

On the net

www.thehungersite.com

What with Lent approaching, and a few weeks without jam roly poly looming large, the hunger site might just be the order of the day. Set up in 1999 by John Breen, a software engineer in Indiana, the site aims to reduce world hunger. Each and every time you click the screen, the site's corporate sponsors donate a cup of food to countries such as Bosnia, Lebanon, Indonesia, Afghanistan, Honduras, Mozambique and Eritrea. There are also hunger facts, such as "eight million people die from hunger every year", and "every 3.6 seconds someone dies of hunger. 75% are children". The site is phenomenally successful - there were 95,604,534 donations last year alone.

Just out

Uncle Roy's Mellow Moffat Mustard with honey and malt whisky

Form:
Beige mustard rather than the English yellow.

Flavour:
Very mild; quite fruity, almost appley (no surprise; see below); marked but mellow acidity; musky flavour of mustard comes through late in the day.

Verdict:
Made with water, mustard flour, apple puree, honey, vinegar, salt, malt whisky, salt and spices - not sure what happened to the whisky, but the rest is in evidence. And I can't stop tasting it...

Delivery:
Made by a small shop, Harvest-Time, and available by post (01683 221177). 10p from each jar goes to Help a Child. It's a taste-good, feel-good package.

Cost:
£1.90/190g

webTitle: Nigella Lawson wins author of year

fields.headline: TV chef wins author of the year at 'Nibbies'
fields.trailText: The TV chef Nigella Lawson was named author of the year last night at the British Book Awards or 'Nibbies' in London, the awards ceremony that represents the book trade's preferences. Her literary domination will continue in the run-up to World Book Day on March 1, as she is fronting the annual campaign to encourage literacy and joy in reading (her favourite book, she revealed, is the Raymond Chandler Papers).
fields.body:
The TV chef Nigella Lawson was named author of the year last night at the British Book Awards or 'Nibbies' in London, the awards ceremony that represents the book trade's preferences. Her literary domination will continue in the run-up to World Book Day on March 1, as she is fronting the annual campaign to encourage literacy and joy in reading (her favourite book, she revealed, is the Raymond Chandler Papers).

The Nibbies, which began in 1990, are a strange mixture of trade and glamour - a combination reflected in the eclectic mix of attendant celebrities, which included shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe and former footballer Sir Geoff Hurst.

How to Be a Domestic Goddess, Lawson's bestselling hymn to buns and baking, beat off competition from Harry Potter's creator, JK Rowling (though Harry Potter IV deservedly won for its marketing campaign). Lawson stressed that her recipes were intended not to push people towards perfection but to make them feel they had already achieved it.

Tony Parsons' poignantly sentimental tale of single fatherhood, Man and Boy, was book of the year, beating off the bestselling tome of another chef, Jamie Oliver. The Naked one revealed possible plans to take his talents to America, where his TV show is doing well (audiences can't understand his accent, he explained, but "when they see the food and the colours they get really excited").

Footballer David Beckham won an award for his autobiography, My World - though this particular literary gong went to the book's stylish red-tinted cover.

The Whitbread and Guardian First Book Award prizewinner Zadie Smith won the newcomer of the year award for her novel about life in multicultural London, White Teeth, while Terry Pratchett was honoured for services to bookselling - a sentiment with which no one could disagree.

The winners in full

Butler & Tanner Book of the Year - Man & Boy, Tony Parsons (HarperCollins)
