fields.bodyText: The TV chef Nigella Lawson was named author of the year last night at the British Book Awards or 'Nibbies' in London, the awards ceremony that represents the book trade's preferences. Her literary domination will continue in the run-up to World Book Day on March 1, as she is fronting the annual campaign to encourage literacy and joy in reading (her favourite book, she revealed, is the Raymond Chandler Papers). The Nibbies, which began in 1990, are a strange mixture of trade and glamour - a combination reflected in the eclectic mix of attendant celebrities, which included shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe and former footballer Sir Geoff Hurst. How to Be a Domestic Goddess, Lawson's bestselling hymn to buns and baking, beat off competition from Harry Potter's creator, JK Rowling (though Harry Potter IV deservedly won for its marketing campaign). Lawson stressed that her recipes were intended not to push people towards perfection but to make them feel they had already achieved it. Tony Parsons' poignantly sentimental tale of single fatherhood, Man and Boy, was book of the year, beating off the bestselling tome of another chef, Jamie Oliver. The Naked one revealed possible plans to take his talents to America, where his TV show is doing well (audiences can't understand his accent, he explained, but "when they see the food and the colours they get really excited"). Footballer David Beckham won an award for his autobiography, My World - though this particular literary gong went to the book's stylish red-tinted cover. The Whitbread and Guardian First Book Award prizewinner Zadie Smith won the newcomer of the year award for her novel about life in multicultural London, White Teeth, while Terry Pratchett was honoured for services to bookselling - a sentiment with which no one could disagree. fields.headline: 'Very Prada, very Miu Miu' - restyle for Scout uniform thrills fashionistas
fields.standfirst: Special report: London Fashion Week 2001
fields.trailText: All was as expected yesterday, on the fifth morning of London fashion week. Or not. This was the Scout Association showing its new uniforms, the first for 34 years. Available this summer, they are eagerly awaited by 500,000 Scouts in the UK.
fields.body:
The fashion show was, of course, running a little late. The models milled around backstage, world-weary.

At last, music began to pump out and they strutted down the catwalk, unperturbed by the flashbulbs. All was as expected yesterday, on the fifth morning of London fashion week.

Or not. This was the Scout Association showing its new uniforms, the first for 34 years. Available this summer, they are eagerly awaited by 500,000 Scouts in the UK.

The association's timing mirrored its motto of being prepared. Not only was the show in the middle of London fashion week, but was staged at Baden Powell house in South Kensington, across from the West Lawn Tent, venue for most of the more conventional shows.

The main change is greater use of colour. Instead of the distinctive palette of khaki and dark green, there is emphasis on navy blue, bright green and even turquoise for the young Beaver Scouts.

Dark blue culottes, which can now be worn by all Scouts, flapped casually about the knee, while alternative navy trousers or a dapper pencil skirt were equally tempting. Jade shirts were elegantly blouson. A Sea Scout's blue sweatshirt showed a body-conscious cut, combined with comfort. All demonstrated practicality combined with style. In a belated nod to last season's logomania, the uniforms carry a new Scout emblem. The woggle has, thankfully, been retained.

Created by Meg Andrew, the ensembles received greater approbation than many other shows this week. "I think they're really cool. Very Prada, very Miu Miu," said Sarah Leon, head of New Faces at Select Model Agency, while watching her young but professional charges. "That military look is really big on the catwalks this season, and they keep their youth element." Beaver Scout Krishan Clark, seven, was more succinct: "This is new. So it's better."

fields.headline: Oversubscribed
fields.standfirst:
Julien Macdonald at the V&A
Special report: London Fashion Week 2001
fields.trailText: Julien Macdonald at the V&A
fields.body: Never say fashion isn't democratic. You may need to sacrifice your first-born to gain entry to some stores, you will be ejected from shows for wearing the wrong socks, but that is only part of the picture. For the past18 months,the V&A Museum (020-7942 2000) has put on a monthly event, Fashion in Motion, focusing on the life and frocks of a particular designer, and any old Tom, Dick and Harry can go. Today Julien Macdonald, Glamour award winner at this year's British Fashion Awards, is the star. There are shows at 1, 4 and 6.30, and after you've checked him out, you can catch up on a bit of culture. So not only is fashion democratic, it's educational, too.

fields.headline: Overexposed
fields.standfirst:
Messy hair
Special report: London Fashion Week 2001
fields.trailText: Messy hair
fields.body:
Fashion shows - you'd think they would be about style, glam, looking good, pretty girls. Well, yes, that may be true, but only in the audience, it seems. London's young and trendy designers may have finally realised that creating conceptual, deconstuctionist clothing may be all very well for your street cred but if the punters can't wear it, it ain't going to sell. So in order to maintain their cutting edge reps, this season many have resorted to more wearable clothing but messing up models' hair to within an inch of their follicles. Brilliant!

Preen, Maria Chen and Robert Cary-Williams decided a huge backcombed knot was the way forward. At Russell Sage, hair poked pathetically out of little hairnets bundled on top of the models' heads to create that desirable triple bun (bun fest?) look. John Rocha went for the greasy and unwashed look; Markus Lupfer, betraying his Teutonic roots (pun intended), greased back models' hair so they resembled German rock'n' roll fans, circa 1980. Worse was to come at Hamish Morrow, where the stylist seemed to have taken Gary Rhodes for inspiration.

C'mon, guys! Have more faith in your clothes! You don't need to ensure they look good by making your poor, hapless models look as hideous as possible.

webTitle: Glitter for exhibitionists and the more modest

fields.headline: Glitter for exhibitionists and the more modest
fields.trailText: In a city obsessed with making the different seem normal, the skin jewellery of J Maskrey, shown last night for London fashion week, was an undeniable success.
fields.body:
In a city obsessed with making the different seem normal, the skin jewellery of J Maskrey, shown last night for London fashion week, was an undeniable success.

Maskrey, whose stick-on pieces of short-lifespan jewellery have been copied by every high street chain, proved that there was more to her work than just elaborate transfers.

Previously, the designer has shown in lapdancing clubs, but this season her nearly naked models walked austerely around the catwalk to cheers from the audience, which included the singer Andrea Corr.

In place of tattoo-like images swirling around the body, Maskrey chose to explore the trompe l'oeil effect of clothing on the skin. The first "outfit" was a houndstooth sweater made from glistening Swarovski crystals, the jagged shapes that made up the pattern each individually applied to the body.

In case you are concerned about modesty, the look was shown with a one legged pair of trousers - not much more adaptable to everyday life, but stunning on the catwalk.

What makes Maskrey forgivable for this obvious problem - that few are going to wear the designs as shown - is the sheer quality of her work. The craftsmanship on display, both in the jewellery and in the few accompanying pieces of clothing, is almost unmatched on the London scene.

And although only true exhibitionists would think of wearing an outfit purely of skin stickers, come the autumn, when these designs go on sale, expect to see many celebrities with a single crystal flower stuck to their body accompanying their red carpet dress.

webTitle: Fluid modes that women might wear

fields.headline: Fluid modes that women might wear
fields.standfirst: Special report: London Fashion Week 2001
fields.trailText: In a season in which many feel that inexperienced designers have been promoted beyond their skills, it took the winner of this year's British Fashion Council's street style award to show how it should be done.
fields.body:
In a season in which many feel that inexperienced designers have been promoted beyond their skills, it took the winner of this year's British Fashion Council's street style award to show how it should be done.

The label, i.e.uniform, designed by Royal College of Art graduates Roger Lee and Lesley Sealey, showed a strong collection which featured clothes that women might want to wear, a rarity during concept-obsessed London Fashion Week.

i.e.uniform showed as part of Fashion East, a project set up to provide young designers with funding and support.

The i.e.uniform silhouette, of fluid knee-length skirts and scarf effect high-necks, was easy to translate into real life. The collection showed why the three year-old label is already stocked in 30 stores worldwide.

The other three designers showed competent, if less complete, presentations. Louis de Gama, a Portugese-born University of Westminster graduate, was seemingly inspired by Hussein Chalayan's architectural construction, with layers of assymetric, jagged hems circling around the bottom of black dresses.

Lizzy Disney, a Central St Martin's graduate, warped some 50s housewife clothes, with high-waisted bell skirts sexed up by black sweaters of wool contrasted with leather.

PPQ, designed by Percy Parker and Amy Molyneaux, expanded on their trouser range with off-shoulder chunky knits, military-inspired rope cummerbunds, mini-dresses and big buttoned cardigans.

 Charlie Porter discusses London fashion week online at 3pm today. Post your questions and comments now at Special report: London Fashion Week 2001.

fields.headline: Debussy: Jeux
fields.standfirst: In our series on building a classical library, Andrew Clements selects the definitive recording of Debussy's Jeux
fields.trailText: In our series on building a classical library, Andrew Clements selects the definitive recording of Debussy's Jeux
fields.body:
Debussy, Jeux

The poème danse that is arguably Debussy's supreme achievement, and certainly his greatest orchestral work, was written in the astonishingly short period of three weeks in August 1912, though the premiere, danced by Diaghilev's Ballets Russes, did not take place until the following May. Perhaps it was the very speed of composition that allowed Debussy's musical thoughts freer than usual rein, and gave an intuitive shape to the piece that came to closer than ever before to the ideal of free musical association to which so much of his mature music aspires.

Even an "impressionist" masterpiece such as La Mer has a strong symphonic framework to bolster its evocative imagery, but Jeux is sustained on a web of tenuously connected ideas in which one motif seems to spawn the next, so that nothing ever returns in identical fashion. The scenario to which it was originally danced seems almost irrelevant nowadays. "There is a park, a tennis court; there is a chance meeting of two girls and a young man seeking a lost ball; a nocturnal landscape, and a suggestion of something sinister in the darkening shadows" - that was how Debussy described it in a letter to the Paris newspaper Le Matin. But it was the fact that the score seem to score defy rigorous analysis that raised into a modernist icon for the post-Webern generation of serialists, who pored over the subtle interrelations of its themes and the ambiguity of its overall form, clothed in ever-changing orchestral colours.

Jeux has never been as popular in the concert hall and on disc as La Mer and Debussy's orchestral Images - partly, I suspect, because it sets orchestras and conductors such problems of balance, phrasing and continuity. Some of the recorded performances show the difficulties all too clearly - Yan Pascal Tortelier's version (Chandos) is not played precisely enough, while Jean Martinon's (EMI) is overblown and Charles Dutoit's (Decca) too matter-of-fact; even Simon Rattle and the City of Birmingham Symphony can't resist self-consciously drawing out some of the score's melodies in a piece where suggestion and understatement are everything.

The two conductors who get it right could hardly be more different. Bernard Haitink's old Philips performance with the Concertgebouw Orchestra is a marvel of precision and colour, and reissued in a mid-price two-disc survey of Debussy's orchestral music it is a marvellous bargain. But the more recent of Pierre Boulez's two versions, with the Cleveland Orchestra, is as near definitive as could be imagined in such an elusive work. All its details are perfectly realised, and Boulez weaves delicately coloured webs of connections between all the constituents.

· Key Recording: Boulez (Deutsche Grammophon)

fields.headline: Esquire editor blasts lads' mags
fields.trailText:
11am: Peter Howarth claims Hollywood agents no longer want to put their high-profile clients on men's magazine covers, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Feb 15: Esquire sheds downmarket readers
fields.body:
Esquire's editor, Peter Howarth, has claimed the lads' mag explosion has damaged the credibility of men's titles among the all-powerful Hollywood showbusiness agents.

Mr Howarth claimed "by the end of 1999, Hollywood agents loathed and detested men's magazines and would not put forward their stars for covers".

His remarks follow a 40% circulation drop for Esquire in the last ABCs.

This has been blamed largely on the decision to move away from using semi-naked women on the cover.

Mr Howarth told MediaGuardian.co.uk: "If the perception among agents is men's magazines are just about showing women in a state of undress, they won't put forward their highest-profile female stars."

And he argued men's magazines feature much lower-profile celebrities now than they did before the lad's mags took off in 1994.

Many will regard Mr Howarth's comments as sour grapes - his magazine's circulation took the heaviest battering in the beleaguered men's sector.

But he claimed he is pleased Esquire has shed its downmarket readers.

Mr Howard said it was time for the rest of the industry to stop scrapping over the "general purchasing slurry" and stake out their magazines' own identities.

fields.headline: Reds relief as Roma rage
fields.standfirst:
Liverpool reach last eight after penalty about-turn
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Despite being comprehensively outplayed and amid chaotic scenes at Anfield, Liverpool earned a quarter-final against Porto last night after the referee seemed first to award the Italians a penalty lifeline for handball, then to think better of it.
fields.body:
Liverpool warmed up for Sunday's Worthington Cup final by completing the stormiest of passages into the Uefa Cup quarter-finals, hanging on to beat Roma in a concluding quarter-hour that threatened to turn ugly after the Spanish referee seemed first to award the Italians a penalty lifeline for handball, then to think better of it a few moments later.

Four yellow cards were brandished in a matter of seconds as the furious Roma team engulfed Jose Maria Garcia-Aranda after he indicated that the award was, in fact, a corner kick. Roma tempers quickly frayed and one of those cautioned, Damiano Tommasi, was sent off five minutes later for a lunge at Robbie Fowler.

The Italians league leaders' coach Fabio Capello was still angry after Roma's increasingly frantic efforts had ultimately fallen short. "Of course it was a penalty. The referee pointed to the penalty spot twice. But Gabriel Batistuta hadn't seen the decision and ran to the corner flag to take what he thought was a corner.

"But because of that it looked like the referee changed his mind. But you can't just change your mind like that."

Capello's dismay over the imbroglio was understandable as his team had only minutes earlier scored to make it 2-1, the substitute Gianni Guigou throwing the tie back into the melting pot with a marvellous long-range strike.

For the home manager Gérard Houllier there was the satisfaction of winning despite being comprehensively outplayed, almost from first whistle to last. Without style or panache Liverpool earned a quarter-final against Porto, who went through 4-3 on aggregate despite losing 2-1 in Nantes last night.

On the plus side Houllier saw his team hold their nerve and keep their discipline in the face of some appalling intimidation. "Of course I am delighted to be through but they are a great side and we were a little lucky," said the manager. "To defeat the current leaders of the Italian league is a marvellous achievement and I am very, very proud of my players."

Roma left with their pride restored but with many regrets, the most obvious being the curious events which unfolded in the 78th minute, eight minutes after Guigou's strike. That goal was no more than the Italians deserved and it all but shattered Liverpool's composure.

As Roma rolled forwards like a sea mist and Liverpool pulled everyone back behind the ball, Vincenzo Montella crossed from the left and the ball struck the full-back Markus Babbel on the elbow.

Garcia-Aranda seemed to give the penalty and Babbel held his head in his hands as the Roma players congratulated Montella and the Kop groaned its disapproval. Then, to general astonishment and Liverpool's relief, the referee indicated his actions had been misinterpreted.

Houllier is shrewd enough to take the lessons of last night on board at once. A man who preaches ultra-professionalism, he will have spent the hours leading up to kick-off reminding his team that the twin enemies of arrogance and complacency are at their most dangerous when the outcome of a contest would appear to have been already shaped.

By winning the first leg 2-0 in Rome last week Liverpool convinced many that this second meeting was something of an irrelevance. How wrong they were. There was a good deal more steel to Roma this time. The iron fist was withdrawn from the velvet glove and used at regular intervals.

For most of the first half Liverpool's back four were mean and efficient, coaxing the Roma strikers forwards before springing the offside trap. But as the Italians' dominance became more pronounced their industry in midfield began to produce chances. Marco Delvecchio steered hopelessly wide on 20 minutes after Liverpool's backline had been undone by Hidetoshi Nakata's splendid pass.

Despite being surrounded by home comforts and many friends, Liverpool were ill at ease and they had to wait until eight minutes before the interval for the glimmer of an opening. Then two arrived in quick succession.

After the Roma goalkeeper Francesco Antonioli had thrown himself down marvellously to halt a Christian Ziege free-kick, Michael Owen found space inside the area only to screw his drive wide.

Owen had the chance to kill the game and the tie on the hour but he passed it up, Antonioli saving his poorly struck penalty, contentiously awarded after Emile Heskey had tangled with Jonathan Zebina.

In the end it did not matter but Liverpool will look back on last night with only relief.

 There will be no Italian Uefa Cup quarter-finalists for the second year in a row after all three Serie A clubs went out last night. The English referee Graham Barber called time early at San Siro due to crowd trouble when Alaves, in their first season in Europe, led Inter 2-0 and 5-3 on aggregate. Three other Spanish clubs went through, Barcelona beating AEK Athens 6-0 on aggregate helped by a Luis Enrique hat-trick.

Liverpool (4-4-2): Westerveld; Babbel, Hyypia, Henchoz, Carragher; Barmby (Fowler, 82min), McAllister, Hamann, Ziege; Owen (Smicer, 68), Heskey.

Roma (3-4-1-2): Antonioli: Samuel, Rinaldi (Guigou, 59), Zago; Zebina, Tommasi, Assuncao, Candela; Nakata; Delvecchio (Batistuta, 59), Montella (Balbo, 82).

Referee : J Garcia-Aranda (Spain).

Ties to be played March 8 and 15

fields.bodyText: Liverpool warmed up for Sunday's Worthington Cup final by completing the stormiest of passages into the Uefa Cup quarter-finals, hanging on to beat Roma in a concluding quarter-hour that threatened to turn ugly after the Spanish referee seemed first to award the Italians a penalty lifeline for handball, then to think better of it a few moments later. Four yellow cards were brandished in a matter of seconds as the furious Roma team engulfed Jose Maria Garcia-Aranda after he indicated that the award was, in fact, a corner kick. Roma tempers quickly frayed and one of those cautioned, Damiano Tommasi, was sent off five minutes later for a lunge at Robbie Fowler. The Italians league leaders' coach Fabio Capello was still angry after Roma's increasingly frantic efforts had ultimately fallen short. "Of course it was a penalty. The referee pointed to the penalty spot twice. But Gabriel Batistuta hadn't seen the decision and ran to the corner flag to take what he thought was a corner. "But because of that it looked like the referee changed his mind. But you can't just change your mind like that." Capello's dismay over the imbroglio was understandable as his team had only minutes earlier scored to make it 2-1, the substitute Gianni Guigou throwing the tie back into the melting pot with a marvellous long-range strike. For the home manager Gérard Houllier there was the satisfaction of winning despite being comprehensively outplayed, almost from first whistle to last. Without style or panache Liverpool earned a quarter-final against Porto, who went through 4-3 on aggregate despite losing 2-1 in Nantes last night. On the plus side Houllier saw his team hold their nerve and keep their discipline in the face of some appalling intimidation. "Of course I am delighted to be through but they are a great side and we were a little lucky," said the manager. "To defeat the current leaders of the Italian league is a marvellous achievement and I am very, very proud of my players." Roma left with their pride restored but with many regrets, the most obvious being the curious events which unfolded in the 78th minute, eight minutes after Guigou's strike. That goal was no more than the Italians deserved and it all but shattered Liverpool's composure. As Roma rolled forwards like a sea mist and Liverpool pulled everyone back behind the ball, Vincenzo Montella crossed from the left and the ball struck the full-back Markus Babbel on the elbow. Garcia-Aranda seemed to give the penalty and Babbel held his head in his hands as the Roma players congratulated Montella and the Kop groaned its disapproval. Then, to general astonishment and Liverpool's relief, the referee indicated his actions had been misinterpreted. Houllier is shrewd enough to take the lessons of last night on board at once. A man who preaches ultra-professionalism, he will have spent the hours leading up to kick-off reminding his team that the twin enemies of arrogance and complacency are at their most dangerous when the outcome of a contest would appear to have been already shaped. By winning the first leg 2-0 in Rome last week Liverpool convinced many that this second meeting was something of an irrelevance. How wrong they were. There was a good deal more steel to Roma this time. The iron fist was withdrawn from the velvet glove and used at regular intervals. For most of the first half Liverpool's back four were mean and efficient, coaxing the Roma strikers forwards before springing the offside trap. But as the Italians' dominance became more pronounced their industry in midfield began to produce chances. Marco Delvecchio steered hopelessly wide on 20 minutes after Liverpool's backline had been undone by Hidetoshi Nakata's splendid pass. Despite being surrounded by home comforts and many friends, Liverpool were ill at ease and they had to wait until eight minutes before the interval for the glimmer of an opening. Then two arrived in quick succession. After the Roma goalkeeper Francesco Antonioli had thrown himself down marvellously to halt a Christian Ziege free-kick, Michael Owen found space inside the area only to screw his drive wide. Owen had the chance to kill the game and the tie on the hour but he passed it up, Antonioli saving his poorly struck penalty, contentiously awarded after Emile Heskey had tangled with Jonathan Zebina. In the end it did not matter but Liverpool will look back on last night with only relief.  There will be no Italian Uefa Cup quarter-finalists for the second year in a row after all three Serie A clubs went out last night. The English referee Graham Barber called time early at San Siro due to crowd trouble when Alaves, in their first season in Europe, led Inter 2-0 and 5-3 on aggregate. Three other Spanish clubs went through, Barcelona beating AEK Athens 6-0 on aggregate helped by a Luis Enrique hat-trick. webTitle: Birth centres could solve the midwifery crisis

fields.headline: Birth centres could solve the midwifery crisis
fields.standfirst: A worldwide shortage of midwives is putting women at risk. Jane Sandall believes birth centres could be the answer
fields.trailText: At an international meeting on maternity care, two key issues were seen to be affecting midwives, mothers and babies. The first was the rising rate of unnecessary interventions during childbirth, the other was difficulties in the recruitment and retention of midwives, writes Jane Sandall
fields.body:
Around the globe, midwifery is in crisis. At a recent international meeting on maternity care, two key issues were seen to be affecting midwives, mothers and babies across the globe. The first was the rising rate of unnecessary interventions during childbirth, especially caesarean section, the other was difficulties in the recruitment and retention of midwives.

In this country, the government recently launched a new working group on maternity care made up of representatives of health authorities and the royal colleges of midwives, paediatricians, and obstetricians. The aim is to tackle the ongoing crisis in maternity services. Leaked details of a previous royal colleges joint report, which has remained unpublished, highlighted the need to rethink the delivery of maternity services, due to changes in neonatal care provision, obstetric training and staffing and shortages of midwives. Unless the new group addresses these issues, the result will be less accessible services and fewer choices for parents to be.

The number of practising midwives continues to fall in the UK. According to the latest audit of services by the English National Board (ENB), more than 30% of maternity units were unable to provide women with one-to-one midwife care in labour in 1999. There is an important link between a lack of continuous midwifery support during childbirth and the rising incidence of medical intervention, including caesarean section during childbirth. When women have continuous support during labour and birth, there is a reduction in their need for pain relief, fewer operative vaginal and caesarean deliveries and, the baby is more likely to be born in a better condition.

Currently women don't get all the midwifery support they need in childbirth and suffer unnecessary interventions. The latest figures from the ENB show that in 1999, 41% of NHS maternity services had a caesarean section rate of more than 20%, compared with 25% of units in 1998. Maternal mortality, even for non-emergency operations is nearly three times higher than for vaginal birth. A caesarean section, particularly a second one, increases risks of haemorrhage and emergency hysterectomy.

So why do we have midwife shortages? Around two-thirds of midwives are mothers themselves, and more than half of midwives in the UK now work part-time. Midwifery is one of the most "unfriendly" occupations for those with family responsibilities, as midwives need to be available 24 hours a day to attend women during childbirth.

Around the globe, midwives report that their employers are resistant to family friendly working. This old-fashioned view is one of the midwife as a dedicated professional, it regards those who work less than full-time as "not committed to the job", sees discussion of family responsibilities as "unprofessional", and efforts to accommodate flexible working as a sign of managerial weakness. The government has stated these opinions are no longer tenable in the NHS, but how long will it take to change on the ground?

Midwives around the world have traditionally seen themselves as "guardians of the normal" and we know that where midwifery is autonomous evidence shows that outcomes for low-risk women and their babies are excellent. If the trend of mergers of maternity units continues, one solution promises to contribute to solving both the rising intervention rates and the midwifery staffing crisis.

Midwife-led birth centres provide care for low-risk women, are locally accessible, provide continuity of care, humanised care and have had good outcomes for women and babies. Community-based midwifery group practices link into birth centres and GPs, and offer a range of services to women, from offering birth at home or in a birth centre to providing integrated care to women with complex problems. Birth centres are supported by tertiary referral centres that are fully equipped with specialist midwifery, obstetric and neonatal services to care for women with complex problems in pregnancy and birth.

In addition, most birth centres have waiting lists of midwives who want to work in them. They offer the possibility of autonomous midwifery practice and provide excellent training opportunities for students. Birth centres provide appropriate care for women living in inner cities and for women living in remote areas of the UK, and they can provide a focus in the community for other activities such as health advocacy and welfare rights projects. We need more research, but with good screening criteria, birth centres can deliver safe, effective humane care and help to solve the recruitment and retention crisis in midwifery.

 Jane Sandall is professor of midwifery and women's health at King's College, London.

fields.headline: Desmond at loggerheads with Telegraph
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The row over the Westferry printing plant has escalated with Richard Desmond refusing to pay a £4m bill, writes Dan Milmo.
Feb 6: Stalemate over Westferry price
fields.body:
The multi-million pound squabble over a printing plant shared by the Express and the Telegraph escalated today with the tabloid's new owner Richard Desmond refusing to pay a £4m bill.

Mr Desmond, who is co-owner of the Westferry Plant, has told Telegraph owner Hollinger he will not settle the printing charges until he gets £11m from his partners.

He claims the money is the dividend owed to his Northern & Shell company for his 50% stake in the plant.

But insiders at Hollinger are privately seething at the behaviour of Northern & Shell executives, with one claiming "those guys must be smoking something".

Today's development marks a new low-point in relations between both parties, who fell out earlier this year when Hollinger agreed to buy the stake.

Hollinger has balked at the £80m price demanded by the OK! publisher's advisers, and the opposing camps are poles apart in terms of valuation.

"The Westferry company owes the Express an £11m dividend, so the Express has stopped making printing payments.

"Hollinger's refusal to pay out is part and parcel of the brinkmanship behind this process," said a source close to Northern & Shell.

The source added the proposed fee for the Westferry stake had been calculated through a complex formula designed by Hollinger owner Conrad Black, and had been approved by three independent parties.

The dispute was sparked when Mr Desmond inherited the stake in the plant through the £125m acquisition of the Express group from Lord Hollick's United Business Media group in November last year.

Dan Colson, vice-chairman of Hollinger, today scorned Northern & Shell's demands for a dividend.

He said the money could only be paid out if Mr Desmond supplied a budget for his contribution to the plant.

"We have no objection in principle to the idea of a dividend because half of it comes to us," he said.

"But we have a problem with paying a dividend where proper budgets have not been agreed between the shareholders.

"The dividend needs to take into account the ongoing capital expenditure and working capital requirements of the business," he added.

The dispute over the Westferry stake is heading for the courtroom as both sides have yet to agree on an arbitrator.

If no arbitrator can be found over the next nine days, the matter will go to court, where a judge will appoint an independent negotiator to settle the price for the stake.

"Northern & Shell is a thorn in the side to Hollinger, because it does things in a different way.

"They will kick you in the nuts if they feel they are being kicked in the nuts," said one source close to the dispute.

Westferry is a lucrative property that prints the southern editions of the Financial Times, the Guardian, the Daily Telegraph, and the Express newspapers.

Mr Desmond has decided to sell his 50% holding after taking out a £97m loan to fund the Express acquisition.

fields.headline: VNUNet.com cuts staff in restructure
fields.trailText: 8.30am: IT news site VNUNet.com is to undergo a major overhaul with the loss of 10 jobs, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
VNUNet.com, the IT news website from publisher VNU, is to undergo a major overhaul with the loss of 10 jobs.

VNUNet CEO Jonathan Ross explained the move as a way of being "cleverer" in the increasingly competitive IT sector.

"We need to get all the magazines much more involved in the website and to encourage the editorial teams to have more influence, while building up the respective magazine sites," said Mr Ross.

As a result of the integration plan, six journalists and four support staff on the portal VNUNet.com have lost their jobs "because of overlaps", explained Mr Ross.

He said the website would still have 20 staff.

Ten of these are journalists who focus on breaking news.

The changes to the site will take place over the next few months.

They will include the introduction of seven categories, such as e-commerce, business strategy and games and entertainment.

Magazine journalists will also be encouraged to start breaking stories on the website rather than storing them up for the weekly print publications.

The rejig has been linked to an announcement about developing cross-media solutions to enable clients to target audiences across the print, internet, PDA, WAP, CD and email media.

webTitle: Pacino suffers Insomnia for Memento director

fields.headline: Pacino suffers Insomnia for Memento director
fields.trailText: Al Pacino is to star in a remake of Insomnia, a Norwegian thriller about a man who is blackmailed after he commits a murder, which will be directed by Christopher Nolan
fields.body:
Al Pacino has signed up to star in Insomnia, a remake of a 1997 Norwegian film to be made by Christopher Nolan, director of Memento.

According to Variety, Pacino, whose partner Beverly D'Angelo recently gave birth to twins, was courted for weeks before he agreed to play a detective who, after accidentally killing his partner during a murder investigation in an Alaskan town, is then blackmailed by the killer into pinning the murder on an innocent person.

"Any time you get a chance to work with Pacino, you jump at it, but this is particularly exciting because he's who we had in mind almost since we got the remake rights three years ago," producer Paul Witt told Variety.

Insomnia is set to start production on April 9 - before any possible strikes - in and around Vancouver.

 More on Al Pacino.

fields.body:

The London Stock Exchange has no plans to tighten the regulation for non-financial metrics for listed companies, despite this week's E-District scandal.

Ipoints has become the first UK online rewards scheme to offer consumers a credit card so they can acquire loyalty points in high street stores.

Lawyers have dismissed the much-hyped copyright directive amendments passed last week by the European Parliament as "tinkering".

fields.headline: Putin pulls White House perks
fields.standfirst: The latest glitch in Moscow-Washington relations sees Russian MPs refusing US sponsorship for political tourism, reports Ian Traynor
fields.trailText: The latest glitch in Moscow-Washington relations sees Russian MPs refusing US sponsorship for political tourism, reports Ian Traynor
fields.body:
Russian MPs are apparently to forgo one of the more pleasurable perks of their position, all in the interests of the souring relationship between Washington and Moscow.

Dmitri Rogozin, the influential head of the Duma's foreign affairs committee, has just announced that his parliamentary colleagues are to put a stop to "political tourism" funded by the Americans. The Duma will henceforth pay for its members' trips to the US.

White House or Congressional sponsorship offers will be refused. Russian feelings are hurt by US magnanimity, it seems, though it is not clear why. But in the Moscow-Washington double act these days, the Russians are very quick to take offence, while the Americans appear to be issuing insults gratuitously and with gusto.

The other week in Munich when Donald Rumsfeld, the Pentagon chief, made his European debut at a security conference, he deliberately forgot to mention Russia even once in his speech.

To rub salt into the wound, he then went back to America without finding the time to see Sergei Ivanov, President Vladimir Putin's top aide, who then made a speech to the conference which bristled with resentment of the west.

"It was Rumsfeld's way of sending a signal, part of the psychological attack," said Sergei Rogov, director of the Moscow think tank, the US-Canada Institute. "He sees Russia as a less important issue, so he met the Nato ministers and ignored Ivanov."

Such calculated snubs rankle the Russians. The erstwhile superpower is used to a seat at the top table, demands to be accepted as an equal in international relations, just can't accept the reduced status that goes with having a gross domestic product smaller than Belgium's.

Madeleine Albright last year called America the world's indispensable power. This week one of her colleagues in the Clinton administration called Russia "a jealous and crumpled superpower".

On an entire raft of issues from Nato expansion to national missile shields, from Iran and Iraq to the Balkans or the oil fields of central Asia, from media freedoms to freedom of religion, the US and Russia are at odds. The early noises from the new Republican administration are worrying and angering the Russians.

In recent weeks, the US defence secretary, national security adviser and CIA chief have all described Mr Putin's Russia as a "problem" and a "threat to the west". While the US this week arrested an alleged Russian mole inside the FBI, on Monday the Russians are to try a young academic accused of spying for American military intelligence.

Amid all these neo-cold war jitters, the most telling shift in perception and the point that upsets the Russians most may be that the Bush administration is downgrading Russia as a foreign policy priority and relegating it to second rate status.

The Russian military analyst, Alexander Golts, noted recently that Russia's top generals and politicians thrive on confrontation and argument and enjoy being seen as peers and rivals. It is more humiliating by far for them to be treated as has-beens, ignored as representatives of a once great power now in steep decline.

The Russian army top brass appear to be relishing the row with the Americans over ''Son of Star Wars'', the US national missile defence project, because it takes them back to their cold war heyday when they called the shots and were taken seriously.

It's hardly surprising, says a west European ambassador in Moscow, that the Russians are having such troubles adjusting to the straitened circumstances of imperial retreat and loss of great power status.

The jury is still out, he says, on whether the elites of Britain or France have fully adapted to their more limited post-imperial identities decades after they lost their colonies. Russia's struggle to come to terms with the loss of empire will, if anything, be longer and harder.

On the missile shield row, this helps explain Russia's determination to cling to the terms of the 1972 anti-ballistic missiles treaty, the bedrock of modern arms control, as well as the new US administration's apparent resolve to ditch it.

The ABM treaty gave and still gives the Russians a certain parity with the US, allowing the Russians these days to punch above their weight.

fields.headline: An everyday story of countryfolk
fields.standfirst: With farmers 'facing the abyss', what's in the stars for the Archers?
fields.trailText: February 23: Maggie Hyde asks what's in the stars for the longest running radio serial in the world.
fields.body:
The Archers, "an everyday story of countryfolk", is the longest running radio serial in the world.

Its origins go back to a farmer's brainwave at a meeting of broadcasters, farmers and Ministry of Agriculture officials on January 3 1948.

This was the day of an uncommon planetary configuration - Uranus opposite to horsey Jupiter in fiery Sagittarius, the sign of the Archer.

Why Uranus? This is the hi-tech planet of innovation and, as part of its public service brief, the BBC was expected to coax farmers to submit to modern methods in the dark days of post-war rationing.

So in the opening episodes, Dan Archer retires his two shire horses, Blossom and Boxer, to make way for the tractor.

The horoscope for the first broadcast (11am, January 1 1951) lacks fiery passion and high drama and is stacked with practical, earthy Capricorn, with innovative Uranus prominent again.

Capricorn is a conventional, conservative sign - famous for longevity and improving with age - and astrologers reckon the Goat gets younger and hornier as it gets older.

In addition to strong earth, the Archers also has a principled Mars in Aquarius and a Libra Moon. These air signs love people, putting an emphasis on social values and being part of a community.

Vanessa Whitburn has been producer since 1991 and she is a lively Sagittarian Archer herself. She connects with the programme's Libran Moon through her serious Saturn and tough-minded Mars, giving it a hard edge of authenticity when it comes to the realistic worries of country people.

Libra often has a problem with balance, however, and Whitburn admits she has sometimes failed to get this right in the past.

Her feminism has led to a long-running spat with a former producer, William Smethurst, headlined in the Telegraph (9/9/96) as an "everyday story of Leftist tripe".

Similar questions of political correctness have now resurfaced with Lucas Madakane, a new character from South Africa, and the big, unanswered question, "Is he black?".

The listener is never quite sure because nothing is stated explicitly, but how real would this non-comment be in a real-life Ambridge?

Mark Lawson (16/2/01 Guardian) believes "Ambridge's racism, like its defecation, may be occurring out of earshot" and that the programme gets its messages across with subtle, rather than blatant references - "The Archers is playing a complicated and fascinating game with our attitudes to race".

On the other hand, Daily Telegraph readers may switch off in droves. As always, getting the right balance is never easy for a Libran Moon.

Vanessa Whitburn's horoscope shows controversy this autumn and she may decide to come out fighting and push social realism even further. The programme could also be in the media spotlight and have a celebrity profile in the latter half of 2002.

So are we heading for another 50 years of life in Ambridge? The Archers has such a dignified horoscope, there is no obvious sign of it running out of steam - ever. Da di-dum di-dum di-dum...

fields.headline: LG electronics clinches snooker deal
fields.trailText: 9.45am: World Snooker has signed LG Electronics as the £1m sponsor of the Grand Prix tournament, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
World Snooker has signed LG Electronics as the £1m sponsor of the Grand Prix tournament, which is to be renamed the LG Cup.

It is the second major sponsorship deal within a week for LG Electronics, formerly known as Lucky Goldstar.

Last week it shelled out £2.5m to have its name emblazoned across the shirts of Leicester City Football Club, replacing the Walkers Crisps logo.

LG Electronics also sponsors football's reigning world champions France, the Australian national team, top Romanian club side Dynamo Bucharest and yachting's BT Global Challenge.

BBC Sport will cover the LG Cup at Preston's Guild Hall exclusively from September 1 to 9.

The Korean-based company's sponsorship will run for three years.

World Snooker believes the involvement of LG Electronics will enable the sport to attract interest from more blue-chip companies.

"We promised members a new sponsor and we have delivered," said Mark Wildman, chairman of World Snooker.

"The fact such a prestigious company has decided to get involved at the top of the game is a real boost for the sport and I am sure that both parties will reap the benefits," he added.

Barry Willmore, LG Electronics UK managing director, said: "We are certain the creation of the LG Cup, and the high profile we expect the tournament to achieve, will help us reach a large global audience in addition to the terrestrial TV viewers watching this prestigious event on the BBC."

webTitle: Political fallout threatens Turkey's chances of joining EU

fields.headline: Political fallout over reform threatens to bury chances of joining EU
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the IMF and World Bank in Prague
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Ahmet Necdet Sezer has enjoyed a burgeoning popularity since becoming president of Turkey last May. The former chief of the constitutional court has championed the need to bolster democracy, tackle corruption and meet EU standards of governance. The simple fact that his motorcade stops at red traffic lights has deeply impressed Ankara residents.
fields.body:
Ahmet Necdet Sezer has enjoyed a burgeoning popularity since becoming president of Turkey last May. The former chief of the constitutional court has championed the need to bolster democracy, tackle corruption and meet EU standards of governance. The simple fact that his motorcade stops at red traffic lights has deeply impressed Ankara residents.

Whether his popularity can be sustained amid the political and economic turmoil arising from his public clash with the prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, is open to question. The two men share responsibility for the crisis that has engulfed Turkey since they fell out last Monday at a stormy meeting of the national security council, which groups the country's separate and often competing political and military leaderships.

Mr Sezer's accusation that Mr Ecevit was dragging his feet over several ongoing public sector corruption inquiries touched on the more fundamental question facing Turkey's 66m people. It is whether those who hold power have the ability and the will to deliver the sweeping political, social and economic reforms required if Turkey is to become a modern and prosperous democratic European state.

The president's criticism of Mr Ecevit may have been a trifle harsh. The prime minister has committed himself to fighting sleaze. But he is aware that the inquiries have the potential to compromise or destroy his delicately balanced, three-party coalition, some members of which have been tainted by the scandals. With such a collapse could go his IMF-backed efforts since 1999 to reduce inflation, cut the budget deficit and pursue deregulation and privatisation programmes.

Mr Ecevit has not so much been blocking these investigations as trying to find ways of living with them. All the same, the bigger questions of reform reach far beyond tawdry kickbacks and bribes. The choice for Turkey is stark and for Europe, too, the stakes are high.

On one hand, there is the prospect, agreed at the 1999 Helsinki summit, of full Turkish membership of the EU within a decade. Linked to that aspiration are hopes that the long dispute over Cyprus, which Turkey invaded in 1974, can be settled; that Aegean territorial disputes with Greece can be defused; that Turkey's dismal human rights record will be improved; that legal recognition of the cultural and linguistic rights of Kurds and Armenians can be achieved; and that Turkey's secular tradition can find peaceful accommodation with a more assertive Islamism.

On this uncertain prospect of reform rests the overall aim of Turkey becoming an integrated member of the EU, a solid western ally and a bridge to central Asia and the Middle East. Uniquely, for example, Turkey currently pursues unofficial commercial cooperation with Iraq and military cooperation with Israel, while hosting US planes enforcing the Kurdish no-fly zone at the same time.

The likely scenario if reform fails, on the other hand, is dismaying. If Mr Sezer and Mr Ecevit cannot sort out their differences and the economic crisis turns overtly political, one or both may be forced to resign and the coalition government may fall. That could presage worsening chaos and the army could step in.

The Turkish military has overthrown civilian governments three times since 1960 in the name of law and order and of safeguarding the state.

As recently as 1997, the military quietly squeezed out the Islamist-led administration of Necmettin Erbakan. Last month, the chief of the general staff warned that it was ready to act again against "political Islam".

Any move by the generals to take overt control would result in an immediate freezing of negotiations with the EU and cast a pall over the Cyprus talks. Recession and turmoil in Turkey could also bring big, new immigration headaches for the EU.

The collapse of Mr Ecevit's government would also ring alarm bells in Washington, which views Turkey as a key Nato ally facing Russia and as a bulwark of pro-western influence in opposition to Iran, Syria and Iraq. For these reasons alone, should the economic crisis grow more severe, the Bush administration may be forced to overcome its dislike of financial bailouts and push the IMF into providing expanded assistance.

But the biggest victims of any extended crisis would be the Turkish people, let down once again by the political, business and military elite's inability to reform, and frustrated in their ambition to join the ranks of modern European nation states.

webTitle: Fund to beat third world disease

fields.headline: Fund to beat third world disease
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown and Clare Short will announce plans on Monday for a multibillion-pound international fund to provide cheap vaccines against childhood diseases to developing countries.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown and Clare Short will announce plans on Monday for a multibillion-pound international fund to provide cheap vaccines against childhood diseases to developing countries.

The chancellor and international development secretary will use a London conference on children to unveil proposals for the fund, aimed at reducing the 10m deaths each year of children under five.

The plan is for the world's richest countries, the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the UN Children's Fund (Unicef) to guarantee a market for drugs produced by the pharmaceutical industry, and subsidise research costs.

It is intended to make up lost ground in meeting the aim of reducing world poverty by 2015, set at the UN social summit in Copenhagen in 1995.

Mr Brown said in an interview with the Guardian: "The loss of life is unacceptable ... there is a recognition now that unless we act together and are clear about who takes responsibility, the targets we have set will take longer to meet and in some cases may not be met at all. We are determined to move further and faster towards meeting the UN targets."

Two weeks ago the Guardian highlighted the problem faced by developing countries which cannot pay the huge bill for drugs needed to fight Aids and other epidemics.

Mr Brown believes it is time the G7 most industrialised countries used their influence as the dominant members of the IMF and World Bank to focus their attention on the 2015 targets: to cut infant mortality by two-thirds, put every child in primary school and reduce the number of people living below the breadline by half.

Oxfam says child mortality is falling at less than half the rate required to meet the first target: if present trends continue there will be 8.5m child deaths in 2015.

The education target is even more in danger unless the G7 takes the initiative next week, and this too will be raised at Monday's conference.

The conference, attended by the heads of the World Bank and IMF and addressed by video link by Nelson Mandela and the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, will be the first of a series of international meetings highlighting concern for children.

fields.headline: Using a charity's name - the law
fields.trailText: Part II of the Charities Act 1992 includes requirements for:
fields.body:
Part II of the Charities Act 1992 includes requirements for:

 A written agreement, in a prescribed form, between the charity and the professional fundraiser or commercial participator;
 A statement to be given to inform potential donors what proportion of their donation will be used to pay the costs of the fundraiser;
 The public to be informed how the charity will benefit from its involvement with a commercial participator; and
 The transfer of funds raised by professional fundraisers or commercial participators to the charity.

webTitle: Concern at Jackson's plan to set up UK charity

fields.headline: Concern at Jackson's plan to set up UK charity
fields.trailText: UK children's charities are wary about singer Michael Jackson launching a charity in Britain to help at-risk children.
fields.body:
UK children's charities are wary about singer Michael Jackson launching a charity in Britain to help at-risk children. Karen Irving, chief executive of adoption charity Parents for Children, said: "There have been allegations about his relationship with a child and I don't know why he is setting up a charity over here."

In 1993 the parents of a 13-year-old boy accused Mr Jackson of sexually abusing their son. The family withdrew their accusation after reaching an out of court settlement with the singer.

Other children's charities refused to comment on record, saying they would wait to see what he intended to do with the charity.

Ms Irving added: "There are a large amount of children's charities over here and I think it would be better to set up a charitable trust to fund other charities already working in the field."

Mr Jackson hopes the charity will act as an ambassador to raise awareness of initiatives for children. The website names Save the Children's Foster Grandparent Program as one example of a possible partnership.

A spokesperson for Save the Children said there had been no discussion with the charity about working together in the UK.

Mr Jackson is setting up the charity as an off-shoot of his Heal the World Foundation which he established in 1992.

The foundation's website reports no achievements since 1997 apart from launching Heal the Kids in the US. It boasts of sending a youth ambassador to conferences in Mexico and Washington in 1996, and in 1994 it shipped two pallets of toys to children in Bosnia.

webTitle: Tories look to abolish council housing

fields.headline: Tories look to abolish council housing
fields.trailText: A Tory government would slash Labour's spending plans on housing within three years of coming to power, the shadow environment secretary, Archie Norman, has promised.
fields.body:
A Tory government would slash Labour's spending plans on housing within three years of coming to power, the shadow environment secretary, Archie Norman, has promised.

A large proportion of the savings would come from the Tories' commitment to bring about the virtual abolition of council housing within their first term in office.

Council ownership of homes was "not acceptable" in the long term, said Mr Norman, in an interview with homelessness charity Shelter's magazine Roof.

The Tories said in February that they would more than match Labour's total planned spending on affordable housing, although it is clear that they expect private funding will account for the lion's share of this figure.

Mr Norman gave no precise details of what proportion of the £1bn which the Tories aim to save from the budget of the Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions would come from housing.

But he made clear that the government's planned £1.8bn increase in housing expenditure between 2001-02 and 2003-04 would be cut.

He said: "There are no immediate plans in year one to change the balance of that expenditure. But by year three, I'd be very disappointed if that balance wasn't changed and by year five I hope that we would have reduced the dependence on state expenditure for the housing sector significantly, because if we hadn't, we wouldn't be succeeding."

Within five years of a Tory election victory, every council would have to have developed detailed plans for the disposal of all of their housing stock, apart from a small proportion required for special needs, such as sheltering refugees, said Mr Norman.

He said: "It is not acceptable that there is a long-term role for council ownership of housing. "It ties up a huge amount of capital and maintenance and the cost of managing council housing is greater than it should be. It's very inefficient and the result for tenants is very poor."

Most of the homes would be transferred to the housing association sector, which would be "revitalised" by moves to ensure that the best associations expand the most, said Mr Norman.

He played down the issue of social housing for ex-offenders, which sparked controversy last year when the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, announced plans for former prisoners to be given priority in allocation of homes.

Mr Norman said: "I don't think we regard it as being the biggest issue. It is important that people in communities who have worked hard and are saving hard and trying to get ahead in life don't feel their position on the housing list is being jumped by somebody who has just come out of prison.

"But it's not as simple as saying they go to the back of the queue, because it's equally important socially that we do try and enable prisoners to find somewhere to live when they come out."

Conservative insiders said later that the 400,000 council houses transferred to the voluntary and private sectors in the past 10 years had generated an additional £11.5bn of private investment. If the remaining 3.3m council houses were to receive similar levels of private investment, this would generate an additional £100bn of investment in Britain's housing stock, they said.

A programme of savings released by the Tories last month set out their argument that divesting the state of responsibility for municipal housing would save £300m from Labour's projected spending.

fields.headline: Napster stymied by Sony venture
fields.standfirst:
More net news
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Sony and Universal Music are developing a shared website to compete against Napster, reports John Cassy.
fields.body:
Napster's plans to transform itself from a renegade song swapping service into a paid-up member of the music industry establishment received a setback yesterday when two of the world's biggest companies in the sector said they would develop a shared website to compete against it.

Vivendi Universal-owned Universal Music and Japan's Sony underlined their determination not to cede ground or revenues to Napster by giving first details of plans to use a joint venture named Duet to buy up licensing rights to half the world's music.

"We often thought an alliance with Napster would be the only possibility but I don't believe it is right to give the advantage to pirates," said Vivendi Universal chairman Jean-Marie Messier.

Mr Messier said he was also to approach other, as yet unnamed parties about joining the Universal-Sony accord. "We hope others will join us," he told French economic daily La Tribune.

The development could be a significant reversal for Napster which, with the backing of Bertelsmann-owned record label BMG, has offered the big record companies $1bn (£693m) over five years for the right to use their music online.

Duet, which operates out of San Francisco, is expected to offer both a subscription service and a pay-per-listen option. It would unite online stars including Sony's Jennifer Lopez, Ricky Martin and George Michael, with Universal's Boyzone and Elton John.

Napster is looking to introduce a monthly subscription fee of its own. Earlier this month it was found guilty of copyright infringement at the end of a year-long legal battle with the industry's biggest firms, including Universal, Sony, EMI and Warner.

fields.headline: The British patient
fields.standfirst: In the final extract from their book auditing the performance of the Blair government, Guardian writers anatomise the health service.
fields.trailText: In the final extract from their book auditing the performance of the Blair government, Guardian writers anatomise the health service.
fields.body:
The existence of the NHS does relatively little for the nation's health: just as sewers not doctors cured cholera, so creating a better off, better educated population does more for heart attacks than building extra coronary care units. But the political health of successive governments has depended on perceptions of the NHS. Unless it is drip-fed above-inflation increases every year, there is hell to pay. Parsimony always results in winter crises, soaring waiting lists and patients on trolleys plastered all over the front pages. It was a lesson of post war political history Labour should not have ignored.

For the first two years spending bumped along at the bottom. This followed a thin time under John Major, when annual increases in NHS spending averaged 2.6%, compared with a post-war average of 3.4%. Since the founding of the NHS was Labour's proudest boast, people expected to see real improvements and fast, however hard the party tried to damp down expectations. They did not happen. The pledge to cut waiting lists by 100,000 was modest - but even that proved perilously hard to achieve. To compensate, a flurry of hospitals were built at once on the never-never. Thanks to the private finance initiative, capital spending was taken off Treasury accounts. The government reckoned patients seeing gleaming new hospitals would not bother to question dubious 30-year debts to the private sector.

Labour's NHS crisis broke in late 1999, personified in Mavis Skeet whose cancer operation was cancelled four times in five weeks because of bed shortages, until her condition became inoperable. Political reaction to her story triggered the biggest spending promise the NHS has ever had. After Lord Winston, the nation's most famous doctor, said the NHS was the worst in Europe and Labour policy "deceitful", Tony Blair dashed to the studios to calm nerves.

He promised the UK would henceforth match the European Union average in health spending, expressed as a proportion of GDP. That meant a guaranteed 6.1% year on year increase, 35% more by March 2005. When the chancellor confirmed it in the budget, the British Medical Association tore up the usual grumbling press release it had prepared and spoke unequivocally of its delight. The good news only goes so far, however, as the graph shows. New calculations by the King's Fund show the gap between the UK and the rest of Europe remains and may even grow.

Besides, for voters mammoth figures signify little. Most NHS cash goes on staff who are hard to find and long to train. Official waiting lists did come down thanks to much pushing - and longer waiting times for first appointments. Demand rose and so did total volume of treatment, as it has steadily since 1948. After a bad first two years, pay for doctors and nurses did rise, but not enough to stem shortages - 22,000 unfilled nursing vacancies at the end of 2000.

With the money came a new NHS plan. It embraced the already launched National Institute for Clinical Excellence which seeks to identify the most effective drugs and treatments, spreading best practice everywhere. The new commission for health improvement acts as a medical Ofsted, examining hospital performance. Tony Blair envisioned a consumer-friendly health service so the first available new money went to the most visible places - accident and emergency departments and 25 high street walk-in clinics for people too busy to take half a day off to see a GP. The plan promised abolition of hospital waiting lists by 2005 and shorter waiting for GP appointments. To the prime minister the danger was that the middle classes would abandon the NHS if it failed to compete with the glossy brochures of the private clinics.

The national plan of July 2000 offered a long menu: 7,000 more beds, 7,500 more consultants, 2,000 more GPs and 20,000 more nurses, with targets for everything from cleaner hospitals and prescribing powers for chemists and nurses. But since none of this has happened yet, it has made no impact with the public. It has, however, stuffed the mouths of the medical professions for the time being: there is a lull in the usual grumbling from the wards.

Before the big promise to match EU funding, speculation was growing that the NHS could not survive on the current basis. The Tories and rightwing think-tanks claimed that only private insurance would raise standards. Even Labour ministers were floating the need for a hypothecated tax - an ear-marked extra tax for the NHS. The big spending promise stilled these voices. But we may now be witnessing the NHS's last chance, at least as a service paid for out of general taxation. If even this great increase fails to deliver standards that match public expectations, many more may turn to private practice, leaving the NHS as a poor service for poor people. But the NHS is recognised internationally for its efficiency in getting value for the low sums spent. If total health outlays in the UK were to come near to what the French and Germans spend, it ought to improve markedly. But that is for the future. For the Blair government 1997-2001, the outcome so far is poor.

webTitle: Agency steps up food safety publicity

fields.headline: Agency steps up food safety publicity
fields.trailText: 8.30am:The Food Standards Agency is attempting to allay fears about the outbreak of foot and mouth disease, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The Food Standards Agency is stepping up its publicity campaign surrounding the outbreak of foot and mouth disease to allay consumers' food safety fears.

An FSA spokesman said consumers are confused about whether the disease affects food safety.

Consumers have been calling the FSA's hotline to ask whether meat and dairy products are safe to eat.

The agency is monitoring the hotline closely for evidence of increasing consumer concern.

"We have received a number of calls from members of the public unnecessarily worried about the safety of meat and dairy products.

"We need to explain why the disease does not pose a food safety threat," said the spokesman.

The FSA is due to post new information on its website this afternoon to help explain the implications of foot and mouth disease.

"There is no sign of panic in this country and at the moment no sign of a dip in the meat trade here.

"This is a sign that people are absorbing the message that this is an animal health problem, not a food safety one," said the spokesman.

The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food is concentrating its efforts on keeping the farming community up to date with information on the control of the disease.

A spokeswoman said the ministry is using the press, its website, Ceefax and direct contact with farmers and their industry bodies to disseminate information about the outbreak.

fields.headline: Belt-up ad impresses French
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The French government has asked to use a highly effective UK road-safety advert, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
A hard-hitting British advertising campaign to persuade car passengers to fasten their seat belts has been so effective the French government wants to use it.

In the commercial, a woman driver is killed by her own son because he is not wearing a seat belt in the back seat.

It is to be shown in France in a bid to cut the country's high rate of road accidents.

It will be dubbed into French and will run on commercial channels from next week.

The French road safety ministry asked permission to use the campaign after it saw UK government statistics showing how effective it had been.

"We are delighted that what has been such a successful ad for us could help to save French lives too," said transport minister Lord Whitty.

"Since the ad was first shown in this country in 1998 it has helped to increase the wearing of rear seat belts from around 46% to nearly 60%, and the wearing of rear seat belts by children from 80% to 90%."

The commercial shows a mother driving her two children.

When she has to stop suddenly, her son, who is sitting in the back seat and not wearing a seat belt, is thrown forward, hitting her in the head and killing her.

The advert aims to show it is not just your own life you could be putting at risk when you fail to belt up in the back - and fatalities can occur at speeds as low as 30 miles an hour.

The Transport Research Laboratory, which carries out research on road safety for the government, estimates over 50 lives have been saved and 600 injuries avoided as a result of the advertising campaign.

The commercial was created by Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO and is due to be shown in the UK again between March 12 and March 19.

"Since the ad was first shown in this country in 1998 it has helped to increase the wearing of rear seat belts from around 46% to nearly 60%, and the wearing of rear seat belts by children from 80% to 90%." The commercial shows a mother driving her two children. When she has to stop suddenly, her son, who is sitting in the back seat and not wearing a seat belt, is thrown forward, hitting her in the head and killing her. The Transport Research Laboratory, which carries out research on road safety for the government, estimates over 50 lives have been saved and 600 injuries avoided as a result of the advertising campaign. The commercial was created by Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO and is due to be shown in the UK again between March 12 and March 19.

fields.headline: Scottish Radio soundings
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Plot thickens as SMG increases holding in Scottish Radio, writes Neil Hume.
fields.body:
Speculation about the future of Scottish Radio Holdings, has been mounting ever since SMG, better know as Scottish Media Group, took a large stake in the company back in December.

Since then Scottish Radio has said it is in bid talks with several parties, and DC Thomson, the Dundee-based publisher of the Beano and Dandy children's comics, has taken a 10% stake in the company.

Yesterday the plot thickened. SMG, owner of the Scottish and Grampian ITV franchises, revealed it had increased its holding to 23% through the purchase of 748,000 shares for £11.9m. Unfortunately for Scottish Radio shareholders the stock price failed to react, closing unchanged at £15.87. This was hardly surprising.

SMG is unlikely to mount an offer for Scottish Radio, until the rules governing the ownership of media assets have changed.

fields.headline: IPA woos graduates with vodka
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The IPA has launched an ad campaign with Absolut to encourage graduates to consider a career in advertising, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Ad industry body the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising has launched a high-profile ad campaign in universities to attract graduates into the advertising professioni.

Students in Edinburgh, Oxford, Bristol and York are being targeted in a teaser campaign.

The ads use the Absolut vodka brand in a mysterious way to encourage the students to think about advertising as a career.

Guerrilla marketeers wearing Absolut-branded T-shirts have been dispatched to campuses to hand out postcards, drop cut-outs of an Absolut bottle in students' pigeon holes and paste up Absolut posters on noticeboards.

A website has been developed to support the underground activity at ipa.co.uk/absolutintrigue.

The second stage of the campaign, developed by TBWA\London and Naked Communications, reveals venues for a series of advertising careers roadshows being held at the universities.

Matt Hardisty, strategist at Naked Communications, said: "It was key to provide a 'knowing wink' to the target audience, in a young and fun but not frivolous way. The aim is to stimulate conversations on campus."

If the campaign to entice students to the IPA seminars is effective it is likely to be extended to other universities across the country.

Ann Murray Chatterton, IPA's director of training and development, said: "Our research shows advertising is still misunderstood by most undergraduates.

"The teaser campaign is designed for the undergraduate market and should appeal to the curious.

"We hope it will attract graduates who are looking for a challenging career but have not yet thought about advertising as an option."

fields.headline: Reed gleans net revenue boost
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
More net news
fields.trailText: Publisher Reed Elsevier yesterday underlined the change in fortunes it has experienced since Crispin Davis took over as chief executive 18 months ago by publishing better than expected full-year results and revealing a jump in revenues from its internet services.
fields.body:
Publisher Reed Elsevier yesterday underlined the change in fortunes it has experienced since Crispin Davis took over as chief executive 18 months ago by publishing better than expected full-year results and revealing a jump in revenues from its internet services.

Internet revenues grew from £130m in 1999 to £436m in 2000. Reed hopes to lift the figure to £1bn by 2002, and expects around 80% of revenues from divisions such as science and legal to come from online activities within five years.

The company also predicted that ambitious long-term growth targets will shortly be met. Mr Davis said that the £143m in cost savings that he has stripped out of the business since arriving at Reed place it on track to deliver its stated aims of above-market revenue growth and double digit earnings growth by 2002.

"There are still very big challenges ahead, and we are only one year into a three-year programme but everyone here is making damned sure we deliver what we said we would," he said.

"We have a fired up management, looking forward to a year of execution and delivery."

Revenue for the year to December beat analysts' forecasts as it climbed 9% to £3.77bn. However, pre-tax profits slipped 3% to £690m as the Anglo-Dutch group spent heavily on new ways to make its catalogue of medical, scientific and business publications such as the Lancet and New Scientist available to paying subscribers online.

"Reed Elsevier will eventually become a largely electronic, internet-based business," Mr Davis said. Shares in Reed yesterday rose 27 to 662p.
