webTitle: Centrica looks at online car sales

fields.headline: Centrica looks at online car sales
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
More net news
Special report: Britain's car industry
fields.trailText: Centrica, the ever-expanding consumer services group, is seriously considering plans to enable its 11m AA members to buy cars online as it sets course for ambitious growth in the North American and European energy markets.
fields.body:
Centrica, the ever-expanding consumer services group, is seriously considering plans to enable its 11m AA members to buy cars online as it sets course for ambitious growth in the North American and European energy markets.

Announcing a 22% rise in pre-tax profits last year to £512m, chief executive Roy Gardner said it would be "entirely sensible" to give the AA's members the chance to buy cars at a click of a mouse.

Initially Centrica, which this week launched its first Goldfish ISA via its tie-up with Lloyds TSB, would offer advice on which car to buy and where to buy it rather than marketing a financial package.

Stressing that the plans are at an early stage, Mr Gardner said it might prove a good idea to enable AA members to buy cars direct - "if our customers want it and it's economically sensible we will do it".

Online car buying, partly driven by the continuing gap in prices between the UK and mainland Europe, is expected to grow significantly but so far accounts for just 20,000 of the 2.2m new and 1m used cars sold in Britain every year, according to the Retail Motor Industry Federation.

RMIF officials cautioned that buyers were not yet confident enough about securing finance - and avoiding fraud - in using the internet, with the basic problem of signing a credit agreement via a site yet to be cracked.

Manufacturers are also said to be warning dealers about undercutting their prices despite government moves to inject greater competition.

The foray into car-buying is the latest venture by Centrica - part of privatised British Gas just over three years ago - to offer customers the full range of energy, home, roadside and financial services, including current accounts, mortgages and life assurance. "We're not planning to sell you food," Mr Gardner said.

He sent a shudder through competitors by increasing his target for electricity customers by 1m to 7m by the end of next year and revealing that British Gas, its trading arm, is winning up to 50,000 new electricity customers a week.

It virtually doubled its electricity accounts to 4m last year alone and, with a 15% market share, is set to become the largest supplier. British Gas, which claims to be winning back two for every three customers it loses, retains "a tad" under 70% of the domestic gas market despite posting a 4.7% price rise this month. This share was down from 73.3% in 1999, but the group's overall domination of the UK energy market rose from 37% to 40%.

Mr Gardner dismissed rivals' complaints about his group's marketing muscle, insisting it enjoyed good relations with both government and regulator. "It's above board and in no way are we acting in an uncompetitive manner," he said.

Centrica has taken on 1.2m North American energy customers via three recent purchases and, according to Mr Gardner, aims to capture 10m by 2003 - in Canada and along the eastern seaboard and in the south of the US. It expects to win 30% of the 5m potential customers alone in Ontario, where full competition opens later this year.

By 2005, the group plans to serve 5m customers in mainland Europe, with a new push towards enforced liberalisation expected from the Stockholm EU summit next month.

fields.headline: Fury over Shell's 1p petrol rise
fields.standfirst:
Oil group increases forecourt prices hours after Treasury cuts duty

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Motoring organisations last night attacked Shell after the oil group increased petrol prices by a penny a litre only hours after the government had announced a temporary reduction in fuel duty.
fields.body:
Motoring organisations last night attacked Shell after the oil group increased petrol prices by a penny a litre only hours after the government had announced a temporary reduction in fuel duty.

The Treasury announced on Wednesday that it would cut duty by 2p a litre on unleaded petrol until June in next month's Budget to match a planned reduction in tax on ultra low sulphur fuel.

Motoring organisations said Shell's move raised questions over whether it was profiteering from the chancellor's pre-Budget give-away. Earlier this month, the Anglo-Dutch company reported record annual profits of £9.04bn, an increase of 85% from 1999.

"Motorists will by asking serious questions about the excessive profits of these oil companies... It seems that they take every single opportunity to raise prices," said a spokesman for the RAC.

A senior Treasury official said the government had "certainly been taken by surprise. We would expect any reduction to fuel duty we make on Budget day to be passed on to customers".

Shell defended itself, saying it had been forced to act because wholesale petroleum prices had jumped in the wake of increases in crude oil costs. The penny rise took effect from midnight on Thursday at 900 of Shell's 1,100 petrol outlets. "The cost of refined petroleum products has risen by 3-4p a litre since the end of 2000, while prices at the pump are at a 12-month low," a spokeswoman for Shell said.

But Shell's defence did not assuage critics. Ray Holloway of the Petrol Retailers' Association, a body representing UK independents, said some oil companies are trying to sneak in a price rise before Budget next month to recoup any tax give-away.

"I just don't understand it," he said. "There is no justification for a rise. Isn't it a remarkable coincidence that the Treasury makes an announcement drop and then Shell puts the prices up?"

The rise takes Shell's average national unleaded price to 75.9-79.9p a litre.

Britain's other leading petrol retailers are holding fire, however. Both Esso - the UK's largest company with 1,600 sites - and BP Amoco said yesterday that they had not raised prices and had no immediate plans to do so.

Oil companies insist their record profits this year have been made in refining, not retailing, and that margins on the forecourts are wafer-thin.

But the leaders of last autumn's fuel protests have warned that action will escalate again in the run-up to the election unless the government and oil companies act to cut fuel prices.

webTitle: Record number of Hollywood stars to attend Baftas

fields.headline: Record number of Hollywood stars to attend Baftas
fields.trailText: The decision to present the Baftas before the Oscars has encouraged more Hollywood stars than ever to attend the ceremony on Sunday
fields.body:
This year's Baftas appear likely to welcome the largest turnout ever of Hollywood stars to Britain's top film awards ceremony. According to Variety, the American actors at Sunday's ceremony will include Tom Hanks, Hilary Swank, Kate Hudson and Joaquin Phoenix, plus Australian superstars Russell Crowe and Geoffrey Rush.

The high attendance is a reflection of the event's higher profile due to its new pre-Oscar slot, which has persuaded studios and stars to see it as a stepping stone to Academy Award success.

It is hoped that about 90 per cent of the nominees will attend the ceremony at the Odeon Leicester Square which will be hosted by Stephen Fry. The only big name who definitely won't be there is Michael Douglas, a Best Actor nominee for Wonder Boys, while Julia Roberts has not yet decided whether her current acting commitments will allow her to turn up.

The array of celebrities owes something to a new venture by BAFTA. This is the first time that someone has been employed to focus on the talent arrangements and it has clearly paid off.

webTitle: Comment: Iraq's devastation is due to Saddam, not sanctions

fields.headline: Iraq's devastation is due to Saddam, not sanctions
fields.standfirst:
Inefficiency and bribery are destroying the lives of the people

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Inefficiency and bribery are destroying the lives of the people.
fields.body:
The arguments that have gone on for years over Iraq have become so entrenched and bitter that it is difficult to disengage from them and recognise how much has changed. Sanctions are still discussed as if they were effective, whereas they have now almost completely withered away. Military action by the Americans and the British is still weighed as if the initiative lay with Washington, which has not been so for years. Neither the flurry of condemnatory declarations around the world after last week's raids, nor the justifications of the generals who ordered them moves us much forward in understanding the nature of what is undoubtedly one of the gravest world problems, the continued existence of Saddam Hussein's regime.

Some critics of the raids persist in presenting them as an attack pure and simple, whereas they are more properly seen as an attempt to prevent an escalation of the conflict. The American and British governments acted not only to safeguard their servicemen after Iraq upgraded its air defences but also to avert the political and military crisis that would have burst upon us had the Iraqis shot down aircraft and captured pilots.

Think of the pressures both for retaliation and for appeasement in that case, the opportunism of third parties rushing in to mediate, the upsurge of emotion in the Arab world, the difficulty of taking rational decisions in such an atmosphere! This danger has been reduced by the raids, but at the same time they show how fragile is a policy which depends on the calculation that we will never lose planes or aircrew, certainly not in any number.

Yet the no-fly zones are still the most intact and the most defensible element in the once formidable array of measures to contain Iraq. They provide some protection for the Kurds and for the Kuwaitis, in that as long as they exist Saddam could never be sure of American reaction if he tried to resume full control of the north or if he moved in a big way toward the Kuwaiti border. Those inclined to think of the no-fly zones as disposable should bear in mind the attitude of people like Mahmoud Osman, a Kurdish socialist leader, who told the Guardian this week that he knew of no Kurd who did not want them to continue to be enforced, and the views of the Kuwaitis, so often brushed aside by other Arabs. The no-fly zones also symbolise some degree of resolve.

Like sanctions, even in their now vestigial form, they are a way of saying that the Iraqi regime is not a normal government, to be treated in a normal way, and that at no point in the years since the Gulf war ended has it made a single sincere effort to comply with United Nations resolutions.

But is a point of principle worth imposing if it causes much human suffering? Here again, events have moved us on from the old arguments. Madeleine Albright became infamous in the Arab world when she replied to questions about the impact of sanctions on Iraqi civilians, especially children, by saying: "We think the price is worth it."

But that was before the effect of sanctions had been reduced both by changes in the rules which gave the Iraqi government more income and freedom to trade, and by massive evasions. The critics of sanctions cannot say both that they have become a joke and that they are still, whatever may have been the case in the past, the main cause of the misfortunes of Iraqis.

The deterioration in the conditions of life in Iraq must have many causes, notably the devastation that Saddam brought on his country by waging war on Iran. The damage done in the Kuwait war was piled on top of that.

A society which for a while had appeared to be flush with funds and which was engaged in pell-mell modernisation and urbanisation, highly dependent on imported items for its infra-structure, suddenly regressed. If it had been less developed, it would have been less damaged.

Saddam's government was peculiarly incapable of managing the resulting crisis. Quite apart from the ruthless diversion of funds to military spending, the Iraqi government is neither efficient or fair. It had operated for years a wasteful system of social bribery, selectively rewarding army, party, bureaucracy, and business class.

In the old days even the least privileged derived some benefit, and there was typically lavish spending on social services. Indeed the case can be made that Saddam went to war, both with Iran and Kuwait, precisely so he could maintain this profligate style. When this could no longer be done, the circle within which people were sustained and rewarded by the government was redrawn, and those outside duly suffered.

Sanctions certainly did not help, but the argument that they were contributory rather than central is strengthened by the fact that there has been no clear improvement in life for ordinary people in Iraq since they were run down.

The new American secretary of state, Colin Powell, travelling around the Middle East over the next few days, has the unenviable job of trying to persuade Arab leaders that there can be a common approach to Iraq. But the coalition created at the time of the Gulf war cannot be revived.

It was already on its last legs in 1996, when Saddam sent his tanks into Irbil and suffered no consequences, and it expired by late 1998, when the last major American missile onslaught on Iraq went unsupported. Arab governments are motivated by a fear of Saddam and by a fear of their own public opinion, and these fears could only be allayed if they thought the United States was determined to remove Saddam.

The Bush administration has not shown such a determination, and, while it may be harder on Iraq than its predecessor, it does not seem likely it will do so. In deed, the US and Britain would probably end sanctions in all but a few categories if Iraq would agree to a restoration of arms inspections, even if those inspections were likely to be superficial. Saddam's desire for the total humiliation of his enemies may nevertheless prevent this happening.

Sanctions might have worked, in spite of Saddam's obstinacy, if they had not been quite quickly subverted. As Tim Trevan, a former adviser to the UN special commission for Iraq, wrote in his book "impatience with sanctions is the best way to ensure they will not work", while "increasing support for sanctions over time, as with Rhodesia and South Africa" can convince a regime that it must buckle under.

Iraq, instead, saw sanctions unravelling rather than strengthening as Russia, China, France, and Arab states dropped out. Have sanctions strengthened Saddam, or is it more that weak sanctions have strengthened him? Can it truly be said that he is strengthened at all? It is hard to know, concerning a society as necessarily secretive and devious as Iraq is under Saddam. One may repine over the ineffectiveness of the policies applied to Iraq without quite giving up hope that in some way not visible now Saddam has been undermined, and without wanting to abandon a few measures, some practical and some symbolic, which mark out the Iraqi regime for what it is, a danger to itself, to its neighbours, and to the world.

If it had been less developed, it would have been less damaged. Saddam's government was peculiarly incapable of managing the resulting crisis. Quite apart from the ruthless diversion of funds to military spending, the Iraqi government is neither efficient or fair. It had operated for years a wasteful system of social bribery, selectively rewarding army, party, bureaucracy, and business class. In the old days even the least privileged derived some benefit, and there was typically lavish spending on social services. Indeed the case can be made that Saddam went to war, both with Iran and Kuwait, precisely so he could maintain this profligate style. When this could no longer be done, the circle within which people were sustained and rewarded by the government was redrawn, and those outside duly suffered. Sanctions certainly did not help, but the argument that they were contributory rather than central is strengthened by the fact that there has been no clear improvement in life for ordinary people in Iraq since they were run down. The new American secretary of state, Colin Powell, travelling around the Middle East over the next few days, has the unenviable job of trying to persuade Arab leaders that there can be a common approach to Iraq. But the coalition created at the time of the Gulf war cannot be revived. It was already on its last legs in 1996, when Saddam sent his tanks into Irbil and suffered no consequences, and it expired by late 1998, when the last major American missile onslaught on Iraq went unsupported. Arab governments are motivated by a fear of Saddam and by a fear of their own public opinion, and these fears could only be allayed if they thought the United States was determined to remove Saddam. The Bush administration has not shown such a determination, and, while it may be harder on Iraq than its predecessor, it does not seem likely it will do so. In deed, the US and Britain would probably end sanctions in all but a few categories if Iraq would agree to a restoration of arms inspections, even if those inspections were likely to be superficial. Saddam's desire for the total humiliation of his enemies may nevertheless prevent this happening. Sanctions might have worked, in spite of Saddam's obstinacy, if they had not been quite quickly subverted. As Tim Trevan, a former adviser to the UN special commission for Iraq, wrote in his book "impatience with sanctions is the best way to ensure they will not work", while "increasing support for sanctions over time, as with Rhodesia and South Africa" can convince a regime that it must buckle under. Iraq, instead, saw sanctions unravelling rather than strengthening as Russia, China, France, and Arab states dropped out. Have sanctions strengthened Saddam, or is it more that weak sanctions have strengthened him? Can it truly be said that he is strengthened at all? It is hard to know, concerning a society as necessarily secretive and devious as Iraq is under Saddam. One may repine over the ineffectiveness of the policies applied to Iraq without quite giving up hope that in some way not visible now Saddam has been undermined, and without wanting to abandon a few measures, some practical and some symbolic, which mark out the Iraqi regime for what it is, a danger to itself, to its neighbours, and to the world. martin.woollacott@theguardian.com Related articles 19.2.2001: Doubts over Iraq air strikes 19.2.2001: Raid shows Bush-Blair bond on Iraq 19.2.2001: No contest in the battle for Arab hearts and minds 16.1.2001: Iraqi sanctions explained Talk about it Iraqi bombing: What do you think? webTitle: Europe holds its breath as Turkish lira dives

fields.headline: Europe holds its breath as Turkish lira dives
fields.standfirst:
Currency crisis leaves government on brink  IMF sending crisis team to Ankara  Billions wiped off share values

Special report: the IMF and World Bank in Prague
fields.trailText: Financial upheaval on the edge of Europe sent tremors across the continent yesterday, after the Turkish government was forced to abandon the fixed exchange-rate policy that had been the centrepiece of its economic reforms.
fields.body:
Financial upheaval on the edge of Europe sent tremors across the continent yesterday, after the Turkish government was forced to abandon the fixed exchange-rate policy that had been the centrepiece of its economic reforms.

Last night the International Monetary Fund was sending a team to Turkey to assess the damage done during a tumultuous week. There were fears that the freefall of the Turkish currency could topple the government and set off widespread aftershocks across the financial markets and the European political system.

The Turkish lira plummeted yesterday, losing nearly 30% of its value against the dollar, after the government was forced to let the currency float.

It was another reminder of the potential for instability in a country which aspires to EU membership and is a vital member of Nato, guarding the alliance's south-eastern borders with the Caucasus and the Middle East.

The decision to allow the lira to slide was taken after several days of financial panic, prompted by a public row between the prime minister and the president about the pace of investigations into high-level corruption.

The prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, had stormed out of a meeting with President Ahmet Necdet Sezer on Monday, speaking of a "serious crisis", after Mr Sezer criticised the government for failing to fight corruption in high places.

Billions of pounds have been wiped off share values and removed from foreign exchange reserves this week. Now ordinary people will pay the price, as inflation eats further into fixed incomes and economic growth stagnates.

Crowds gathered yesterday outside currency exchanges in the capital, Ankara. Clerks sat idle inside, refusing to sell dollars.

"I am in shock, I can't even comment," said one pensioner, who would not give his name. "My debt has doubled. The ones who created this crisis should feel shame. We keep delaying life, we are always indebted."

"They have made the public pay for their greed .. the poor will be poorer, the middle class will be wiped out and the rich will be richer," a former schoolteacher said.

Last night there were growing calls for a major government reshuffle and anger at the way the crisis had been provoked. The Civil Initiative, a coalition of trade unions and employers, called for a government shake-up. "Unsuccessful ministers and bureaucrats must be replaced and more qualified people put in their place," it said.

The devaluation of the lira did help restore some sense of stability to other parts of the financial system. The Istanbul stock exchange, which posted a record loss on Wednesday, rebounded partially, and inter-bank lending rates - some of which had soared to 5,000% - came down sharply.

"We believe that the floating lira regime will revive the economy in a significant way," Mr Ecevit said. "We will try to ensure that wage earners are not harmed by inflation."

Mr Ecevit played down his row with Mr Sezer as a cause of the crisis, preferring to point to economic causes. "There was an economic problem and it exploded."

Confidence in the government's handling of economic policy has by no means been restored, however. Mr Ecevit, who is blamed by most Turks for causing the financial upheaval, has reaffirmed his commitment to economic reform, but the markets will be watching extremely closely.

A programme of strict economic austerity agreed with the International Monetary Fund is dead. Devaluation of the lira means inflation is bound to rise, at least in the short term. Both the government and the IMF know that they need to work on a new set of economic targets.

"We are expecting to reach an agreement to redo the programme, which we are carrying out with the IMF, based on a new and realistic framework," the economy minister and the governor of the central bank said in a joint statement.

The new Bush administration last night promised to lend its backing to the country. "Turkey is an important ally and good friend of the United States. The United States continues to back the IMF's ongoing support for Turkey's economic reform programme," said the treasury secretary, Paul O'Neill.

Washington is aware that failure to agree a new programme would be a big blow to both Turkey and the IMF. But it has already warned that it will not support the IMF giving unlimited funds to countries which have caused their own economic problems - a threat that appears to apply to Turkey.

The other issue still making the financial markets nervous is the fact that the underlying dispute which sparked the crisis has not been resolved. Mr Ecevit and President Sezer are still at daggers drawn.

fields.headline: Global disease on the rise
fields.standfirst: Finger pointed at illegal trade
fields.trailText: The illegal smuggling of animals, increased traffic of refugees, tourism, weak veterinary and waste services and the globalisation of trade are all making foot and mouth a more common global animal disease.
fields.body:
The illegal smuggling of animals, increased traffic of refugees, tourism, weak veterinary and waste services and the globalisation of trade are all making foot and mouth a more common global animal disease, according to the European Commission.

The last two years have been among the worst on record with more than 60 countries experiencing outbreaks, including many which have not had one in generations.

They included Israel, Greece, Japan, Brazil and Uruguay, all of which were previously declared free of the disease by the World Organisation of Animal Health office, representing 155 countries. "Vaccine makers could barely keep up with demand, so bad was the situation," said Alf-Eckbert Fussel of the commission's health directorate. "New virulent types of the disease, similar to the one found in Britain, were introduced to some countries which were previously free. They were not because of legal trading but probably because of smuggling and illegal trade".

Countries are increasingly blaming their neighbours. One serious outbreak last year in Japan, the first in more than 70 years, was traced back to diseased straw brought illegally from China, via Russia.

"A series of outbreaks in southern Brazil last year led to a serious outbreak in Uruguay, its first in 10 years. More than 30,000 animals had to be slaughtered," said Dr Alex Donaldson, head of the UN's world reference laboratory (WRL) for foot and mouth disease at Pirbright, which collates information on the global spread of the disease.

Diseased pigswill, sometimes illegally imported, is increasingly thought to be a cause of outbreaks, according to the WRL.

This is particularly common in Asia, said Dr Donaldson. An outbreak in South Africa last year was traced to the off-loading of rubbish from a ship in Durban. The Uruguay incident was traced to waste food fed to pigs. The 1981 outbreak in Britain was traced to pigs from Brittany, France.

Ben Gill, president of the National Farmers Union, yesterday suggested that globalisation of trade might be responsible for the British outbreak. "Is it a coincidence that we had classical swine fever in east Anglia last year of an Asian origin, and foot and mouth now, also of an Asian origin? It raises questions about freer world trade."

webTitle: Farmers fear of new outbreaks as prices fall

fields.headline: The countryside waits... and hopes
fields.standfirst:
Farmers fear of new outbreaks as prices fall

Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: Nestling among Northamptonshire's rolling hills, the pretty village of Ravensthorpe is a good 100 miles from the Essex abattoir at the centre of the foot and mouth crisis. But here, the outbreak is already having a profound effect on the immediate struggles of farmers.
fields.body:
Nestling among Northamptonshire's rolling hills, the pretty village of Ravensthorpe is a good 100 miles from the Essex abattoir at the centre of the foot and mouth crisis.

But here, as in similar rural communities across the UK, the outbreak is already having a profound effect on the immediate struggles of farmers to make ends meet and on the morale of those who live in the countryside.

Farmers, labourers, suppliers and hauliers spent much of yesterday waiting for more news, trying to separate fact from rumour. More than anything they were waiting - fearfully - for confirmation of new outbreaks. Had the Ministry of Agriculture moved swiftly enough to isolate the virus, or was it already advancing across the country? How would their jobs, their livelihoods be affected?

Exported

The timing could not have been worse for the likes of Trevor and Pat Foss, who farm 200 acres just behind the honey-coloured stone church of St Denys in Ravensthorpe. They are already nurturing 100 early lambs in their rows of neat sheds. The animals will be ready to go to market in a fortnight. With luck the farm will have another 400 lambs by the end of the season. Most would have been exported.

As chairman of the region's National Farmers' Union Mr Foss spent yesterday morning at a prearranged meeting of dairy farmers. Naturally enough, talk of foot and mouth disease dominated the tense discussions. A ministry vet turned up to give advice about the precautions that should be taken.

Mr Foss, a practical and realistic man, acknowledged that there was great concern but said there was not a sense of panic - at least not yet. He said: "The farming industry has been through so much in recent years that we've grown used to facing problems. It's a matter of waiting and seeing and hoping."

More immediately, however, Mr Foss was anxious by late morning yesterday to find out how prices at Northampton market had held up.

The news was not good. Three thousand lambs, which would mainly have been destined for the continent, were expected to begin arriving at the market at dawn. In the end only 1,200 were brought in. Prices plummeted. Last week auctioneer Keith Rose was overseeing the sale of lambs at a healthy £1.20 a kilo - between £8 and £12 per animal. Yesterday he could do no better than £1.

He did not care to say how much his profits had dropped on only the first market day after the export ban came into force. But he admitted: "If this isn't resolved quickly, next week's market could be a lot, lot lower. The problem is that 80-85% of this lamb would have been going to France. Now it has to be sold to the home market and that depresses the price. The mood at the market today was, to say the least, rather sombre."

Meanwhile just up the hill from Ravensthorpe the Pytchley hunt was holding horse trials. "You haven't come from one of the zones, have you?" inquired one of the organisers suspiciously. The outbreak - and the setting-up of exclusion zones around Cheale Meats, in Essex, and around farms which had recently delivered meat there - had made the organisers of this popular event understandably edgy. Horses rarely contract foot and mouth disease but can carry it from place to place. Three lorryloads of horses had failed to turn up to the trials because they were too close to the dreaded zones.

Bill Saunders, a respected local landowner, was among the crowds watching the event and trying to forget their troubles for a few moments. He has farmed the area for 50 years and is resigned to making a loss on the 150 head of cattle he owns that are ready to go to market. Recent bad weather coupled with the lingering effects of the BSE crisis had already meant that he would scarcely break even on the animals.

He said: "I thought I could see the light at the end of the tunnel. Now this. But we are a resilient lot and we will struggle on."

Many farmers in Ravensthorpe and surrounding villages have given up before now, frustrated by the number of regulations they feel they have to cope with and by what they see as a lack of help and understanding from the government. Those left tend to be determined. So Mr Saunders preferred not to dwell on the unhappy lot of the farmer at present but to think of practical solutions. "We're all aware that we're going to face restricted movement if this continues. Well it's no good complaining - we're just going to have to make do."

Disastrous

It is not only agriculture that will be hit. The Pytchley hunt will also be affected. Word gradually seeped through during the trials that hunting had been suspended for seven days. The Pytchley will lose two meetings. If, however, the disease spreads and the hunt's money-spinning spring point-to-point had to be cancelled, the consequences could be disastrous. The Pytchley's woodman Dick Threadgold said: "The impact of something like this can be felt through the whole community. Almost everyone is effected in one way or another."

Back in the village, lunchtime conversation at the Chequers pub had turned inevitably to farming matters. The village's farmers do not tend to drink in the pub at lunchtime, preferring to arrive after their day's toils, but the non-farming regulars were nevertheless discussing the implications for the area.

In a village of only 500 people it is likely that everyone will know someone who will be directly or indirectly affected if the crisis grows.

"It's terribly sad," said Janet Green as she scanned the local newspaper's front page outside the village post office. "We're a tight little community and when something like this happens we are all drawn into it in some way."

Sheep shipment investigation

The Ministry of Agriculture was yesterday investigating how a ship loaded with live sheep was apparently allowed to sail from Britain to France on Tuesday night, after discovery of the foot and mouth outbreak. Animal right protesters claim they tracked a lorry from Wales which passed through what has now become an exclusion zone on the Essex section of the M25 and watched as it delivered its live cargo to the dockside at Dover.

Abattoir sends staff home

Sixty workers at an abattoir near Rhyl, north Wales, were sent home yesterday as the effects of the foot and mouth crisis began to bite. The managing director, Owen Owen, who expects to lose more than £10,000 a week, questioned the necessity of the blanket meat export ban.

Disinfectant firm stretched

The country's biggest manufacturer of agricultural disinfectants was yesterday operating round-the-clock shifts to keep up with demand for its "bio security" products. Antec International of Sudbury, Suffolk, which makes 1m kilos of its best-selling Virkon S product a year, is running 24-hour shifts for its 70 staff as they deal with a huge increase in orders from farmers.

Livestock sale cancelled

A livestock market due to be held today in Essex beyond the 10-mile foot and mouth exclusion zone has been cancelled. A spokeswoman for Stanfords, which runs twice-weekly markets in Colchester, said: "We have taken the voluntary decision not to have the market."

webTitle: The Flying Scotsman to float on London stock exchange

fields.headline: People's engine
fields.standfirst:
Steam icon takes a flyer at market

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: World famous steam locomotive the Flying Scotsman is to puff its way on to the London stock market in a move which will allow rail enthusiasts to own a share in the engine.
fields.body:
World famous steam locomotive the Flying Scotsman is to puff its way on to the London stock market in a move which will allow rail enthusiasts to own a share in the engine.

The locomotive, which took to the tracks in 1923 and was the first in the world officially to break the 100mph barrier in 1934, is to be floated in the coming weeks by owner Tony Marchington.

Pharmaceuticals entrepreneur Dr Marchington last year sold his stake in biotech company Oxford Molecular and has spent nearly £2.5m buying the locomotive, pictured above on a special new year journey through the Axe Vale in Devon, and restoring it to working order.

Money raised from the flotation will part-fund a multi-million pound Flying Scotsman Village, a steam theme park earmarked for a site in Doncaster.

Robin Jones, editor of Heritage Railway magazine, which featured the flotation in its latest issue, said: "The Flying Scotsman has become the definitive icon of the steam age and it is now set to break major new ground in the 21st century.

"By giving the public the chance to own shares in the locomotive, it will become the ultimate 'People's Engine'."

webTitle: Glaxo pins hopes on Aids vaccine to boost earnings

fields.headline: Glaxo pins hopes on Aids vaccine to boost earnings
fields.standfirst: Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: Glaxo SmithKline announced plans yesterday to begin human trials of a vaccine against Aids by the end of the year during a briefing on 161 potential medicines which calmed fears about the weakness of the drugs firm's development pipeline.
fields.body:
Glaxo SmithKline announced plans yesterday to begin human trials of a vaccine against Aids by the end of the year during a briefing on 161 potential medicines which calmed fears about the weakness of the drugs firm's development pipeline.

The preventative vaccine has shown promise in animal trials - when tested on monkeys, it appeared to reduce the impact of HIV for up to a year. If successful, a therapeutic version could be developed to treat patients already infected with the virus.

In its first full update since last year's merger of Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham, the company set ambitious short-term targets for earnings growth. Chief executive Jean-Pierre Garnier promised an increase of 13% in 2001, rising to "mid-teens" in next year.

Mr Garnier promised more acquisitions to bring in new products, describing the group as a "financial monster" with the firepower to consider deals out of the range of others in the industry.

Glaxo expects booming profits in the immediate future from diabetes drug Avandia and asthma treatment Seretide - both considered likely to command annual sales of more than $1bn (£700m). But analysts are concerned that there is a gap in the firm's pipeline between these new drugs and dozens of very early-stage projects.

One analyst said: "Clearly, the pipeline is light in its later stages - there aren't that many exciting launches coming up. There could be a gap in growth in about 2003 or 2004."

However, he added: "They do have time to sort it out - overall, people were reasonably reassured by the update."

Glaxo SmithKline's shares rose 45p to £19.20 following the briefing. Mark Tracey, an analyst at Goldman Sachs, said the firm had "a solid risk profile versus several of its global peers, and a below industry valuation".

Other early-stage projects highlighted by Glaxo SmithKline included a new heart drug, known as 435495, which inhibits a crucial enzyme causing cardiovascular disease. The compound, which is a product of the company's genomics research, has significantly helped treat heart disease among rabbits.

An expected increase in the estimated cost savings from the group's merger did not materialise - the firm said that it still anticipated annual savings of £1.6bn.

fields.headline: Goldman's chief loses out at $22.5m
fields.trailText: Goldman Sachs Group last year shelled out $22.5m (£15.5m) in salary and bonus to chief executive Henry Paulson - a king's ransom for most but a step down for the Wall Street financial group's top employee.
fields.body:
Goldman Sachs Group last year shelled out $22.5m (£15.5m) in salary and bonus to chief executive Henry Paulson - a king's ransom for most but a step down for the Wall Street financial group's top employee.

Mr Paulson's pay package dropped 12% from 1999, when he pocketed $25.3m in cash and stock, according to a company proxy statement filed with the securities and exchange commission yesterday. Goldman cut its bonuses last year despite a 15% rise in profits.

Mr Paulson, who also serves as chairman, received a $14.1m bonus last year, compared with $16.1m in 1999. His base salary was $600,000 and he was awarded about $3.9m in stock and $3.9m in stock options.

David Komansky, head of competitor Merrill Lynch, made a cool $32.5m last year. Bear Stearns' chief executive Jimmy Cayne raked in $33m, while chairman Alan "Ace" Greenberg pocketed nearly $19m in 2000.

Goldman's compensation expenses rose to $7.8bn in the year to November, compared with $6.5bn in the same period of 1999. But it said that it had also decided to cut its bonus pool last year.
Reuters

webTitle: CBI says jobs to go as output slows

fields.headline: CBI says jobs to go as output slows
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: The Confederation of British Industry cut its growth forecast yesterday, warning that the first chill winds from the US slowdown have hit the manufacturing sector.
fields.body:
The Confederation of British Industry cut its growth forecast yesterday, warning that the first chill winds from the US slowdown have hit the manufacturing sector.

Output is forecast to expand by 2.5% this year, rather than the 2.7% growth the employers' body was expecting in November. "The impact of the US slowdown may taken the wind out of the sails of the UK economy," said Kate Barker, the CBI's chief economic adviser.

Manufacturing output will rise by just 1.7% this year and next, and a further 118,000 manufacturing jobs are expected to be lost.

But the slowdown should allow the Bank of England to shave a further half a percentage point off interest rates by autumn this year, according to the CBI, provided the chancellor, Gordon Brown, delivers a prudent budget.

"Sound public finances and low inflation mean there is scope to ease policy and support growth," said Ms Barker.

"If the chancellor maintains his iron reputation and announces a cautious Budget, interest rates could fall by another 0.5%."

The first signs of the fallout from the US crossing the Atlantic was revealed by the CBI's latest snapshot of industry, published yesterday. Firms reported shrinking order books, falling exports and a growing stockpile of unsold goods in February.

"It's the first time we've picked up evidence in our surveys of the impact of the darkening US outlook," said Sudhir Junankar, the CIB's associate director of economic analysis. "Although sterling has weakened recently against the euro, this has yet to have positive effect on exports."

Confidence among firms has taken a turn for the worse after two months of improvement. Export orders, which had also been improving, fell back by 10 points - the sharpest fall since March 1998. "The CBI survey was weak across the board and seasonal factors, which normally boost activity in February, suggest the underlying picture is even worse," said Daniel Kaye, UK economist at Capital Economics.

So far policymakers are predicting the UK should weather any storms from the US slowdown. The Bank of England is forecasting that the American economy will make an equally speedy recovery after its rapid decline, and that its impact on the UK will be limited.

In an interview yesterday, Professor Steve Nickell, a member of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee, predicted that US economy would bounce back rapidly from recession. But Sushil Wadhwani, a colleague of Prof Nickell and a leading dove on the Bank's committee, warned last night this picture may be too optimistic.

"I was one of those who would have been more gloomy than what is embodied in the best collective projection, in part because I believe that standard econometric models do not adequately capture the links between the UK and the US economies," he said. There was, he warned, a danger that the recession in the US could be prolonged.

webTitle: Hamleys' search for a buyer ends in tears

fields.headline: Hamleys' search for a buyer ends in tears
fields.trailText: Toy shop Hamleys has failed to find a buyer after a three-month search by its bankers. Shares in the troubled 240-year-old store fell almost 10% to 134.5p after chairman Simon Burke said the offers received were "unrealistic".
fields.body:
Toy shop Hamleys has failed to find a buyer after a three-month search by its bankers. Shares in the troubled 240-year-old store fell almost 10% to 134.5p after chairman Simon Burke said the offers received were "unrealistic".

Hamleys, thought to have wanted to be taken private by a venture capitalist, is now resigned to remain listed on the stock market, where it made its debut in 1994.

To try to arrest its problems, Hamleys is to convert 12 of its shopping centre-based Toystack stores into its new Bear Factory soft toy shops.

Mr Burke, who is stepping down as chief executive, admitted that Toystack was an "odd bedfellow" for Hamleys.

"Hamleys never made much of a fist of it," Mr Burke said, who added that by converting the Toystacks into Bear Factories the group's profits should be enhanced.

In the past two years, Hamleys has endured four profit warnings and most recently reported £9,000 profits for the half-year to September.

Rumours of a possible sale of Hamleys first surfaced six months ago, when Charter house Development Capital was said to be prepared to buy the business for 170p a share.

After those talks broke down, Hamleys admitted in November that it had hired investment bank Close Brothers to review its options. One industry analyst said yesterday that Hamleys had been hoping to attract at least 180p for each of its shares, but that none of those tentatively offered had been pitched at a high enough level. Mr Burke said Hamleys had not received any formal offers and had decided investors would be better off owning a public company.

Unlike last year, when its position was far more difficult and it was forced to consider any offer, however "miserly", Mr Burke said the group had "now turned a corner".

Refusing to be specific about sales in the early part of this year, Mr Burke said they had been going well since Christmas. This had also influenced talks with potential bidders, thought to have included Alchemy and Apax Partners.

Instead of appointing a chief executive, Mr Burke said operations director John Watkinson would take over as chief operations officer in March. Ian Parker, recruited six months ago, will become finance director while David Fogel, the only executive director to survive the boardroom shake-up instigated by Mr Burke, is to leave at the end of next month.

webTitle: Capita sees benefit of boom in contracts

fields.headline: Capita sees benefit of boom in contracts
fields.trailText: Capita, the group which runs support services ranging from housing benefit to recruiting civil service high flyers, yesterday reported its best ever figures.
fields.body:
Capita, the group which runs support services ranging from housing benefit to recruiting civil service high flyers, yesterday reported its best ever figures.

Buoyed by a balance of public and private sector contracts the group turned in full-year, pre-tax profits of £51.2m, up from just under £40m in 1999. Operating margins were up from 10.9% to 12% and turnover climbed 39% to £453m.

Last year saw the group win a 10-year £400m contract to set up and administer the criminal records bureau for the Home Office. Early this year it secured a £320m deal to develop and administer the Abbey National's general insurance activities.

The group is hoping to clinch a series of further "big ticket" contracts. It has bids in for £850m worth of work and has a track record of winning about half the contracts it bids for, according to chairman Rod Aldridge.

With no contracts up for renewal this year Capita is predicting strong organic growth during the year which "has started strongly with trading materially ahead of the corresponding period last year".

"We view the current year, and beyond, with considerable confidence," Mr Aldridge said.

Chief executive Paul Pindar said: "We are already forecasting underlying organic growth of 25% for 2001, so the revenues are expected to increase to around £640m in 2001," Analysts are forecasting revenues of £549m to £657m.

Last night Capita shares were down 5p at 469p.

webTitle: Ministry faces huge task in tracing source

fields.headline: Ministry faces huge task in tracing source
fields.standfirst:
Abattoir link magnifies scale of problem

Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: Abattoir link magnifies scale of problem
fields.body:
Hundreds of people are involved in the priority task of tracking the source of the outbreak of foot and mouth since the disease was first confirmed in the Essex abattoir at Little Warley, near Brentwood, on Tuesday.

What would have been a relatively simple task had a single outbreak ocurred on a farm has become a detective task of almost Herculean proportions because it happened in an abattoir.

The immediate and logical thought of the Ministry of Agriculture vets investigating was that it probably came from one of the two farms where the sick pigs had been reared. The pigs arrived a Cheale Meats near Brentwood on Friday and become sick on Monday.Logically at least one batch must have been infected before they were delivered.

The problem is that none of the stock remaining at either of the two farms - at Great Horwood in Buckinghamshire and Freshwater on the Isle of Wight - have become sick since or shown any signs of the disease.

A third possibility - a single pig which arrived at the abattoir via a market at Selby, North Yorkshire, on Sunday is also being investigated. But its 6,500 fellow breeders back at the Yorkshire farm also remain healthy so far.

With the virulent type O virus being isolated as the cause of the outbreak, ministry vets were told by the laboratory in Pirbright, Surrey that pigs could catch the disease and within 24 hours show symptoms. This meant that the pigs probably caught the infection in the abattoir rather than at their home farms. It also seemed logical that a bull at a nearby farm that became ill shortly after the pigs had caught the disease was infected by them. It is possible for the virus to carry many miles downwind from pig's breath - but if the wind was in the other direction, the bull could have infected the pigs. But where did the bull get foot and mouth from?

Yesterday, with all obvious leads drawing a blank the ministry was facing a long haul. Hundreds of people have now joined the hunt for the virus. Every movement of lorries, full and empty, cars and people visiting the infected abattoir premises in Essex for three weeks before the outbreak is being tracked.

This is proving a long task since with fewer but larger abattoirs serving the farming industry batches of animals are delivered to Essex from as far away as Northern Ireland and Scotland.

Every lorry movement between farms and markets which ultimately led to, or away from, the abattoir also needs to be checked. Computers are being used to check the strength and direction of the wind to find out the potential carrying distance of the virus in the few days before the outbreak. Foot and mouth has travelled 150 miles on a damp wind and conditions were ideal in Essex last week.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, has already ordered an investigation into how the virus reached the UK in the first place. Stringent controls are in place on imports from the countries where the disease is endemic or where outbreaks have occurred. Mr Brown said yesterday that in his view something illegal must have occurred for foot and mouth to arrive in Britain.

The theory that it has come from infected feed, subsequently incorporated in pig swill, was already being considered on Wednesday. Since the BSE crisis the issue of what farm animals eat has come under closer scrutiny but sloppy practices still exist. It would be a tragic irony if this latest animal health crisis was caused by impoverished farmers trying to squeeze a living by evading the rules on what they can feed their stock.

The outbreak of classical swine fever last August went through the same tracing process back to an original breeding farm in Norfolk. Yesterday the investigation in ot the source of that outbreak was still continuing, but the most likely theory was that the virus was contained in a sandwich thrown into a pig pen by a passing walker.

Tracing the source of foot and mouth is even more complicated because of the range of animals affected. Virtually everything with a cloven hoof - including camels and elephants - plus a few without, like rats, can suffer foot and mouth.

Wild animals like deer, which are far more plentiful in the countryside than during the last serious outbreak in 1967, can suffer from the disease and survive to spread it among domestic animals. Horses which often mix with farm animals and are transported around the countryside to hunts and race meetings can carry the disease and not show symptoms so would need to be individually tested.

A ministry spokeswoman said: "This is no easy task. We are proceeding by a process of elimination. There is a huge amount to do and so far we have drawn a blank but we are determined to find the source and we will."

webTitle: Zero-tolerance detective cleared of corruption charges

fields.headline: Zero-tolerance detective cleared of corruption charges
fields.trailText: The man credited with introducing zero-tolerance methods into Britain heard yesterday he would face no criminal charges after one of the longest investigations into allegations of corruption.
fields.body:
The man credited with introducing zero-tolerance methods into Britain heard yesterday he would face no criminal charges after one of the longest investigations into allegations of corruption.

The decision not to proceed against Detective Superintendent Ray Mallon, and colleagues in Cleveland police, provoked a storm of protest last night - with two local MPs publicly falling out over whether the chief constable, Barry Shaw, should resign.

The Labour peer Lord MacKenzie, a former president of the Police Superintendents Association, also demanded an investigation into methods adopted by the police complaints authority.

Three years after the launch of the operation, codenamed Lancet, into claims that drugs were offered to criminals for information, the crown prosecution service said in a statement there was insufficient evidence for a successful criminal prosecution, although 390 allegations were made.

Since the start of the inquiry, 48 files were forwarded to the CPS containing almost 14,000 witness statements, documents and other reports.

But Sir Alastair Graham, chairman of the PCA, said last night it was awaiting recommendations from Cleveland police on whether further officers should face disciplinary hearings. "We will then take the final decision," he added.

He revealed that two superintendents had already been told they would face disciplinary hearings - with the first to take place in April and the second in June.

After Chief Constable Shaw told a meeting of his police authority yesterday why Operation Lancet was started, the authority chairman, Ken Walker, defended the actions of the force.

With estimates of the cost of the investigation running up to £7m, he said: "No one likes the fact that Lancet has taken so long and cost so much, but that should not detract from the fact that it was launched because the chief constable and his senior officers feared that their drive against drugs, and possibly the safety of officers taking on the drug dealers, was being threatened."

Three years ago Detective Superintendent Mallon was suspended from duty, although last summer he was cleared of any criminal wrongdoing. He still faces disciplinary charges.

Last night Lord MacKenzie said the conduct of Operation Lancet had been "absolutely disgraceful".

He claimed it had developed into a fishing exercise which had resulted, at one stage, in investigating officers interviewing people in prison to ask if they had any complaints against Cleveland police. A full inquiry was needed to discover the facts.

Ashok Kumar, MP for Middlesbrough South and East Cleveland, said the position of the chief constable had now become untenable. "This inquiry has cost us something up to £7m for over three years and today the chief constable should resign," he said.

But Stuart Bell, MP for Middlesbrough, strongly disagreed. "If he had not acted on those allegations - some of which I drew to his attention from constituents coming to me - I would have called for his resignation," he said.

webTitle: Eta bomb kills two as election starts

fields.headline: Eta bomb kills two as election starts
fields.standfirst: Special report: violence in Spain
fields.trailText: A car bomb blamed on the Basque separatist group Eta exploded outside a busy railway station in the coastal city of San Sebastian yesterday, killing two people and seriously injuring four others.
fields.body:
A car bomb blamed on the Basque separatist group Eta exploded outside a busy railway station in the coastal city of San Sebastian yesterday, killing two people and seriously injuring four others.

Doctors said that the suspected target, Inaki Dubreuil, a Socialist councillor from the nearby town of Ordizi, escaped with relatively minor injuries and was being treated for burns and shrapnel wounds. His bodyguard was also hurt when the 6kg (13lb) bomb was detonated at 8am.

The bomb killed two workers from a nearby electronics factory: 31-year-old Josu Leonet and José Angel Santos, 40, both said to be supporters of Herri Batasuna, Eta's political wing.

The bomb followed the announcement on Tuesday that early regional elections will be held in May. Herri Batasuna could lose at least four of its 14 seats in the 75-seat assembly.

The election is expected to be fought over how to end Eta's 32-year campaign of violence for Basque independence.

The regional premier, Juan Jose Ibarretxe, of the Basque Nationalist party, wants to hold talks with Eta but his attempts to work with Herri Batasuna, especially during the 14-month unilateral ceasefire that Eta called off in December 1999, have failed to produce anything resembling a peace process.

His efforts have made him the target of fierce attacks from Spanish prime minister José Maria Aznar's centre-right Popular party, which accuses him of encouraging terrorism.

"This [bomb] shows that there is no point in trying to talk to Eta, as some nationalists think," said the regional Popular party leader, Carlos Iturgaiz, after the bomb.

Mr Aznar yesterday met his interior minister, Jaime Mayor Oreja, to discuss the minister's plans to leave the cabinet and lead the Popular party in the Basque polls.

Mr Oreja, himself a Basque, will be hard to replace. The tough-minded minister refused to talk with Eta during its ceasefire and is a popular cabinet member.

The Popular party, which has lost 11 councillors to Eta's gunmen in the past six years, is expected to gain the most ground in the May elections, although opinion polls show that it is unlikely to overtake Mr Ibarretxe's Basque nationalists which have won every regional poll since democracy was restored 25 years ago.

Mr Aznar hopes Mr Oreja will win enough votes to form a coalition government with the Socialists, making it the Basque region's first non-nationalist government.

 A suspected high-level Eta commander was arrested yesterday in Anglet, France, about 40 miles from San Sebastian, after being spotted in a bar. The Spanish media claims Francisco Xabier Garcia Gaztelu, 34, alias "Txapote", is an Eta executive committee member and one of its three top commanders.

fields.headline: When Blair meets Bush
fields.standfirst:
Britain's PM must speak for Europe too

Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Tony Blair had better watch out for his shoes. If he is not careful, George Bush might grab them only to swap them for his own footwear.
fields.body:
Tony Blair had better watch out for his shoes. If he is not careful, George Bush might grab them during their meeting in Washington today, or at Camp David this weekend - only to swap them for his own footwear. That is, after all, what he did with Vicente Fox, president of Mexico and the first foreign leader to receive Mr Bush since he took office: the two men, both ranchers with a fondness for stetsons and denim, sealed their bond of friendship by exchanging cowboy boots.

Come to think of it, Mr Blair may not be treated to so chummy a gesture. The new American president has demoted the British PM to third in his batting order of foreign summits and, by putting Mexico first, has clearly signalled his diminished view of Britain's (and Europe's) importance. Both his meagre record of international travel - just three trips outside the US, apart from Mexico, in his adult life - and last year's campaign rhetoric underlined the point: when it comes to the rest of the world, George ain't really that interested.

Those are not the only elements that will make Washington a chillier place for Mr Blair than it was on his previous visits. He has an ideological gap to bridge with Mr Bush, too. The bond with Bill Clinton was as much a Labour-Democrat affair as a British-American one: Tony and Bill regarded each other as political soulmates, engaged in parallel struggles to modernise their parties and change their countries. There is no similar force to bind today's pair. Moreover, Mr Bush hails from a party whose animating creed is a suspicion of government - while (on a good day) Mr Blair's mission is to rehabilitate the state as an agent of progressive change. The considerable charm skills of both men will be tested.

Which is not to say they will lack things to talk about. Now that they have been jointly blooded in battle, sharing in last week's wrong-headed air strikes near Baghdad, they have a certain amount of male bonding behind them. Since, we are told, they did not discuss the Iraq action directly before they took it, perhaps they can use this weekend to chat about Saddam Hussein and the lonely Anglo-American crusade against him. Maybe Mr Blair may even dare to revive the policy shift Britain's own Foreign Office was mulling before the nostalgic rerun of Operation Desert Storm: a move away from the ineffective and indefensible sanctions regime which punishes Iraq's people and leaves its leader unscathed.

That may be too much to hope for. There is certainly no chance of Tony Blair following the advice of some Europhiles, who dream of the day our PM will show two fingers to an American president, telling him that Britain's future lies with Europe instead. It is not going to happen, and nor should it. Mr Blair is right to argue, as he did during his brief stop in Canada yesterday, that the choice between the European Union and the United States is a false one - we can and should stick with both. A close alliance with the world's sole superpower is a British interest and Mr Blair cannot sensibly do other than nurture it.

But that does not mean serving only as a faithful lapdog. Instead the prime minister can act this weekend as an emissary from Europe, telling Mr Bush some uncomfortable truths. He might begin by explaining that the Republican flirtation with "America alone" notions of unilateralism make no sense; the only way America can play in today's world is as a team, sharing power with its allies. The two-nation solitude of the Iraq offensive is not sustainable for long.

Mr Blair can even offer a deal. He might tell Mr Bush that he could help him work out a plan for collective missile defence acceptable to the European allies and others so long as the president tells his top brass, including his hawkish defence secretary, to stop branding the EU's plan for a rapid reaction force a threat to Nato. That would be a useful deal to come home with - and proof that Mr Bush is a man with whom Mr Blair can do business.

fields.headline: DTI reignites TransTec row
fields.standfirst:
Firm founded by Robinson made unexplained £400,000 payment to Rover

Special report: Britain's car industry
fields.trailText: Firm founded by Robinson made unexplained £400,000 payment to Rover.
fields.body:
A preliminary report into the collapse of TransTec, the engineering firm founded by the former paymaster general Geoffrey Robinson, has uncovered fresh accounting irregularities including an unexplained payment of £400,000 to the motor manufacturer Rover.

The report, by the Department of Trade and Industry, finds that Mr Robinson and other non-executive directors were unaware of an $18m (£12m) claim from Ford which effectively bankrupted the business - the demand was kept secret in a cover-up that was named "project Durham".

However, it describes TransTec's general accounting practices as "aggressive" and reveals that there were significant shortfalls in the pension fund of a subsidiary.

The most significant new finding concerns £400,000 paid to Rover in July 1997, two months after Mr Robinson quit as chairman to join the newly elected Labout government.

The inspectors report that "the precise nature of this payment is not yet clear to us". They say TransTec's manage ment regarded it as a payment to secure a new contract, known as "NG4 sump", although when the transaction occurred, "no definite contract for the sump was, so far as we are aware, in existence".

The Rover transaction appeared in TransTec's accounts as an advance payment for tooling.

Trade secretary Stephen Byers commissioned the DTI inquiry to establish the facts surrounding TransTec's sudden plunge into receivership in December 1999.

The two inspectors investigating the affair stress they are not, at this stage, criticising any "company, firm or individual".

At the time of its collapse, TransTec's non-executive directors announced that they had just discovered a £12m compensation demand from Ford, which was angry at poor supply of cylinder heads for its Explorer cars.

The report reveals that the first demand for money from Ford was on April 23, 1997 - a couple of weeks before Mr Robinson stood down.

It reports: "Shortly after the claim was brought to the attention of TransTec it was determined to keep the matter as confidential as possible. The claim and its treatment were given a code name, project Durham. No non-executive directors were involved."

Mr Robinson, now backbench MP for Coventry North West, welcomed this finding. His magazine, New Statesman, issued a statement saying the report "confirms the account he has stood by throughout that neither he nor any other non-executive director had any knowledge of the Ford claim".

The statement went on to point out that TransTec's collapse occurred "more than two and a half years after he left the company".

In a wider comment, the DTI inspectors said TransTec's "aggressive" accounting practices tended to anticipate future profits and defer expenditure.

The report remarks: "Another way of putting this is that a more conservative view could have been taken of profits".

Mr Robinson was told in October that he would not face charges following a police investigation into government grants to the company between 1986 and 1989. The Serious Fraud Squad dropped an investigation into his role in TransTec's failure last March.

fields.headline: Investors attack trust chief
fields.trailText: John Duffield, the multimillionaire fund manager, was under fire last night from his former colleagues, including the brother of actress Helena Bonham Carter, about the way he is running a £117m trust set up to manage their savings.
fields.body:
John Duffield, the multimillionaire fund manager, was under fire last night from his former colleagues, including the brother of actress Helena Bonham Carter, about the way he is running a £117m trust set up to manage their savings.

The row comes after Mr Duffield's acrimonious and high profile departure last year from Jupiter, the fund management group owned by Commerzbank of Germany.

After leaving, Mr Duffield set up a rival operation named New Star and left Edward Bonham Carter in charge of the remaining business at top performer Jupiter.

A court battle to agree the terms of his departure from Commerzbank took place in November. Yesterday's controversy follows the detail of that agreement - which is said to have involved Mr Duffield agreeing to split up the New Star Investment Trust, which was set up last April as a savings vehicle for his then colleagues at Jupiter. He is said to have a stake of almost 40% in the trust.

His former colleagues at Jupiter argued yesterday that after three months, Mr Duffield has not acted swiftly enough to split up the fund.

At his new business, Mr Duffield has lured a number of former colleagues from Jupiter and other high profile City figures such as Howard Covington, a former mergers expert at Wasserstein Perella.

Late last month, the board of the trust appointed Mr Duffield's new firm, New Star, to take over the management of the trust from Jupiter. Mr Duffield is chairman of the board of the trust.

Yesterday, shareholders in the trust said they had issued a requisition to the board of the trust to call an extraordinary general meeting.

These shareholders want the trust to spit into two unit trusts and to give shareholders the opportunity to chose whether to put their money into one managed by Jupiter or that run by New Star.

A spokeswoman for the trust denied that any such requisition had been received.

webTitle: Lack of relish for Burger King hurts Diageo

fields.headline: Wilting Whoppers
fields.standfirst: Lack of relish for Burger King hurts Diageo
fields.trailText: Burger King has been serving up too many cold Whoppers, according to Diageo's chief executive Paul Walsh, who yesterday admitted he was "disappointed" with the fast-food chain's performance.
fields.body:
Burger King has been serving up too many cold Whoppers, according to Diageo's chief executive Paul Walsh, who yesterday admitted he was "disappointed" with the fast-food chain's performance.

Half-year profits from Burger King fell 7% to £99m, taking the shine off surging sales of Malibu and Bailey's in Diageo's drinks businesses. Group overall profits rose 11% to £1.23bn.

Mr Walsh admitted customers had been deserting Burger King in favour of McDonalds because of a lack of "operational consistency" in the preparation of the chain's trademark burger.

"Unfortunately, you do get a variable quality of Whopper," he said. "It may be not as hot as you'd like, or it may not have the correct level of mayo."

Burger King's stumbling progress looks likely to delay a planned flotation of the £2.5bn business. Diageo had been expected to float 20% of the business on the New York Stock Exchange this year but analysts now believe the move will be in 2002 at the earliest.

Mr Walsh said Burger King would need to turn in "one or two quarters of rea sonable performance", before any share offering, which would only be attempted in a "favourable market climate".

Northwest Airlines boss John Dasburg was poached this week to take over at Burger King. The group has called in two new advertising agencies to try to revive the chain's image.

Mr Walsh pointed out that Burger King only amounts to 8% of Diageo's overall profits. The firm's spirits and wines business fared better, with operating profits up 14% to £693m.

Diageo has increased its marketing spend on top brands, to give them a more youthful image. Sales of Bailey's have reached 5m cases a year, helped by sponsorship of television programmes such as Friends and Sex in the City. Malibu sales jumped 21% to 1.2m cases, while Smirnoff volumes rose 5% to 9.7m cases due to the surging popularity of Smirnoff Ice.

Analyst Charles Winston, of Schroder Salomon, said: "These are good results, but the question is how much is down to Diageo's own efforts, and how much to riding the wave of consumer spending in the US last summer." He expressed concern about Diageo's beer operations -Guinness volumes rose just 3%, hit by a decline in Ireland. Diageo's shares slipped 4p to 679p.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Northern Rock changes tack
fields.body:
Northern Rock changes tack

Mortgage bank Northern Rock joined the renewed battle in Britain's home loan market yesterday, offering existing borrowers the same deals it had been using to lure new customers.

Northern Rock, one of the smaller lenders in the market, said while it was keen to win new mortgage and savings customers, it also wanted to ensure that it treated its current clients fairly.

Northern Rock's standard variable rate is set at 7.5%, but it said that it would give a discount of 0.51% to existing customers who have had their loans for seven years, giving them a loyalty rate of 6.99% from April 1.

Hilton escapes racing losses

The cancellation of more than 100 races last year as a result of bad weather could have made a big hole in the profits of Hilton Group, the hotel and Ladbroke betting chain.

Punters switched their bets to other events, however, and the group ended the year with profits before tax, goodwill and exceptional items just £3.8m lower at £301.2m.

Hanson reacts to oil price rise

Hanson, one of the world's largest concrete and ready mixed cement groups, is planning above inflation price rises to offset the impact of the higher oil price.

The group, which reported that pre-tax profits before exceptionals rose just 1.2% to £318.2m last year, is a heavy user of oil related products.

The firm's finance director, Jonathan Nicholls, said the knock-on effect had cost the group £40m last year. He said he aimed to raise prices by about 10% in Britain and by up to 4% in the US, where it earns about 64% of its overall profits.

Decline in car values hits Lex

Falling car prices wiped £14m off underlying profits of Lex Service last year.

Lex, which sold its franchised car dealerships after buying the RAC motoring services business in mid-1999, said its car leasing and importing businesses had been hurt by the "exceptional fall" in car values.

The company ended the year with underlying profits a third lower at £41.7m. A £45m provision against a further slide in vehicle values left it with a pre-tax loss of £17.5m, against a £106.2m profit the previous year.

British Ports steams ahead

Associated British Ports has recorded a 10% increase in full-year profits. Britain's biggest port operator, which has been selling property and other non-core businesses to focus on its main port activities, said that underlying pre-tax profit rose to £124.3m from £113.5m a year ago. Group turnover rose 11% to £390.6m - higher than expected.

webTitle: Market forces: Autonomy takes a tumble

fields.headline: Autonomy takes a tumble
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: Market forces.
fields.body:
The techs were under pressure in London yesterday, with the Nasdaq opening lower on the other side of the Atlantic. But that did not explain the late drop in the price of Autonomy, the Cambridge-based intelligent software company.

From £16.15 at 3.30pm, the stock dropped to £14.95p, down 175p, in the space of an hour as speculation spread through the market that Goldman Sachs was placing a large line of the stock.

According to sources, Goldman had bought the 7% stake of founding shareholder Apax Partners (some 8.9m shares) and was selling it on to its institutional client base at the knock down price £14.95 a share. Autonomy shares closed at £16.67 on Wednesday night.

Earlier this month, Apax was saying that it had "no immediate intention" to sell. Observers see the sale of the Apax stake as positive for Autonomy. "It removes a lot of the uncertainty around the stock," said one.

"At least this proves there are some buyers for the stock, albeit at a lower level," said another.

But with the Nasdaq market looking sicker by the day, dealers now fear that Enic, the sports and media group, might also dump its stake in Autonomy. It is seeking approval from shareholders to sell some or all of its 2.8% holding.

Autonomy was not alone in suffering. Logica, the IT services group, was under pressure for a second consecutive session as analysts digested Wednesday's figures and decided they did not pass muster.

CSFB was most critical. Cutting its target price to £15.50, the broker said a closer inspection of the figures revealed a number of trends that could present near-term difficulties. In particular, it noted signs of slowing growth in Logica's important mobile networks division.

Goldman Sachs was also bearish, arguing that the figures suggested the company was either experiencing "growing pains" or "weakening fundamentals". Logica ended 122p lower at £13.25.

Elsewhere, things were looking rather brighter. Leading shares reclaimed the 6,000 level thanks to a strong showing from some of London's more heavily weighted stocks.

Recovering from a low of 5,937.1, the FTSE 100 index ended 30.7 points higher at 6,003.1, with GlaxoSmithKline (45p better at £19.65) and a resurgent Vodafone (up 6.25p to 189.5p) providing most of the upside.

Although Vodafone is no longer London's most valuable company - with BP holding top spot, it fell from second to third place yesterday after Glaxo's strong rise - it still sets the pace for the rest of the telecoms sector. Energis, 17p higher at 450p, and Marconi, 20p higher at 517p, both moved up in its slipstream.

Elsewhere, the FTSE Tech mark 100 index fell 59.89 points to 2,340.31, unsettled by the early performance of the Nasdaq.

Companies reporting figures featured prominently on the FTSE 100 leader board. Publishing group Reed International added 27p to 662p after posting full-year results ahead of expectations, while leisure group Hilton rose 8p to 231p on news that betting profits had held up last year.

Over in the banking sector, the late fightback of Abbey National surprised dealers. Down 19p at one point, its shares recovered to end 25p higher at £11.39. City sources said the recovery was the result of arbitrageurs reversing their earlier positions, which were based on the expectation that the offer from Lloyds TSB, up 5p to 642p, will be referred to the competition commission.

"Clearly this sector of the market [arbitrageurs] believes the government will not refer the deal," one trader said.

Among second-line stocks, SkyePharma rose 9p to 104p after GlaxoSmithKline highlighted at presentation to City analysts the potential for a reformulated version Paxil, an anti-depressant drug developed by the biotech company.
