webTitle: Croat war crimes suspect in court

fields.headline: Croat war crimes suspect in court
fields.standfirst: Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: Croatia's most senior war crimes suspect, General Mirko Norac, appeared before a district court yesterday and was remanded in custody after a two-week manhunt and mass protests which threatened to bring down the fledgling centre-left government.
fields.body:
Croatia's most senior war crimes suspect, General Mirko Norac, appeared before a district court yesterday and was remanded in custody after a two-week manhunt and mass protests which threatened to bring down the fledgling centre-left government.

He stands accused of orchestrating the murder of some 40 Serb civilians during Croatia's 1991 war of independence against the Yugoslav army and Serb rebels.

But attempts to bring him to trial have infuriated Croatian nationalists who regard him as a war hero. Earlier this month 100,000 demonstrators took to the streets of the Adriatic port of Split to protest at what they perceive as his persecution.

Gen Norac, 33, turned himself into the authorities late on Wednesday night after the prime minister, Ivica Racan, said he would not be extradicted to the Hague war crimes tribunal, and that his case would be handled by a Croatian court.

Mr Racan spoke shortly after the UN-sponsored tribunal announced that Gen Norac was not wanted by its prosecutors.

Gen Norac yesterday told the investigative judge, Sajonara Culina, at the Rijeka county court that he had no knowledge of the incidents the court is investigating, Croatian radio reported. In a brief television appearance on Wednesday, he claimed: "The allegations are unfounded and will easily be disproved in court."

But the charges are grave. As the wartime commander of Croat forces in the town of Gospic, south-west of Zagreb, he is alleged to have chaired a "death meeting" at which he ordered the execution of some 40 ethnic Serb civilians.

Ms Culina has until March 11 to complete her inquiry and hand the case to the county prosecutor who will decide whether to indict Gen Norac.

webTitle: England and Wales top crime league

fields.headline: England and Wales top crime league
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: England and Wales have one of the worst crime records in the industrialised world - even worse than America - according to the findings of an official survey published yesterday which compares the experience of victims across 17 countries.
fields.body:
England and Wales have one of the worst crime records in the industrialised world - even worse than America - according to the findings of an official survey published yesterday which compares the experience of victims across 17 countries.

The study, coordinated by the Dutch ministry of justice, shows England and Wales at the top of the world league with Australia as the countries where you are most likely to become a victim of crime. These countries face an annual rate of 58 crimes for every 100 inhabitants.

The findings, based on interviews with 35,000 people about their experience of crime across the 17 countries, were carried out last year. They are a blow to Labour's record and underline the challenge facing Tony Blair when he marks the launch of Labour's 10-year anti-crime plan next Monday by becoming the first serving prime minister to visit a prison.

The 2000 International Crime Victimisation survey shows that the falls in crime recorded since the mid-1990s in England and Wales are part of a general pattern of falling crime across the industrialised world but, unlike America, crime levels in England and Wales are still higher than they were at the end of the 1980s. When the survey was last carried out in 1996, England and Wales also topped the league table with 61 offences per 100 inhabitants.

The survey does show, however, that Britain has the best services when it comes to looking after the victims of crime, but it also shows we have a tougher approach to punishing criminals. Asked what should be done with a burglar convicted of stealing a colour television for a second time, more than 50% in England and Wales said he or she should be sent to prison for two years. Only 7% in Spain and 12% in France thought he or she should be jailed at all.

People were asked whether they had been victims of a range of 11 different offences in the previous 12 months, including violent and sexual assault, car crime, burglary and consumer fraud.

The survey also shows that Scotland, with 43 offences per 100 inhabitants, ranks joint fifth alongside America in the international crime league behind England, Australia, the Netherlands and Sweden. Northern Ireland has the second best crime record of the countries surveyed, with 24 offences per 100 inhabitants - the same rate as Switzerland and only just above Japan where the biggest crime problem is bicycle thefts. The detailed findings of the ICVS survey showthat England and Wales are top of the international league for car thefts with 2.6% of all car owners suffering the loss of their vehicle in the previous 12 months. In other sorts of car crime, England was second only to Poland.

Australia and then England and Wales had the highest burglary rates and rates for violent crimes such as robbery, assault and sexual assault .

One area in which England and Wales did not feature at the top of the league was in consumer fraud, which is far more of a problem in Poland, Denmark and the US. Some 5% of Polish people surveyed said they had had to pay a bribe to a police officer or government official in the previous 12 months.

The survey says the results show the industrialised world splitting into three separate groups as far as crime is concerned.

High crime countries where more than 24% of the population are victims of crime each year are Australia, England and Wales, the Netherlands and Sweden.

Canada, Scotland, Denmark, Poland, Belgium, France and America are medium crime countries where between 20% and 24% are crime victims each year.

Low crime countries which have crime victimisation rates below 20% are Finland, Spain, Switzerland, Portugal, Japan and Northern Ireland.

webTitle: Online grocers fail to deliver in the US

fields.headline: Online grocers fail to deliver in the US
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Online grocers, once some of the brightest stars in the dot.com firmament, have fallen to earth in the US, decimated by a wave of mergers and closures.
fields.body:
Online grocers, once some of the brightest stars in the dot.com firmament, have fallen to earth in the US, decimated by a wave of mergers and closures.

Kurt Barnard, president of the Barnard Retail Monitor, said: "No one has really been able to evolve a model that is capable of producing profits." He believes that even fewer consumers will be prepared to pay extra for their groceries to be bagged and delivered now that the US economy has slowed down.

Ken Cassar, e-commerce analyst at online research group Jupiter Communications, says that even in areas where local deliveries made sense - wealthy, urban neighbourhoods - the services have suffered from serious traffic congestion during the busiest times.

But some analysts remain optimistic. Jupiter forecasts the US online grocery market will increase from an estimated $700m (£485m) this year to $18.5bn in 2005. At these levels, online deliveries would represent just 3% of the total grocery market.

Among the companies that have tried to make online grocery business pay is Webvan. Perhaps the best known of online grocers, it has big problems. In the last quarter it annnounced a loss of $109m with full-year losses of $413 - almost double the previous year.

The company, which hired George Shaheen, the former head of managment consulting group Anderson Consulting, as its chief executive, has closed some operations and cut jobs to slow the pace at which it is consuming the $200m cash it has left in the bank. Shares of the company have dropped from a 52-week high of $18.50 to a low of 21 cents a share and it faces relegation from the Nasdaq stock market. It delivers more than 15,000 items in 10 US cities and had planned to move into 26 more cities by 2002.

Peapod was founded by brothers Andrew and Thomas Parkinson in 1989 after they read that consumers would rather not shop for groceries. Investors pulled the plug last year but Royal Ahold, the Dutch supermarket group, stepped in and now owns 51%. Some 100,000-plus members -largely working mothers - pay monthly dues of $5 plus order and delivery fees.

"No carts, no lines, no hassle" is the Netgrocer slogan. It may also be close to having no money. The New Jersey-based company uses Federal Express to post its goods. With a promise of delivery to 48 US states within three to four days, the company cannot offer staples such as dairy, meat or frozen foods.

Streamline.com, the company which installed refrigerators in customers' garages, closed in November. It had been unable to find any investor willing to continue to stem losses that added up to $56.4m by the beginning of this year.

Kozmo and Urbanfetch, two Manhattan delivery services set up within months of each other, took each other to court on alleged espionage charges. Kozmo expanded into several US cities and Urbanfetch into London. Both started to retrench as the downturn kicked in and last year started merger talks which were aborted.

fields.headline: At this price?  SSL International
fields.trailText: When Steve Plag talks, the City listens. The CSFB pharmaceuticals analyst, given the top accolade in Tuesday night's Reuters awards, has turned his charms on Durex maker SSL International.
fields.body:
When Steve Plag talks, the City listens. The CSFB pharmaceuticals analyst, given the top accolade in Tuesday night's Reuters awards, has turned his charms on Durex maker SSL International.

Recent months could hardly have been more uncomfortable for the Cheshire-based health care group which has been riddled with bitter boardroom infighting on the back of a profits warning issued in November.

These disputes came to a climax on Monday, with the departure of chief executive Iain Carter and confirmation that chairman Stuart Wallis is due to follow in July.

To Mr Plag and his team, who have reinitiated coverage of the stock with a "buy" recommendation, this is strong evidence that the company is positioning itself for a rousing performance.

In a new research note on SSL, CSFB insists that the group's share price is more than 80% undervalued, and predicts it will deliver "exceptional share price performance" over the next 12 months - praise indeed.

It points to the company's strong portfolio of core brands, including condom maker Durex and foot care producer Scholl, increased production capacity of surgical gloves and imminent product launches, as reasons for investors to be cheerful.

SSL is also likely to benefit in the short term from the launch of two new products - Scholl compression socks for long haul flights and Biogel Skinsense surgical gloves.

The comments were certainly enough to arouse interest in the City, where SSL shares rose 29p to 477.5p as the London markets closed.

Mr Plag blames a "stream of poor guidance" for the low rating, which has been caused by various factors, including financial targets and management uncertainty.

It estimates the excess stock levels are actually £100m - much higher than the firm's £40m figure - and predicts it will not be able to achieve its two-year targets. Investors should wait until the picture becomes clearer.

webTitle: Walkers warned to stay away from animals

fields.headline: Walkers warned to stay away from animals
fields.standfirst:
Rural rally at risk as hunts are suspended

Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: The British countryside could be more peaceful than at any time since the 1960s this weekend as farmers, walkers, horse riders and hunters advised people to stay clear of livestock until further notice, and not to travel into rural areas unless necessary.
fields.body:
The British countryside could be more peaceful than at any time since the 1960s this weekend as farmers, walkers, horse riders and hunters advised people to stay clear of livestock until further notice, and not to travel into rural areas unless necessary. The government has not yet warned people against travelling to or from rural areas, advising them only to avoid walking on farmland where there are animals.

But Ben Gill, president of the National Farmers' Union, said: "The outbreak of foot and mouth could become a disaster if people travel into rural areas. Everyone must be vigilant and journeys into the countryside where there is livestock should not take place."

But as confusion and hysteria built up, he also appealed for calm .

Leisure groups picked up the farmers' message and advised their members to stay away if possible.

After talks with farmers, the Ramblers Association advised its 250,000 members and all other ramblers to cancel all walks in affected counties and stay away from farmland throughout Britain until the crisis has eased. Foot and mouth can be spread 150 miles by air alone or on the wheels of vehicles and the soles of shoes.

There are no formal restric tions on people travelling except for farmers and their families who are on the affected farms. In the 10-mile exclusion zone in Essex, and around farms linked with the abbatoir or with suspected infections, formal restrictions are on the movement of animals not people.

Farmers with livestock everywhere are being asked to place disinfectant-soaked straw at the vehicle and foot entrances to their farms so the carrying of infection can be minimised.

The Ministry of Agriculture also suggested yesterday that farmers should ask walkers or visitors to keep away from fields or buildings containing their animals until the emergency is over.

All hunting by foxhounds, harriers, beagles, and staghounds was also voluntarily suspended for a week after meetings between masters of hunts. "It would be unfair to go hunting when farmers do not know if foot and mouth will spread. Farmers' interests are paramount," said Alastair Jackson, director of the Master of Foxhunting Association.

The decision was greeted with undisguised glee by hunt saboteurs and animal rights protestors who envisaged having a weekend off for the first time in years.

Also at risk is the Waterloo Cup, the controversial hare coursing event, which is due to take place near Southport next week. The hares are caught mainly in Norfolk and trucked up to Lancashire.

The crisis also gave hope to many anti fox-hunters in London that the countryside rally in London next month might be called off. The organisers, the Countryside Alliance, yesterday said that the March for Livelihoods and Liberty planned for March 18 and expected to attract up to 300,000 people, "will be reviewed depending on the spread of the outbreak".

Animal welfare organisations called on the Countryside Alliance to cancel the march in light of the foot and mouth disease outbreak. Campaigners described the march plans as "reckless and irresponsible".

The British Horse Association, which has 55,000 recreational rider members and approves more than 700 schools, advised riders everywhere to keep to the roads and off all bridleways and farmland. "Farmers are worried sick as it is. Let's not worry them unduly," said a spokeswoman.

The Jockey Club, in charge of horse racing in Britain, said no racing was yet affected, but recommended that all venues around the country set up "pads" of disinfected straw and that all vehicle wheels be sprayed. A point-to-point meeting at High Easter, near the restricted zone in Essex, was yesterday postponed.

London Zoo and other wildlife parks which have elephants, buffalo, yak, camels and llama, all vulnerable to foot and mouth, said precautionary measures would be taken, but were taking advice from the government.

The Corporation of the City of London, which manages the 8,000-acre Epping forest on the outskirts of London, yesterday banned the public from entering the large deer sanctuary and insisted that all vehicles entering it were disinfected.

Paris

 In solidarity with your US writers (Letters, February 20) would it not be appropriate to refer to George Bush as "President" Bush until such time as he wins a mandate from the US electorate?
Julian Dunn
Great Haseley, Oxon

 Like Mark Tran (G2, February 21) I enjoy living without a TV and have done for a dozen years. Cley-next-the-Sea, Norfolk

Totnes, Devon

Paul Whysall
West Bridgford, Notts

Crewe, Cheshire

fields.headline: 'Take on the dome and you'll drown in a barrel of red ink,' PY is warned
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The troubleshooter brought in to rescue the Millennium Dome yesterday launched a blistering attack on its former chief executive, PY Gerbeau.
fields.body:
The troubleshooter brought in to rescue the Millennium Dome yesterday launched a blistering attack on its former chief executive, PY Gerbeau, challenging his plan to maintain the site as a visitor attraction and questioning his business acumen.

In what he described as an "unbuttoned" account of his six months as executive chairman of the New Millennium Experience Company, David James insisted the visitor attraction was "never viable" and predicted anyone backing a similar scheme would "drown in a barrel of red ink".

"Dramatic under-resourcing" and inflated visitor estimates were also to blame for it being seen as a failure - and, in what will prove a further embarrassment for the government, he questioned whether it should have gone ahead with a project that finally swallowed £628m of lottery funding.

But the crisis manager's most savage attack was reserved for Mr Gerbeau, his former colleague, who plans to put in a bid to run the Greenwich site. Mr Gerbeau, a former vice-president of Disneyland Paris, is in talks with the Ministry of Sound entrepreneur James Palumbo and the Japanese bank Nomura, the govern ment's original preferred bidder.

While describing him as "a wonderful chap", Mr James said the proposal to rent the site at a hugely subsidised rate from the government and to maintain it as a visitor attraction would still cost "hundreds of millions of pounds" and said there was "a real question mark of its credibility".

"PY's a great guy, we all owe him an enormous amount, but he's a young man with great enthusiasm and he still has a little way to go in terms of bringing together the threads of commerciality," he said.

Asked about Mr Gerbeau's project, he responded: "If anyone can tell me what he's up to, let me know. We've have nothing specific from PY.

"It may be he has some masterplan which has not yet been unveiled, in which case it's time for him to put his plan where his mouth is. What we're getting at the moment is puff and the government can't be expected to give PY a sweetheart deal on a greenfield site.

"This place has been a victim of one dud financial estimate after another. How on earth can anyone expect the government to underwrite another in which they have no confidence?"

In a further blow to Mr Gerbeau, Mr James strongly hinted that he would prefer a bid by a rival consortium which includes the Duke of Westminster's Grosvenor Estates and other property companies, which are in talks with the BBC, the Tussaud's group and Harvey Goldsmith.

The group envisages developing land around the dome, while reopening the venue as a 55,000-seat concert venue and exhibition centre. "That sounds as ideal a plan as you could get," he said.

Mr James will have no influence over the final decision on who takes over the site.

A close aide to Mr James later said he had been "itching to get this off his chest" because he believes the possibility of the dome being reopened as a visitor attraction had not been sufficiently analysed. Asked whether it could be a viable attraction again, he said: "What do you mean again? It never was. It lost £131m as a trading entity in one year."

Mr Gerbeau said he was "very disappointed" by the comments: "I have the greatest of respect for David James, he is my friend and we made a great team. But I now repre sent another team of serious heavyweight business people who are putting together a very credible bid for the dome. This is not about PY doing something, this is about a serious team."

Mr James's attack came as he addressed journalists gathered to report on the imminent auction of much of the dome's contents - including a six-foot hamster, a giant seagull and pubic lice.

webTitle: Focus switches to Tyneside pig centre

fields.headline: Focus switches to Tyneside pig centre
fields.standfirst: Disease trail leads to possible source
fields.trailText: Disease trail  leads to possible source
fields.body:
A collection of concrete barns standing beside a low slurry silo up a winding lane on Tyneside has been identified as a possible source for the foot and mouth outbreak 300 miles south at an abattoir, near Brentwood, Essex.

According to villagers at Heddon-on-the-Wall, the barns are where pigs are delivered from all points north for fattening. They are held there for several months, then sent south for slaughter and to the continent and beyond.

For a so-called pig holding centre, Burnside farm was silent last night - although Philip Leadbetter, who says he rents it to a man from nearby Sunderland, Ronalde Waugh, thought that usually 200 or so animals were kept there.

Whether some animals were still inside was not clear - but a notice from the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, pinned to a big gate, beside the slurry tank, told its own story: "Foot and mouth disease -please keep out. Animals on these premises are under observation. Essential visitors only please."

Although the ministry said the case was linked to the first confirmed outbreak in Essex, and it had created an 8km (five mile) exclusion zone around the farm, there was little sign of extra security beyond a statement that warned of a "highly suspicious disease in a number of pigs on the premises".

Mr Leadbetter, who owns farm buildings and a house behind a bolted gate opposite the barns, said he gave up pig rearing five years ago.

"I lost interest in it," he said. "There's no money in this. If I'd had stayed in the job, I'd have been bankrupt. We came here in 1958 and there was nothing. We built everything. I carried on for 15 years after my father died and gave up after 10 years because I couldn't make it pay."

He was not surprised by the notice on the gate. "I thought it would probably happen. The trouble is all this suspect feed is coming from Europe and getting into our food chain - maybe someone was eating a ham sandwich, or something, with meat from abroad, and threw it into a field?"

Up the road from Burnside, beside the busy A69 dual carriageway, was another pig farmer. "I am saying nothing," he said. "This is just a precaution," said his wife. "Aye, just a precaution," he added.

Another farmer added that holding centres such as Burnside were necessary under new legislation to ensure animals are more safely transported.

webTitle: British brothers reach Australia by bike

fields.headline: 100 punctures and 6m pedals later, British brothers reach Australia
fields.trailText: Two British adventurers yesterday completed the fastest and longest human-powered journey in history when they swept past the Sydney Opera House after a 520-day, 17,000-mile journey by bike and sea kayak from London.
fields.body:
Two British adventurers yesterday completed the fastest and longest human-powered journey in history when they swept past the Sydney Opera House after a 520-day, 17,000-mile journey by bike and sea kayak from London.

Team leader Richard McLaughlin, 28, and his brother Andrew, 25, got lost in Lille, trod a diplomatic tightrope in Tibet, braved gunfire in West Timor and survived a shipwreck off Australia to complete their expedition.

"Not long before we left Britain it was said that the spirit of adventure was dead. We've shown that's not true," said an elated Richard McLaughlin at the finish line, some 6m turns of the pedals and 100-odd punctures from London. "To feel you're the first person to do something is pretty special."

The brothers said they hoped their feat - likely to be marked with the creation of a new category in the Guinness Book of Records - would help to inspire more people to use sustainable means of transport.

The expedition, which also featured Tim Stocks, 28, Nadine Potter, 27, and Richard Scriven, 29, who accompanied the McLaughlins for much of last year, has raised money for Sustrans, a charity which helps to build cycling networks in the UK, and Intermediate Technology, which develops the technical skills of impoverished communities.

After Andrew completed a degree at Cardiff University and Richard left his job at Thames Water, the brothers, originally from Taunton, set out from the Greenwich meridian line on September 22 1999.

They nearly didn't make it to France. Hitting a four-metre swell outside Dover harbour in their kayaks "we wondered whether we'd reach the other side," said Richard McLaughlin.

Finding the right road for Sydney was the biggest problem in several European cities. The brothers required a compass to navigate themselves out of the heart of Lille and Vienna, had difficulties reading signs in Bulgaria, and briefly cycled back the way they came in Thailand. The cyclists also required an army escort to protect them from bandits in the Great Sandy Desert, from Iran to Pakistan.

An arduous climb of 15,000ft in 100 miles to cross the Himalayas was the highlight of the trip, although the McLaughlins had to deal with sub-zero temperatures and tricky negotiations through Chinese border crossings in Tibet. They stepped into their kayaks again to island-hop through Indonesia.

In West Timor, a spot of passport trouble led the team to be fired on by a 10-strong group of gun-toting, knife-wielding police. Having set a record for the fastest and longest human-powered journey in Indonesia, the adventurers resorted to sail power from the island of Flores for the tricky crossing to Australia.

Approaching Australia in December, they hit a tropical cyclone and lost their compass. Richard McLaughlin and Ms Potter were rescued by coastguards, before the rest ran aground on Dundee beach, famed for its salt water crocodiles. Ten days and 560 miles later, they cycled into the enthusiastic embrace of their families and friends, who had flown out to see them reach Sydney.

The team admitted they had been lucky with injuries and breakdowns. Andrew was knocked off his bike in an Indian city, while Richard fell off hurrying through a Chinese checkpoint in eastern Tibet.

The brothers are planning further expeditions, but Andrew McLaughlin said: "First we'll have a couple of days' rest then it's back to the UK to face the real world and get back to work."

Senior Democrats, many of whom went to Bill Clinton's defence in the Monica Lewinsky scandal, have been lining up to disown him as the political damage to the party caused by the pardons scandal begins to sink in.

One of the most savage blows came from the only other living Democratic president, Jimmy Carter, who called the pardon of Marc Rich "disgraceful", adding that there was "no doubt" that Mr Rich's pardon was "attributable to his large gifts".

At a time when the party leadership had intended to mount a blistering campaign against President Bush's proposed tax cut and his Alaskan oil exploration plans, it has instead found itself on the defensive.

Whereas most Democrats had dismissed Mr Clinton's impeachment as a politically motivated witch-hunt focused on his private life, this time party leaders have been at a loss to think of words to mitigate their erstwhile leader's behaviour.

Senator Joseph Biden, who had previously anointed Mr Clinton "a great president", called the Rich pardon "totally indefensible". Senator Charles Schumer, another impassioned opponent of impeachment, said: "Pardoning a fugitive stands our justice system on its head and makes a mockery of it."

Political analysts say the scandal has done significant damage to the party. The leadership had been hoping to win back the evenly balanced Senate and House of Representatives in 2002, by which time they believed the stain of impeachment would have faded. Now the sleaze looks more indelible and the Democrats will find it harder to avoid being defined by the Clinton excesses.

Escaping the Clinton shadow has been made all the harder by the elevation of Terry McAuliffe, Mr Clinton's hand-picked candidate and close friend, to the position of party chairman. As the party's biggest fundraiser in the Clinton years, Mr McAuliffe was involved in a series of political donations now being examined, and he may become entangled in the Rich affair.

fields.headline: Pardons scandal engulfs Clintons
fields.standfirst: Revelation of fee paid to brother draws Hillary into controversy
fields.trailText: Revelation of fee paid to brother draws Hillary into controversy
fields.body:
The deepening scandal of the presidential pardons enveloped Hillary Clinton yesterday when it was revealed that her brother, Hugh Rodham, received $400,000 (£275,000) from a convicted drug trafficker and a convicted swindler for his successful efforts to secure their pardons.

Mrs Clinton's attempts to distance herself from the burgeoning scandal were undermined further by revelations that William Cunningham, her campaign treasurer, had also taken money to lobby for pardons for two businessmen, James Fanning and Bob Fain, who had tax evasion convictions in the 1980s.

The scandal, which began life as a relatively minor glitch during the Clintons' departure from the White House, has grown to huge proportions and threatens not only to overwhelm Bill Clinton's attempts to rehabilitate himself after the Monica Lewinsky affair but also to cast a long shadow over his wife's widely reported aspiration to run for the presidency.

As a congressional investigation into the payments began, Mr Rodham bowed to a joint appeal from the Clintons and returned the money he received from Glenn Braswell and Carlos Vignali. Mr Braswell was convicted of fraud and perjury for marketing a bogus baldness remedy, and Mr Vignali was sentenced in 1993 for his role in a cocaine ring. Both gave about $200,000 to Mr Rodham, a Florida lawyer, in exchange for his lobbying efforts, and both were pardoned by Mr Clinton in his last hours in office.

His successor, George Bush, refused to comment on the scandal yesterday, saying: "I've got too much to do _ to be worrying about decisions that my predecessor made." He promised that if he granted pardons he would observe "the highest of high standards".

Mr Rodham stayed at the White House for much of the Clintons' last weeks there, but Mrs Clinton denied knowing of her brother's involvement in the Braswell and Vignali cases. "He was a frequent guest at the White House. He's my brother. I love my brother. I'm just extremely disappointed in this misjudgment that he made," she said, adding that she was "heartbroken" by news of his involvement.

Mr Rodham's lawyer issued a statement denying any wrongdoing, saying that he had not discussed the pardon petitions with the president.

Mrs Clinton was elected junior senator for New York state in November, and it was widely seen to be her first step towards a presidential attempt. It now appears that Mr Cunningham, her campaign treasurer, also took money to lobby for two presidential pardons.

Mrs Clinton denied knowing about this, saying Mr Cunningham was "a fine lawyer and a fine man" who was simply performing a professional legal service for a client. Facing the press in the Capitol building yesterday, she referred questions about pardons to her husband and his staff. She said he had merely passed on clemency requests.

"There were many, many people who spoke to me and asked me to pass on information to the White House counsel's office," she said. "People would hand me envelopes and I would just pass them on. I didn't have any reason to look into them."

She said she believed there was "absolutely no connection whatsoever" between the money that Mr Rodham received and the pardons for Mr Braswell and Mr Vignali.

Dan Burton, a long-standing Clinton foe who is chairing the house inquiry into the pardons, announced that he was broadening the investigation to include Mr Rodham's involvement and had asked for information about the case from him and from lawyers for Mr Braswell and Mr Vignali.

His committee on government reform was already looking into the pardon Mr Clinton gave Marc Rich, the billionaire financier wanted for tax evasion and defying sanctions, whose ex-wife made substantial donations to the Democratic party and the Clinton presidential library.

Mr Clinton's lawyers handed over information about a dozen library donors yesterday, but Mr Burton was not satisfied and said he would subpoena the head of the library foundation for a full list.

Mr Clinton's lawyers called the original request a "fishing expedition".

A parallel Senate committee also intends to look into Mr Rodham's role.

Mr Clinton said in a statement yesterday that he could not recollect a conversation with Mr Rodham about the pardons. His former deputy White House counsel, Bruce Lindsey, said he could remember a "general conversation" with the president's brother-in-law about the cases.

Like the Marc Rich case, Mr Braswell's pardon and the commutation of Mr Vignali's sentence bypassed the normal justice department approval process.

Mr Braswell was convicted in 1983 of charges relating to his vitamin and health supplement business. Mr Clinton said that when granting the pardon he had been unaware that Mr Braswell was also under investigation for money laundering and tax evasion.

From the White House to the dog house

 The pardons

Bill Clinton issued 176 pardons two hours before handing over power:

Glenn Braswell

A businessman convicted of mail fraud and perjury in 1983. Paid Hugh Rodham, Hillary Clinton's brother, to lobby for a pardon, which bypassed the justice department.

Before the pardon was granted, federal prosecutors began investigating new allegations of money laundering and tax evasion.

Carlos Vignali

Sentenced to 15 years in 1994 for cocaine trafficking, he was released on January 20 after lobbying by Mr Rodham.

Together Mr Braswell and Mr Vignali paid Mr Rodham $400,000 in fees.

Marc Rich

The billionaire fugitive and his business partner, Pincus Green, who faced charges of tax evasion and trading with the enemy, were added to the pardon list in the early hours of Mr Clinton's last morning in office, over the objections of White House advisers. Mr Rich's ex-wife Denise had contributed nearly $1m to the Democratic party, $450,000 to the Clinton library, $70,000 to Mrs Clinton's Senate campaign and $10,000 to the Clinton legal defence fund.

Roger Clinton

The ex-president's half brother, a singer in a rock group, was convicted on cocaine charges in 1985. He was placed on the pardon list with special instructions that the pardon be reviewed only by senior justice department officials, not the FBI as normal.

Susan McDougal

A Clinton friend from Arkansas who was jailed on minor charges after she refused to implicate the Clintons in the Whitewater real estate deal investigated by Kenneth Starr, the independent counsel.

Harvey Weinig

Convicted of laundering $19m for the Cali drug cartel. The pardon cut his 11-year sentence in half, raising howls of protest from prosecutors, who said they had evidence that he had also been involved in a kidnapping plot.

 The White House furniture

The Clintons shipped large amounts of furniture out of the White House to their new home in Chappaqua, New York. But after some donors complained they had intended the furniture for the presidential living quarters rather than for the Clintons, the former first family returned $28,000 worth of furnishings and paid for $86,000 more.

 The gifts

Friends of the Clintons solicited rich acquaintances for gifts in the last weeks of the presidency. The Clintons later disclosed a total of $190,027 in gifts, including $7,375 worth of coffee tables and chairs from Denise Rich.

 The offices

Mr Clinton chose a penthouse suite in the exclusive Carnegie Hall Tower for his New York presidential offices. Most of the annual $700,000 cost would have been borne by the taxpayer. After a press and public outcry, he opted for cheaper quarters in Harlem.

webTitle: Complacency is a risky game in the global economy

fields.headline: Why complacency is a risky game
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the IMF and World Bank in Prague
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: On the Richter scale of emerging market crises, Turkey is somewhere between Russia's debt default in 1998 and the Brazilian devaluation a few months later.
fields.body:
On the Richter scale of emerging market crises, Turkey is somewhere between Russia's debt default in 1998 and the Brazilian devaluation a few months later.

The first threatened to bring down the global financial system and forced the US authorities to mount a £2.4bn bailout of a troubled hedge fund. The second shook the markets briefly but is now scarcely remembered outside Brazil.

So far the latest upheaval looks as if it has been contained within Turkey. But in an increasingly integrated global economy, pronouncing a crisis over is a risky game.

Last night Argentina was forced to reassure the markets that it has no intention of following in Turkey's footsteps and abandoning its currency's peg with the dollar.

In Turkey the signs of crisis are spectacularly evident. Earlier this week interest rates hit almost 5,000% and the stock market fell through the floor. On Wednesday the authorities gave up the struggle against financial market panic and allowed the lira to find its own level. It promptly crashed to more than 1m to the dollar.

Though the immediate trigger for the crisis was Monday's falling-out between the prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, and the president, Ahmet Necdet Sezer, over the government's willingness to tackle corruption, the underlying cause was the shaky state of the Turkish economy - a combination of an overburdened financial system and corrosive inflation.

In November the International Monetary Fund rescued Turkey from its last financial crisis in exchange for a package of belt-tightening measures. The centrepiece was a gradual revaluation of the lira against the dollar - a strategy which now lies in ruins.

So far the devaluation has acted as a safety valve for the most immediate pressures. Interest rates have fallen from the levels seen earlier this week and the stock market has recouped some of the week's losses. But it has also added to Turkey's problems.

Some £13bn of foreign debt is due to be repaid this year, and the lira's plunge has made these loans costlier to repay. In addition, Turkey's ambition to join the EU in the next wave of entrants has been dealt a blow.

In a bid to re-establish control of the economy, and retain the support of the IMF, Ankara has agreed to an inflation-targeting regime, but there is concern over whether it can put together a new package.

Turkey is not the only victim of this week's events. The IMF has been left with egg on its face at a time when its role in stabilising the global financial system is under scrutiny from a sceptical new administration in Washington.

webTitle: This is the virus that has closed the countryside

fields.headline: This is the virus that has closed the countryside
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
Special report: the countryside in crisis
Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: A "highly suspicious" new case of foot and mouth disease was found last night in pigs at a farm in Northumberland. It could be the source of the original outbreak of the virus, which has thrown the British farming industry into fresh crisis.
fields.body:
A "highly suspicious" new case of foot and mouth disease was found last night in pigs at a farm in Northumberland. It could be the source of the original outbreak of the virus, which has thrown the British farming industry into fresh crisis.

The development came as the countryside began to close down, with appeals for ramblers and horse riders to stay away, markets shutting up shop and the suspension of all hunting for a week.

The suspected outbreak in Northumberland, at Heddon-on-the-Wall, was traced by the Ministry of Agriculture because the farm had delivered pigs for slaughter to Cheale Meats at Little Warley in Essex, where the virus was first identified on Monday night. When vets arrived at the farm some of the remaining pigs were sick with symptoms similar to foot and mouth but no confirmation has yet been made.

Another case of the disease was confirmed in cattle at Great Warley, near Brentwood, inside the 10-mile exclusion zone around the abattoir. The zone had been extended from five miles early yesterday as a precaution. The new case is likely to have been spread by the wind.

All movements of animals, lorries and visitors to the Essex slaughterhouse and its neighbouring farm over the past three weeks were being traced yesterday. The investigation involves hundreds of inquiries as far away as Northern Ireland and Scotland.

The president of the National Farmers Union, Ben Gill, warned: "The outbreak of foot and mouth could become a disaster if people travel into rural areas. Everyone must be vigilant and journeys into the countryside where there is livestock should not take place."

Postmen were asked to leave mail at farm gates and farmers were asked to place disinfectant-soaked straw at access points to their land. At agricultural merchant CWG in Bury St Edmunds, Michael Walpole had run out of disinfectant by lunchtime yesterday: "We have had no notification from Maff [the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food] about what to do but we have sold out. I have also pulled all reps from farm calls."

All hunting by foxhounds, harriers, beagles, and staghounds was suspended for a week after meetings between masters of hunts. The British Horse Association advised riders everywhere to keep to the roads and off farmland.

In the Peak District, Bakewell livestock market cancelled a planned sale on Monday. A partner in the market, Alistair Snedden, said the outbreak could have far-reaching consequences for farmers: "I think the financial and emotional strain could quite simply be too much for some of them."

The ban on all animal exports, which was imposed on Wednesday night and is costing more than £1m a day, will be in force until Britain controls the spread of the disease, the European commission said. If the source of the contamination were pinpointed the ban could be limited to that region, a spokeswoman said.

Tony Blair, on a visit to Canada and the US, said the outbreak was "the very last thing that farmers need" in the aftermath of BSE. "This is a very, very tough time for them," Mr Blair said in Ottawa. "We have to contain the outbreak. We've taken the action necessary to do so, and we will look into the consequences for individual farmers, of how we help them, at a later time."

As fears spread to the continent, the French government ordered checks on the wind direction across the Channel.

The British Veterinary Association said it and Maff had put the country's 14,000 vets on "red alert". "Extreme surveillance is needed," said Eifion Evans, past president of the BVA.

Main points

 Ramblers advised to cancel all walks in affected counties and stay away from farmland throughout Britain.

 Riders told to keep to roads off bridleways and farmland.

 All hunting voluntarily suspended for a week.

 Farmers asked to place disinfectant-soaked straw at entrances to their farms.

 Postmen delivering to infected farms told to hand mail over at gates.

 Public kept from contact with Epping Forest deer.

webTitle: Fund to beat third world disease

fields.headline: Fund to beat third world disease
fields.standfirst:
Special report: globalisation
Taking charge of the drive against poverty
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown and Clare Short will announce plans on Monday for a multibillion-pound international fund to provide cheap vaccines against childhood diseases to developing countries.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown and Clare Short will announce plans on Monday for a multibillion-pound international fund to provide cheap vaccines against childhood diseases to developing countries.

The chancellor and international development secretary will use a London conference on children to unveil proposals for the fund, aimed at reducing the 10m deaths each year of children under five.

The plan is for the world's richest countries, the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the UN Children's Fund (Unicef) to guarantee a market for drugs produced by the pharmaceutical industry, and subsidise research costs.

It is intended to make up lost ground in meeting the aim of reducing world poverty by 2015, set at the UN social summit in Copenhagen in 1995.

Mr Brown said in an interview with the Guardian: "The loss of life is unacceptable ... there is a recognition now that unless we act together and are clear about who takes responsibility, the targets we have set will take longer to meet and in some cases may not be met at all. We are determined to move further and faster towards meeting the UN targets."

Two weeks ago the Guardian highlighted the problem faced by developing countries which cannot pay the huge bill for drugs needed to fight Aids and other epidemics.

Mr Brown believes it is time the G7 most industrialised countries used their influence as the dominant members of the IMF and World Bank to focus their attention on the 2015 targets: to cut infant mortality by two-thirds, put every child in primary school and reduce the number of people living below the breadline by half.

webTitle: Straw right to fix life tariff, judges rule

fields.headline: Straw right to fix life tariff, judges rule
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday saw off a high court challenge to his power to set minimum jail terms for murderers serving life.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday saw off a high court challenge to his power to set minimum jail terms for murderers serving life.

But the judges, who ruled that Mr Straw's powers to set tariffs was not inconsistent with the European convention on human rights, hinted that he might lose on appeal to the House of Lords. Two of the three judges indicated that they would have decided against him had they not been bound by earlier Lords rulings, which cannot be overturned by a lower court.

The judges gave permission for the two lifers who brought the test case, Anthony Anderson and John Taylor, to bring an appeal. Lawyers for the pair said they hoped to take the case to the court of appeal next summer and on to the Lords if they lost there. If they succeed it could open the way for Myra Hindley and other murderers given a "whole life" tariff to regain their freedom.

Anderson and Taylor had argued that to allow a politician rather than a judge to perform what was in effect a sentencing exercise was incompatible with the convention and in breach of the Human Rights Act.

The court rejected the arguments because of earlier judgments from the House of Lords and the European court of human rights, which held that the home secretary's role in fixing tariffs was an administrative rather than a sentencing function.

The pair's QC, Edward Fitzgerald, who also acts for Hindley, had applied for a declaration that judges, and not politicians, should set the minimum terms for mandatory lifers. The home secretary has already ceded the power to set tariffs for discretionary lifers - those sentenced to life for crimes other than murder - and for juvenile murderers sentenced to detention at her majesty's pleasure.

In Anderson's and Taylor's cases, along with hundreds of others, tariffs recommended by the trial judge and the lord chief justice were increased by the home secretary.

Dismissing their application for judicial review, Lord Justice Rose, sitting with Mr Justice Sullivan and Mr Justice Penry-Davey, said: "I conclude that parliament by primary legislation has conferred on the home secretary the power to fix the tariff for mandatory lifers."

Lord Justice Rose said the tariff procedure had been approved by the House of Lords and the propriety of the procedures had never been successfully challenged under European or domestic law.

webTitle: Mass rape ruled a war crime

fields.headline: Mass rape ruled a war crime
fields.standfirst:
Hague tribunal finds Serbs guilty of systematic enslavement and torture of Bosnian Muslim women

Special report: Yugoslavia war crimes
fields.trailText: Hague tribunal finds Serbs guilty of systematic enslavement and torture of Bosnian Muslim women.
fields.body:
Mass rape and sexual enslavement in time of war will for the first time be regarded as a crime against humanity, a charge second in gravity only to genocide, after a landmark ruling from the Yugoslav war crimes tribunal in the Hague yesterday which sentenced three Bosnian Serbs to a combined tariff of 60 years in jail.

In a judgment that is likely to have far-reaching implications for war crimes trials in Rwanda, Kosovo and East Timor, the tribunal elevated systematic rape from being a mere violation of the customs of war to one of the most heinous war crimes of all - a crime against humanity.

"This verdict is a significant step for women's human rights. Sexual enslavement in armed conflict is now legally acknowledged as a crime against humanity and perpetrators can and must be held to account," said Amnesty International in a statement after the decision.

The court ruled that the three veterans of the 1992-95 Bosnian war - who stood in silence as the verdict was read out - were guilty of the systematic and savage rape, torture and enslavement of Muslim women in 1992 in the town of Foca in south-eastern Bosnia. They were convicted on 19 separate counts.

"This is the first case where sexual slavery has been charged," the UN prosecutor Dirk Ryneveld said yesterday. "What sets this apart is that this is a case in which we have a large rape camp organisation. This is the first case of sexual enslavement and the only one with sexual assaults and no murders."

In the past international courts such as the tribunals set up in Nuremberg and Tokyo after the second world war have been reluctant to class wartime rape as a serious crime of war but the Hague tribunal took a much tougher line on the issue.

The judgment will give hope to thousands of surviving "comfort women" used as sex slaves by Japanese soldiers during the second world war who have been fighting in vain for recognition and compensation from the Japanese government.

The presiding judge, Florence Mumba of Zambia, described in graphic detail how the three Bosnian Serbs had in the summer of 1992 abducted girls as young as 12 and subjected them to appalling sexual torture in sports halls and a variety of "rape houses".

"The three accused are not ordinary soldiers whose morals were merely loosened by the hardships of war. They thrived in the dark atmosphere of the dehumanisation of those believed to be enemies," she told the court.

"Rape was used by members of the Bosnian Serb armed forces as an instrument of terror," the judge concluded at the end of the 11-month trial as she read out the verdict to the three accused.

"You abused and ravaged Muslim women because of their ethnicity and from among their number you picked whomsoever you fancied. You have shown the most glaring disrespect for the women's dignity and their fundamental human rights on a scale that far surpasses even what one might call the average seriousness of rapes during wartime."

Dragoljub Kunarac, 40, said to have been involved in a "nightmarish scheme of sexual exploitation", was given 28 years for rape and torture. Radomir Kovac, 39, was sentenced to 20 years for similar crimes. The third defendant, Zoran Vukovic, 45, was given a sentence of 12 years because prosecutors were able to produce less evidence in his case. He was, nevertheless, convicted of raping and torturing a 15-year-old Muslim girl who was about the same age as his own daughter.

The three had looked confident before the judgment was read out, shaking hands with their lawyers, but when the verdict was pronounced Kunarac sank slowly into his seat and shook his head.

In Sarajevo a group of Bosnian Muslim women reacted with fury to the sentences, which they regarded as insufficiently tough.

"We are shocked with the verdict. Justice has not been done, as the three received a minimum punishment for what they have done," argued Nezira Zolota of the Sarajevo association of former camp inmates.

Human rights groups estimate that tens of thousands of Muslim women and girls were systematically raped during the war. Many were deliberately impregnated so as to bear Serbian babies and advance the cause of ethnic cleansing.

fields.headline: Spy claim forces lie-test rethink
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Russia
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The FBI counter-intelligence agent accused of spying for the Russians for the past 15 years was given no lie-detector tests in that time even though he was one of the few at his agency with access to such a wide range of secrets, it was disclosed yesterday.
fields.body:
The FBI counter-intelligence agent accused of spying for the Russians for the past 15 years was given no lie-detector tests in that time even though he was one of the few at his agency with access to such a wide range of secrets, it was disclosed yesterday.

The bureau had rejected recommendations that its agents be subjected to polygraph tests more often. It did not want to undermine trust or uncover extraneous information that might damage agents' careers.

New agents are tested before being hired but those with long service are not, unless they are under suspicion. There were no questions about Robert Hanssen, 56, until last year. The FBI wanted to avoid the experience of the CIA, which has sidelined agents because of inconclusive test results.

The authorities say that Mr Hanssen, an FBI man of 25 years' standing, was caught red-handed five days ago dropping off classified documents near his suburban Washington home. The Russians are alleged to have paid him $1.4m (currently £965,000) in cash and diamonds. His lawyer says he intends to plead not guilty.

William Webster, a former director of both the FBI and the CIA who is heading an inquiry, said he would look at the bureau's use of lie-detector tests: "I would ask the question, 'What level of privacy are you willing to forgo to carry the substantial trust the country has placed in you?' "

But Nancy Polosi, a Democratic member of the House of Representatives select committee on intelligence, said: "I am not in support of indiscriminate use of polygraphs. We need to uphold the morale of our people and be respectful of their rights."

Mr Hanssen was said to have had full access to the details of counter-espionage against the Russians, documents from the CIA and the National Security Agency.

David Major, who was his boss, said: "There's only a few people in counterintelligence that have to know everything and he was one of them. Everything - all sources, all methods, all techniques, all targets. Some of the documents he gave them, I know what they are and I shudder."

Ed Curran, another former colleague, said: "This is a person who drew no attention to himself."

Herbert Romerstein, a former US Information Agency official, said: "He was a very skilled counterintelligence officer. He knew what things to do to avoid detection and he also knew what to do to create an image. He became the man no one would ever suspect: a religious man, a family man, a patriotic man."

webTitle: Visit those you jail, judges told

fields.headline: Visit those you jail, judges told
fields.standfirst:
Big shake-up aims to break cycle of crime

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Judges are to be told that they must follow the fate of the individuals they convict - perhaps by visiting them in prison, or at least by regularly reviewing the offenders' efforts at rehabilitation.
fields.body:
Judges are to be told that they must follow the fate of the individuals they convict - perhaps by visiting them in prison, or at least by regularly reviewing the offenders' efforts at rehabilitation.

The dramatic initiative is designed to break the cycle of reoffending and develop a culture of rehabilitation in Britain's overcrowded prison system. It will form the centrepiece of the government's 10-year crime plan to be announced on Monday.

Prisoners will be given credit with community sentences or early release if they show willingness to undertake job training or take part in literacy classes. The plan is directed at reducing reoffending by the 100,000 hardcore criminals. It is estimated that 10% of offenders accumulate at least half of all serious convictions.

The crime plan will also contain proposals for evening and weekend courts, drug courts, a wider social base for magistrates and the removal of most routine traffic offences from magistrates courts.

There will be moves, long advocated by Lord Williams, the attorney general, for an end to the culture of part-time judges such as recorders, and more training for the judiciary.

Ministers are also to propose reform to the "just desserts policy" in the 1991 Criminal Justice Act whereby the court was directed to take less notice of a criminal's previous convictions and instead sentence on the basis of the specific offence under trial. The 1991 act, piloted by the Tory home secretary Douglas Hurd, led to a fall in the prison population from 50,000 to 42,000.

The new conditions for prisoners on parole, or anyone charged with community sentences, is designed to end the so-called revolving door of 100,000 persistent offenders who leave and then re-enter prison.

Home Office research shows that within two years of starting a community sentence or finishing a jail term, over half of offenders - and nearly 80% of those with more than 10 previous convictions - will be back in court to be convicted for further offences.

Among these 100,000 persistent offenders, half are under 21, nearly two thirds are hard drug users, more than a third were in care as children, half have no qualifications, and three quarters have no work, or little or no legal income.

At present 67% of prisoners do not have the reading and writing skills to do 80% of the jobs in the labour market. The government will as a result place a new premium on literacy courses in prisons.

The crime plan will be presented by Tony Blair on Monday when he visits a home counties jail, the first prime minister in living memory to visit a prison.

A No 10 source said: "We are going to be the first government to take repeat offending seriously. The criminal justice system is based on just desserts for individual offences, but we want to stop people reoffending and move them onto the path back to a lawful life. We are opening up the agenda on this."

A criminal justice minister said the key was to ease the path from prison to work by repeatedly reviewing an offender's efforts to gain qualifications or end dependence on drugs. Ministers concede that criminals currently given short prison sentences or released on an electronic tag rarely receive any help once they are released on probation.

Balancing more frequent court reviews of the criminal's efforts to find work skills, Monday's plan will state that the courts must adopt a tougher sentencing policy towards reoffenders. As a result, the government will state that it has set aside 2,500 extra prison places, the equivalent of five extra jails. A third of the extra £700m set aside for the programme will be spent on rehabilitation programmes.

The classic Blairite balancing of opportunities and responsibilities has been adopted in drug treatment and testing orders, adopted last autumn, which allow anyone convicted of an imprisonable offence and tested positive for drugs to be given a community sentence so long as they agree to attend a regular drug treatment course. Anyone subject to an order can be sent to prison if they repeatedly fail to attend the rehabilitation course or are tested positive for drugs. Pilots of the drug treatment orders found a fall in drug use and reconviction rates.

The tougher sentencing policy for repeat offenders was expected to emerge as part of a Home Office review of sentencing policy due to be completed in May. Critics claim that the courts in effect quietly dropped the just desserts policy two years ago. They also say the parole board rarely releases without proof of the prisoner having undertaken some form of antioffending programmes inside.

Ministers believe specialist judges will be more self-confident and hand out tough sentences without fear of being overturned on appeal.

fields.headline: Vanishing point
fields.standfirst:
When you look hard at the figures, Britain's grand transport plans seem unlikely to go anywhere

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: When you look hard at the figures, Britain's grand transport plans seem unlikely to go anywhere, writes John Ware.
fields.body:
In South Africa this week, we learned what is really meant by the term "angry commuters." Broiling with frustration at yet another signal failure causing the cancellation of their trains home, 6,000 of them burned down Pretoria station. Thankfully we in Britain are still at the moaning stage. But the flames of frustration could yet be stoked here, especially if the government's majestic promises to rebuild our decrepit transport system over the next 10 years don't materialise.

"It has been delivery, delivery, delivery," said John Prescott at New Labour's last conference. Tell that to Londoners. Nearly four years on, the underground remains one of the most expensive, over-used, underfunded metros in the world. There is continuing deadlock between the mayor's American transport supremo, Bob Kiley, and the government over its public private partnership package. Mr Kiley believes that giving control of the tube's infrastructure to private companies is basically barking. It will not deliver a safe underground and threatens to replicate the mess the privatised rail network has found itself in. Mr Livingstone may yet take the government to court in an attempt to give Mr Kiley overall control.

But even if he wins, there might not be much to celebrate, because even the tweaked PPP remains a modest rescue package. We'll be fortunate if the increased capacity it generates keeps pace with forecast passenger growth. In other words we may not notice much difference.

What about the rest of Mr Prescott's "radical" 10-year plan for Britain which he says will deliver a "top class" road, rail and local transport system? For a politician who publicly excoriates spin doctors, his own at the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions have tried to do a pretty good job. Their press release boasts of the plan as an "£180bn investment package".

It's not actually £180bn - but £121bn - that meets the Treasury's definition of "investment" in the sense that it will buy a new railway or new road, or replace old bits of it; £59bn is old-fashioned public operating subsidy which roads and railways have always needed.

Mr Prescott himself has also done some spinning. He says the 10-year plan's £60bn for rail means "we are getting more rail investment for 10 years than the last 100 years". Of course this cannot possibly be true. All the new lines, their electrification, all the new engines and coaches, not to mention the £50bn pumped into British Rail between its birth in 1948 and death in 1994, add up to vastly more than £60bn.

For roads, the 10-year forecasts for reducing congestion, while allowing for a big increase in traffic, are also less than meet the eye. Overall the plan promises a 6% fall in "time lost due to congestion", a simple sounding but highly complex mathematical measurement which Phil Goodwin, professor of transport policy at University College London, says not even ministers understand. So Professor Goodwin - Mr Prescott's chief adviser for his transport white paper - has spent the last several months translating these forecasts into plain English. In many cases, he concludes, despite Mr Prescott's £58.6bn road building programme, travel conditions will worsen. At best, only a few seconds will be shaved off some journeys.

And perhaps not even this barely detectable gain will be achieved, for the government's forecasts seem not to have taken account of the disruption that the road building programme will cause. Also, they rely on the rail part of Mr Prescott's 10-year plan being delivered. This is already falling behind schedule and is short of money.

Of the £60bn for rail, £26bn comes from the public purse which at 2000/01 prices is only about £2.8bn more public expenditure than was spent over the past decade. However, very little of the plan's remaining £34bn is guaranteed, since this is down to Railtrack and the train and rolling stock companies to raise from the private sector.

The success of this PPP largely depends on there being a 51% increase in the number of passengers and 80% increase in freight. Only by generating this extra revenue might the financial markets be persuaded to loan the many billions required to increase the capacity of the presently over stretched network by resignalling and building new lines and stations.

These were the assumptions, which last July Mr Prescott described as "realistic", underpinning the 10-year plan before Railtrack managed to bring a functioning railway to its knees with the crash at Hatfield in October, five and a half years after privatisation. "Realistic" is not how these assumptions seem post-Hatfield, a crash that will cost Railtrack many hundreds of millions in compensation and restoring the 20,000-kilometre network to a state that is no better than it was when Railtrack became its custodians in 1994. Next year's profits are already blown.

Railtrack is now so broke it has been seriously contemplating scrapping up to £6bn worth of projects scheduled for the first half of the 10-year plan. Even then, its debt by 2003 is projected at £8bn and according to Deutsche Bank, a staggering £14.5bn by 2006. Banking covenants on this level of debt would require Railtrack to cover its more than £1bn annual interest payments with pre-tax operating profits of around £2.5bn. This is fantasy.

So, if Mr Prescott is to deliver his plan, it looks as if the chancellor will have to spend quite a bit more of his surplus to ensure that the public bit of the PPP becomes the dominant partner. If the 10-year plan's finances seem shaky, so does its timetable. Save for the upgrading of the West Coast Mainline and the Channel Tunnel Rail link, the details of most of the remaining projects have yet to be crunched by the Strategic Rail Authority (SRA), the new fragment Mr Prescott has added to an already fragmented railway. Orchestrating the expansion of stations, new freight lines, the needs of commuter services, interspersed with many more higher speed trains traversing an overpopulated country, all stitched together by legal contract through a multitude of different franchises, is a task of the most enormous complexity. The SRA's "strategic plan" was first promised last autumn. This was delayed to January, then February. Now there's just an "agenda" for the plan, it having been further delayed to this autumn.

In 1997 Mr Prescott said he would have failed "if in five years' time there are not more people using public transport and far fewer journeys by car. It is a tall order but I want you to hold me to it". The BBC's transport correspondent, Simon Montague, recently tried to do just that in a BBC Online interview with Lord Macdonald, the transport minister. But the Scottish TV tycoon, ennobled by Mr Blair to bring a steadying hand to transport, said his boss had been misunderstood. The challenge Mr Prescott had set himself was not to deliver a reduction in congestion, but a reduction in its growth.

Expectations, having been raised, are now being massaged down. Overspun plans whose benefits have been undetectable in this government, may barely be detectable in the next. "Cry Pretoria" could yet become the rallying call for Surbiton and Woking.

webTitle: Most western bombs missed Iraqi targets

fields.headline: Most western bombs missed Iraqi targets
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Fewer than half the missiles fired by Britain and the United States at radar installations around Baghdad a week ago hit their targets, the Pentagon disclosed yesterday.
fields.body:
Fewer than half the missiles fired by Britain and the United States at radar installations around Baghdad a week ago hit their targets, the Pentagon disclosed yesterday.

It indicated that computer software used in the missiles' guidance system was being considered as one possible cause for the failure rate, with bombs landing up to 50 metres from the sites.

"We have detectable damage on 38% to 40% of the radars and we still have some data coming in," said a Pentagon official who rated the results as mediocre at best.

The details emerged as US planes struck in northern Iraq for the first time since last week's attack, which was the biggest in more than two years. The US European Command said that yesterday's assault was in retaliation against Iraqi artillery which fired at western aircraft patrolling the northern zone where Britain and the US have prohibited Iraqi aircraft from operating.

A Pentagon spokesman had said earlier that last week's attack on five radar and communications installations - which Iraq now says killed three people and injured 25 - had achieved its objective of disrupting and degrading Iraq's air defences but would say little more for fear of helping Baghdad to prepare for any further bombing.

The 24 British and American planes were deployed because of intelligence that Iraq was integrating its air defences with fibre-optic links that would give it more chance of bringing down enemy aircraft. The US says the work is being done by the Chinese. Baghdad denies this.

"We have some concerns about the performance in about half the weapons because of what appears to be a consistent offset from the aim point," an American defence official said of last week's attack on on the radar centres.

"It implies a common cause whether environmental like wind, whether software or guidance, because it is consistent." Only eight strikes on about 22 radar units had been confirmed; eight others showed no apparent damage. There was not enough information to be sure about six more.

He bypassed some of the embarrassment over the missed radar units by saying that there was greater success against the nodes that link these units to command centres controlling the anti-aircraft system in southern Iraq.

"The way to disrupt the integrated air defence system is to go after computer vans, the electronics that link these things," he said. "The radar is less important. I don't think we've taken the possibility of further strikes off the table at all."

Colin Powell, the US secretary of state ,who is visiting the Middle East this weekend, has two main options for dealing with Iraq: sanctions and military action.

"Containment [of the regime] has been a successful policy and I think we should make sure that we continue it until such time as Saddam Hussein comes into compliance with the agreements he made" at the end of the Gulf war, he said.

But the secretary of state said six years ago in his autobiography: "Sanctions work best against leaders who have the interests of their country and their people at heart." He put the Iraqi leader in a different category, of those consumed by their own interests.

fields.headline: Clinton scandal deepens
fields.trailText: Hillary Clinton became embroiled in the scandal over President Bill Clinton's final day in office yesterday after it was revealed that her brother had received $400,000 (£275,000) for his successful attempts to secure pardons for a convicted drug trafficker and a convicted swindler.
fields.body:
Hillary Clinton became embroiled in the scandal over President Bill Clinton's final day in office yesterday after it was revealed that her brother had received $400,000 (£275,000) for his successful attempts to secure pardons for a convicted drug trafficker and a convicted swindler.

As Mr Clinton's reputation continued to nosedive amid a welter of revelations about the "cash for pardons" affair, Mrs Clinton, who was elected to the US Senate last year, said she was heartbroken by her brother's involvement.

Her attempts to distance herself from the affair were further undermined by revelations that a senior adviser in her election campaign had also been paid for his lobbying on behalf of two other convicts who were granted pardons.

webTitle: Names considered for manslaughter charges in Hatfield crash

fields.headline: Names considered for manslaughter charges in Hatfield crash
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Manslaughter charges against named individuals from Railtrack and its sub-contractors arising from the Hatfield crash are being considered by the crown prosecution service, industry sources said last night.
fields.body:
Manslaughter charges against named individuals from Railtrack and its sub-contractors arising from the Hatfield crash are being considered by the crown prosecution service, industry sources said last night.

Background briefings have been submitted by the British transport police to the service, which will make a decision in a few weeks.

The police have decided against corporate manslaughter charges, because they say there is no legislation for a successful prosecution. Labour is proposing legislation that will strictly define the responsibil ities of a company when faced with a major accident or incident in which it is directly involved. But this will happen only if Labour is returned at the next election.

The prosecution service said yesterday that it had yet to receive "the full file" from the police, and that inquiries were continuing.

Individual names are still being discussed. Industry sources said several candidates from middle management at Railtrack and its sub-contractors were being closely examined. However, it might be decided that even individual charges might be thrown out by the courts.

Yet the overwhelming evi dence from Hatfield has shown that both Railtrack and at least one sub-contractor at the site were officially aware of the poor state of the track 11 months before the accident last October, yet did not move quickly enough to prevent the crash.

Railtrack admits that a 20mph restriction should have been imposed months before the crash. The rail operating companies and Railtrack yesterday met Tom Winsor, the rail regulator, to review the post-Hatfield position. They were told Railtrack could not meet its promise to restore the network to normal working by Easter. Steve Marshall, Railtrack's chief executive, has al ready said it might take until the middle of the year.

Mr Winsor could take legal action against Railtrack to try to fine it for the failure. Railtrack said yesterday it hoped that the network would be "broadly normal" by Easter, but some trains might be "marginally better or marginally worse".

fields.headline: Good soldier
fields.standfirst: Nato leader savours Prague hospitality
fields.trailText: After a hard day at the office of the Czech prime minister and top-level talks about military issues, what better way to relax than with a glass of beer and a rousing oom-pah-pah.
fields.body:
After a hard day at the office of the Czech prime minister and top-level talks about military issues, what better way to relax than with a glass of beer and a rousing oom-pah-pah.

Nato's secretary general, Lord Robertson, donned an officer's cap of the first world war Austrian imperial army yesterday and quenched his thirst in a Prague pub at the invitation of the Czech defence minister, Vladimir Vetchy.

The U Kalicha pub was made famous by the novel Good Soldier Schweik.

The two, along with the Czech prime minister, had earlier struck a more serious chord in discussions about the necessary steps the Czech armed forces need to take to meet Nato standards.

"The Czech forces need to be smaller, they need to be lighter, they need to be more mobile, and they need to be reshaped in order to address the capability deficiencies that presently exist," Lord Robertson said after the meeting with the prime minister, Milos Zeman.
