webTitle: Leader: Turkey's problems aren't just economic

fields.headline: Edgy days in Ankara
fields.standfirst: The problems are not just economic
fields.trailText: The swift, sudden onset of the financial crisis now gripping Turkey has cruelly exposed to public gaze the fragility of its democratic institutions.
fields.body:
The swift, sudden onset of the financial crisis now gripping Turkey has cruelly exposed to public gaze the fragility of its democratic institutions. Problems posed by rampant sleaze triggered the row between Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit and President Ahmet Necdet Sezer. Mr Ecevit was certainly unwise to blow his top so alarmingly and may yet pay a heavy political price. But many if not most countries suffer corruption scandals. Just look at the Dumas trial in Paris, the Kohl affair in Germany, or Bill Clinton's present unedifying travails.

Turks face undoubted difficulties arising from their government's IMF-backed economic reforms. Only last December, an emergency $10bn infusion was required (and supplied). But Mr Ecevit's unlikely coalition of nationalists, social democrats and conservatives has made real progress since 1999 in cutting inflation, reducing the deficit and advancing deregulation and privatisation.

Lots of other countries have suffered similarly painful adjustments. In similar vein, the floating of the lira is likely to reignite price inflation in the short term and will increase pressure on public sector wages. But if reassuring statements from the IMF and the US Treasury yesterday are to be believed, the crisis need not spell an end to Turkey's economic reformation nor will it necessarily spawn an Asian-style international market meltdown.

What makes this Turkish crisis different, and potentially dangerous, is the way it has dramatised the public's deep-seated lack of confidence in the way their country is run. While the French or the Germans can be reasonably sure that official sleaze will be eventually be exposed if not punished, Turks have no such assurance.

While IMF belt-tightening may work elsewhere, Turks worry that in Turkey, "reform" will somehow end up favouring the wealthy elite, as has always been the way in the past. This lack of confidence feeds in turn on more fundamental concerns that the Turkish state has yet to establish a credible system of democratic governance that responds to the wishes of ordinary people, respects the rights of of ethnic and religious minorities like the Kurds and the Armenians, and is secure enough in its pro-western, secular credo to allow Islamists and leftists (and the media) to follow their beliefs and freely express their views.

The fount of all this distrust is the Turkish military. The author of three coups since 1960 and the silent nemesis of Islamist prime minister Necmettin Erbakan in 1997, the army continues to wield decisive, unaccountable, menacing influence.

This institutional weakness handicaps Turkey now, as it wrestles with its plunging currency. It handicaps its broader, future hopes of becoming a modern, prosperous, civil society. This democratic deficit also continues to undermine its key aspiration to join the EU. How Turkey's real rulers behave during the coming days will be closely watched.

fields.headline: Election tips for Labour
fields.trailText: In response to N Flint's questionnaire on Labour's performance (Letters, February 20): The government achievement that has made me the most proud: the Stephen Lawrence inquiry and the publication of the Macpherson report.
fields.body:
In response to N Flint's questionnaire on Labour's performance (Letters, February 20):

The government achievement that has made me the most proud: the Stephen Lawrence inquiry and the publication of the Macpherson report.

The one thing I would reverse: the attitude to asylum seekers; using their plight to play the race card, and particularly the iniquitous voucher system.

What are you most pleasantly surprised by? The use of the Parliament Act to force through the equalisation of the age of consent. The only time to my knowledge when they clearly put principle above expediency.

What are you most disappointed by? The gap between the rich and the poor has not been radically reduced.

What new government department would you like to see created? A ministry for renationalisation of transport and major industry, run by Dennis Skinner.

The five pledges: a more equal Britain working for a more equal world; legislation to force cancellation of third world debt by Britain and British companies; increased direct taxation and decreased indirect taxation; scrapping of all nuclear weapons; proper funding of health, education and transport through increased taxation of those in upper wage brackets.
Paul Patrick
Burnley, Lancs

 A more apposite question would be: "What makes you most ashamed?" I and so many other long-time Labour supporters, former party members and activists wonder how, at the next election, we can square it with our consciences to vote for such a shockingly illiberal party.
Jane Teather
London
teather@compuserve.com

fields.headline: TV: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: The Crimson Pirate | Life Is Sweet | The Hi-Lo Country | Ai No Corrida | Bram Stoker's Dracula | Live Futsal
fields.body:
Films

The Crimson Pirate
(Robert Siodmak, 1952)
10.10am, 4pm, Sky Cinema

Burt Lancaster's sword and teeth flash to good effect in this action-filled adventure about an 18th century pirate and an eccentric inventor leading Mediterranean islanders against a local tyrant. Lancaster and former circus acrobat-chum Nick Cravat perform truly daring stunts, tongues firmly in cheek.

Life Is Sweet
(Mike Leigh, 1990)
10pm, FilmFour

This is life as suburban nightmare, where ambitious restaurateur Timothy Spall plans to bring haute cuisine to Enfield; meanwhile his mate Jim Broadbent runs the greasiest of spoons, while wife Alison Steadman tries to keep charge of two outrageous daughters - Claire Skinner's laddish plumber and Jane Horrocks' bulimic sex maniac. Yes, it's all here, acutely observed, merciless but tender-hearted, and beautifully played under Leigh's multi-layered improvisations.

The Hi-Lo Country
(Stephen Frears, 1998)
11.55pm, Sky Premier

Another American excursion for Frears, though this postwar western doesn't match The Grifters, his brilliant 1990 take on that other staple of US cinema, the crime thriller. This has Woody Harrelson as Big Boy Matson and Billy Crudup as New Mexico cowboys and best buddies who are suddenly rivals for the love of Patricia Arquette's Mona: a far from original tale, but charmingly and handsomely told, thanks in large part to Oliver Stapleton's beautiful cinematography.

Ai No Corrida
(Nagisa Oshima, 1976)
12.10am, FilmFour

Controversy and censorship haunted Oshima's erotic tour de force and its partner, Ai No Borei. And it's hardly surprising: concerned with the confrontation of taboos, with voyeurism and the exploration of the limits of sexual obsession, it depicts in graphic detail a couple (Tatsuya Fuji, Eiko Matsuda) in 1930s Japan locked into a private realm of never-ending arousal, growing increasingly sado-masochistic. But aside from the hardcore elements, it's a moving and deeply humane work.

Bram Stoker's Dracula
(Francis Ford Coppola, 1992)
1.55am, FilmFour Coppola reads the great gothic tale as a grand amour: in the blood-weltered middle ages, Gary Oldman's grieving Dracula condemns himself to the undead when his woman dies. He exists in torment for centuries until, in London, he discovers her living image in Winona Ryder's beautiful Elisabeta. Visually ravishing, it's powered by Oldman's amazing performance as a love-mad, merciless beast. Anthony Hopkins plays vampire slayer Van Helsing, Keanu Reeves is there as Jonathan Harker.

Paul Howlett

Sports

Live Futsal
10am, 2pm, British Eurosport

It's never quite hit the big time here, but Futsal is big elsewhere - particularly in Spain, who have hosted every European Championship so far (there have only been two), winning one and losing to Russia in 1999. This time the frantic five-a-side footballing event has moved to Moscow, but Spain remain favourites. They start against Poland at 2pm.

Simon Burnton

fields.headline: Radio: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Mahler And Klimt | Knowledge And A Girl | Hollywood At War
fields.body:
Fans of Mahler will no doubt be familiar with the story David Huckvale relates in Mahler And Klimt (Radio 3, 8pm). Artistic milieus tend to overlap, but in the case of these two artists there was a common physical thread - Alma, the woman who posed for Gustav the painter and married Gustav the composer.

The idea of fairy and folk tales as veiled repositories of adult wisdom for little girls has been with us for decades, but the subject is perennially intriguing, as Howard Barker's Knowledge And A Girl (Radio 4, 9pm) demonstrates. With a radical reworking of Snow White, Barker makes the "wicked" stepmother the focus of his play, rather than the simperingly sweet girl who stars in versions by Walt Disney and the Brothers Grimm. Barker aimed to upturn the audience's traditional sympathies, so he focuses on an infertile wife and ineffectual husband at the expense of dwarves, pretty little girls and handsome princes.

Hollywood films may see entertainment as their priority but they have rarely lacked a political context. Hollywood At War (Radio 2, 10pm) looks at how the big studios responded to the United States' entry into the second world war. Morale-boosting films of the Mrs Minniver ilk were only part of the tale; stars entertained the troops, some served in combat units, while in peacetime the war film became an increasingly popular but sanitised genre.

webTitle: Letter: Don't listen to the BMA

fields.headline: Don't listen to the BMA
fields.trailText: The knee-jerk response of the BMA to Alan Milburn's creative pay offer shows how little they represent the vast majority of NHS consultants (Golden NHS handcuffs on offer to consultants, February 22).
fields.body:
The knee-jerk response of the BMA to Alan Milburn's creative pay offer shows how little they represent the vast majority of NHS consultants (Golden NHS handcuffs on offer to consultants, February 22). As few as 6,000 of Britain's 22,000 hospital consultants undertake any private practice and major earnings are concentrated in those specialities which have long NHS waiting lists - the so-called perverse incentive.

Many working in frontline specialities such as medicine and paediatrics cannot accrue waiting lists, as the sheer clinical urgency of our patients demands an immediate response. We have seen our hours of work steadily rise as we struggle to provide a high-class service in the face of ever-rising public expectations. At last the new pay deal on offer can reward those of us who are fully occupied with NHS duties. A clearer separation of NHS and private work has long been overdue, and the new deal on offer will enable those who wish to undertake private work to have their lesser NHS commitment rewarded at a lower level than those of us who only work in the NHS.

So don't listen to the unrepresentative voices of the BMA: there are many of us who welcome Mr Milburn's creative and positive pay offer. At last we have an opportunity to remove the perverse incentive of the waiting list as the major driver to health care planning in this country.
Prof Anthony Nicholls
Consultant physician, Royal Devon & Exeter Hospital
anicholls@talk21.com

Many working in frontline specialities such as medicine and paediatrics cannot accrue waiting lists, as the sheer clinical urgency of our patients demands an immediate response. We have seen our hours of work steadily rise as we struggle to provide a high-class service in the face of ever-rising public expectations. At last the new pay deal on offer can reward those of us who are fully occupied with NHS duties. A clearer separation of NHS and private work has long been overdue, and the new deal on offer will enable those who wish to undertake private work to have their lesser NHS commitment rewarded at a lower level than those of us who only work in the NHS. So don't listen to the unrepresentative voices of the BMA: there are many of us who welcome Mr Milburn's creative and positive pay offer. At last we have an opportunity to remove the perverse incentive of the waiting list as the major driver to health care planning in this country. Prof Anthony Nicholls Consultant physician, Royal Devon & Exeter Hospital anicholls@talk21.com

webTitle: Did the earth move for you?

fields.headline: Did the earth move for you?
fields.trailText: Horizon | Trisha
fields.body:
There's something oddly rewarding about a paradox. Absurd statements that are true, or are possibly true, are always delicious - in a Freudian way, one suspects - and can be quite tickly. Simple paradoxes are the best kind, my personal favourite being "I always tell lies." More complex ones can lead to nose bleeds. Thinking too much about Bertrand Russell's paradox, for example, can cause your brain to drip out of your nose. Along with fur-trimmed anythings (other than live animals, of course), this isn't a good look, despite what you might hear at London Fashion Week.

If you haven't heard of Russell's paradox - and if you have a life, why would you? - it arises within naive set theory by considering the set of all sets that are not members of themselves. Such a set appears to be a member of itself if, and only if, it is not a member of itself. Some sets, such as the set of all teacups, are not members of themselves. Other sets, such as the set of all non-teacups, are members of themselves. Call the set of all sets that are not members of themselves S. If S is a member of itself, then by definition it must not be a member of itself. Similarly, if S is not a member of itself, then by definition it must be a member of itself. Clear? Good.

Like I said, my favourite is "I always tell lies."

I mean it.

Anyway, it was the paradox of the runaway freeze, and whether the rather eccentric group of scientists could square that particular circle, which kept Horizon (BBC2) so watchable. The boffins - one beardy, one squeakily voiced, one big and burly - were trying to prove that 600 million years ago, the whole world was covered in ice, even the tropics. Orthodox wisdom, as is its wont, scoffed at such a claim. If the whole world was covered in ice, it would have been so cold that it could never have thawed. Everything would be dead and we wouldn't be here. There was a far simpler solution: aliens. No, not really. The simpler solution was continental drift. The rocks must have been deposited in Namibia before Namibia was where it is today.

Continents, you may be interested to know, move at the same speed as your fingernails grow. It takes 400 million years for the continents to move from the polar regions to the tropics. I think this means that if you let your fingernails grow for 400 million years, they 'd stretch from the equator to the South Pole. Handy if you wanted to scratch a penguin from really far away.

But I digress. Beardy, Squeaky and Burly had magnetic rocks with which to refute the simple solution. The magnetism of these dropstones proved that they hadn't left Namibia where it is today, so the country had once been frozen. But - and there's always a but when Horizon seems all sewn up after 20 minutes - orthodoxy wasn't prepared to lie down and surrender. So the challenge for Beardy, Squeaky and Burly was then to solve the paradox of the Runaway Freeze by rewriting the rules of conventional science. This involved imagining what could have warmed up the snowball earth (no, not aliens, but a build-up of carbon dioxide from erupting volcanoes), musing on how tremendously violent weather, including acid rain, lasted over a century and blew away the carbon dioxide, and explaining how life had managed to survive on snowball earth throughout (the ice was very transparent and had allowed bacteria in the sea under it to photosynthesise).

Watching Beardy and chums weave their windy, windy story thus far was jolly enough, but the ironic coup de grce came when it was revealed that snowball earth and its defrosting led to the big evolutionary burst of which we are the end result. Hard to believe when watching Trisha (ITV), but true nonetheless. ("You're An Embarrassment" was the title of yesterday's programme, which saw men dressed up as Ali G and a Twiglet.)

But just when you think, "What an intelligent, unmelodramatic, quality Horizon that was", they go and spoil it by coming over all Armageddon. Ominously warning that since no one knows why or how ice ages come about, it could happen again and everything would die. "Including us." Well, technically, that's true but, as the programme itself admits, not for millions of years. That's a time scale not really worth losing sleep over, is it? Not unless you're growing your nails to scratch a penguin.

fields.headline: Private lives
fields.standfirst: My wife thinks my teenage son from my first marriage should live with his mum. But his mum doesn't want him. What to do?
fields.trailText: My wife thinks my teenage son from my first marriage should live with his mum. But his mum doesn't want him. What to do?
fields.body:
When I remarried three years ago my 12-year-old son (then my only child) chose to live with me and his stepmother. His mother was very upset but accepted his choice. Three years on, my wife and I have just had a baby and my son is, at 15, going through a rebellious phase, so much so that my wife thinks it would be better for him to go back to live with his mother. But she says she is not prepared to be "switched off and on". She has a boyfriend and intends to work in Germany for a year. She wants our son only to spend holidays with her. In the meantime, to give everyone breathing space, my son is staying with my parents who live near his school. They adore him but feel he should be with one of his parents. How can I best tackle this?

Ask him what he wants

Three years ago your son's decision seemed acceptable to all, except your ex-wife. Now, because of the baby, your second wife wants him to go away for a while and your first wife does not want to be made a convenience of; besides, she wants to work in Germany, perhaps for more than one year. When I remarried, my second wife's 16-year-old daughter said if I came to live in her mother's house she would move out. We gave her a self-contained flat in the house.

You don't say if you have asked your son what he wants. The main options may be for him to stay put or live temporarily with his grandparents. He will be working for GCSE next year and his (boarding?) school will give him a certain degree of stability. Answer this question honestly: how do you value your relationship with your son?

Frank Maddern, Surrey

Seek professional advice

I have been in a similar situation, and I can understand the very strong feelings around the issue of fragmented families and delicate new relationships.

The most vulnerable person here is your 15-year-old son. I can only imagine his churned-up feelings of bewilderment, rejection, jealousy, rage and confusion - all of which are normal reactions to being that age, but made worse by his predicament. He needs to be shown that he is loved and wanted. He appears to be so alone while your wife and yourself have established new partnerships.

I feel for you, too, as the person caught up in the middle of the opposing standpoints of both your wife and ex-wife. You don't say why the first marriage ended - could that have contributed to your son's distress?

I wish now that I had sought outside help when I was involved in a similar problem - an external view of the situation would have helped avoid a great deal of heartache. I suggest that you do that - you have taken the first, very brave step, in contacting the paper.

Name and address withheld

Trust the grandparents

In Britain, received wisdom has it that a child is always better-off with at least one of its parents. In many other cultures it is seen as normal, even beneficial, for children to divide their time between several homes. Provided that your parents are reasonably fit and energetic, and not excessively over-indulgent, the best thing might be for your son to remain with his grandparents for the foreseeable future. The worst thing would be for him to be in a situation where he is not wanted. At a difficult stage in my life, my son spent a year with his newly retired grandparents. All parties benefited from the arrangement. One or two English people seemed to think this was an odd situation: my Asian friends and relatives saw nothing odd in the arrangement.

Mary Searle-Chatterjee, Manchester

Seek a solution together

Take a look at this through your teenage son's eyes: you see rebellious behaviour, but perhaps he's feeling insecure. If he is, how do you imagine he feels to be shuttled around between parents and grandparents who are all (from his point of view) saying "I don't want him, you have him" to each other?

I say this as someone who once was a rebellious teenager, also "sent away" by my parents. Fortunately, I was sufficiently rebellious to protest at my fate being decided without my input because I didn't want to be sent away from my boyfriend, friends and school as well as my family. I was eventually given a choice - it eased the pain of apparent rejection and having some control over my own life made me feel more like an adult (so I started behaving more like one).

Treat him like an adult - explain the problems and his choices and listen to what he says in reply. Seek a solution together.

Name and address withheld

Stop being selfish

And they say couples who choose not to have children are selfish! To describe any 15-year-old as "rebellious" is like saying grass is green. So now you have a new baby, your 15-year-old is surplus to requirements. If I were him I'd contact social services and ask to be placed with caring foster parents until I was old enough to look after myself. Let's hope his experience of "family" life will not have put him off forming relationships in the future. He surely hasn't had much luck or encouragement so far.

Sheila Harrison, Wales

Next week

Three and a half years ago my much-loved surviving parent died. Two months later my partner of 18 years left me for someone he had been having an affair with. I was left with debts. I have lots of lovely people in my life - siblings, nieces, nephews, godchildren, good friends and a good social network. I have switched to a worthwhile and interesting job, have paid off the debts and sorted out the legal problems on our jointly owned flat. However, I still feel overwhelmed by depression. I have had counselling, bereavement counselling, psychotherapy, drug therapy, and hypnotherapy. I have taken holidays and have spent money on nice things to do. But on an almost daily basis I think about suicide. I have no interest in my appearance, finding a new partner, sex, making new friends or planning for the future. I have become horribly forgetful about other people and their needs. Can anyone suggest what I can do or try, to help me recover from this unhappy existence?

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Looming large
fields.trailText: Cotswolds
fields.body:
Cotswolds

The architectural heritage of the handloom weavers - disproportionately large windows designed to admit light to the domestic loom - may still be seen in the cottage lanes of Cam and Dursley.

More surprisingly, techniques of handloom weaving - the classic example rehearsed by economic historians of technologically occasioned instant redundancy - are still practised there today.

I saw them, albeit in a factory setting, at a local company which recently moved from the Old Rope Works in Union Street, their base from 1890, to an industrial estate nearby.

Richard, fourth generation of the Harrold family to run the factory, showed me the process. They make endless drive belts - technically, rotary moulding web - for the biscuit industry, by a handloom process which employs a workforce of 18, starts with bobbins of best Egyptian cotton, and ends with endless belts - usually over a metre wide, and polyurethane sealed - which convey the dough into the continuous ovens so that the biscuit companies can bake the custard creams which serve the nation's sweet tooth. United Biscuits and Burtons buy the belts to feed their baking processes.

P&S Textiles, now a subsidiary of a Wetherby textile company, also have an export trade - their endless belts go to Korea and Mexico. During last century's European hostilities they used the same techniques to manufacture parachute webbing for the war effort.

I was intrigued by the hidden history of this ongoing and profitable survival of a weaving technique which still depends on the handloom skills of the operatives. Ned Ludd would be surprised.

fields.headline: Radio review
fields.standfirst: Club sandwich with Mayo to go
fields.trailText: Club sandwich with Mayo to go
fields.body:
The big story this week: the revamp of Radio 1's daytime schedule. Simon Mayo, a man long out of time on the station, is gone. Other people, who already present shows, get to do so for longer and at slightly different times. That's about it. You can spin it into something sexier - blonde women in the morning, brunette men in the afternoon - but the only significant change is that much of the day, 10am-3pm, is now in the safe hands of Jo Whiley, Mark Radcliffe and Lard, DJs who know their music and make their disdain for chart pap clear.

Otherwise it's business as usual, with Sara Cox, funnier sans Rajesh Mirchandani, but still saying "layday!" too often, and Chris Moyles still being, well, Chris Moyles. "What she should have done," he said on Wednesday, about a woman with "bigger teeth than Shergar, but a nice rack, beautiful breasts"... "was to pull her sweater up over her head."

Something of a relief after this, you might think, to tune into LBH Radio, the Colchester-based gay station transmitting (1386AM) from 9pm each night, on the internet (www.lbhradio.com and Sky Digital 24 hours a day. With coverage to Moscow and Crete they have a potential audience of 650m, but while digital and internet radio remain in their infancy, and AM-listening is a masochistic activity, the reality will be a fraction of that.

The shows will have to improve too, if this is to become essential radio. The Scene, presented from 9pm each night by Peter Reede and Baby Jane, repeats the conventional chart music plus cheesy chat formula, except that the chat has a pink tinge to it. News items lead with gay rights issues - for example, Eminem's duo with Elton John at the Grammys is followed by foot and mouth disease (not connecting the two, you understand) and the chat between songs includes stories you wouldn't find elsewhere, like the imprisonment of two Egyptian men for setting up a gay website.

This is all fine, but the format surrounding it remains depressingly familiar. Reede and Baby Jane say things like "that one's so hot" about Shaggy's new single; jingles have new content but stale style (cue deep mid-Atlantic drawl: "radio that's proud to be born this way"); there are lots of ads for mobile phones.

To keep us listening, the presenters endlessly flag up discussion and songs to follow. There are only so many references you can make to forthcoming chat about Dannii Minogue's health. Sure, LBH reveals how avowedly straight most radio is, but also reminds us how stiff most commercial stations are. Both need to be tackled for this to feel radical.

fields.headline: Words over language
fields.trailText: It was a great satisfaction to read your article about English speakers and foreign languages (Can you say that in English? G2, February 21). Moreover, it was about time somebody dared to touch this subject, surely the most talked among non-native English speakers in the UK.
fields.body:
It was a great satisfaction to read your article about English speakers and foreign languages (Can you say that in English? G2, February 21). Moreover, it was about time somebody dared to touch this subject, surely the most talked among non-native English speakers in the UK. When I moved here, people at recruitment agencies (and even at government offices) would talk nonsense just to burst out with laughter when I would ask "pardon?" But the worst is when an English speaker comes to our country and forces us to speak their language and treats us as if we were quite slow.
Daniel Polanco
London
daniel.polanco@allout.co.uk

 Two weeks ago I spent the weekend in Brussels, accompanying five 15-year-old pupils to the Young Enterprise Trade Fair where we took part in a competition conducted in French, "Trois Minutes pour Convaincre". Just before our journey home, we visited a tea room in the Grand Place, where one of our pupils in cautious but perfect French ordered "un chocolat chaud, s'il vous plat" or similar. The waiter replied: "So, that's three hot chocolates and two coffees." Can anyone explain to me what purpose that served, other than to make them feel silly and to ensure that on any future occasion they will speak English? All youngsters take a foreign language at school now, and yet the BBC insists on putting a voice-over on any news items where there is a non-English speaker. Sub-titles would be so much more useful.
Jean Holmes
Clitheroe, Lancs
jeangeoff@aol.com

 If the attitude of the younger generation in this country is anything to go by, the situation regarding the speaking of foreign languages is not set to change anytime soon. An online computer gaming newsgroup to which I subscribe has recently been flooded with messages from disgruntled English-only speaking gamers deploring foreign players' preference to communicate in their own language among themselves rather than in what they dub "the language of the game", ie English. Which is, to say the least, an extremely parochial attitude coming from world wide web users.
María P Hoskins
London

 How about an article on British linguistic competence? As a far from brilliant schoolboy, I taught myself enough German to follow a Hitler speech and enough Russian to understand Moscow Radio. Using both languages in three years' army service in Germany, I met other self-taught linguists and at Cambridge quite a number.

Every penny earned in my working life - and now in retirement - I owe to my command of German and Russian. My son, an excellent German-and-Russianist, has worked in both languages for the past 20 years. We each of us know many, many fine British linguists and are in no doubt that we, as a race, are, as linguists, inferior to none!
George Bird
Okehampton, Devon

fields.bodyText: It was a great satisfaction to read your article about English speakers and foreign languages (Can you say that in English? G2, February 21). Moreover, it was about time somebody dared to touch this subject, surely the most talked among non-native English speakers in the UK. When I moved here, people at recruitment agencies (and even at government offices) would talk nonsense just to burst out with laughter when I would ask "pardon?" But the worst is when an English speaker comes to our country and forces us to speak their language and treats us as if we were quite slow. Daniel Polanco London daniel.polanco@allout.co.uk  Two weeks ago I spent the weekend in Brussels, accompanying five 15-year-old pupils to the Young Enterprise Trade Fair where we took part in a competition conducted in French, "Trois Minutes pour Convaincre". Just before our journey home, we visited a tea room in the Grand Place, where one of our pupils in cautious but perfect French ordered "un chocolat chaud, s'il vous plat" or similar. The waiter replied: "So, that's three hot chocolates and two coffees." Can anyone explain to me what purpose that served, other than to make them feel silly and to ensure that on any future occasion they will speak English? fields.headline: The great pudding scandal
fields.standfirst: You are on a plane, your food tray in front or you. Do you eat the desert? Well, many of us don't, and hundreds of millions are thrown away every year.  Henry Porter launches a one-man crusade to end the waste
fields.trailText: You are on a plane, your food tray in front or you. Do you eat the desert? Well, many of us don't, and hundreds of millions are thrown away every year. Henry Porter launches a one-man crusade to end the waste
fields.body:
A couple of hours into a transatlantic flight two years ago my eyes came to rest on the meal trays around me. My neighbours had tucked into the salad and then a choice of fish, chicken or vegetarian main course, but had all sternly denied themselves the dessert - a confection of sponge and bakers cream sandwiched between two brittle chocolate wafers.

There was nothing wrong with the pudding; in fact, I ate it all. But this must have been one of the very few times that I have. For there is an unspoken rule that to swoop too eagerly on the in-flight sweet is uncool. This particularly applies in business class, which is full of trim executives who seem to view the issue of pudding consumption as little less than a psychometric test. To eat the pudding manifestly compromises your fitness for battle and ascent.

This is scarcely rational. Most of the business-class passengers were disdaining a slightly upgraded version of our pudding for a selection of cheese - triangles of cheddar, stilton and brie, biscuits and one or two grapes. Some even took port or brandy, too. So, plainly the decision to jettison the pudding was not taken on health or dietary grounds.

Suffering only usual restlessness on a long flight, I decided to broaden my survey and took a stroll round the cabin. I found that about six out of 10 chocolate sandwiches had been ignored. Some had been tried and then rejected, while the rest were eaten. The wastage was about 65%.

Over the next year or so during which I took 25 flights while researching a book, I witnessed much the same pattern, although the rates of consumption did vary. I estimated the minimum dessert wastage to be about 40% and the maximum 75%. I began to wonder why airlines do not simply calculate the average consumption and cater for that number, rather than offering desserts to everyone.

But this course would challenge two subtle conventions of air travel. The first is that most airlines, however modest, like to think of themselves as providers of comfort, even luxury. The idea of a passenger going without pudding and then leaving the aircraft feeling hard done by troubles them. Second, to remove the standard dessert from the menu would penalise all those people who derive pleasure from conspicuous self-denial.

Airlines, one suspects, have come to the conclusion that eating or rejecting pudding in the air gives roughly the same pleasure to different sorts of people. Naturally, it is never easy to gauge which sort of people you are about to carry and there is no attempt made by the airlines to ask passengers when they book their flight, or when they check in, whether they are pudding eaters. "Dessert, or non-dessert section, madam?"

As you become gripped by the airline pudding issue, as I have been, you wonder at the vast waste and wretchedness caused by our failure to address it like adults.

Let's take the misery of the airline chef first. Worldwide, there must be hundreds, maybe thousands of men and women who enter the catering profession with the hope of a fulfilling career, only to end up in the dead end of producing millions of puddings that are thrown away. Nothing could be more fruitless and dispiriting. Occasionally you can sense a pudding chef at the end of his tether, as I did last year during a US domestic flight when I was confronted with a greenish, near-viscous substance (think of Swarfega cleaning gel) bearing morello cherries and stewed figs. What was next for this man? Insanity? A life on the streets raving about pannacotta and lime grass sauce?

Still, one has to admit that airline caterers are a robust breed. After 30 years in the business, George Banks of British Airways still works up enthusiasm for air meals. Aside from being the likely author of the phrase "retro dessert" (blancmange, bread and butter pudding, spotted dick, lemon and meringue pie), he is also menu and service style development manager with BA and is exceptionally knowledgeable about puddings.

He doubts my figures, because he says airlines such as BA sometimes have "inbound checks", which means that a team of catering researchers go though hundreds of used trays to see what has and hasn't been eaten.

He concedes that it is not a particularly nice job, but they do it to establish whether a cold rice pudding has gone down well or not (I'd guess the odds are on not). Besides this there are criteria which every pudding ever served on BA is judged by - simplicity, tastiness, healthiness, authenticity, variety, seasonality and visual appeal. He points out that pressurisation results in a loss of taste and that chefs have to try particularly hard to entice, and then satisfy, a passenger with dessert.

Whatever Banks's standards and the professionalism of BA, I know that wastage is huge and I decided to get a rough idea of the actual number of puddings being thrown away untried.

Figures just released show that 1.6bn passengers were carried by commercial airlines in 2000. Of these about 500m travelled on domestic flights, the great proportion of which were in north America.

Some of these flights lasted no more than an hour, during which time passengers were lucky to get a cheese cracker or sandwiches. If there was a sweet, it usually didn't amount to more than a bought-in cup cake, which doesn't count in the sophisticated world of in-flight desserts. So let's agree to reduce the numbers of passengers confronted with some form of sweet during 2000 to 1bn.

Let's also agree that my observations are exaggerated by 15 percentage points. To be on the safe side, we'll make that 20 percentage points That gives us a cautious wastage rate with a range of between 20% and 55% of all puddings.

The mean wastage rate therefore is 37.5%, which gives us a figure for last year of 375m untouched desserts. Even if you halve in order to be scrupulously fair, you get 187.5m, which is still an awful lot of pudding to say nothing of calories, effort, money, ingenuity and time, to throw away each year, especially when you consider the annual increase in air travel. By 2020 the world's airlines expect to carry 4bn people which means something like 450m desserts will be junked.

By then, let's hope we have begun to think about waste a little more seriously.

fields.headline: No 1825
fields.standfirst: Jerry Springer
fields.trailText: Jerry Springer
fields.body:
I'm a skanky ho and I don't care who knows it.
I see. You're not a Liberal Democrat then.

Don't diss me or I'll whup yo ass.
So you've attended the Naomi Campbell school of etiquette and good manners, too?

I love my sister's man and I don't give a damn.
I've got it! You've been watching too much Jerry Springer.

I dig trash chatshow freak show voyeurism masquerading as anthropological study with a self-help bent.
At least you're admitting your problem. That's the first step to healing. The second step might be writing to thank the Independent Television Commission which has issued a revised programming code decreeing that broadcasters should show greater sensitivity to the content of daytime shows when children might be watching. That means Springer, king of the white-trash chatshow, and Trisha, ITV's own mistress of the socially dysfunctional, are off the air during the school holidays lest the kids find themselves in the middle of a debate on how Andrea from Nottingham is too fat to have sex.

I like my ladies big and beautiful.
As nice as that is to know, it isn't really the issue. According to a Broadcasting Standards Commission report published last year, a lot of parents had switched off or changed channel so as not to expose their children to difficult issues.

Too bad, sister. I ain't got no shame.
That may be the case but some parents don't want to be quizzed about child pornography, prostitution, sex change operations gone wrong or any of the myriad of other subjects that come up on the likes of Trisha, Jerry Springer and even This Morning, in between Liza Goddard speaking French and Phil Vickery brandishing a cleaver with intent.

Don't tell me I gotta do without my fix of tarts withhearts and tramps with humps.
'Fraid so. You are so outta here, loser.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: The front page of the latest issue of Country Life magazine shows a picture of six healthy-looking pigs, captioned "Investment". Oh dear. A case of foot-in-mouth perhaps?
fields.body:
 Ah, the grim years of the 1950s - a time when men went out to work and women stayed home doing their domestic duties. Fortunately, society has since moved on. But for a trip down memory lane, turn to the PR rubbish that Proctor and Gamble have been issuing for the last week, along the theme of "What women want." Surprise, surprise, what they really want is ... a new type of laundry product.

So we ask P&G's press office: has marketing director Mark Brickhill been cryogenically frozen since 1952? "No, I can assure you he hasn't," says Nicola Sharpe. Then why is he running a publicity campaign that hasn't advanced one iota from the hackneyed 1950s housewife stereotype? "It certainly wasn't intended as a sexist dig or to imply that is all that women want," said Nicola. Mmm.

To quote from the press release: "There's a new product that women really will want - something revolutionary that will make their lives simpler, easier and cleaner." I'd love to mention the name of the product, I really would. But it would just encourage them.

 The front page of the latest issue of Country Life magazine shows a picture of six healthy-looking pigs, captioned "Investment". Oh dear. A case of foot-in-mouth perhaps?

 A strange spat of warfare breaks out between the City's "bulge bracket" investment banks. JP Morgan has been working away on a merger between two Scandanavian finance houses - Svenska Enskilda Banken and Förenings Sparbanken, if you must know the details - only to be forced to share the glory on the all-important mergers and acquisitions league tables with Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.

They had nothing to do with the deal until yesterday when they announced they were muscling in. "I was working on the deal for six weeks and I never saw them, unless they were serving the coffee," said a fuming JP Morgan banker. Alex Northcott, one of Morgan Stanley's PR people, admits his bank hasn't actually done any work on the merger as yet. "I can conform that we have been mandated as co-adviser," was all Alex would say on the subject.

 We all love squirrels of course, and so does pensions company NPI, which uses a fluffy red squirrel as its mascot and logo. The company even has a full-sized squirrel suit for use at PR jaunts. But sadly a recent squirrel impersonator got ... er ... over-excited while inside. So the company had to shell out for a new Mr Squirrel suit, as no-one wanted to wear it because of the smell. Possibly caused by a problem with nuts, I don't know.

 Spare a thought for the bedraggled Turkish lira, the latest currency to discover that exchange rate pegs don't hold even with overnight interest rates at 4,000%. But the markets shouldn't have been taken by surprise - the warning signs were there, even if they were in the most obscure places. Nick Parsons, currency strategist for Commerzbank, points out the ominous website address of Turkey's national statistics bureau, the Devlet Istatistik Enstitusu: www.die.gov.tr.

fields.trailText: In a report headed Labour likely to impose shortlist in safe seat, page 12, February 22, we incorrectly stated that all four candidates originally shortlisted for the vacant nomination in Leigh, Lancashire, were local. In fact two of the four are not. Ian Wingfield is a London-based councillor and union official, and Barbara Keeley-Hugget is a councillor from Trafford. One of those excluded from the original shortlist, Andy Burnham, is local but now works as a government special adviser in London. Ian McCartney MP has not been involved in the selection in any way.
fields.body:
In a report headed Labour likely to impose shortlist in safe seat, page 12, February 22, we incorrectly stated that all four candidates originally shortlisted for the vacant nomination in Leigh, Lancashire, were local. In fact two of the four are not. Ian Wingfield is a London-based councillor and union official, and Barbara Keeley-Hugget is a councillor from Trafford. One of those excluded from the original shortlist, Andy Burnham, is local but now works as a government special adviser in London. Ian McCartney MP has not been involved in the selection in any way.

In Pass Notes, page 2, G2, February 9, we said of Nigel Dempster that he was convicted of a drink-driving offence in 1998. We neglected to say that the conviction [actually in 1997] was quashed on appeal. Mr Dempster, in fact, has a clean licence. Apologies for suggesting otherwise.

Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor's new biretta became a beretta in a caption to a photograph of the papal kiss, page 14, yesterday. Collins dictionary allows berretta with a double r as an alternative (the Italian spelling). The Spanish spelling is birreta, one t. Beretta in the spelling we used in the caption is the name of an Italian gun manufacturer.

fields.headline: Rob Dawber
fields.standfirst: Radical rail worker and writer who sued his bosses over fatal illness
fields.trailText: Radical rail worker and writer who sued his bosses over fatal illness.
fields.body:
Rob Dawber, who was emerging as a writer after his years as a railwayman, has died aged 45. The cause was mesothelioma, a cancer contracted while working with asbestos on the railways. Last year, he won a significant victory in establishing his employers' culpability for his illness.

Rob was educated at Wath-upon-Dearne grammar school in South Yorkshire, and read politics and English at Leicester University. He decided against the expected middle-class career, in place of which he took a job on the railways. This was partly because of his political commitment; Rob was of that generation of socialists who were inspired by the trade union struggles of the 1970s. Also, as he said, he wanted to work alongside people he liked.

For 18 years, he was a rail worker and trade union activist. He became a branch secretary for the National Union of Railwaymen, and wrote for Socialist Organiser and Off The Rails, a bulletin for rail workers. His Fat Controller column mercilessly lampooned the rail managers who squandered the opportunities of the nationalised industries.

During the miners' strike, Rob toured signal boxes run by rail workers who supported the strike, to maintain solidarity with the miners. Later, he stood as presidential candidate for the Rail, Maritime and Transport Union, to oppose privatisation and the consequent risks to health and safety.

When privatisation finally came, Rob was made redundant. As a militant, his prospects in Sheffield, where so many jobs had disappeared, were not good. So he decided to write. His first script, which I was lucky enough to be sent, was full of life, characters and stories. It was about the break-up of the railways into private companies and sub-contractors.

A week after he was commissioned to develop his original material, Rob was given the shattering news that he was terminally ill. He had fought all his life against the undermining of trade unions and the impact that had on health and safety. Ironically, he was to pay a higher price than most. With others, he had been given the job of breaking up troughs and other items, known by British Rail to contain asbestos, in a decrepit shed with an asbestos roof. The mesothelioma which resulted lay dormant for nearly 20 years until it was diagnosed in December 1998, when Rob was 42.

Rob's reaction was to fight it to the end, and get on with what mattered to him. Furious with the medics for their lack of optimism, he decided "to outlive you all". He searched for treatments throughout the world, and prepared to try the most aggressive therapies that were still in their infancy. His family and friends set up the Rob Dawber Mesothelioma Campaign to fund any possible treatment abroad, and to expose the disease as one which affects working people doing dirty jobs without adequate protection.

Rob's fight also resulted in a landmark court judgment against the residual rail company left after privatisation. It was the first time that an employer was found liable for intermittent exposure out of doors, primarily to white asbestos. An internal memo revealed that, although workers were being routinely exposed to lethal asbestos, it would be too expensive to remove it all or educate them in ways of handling it. The substantial damages went to the campaign.

Two anniversaries of his diagnosis were celebrated, and Rob's family and friends began to believe that perhaps he could defy this most crushing of diseases through his formidable willpower. He took great delight in seeing his film completed, and became the centre of much laughter on the set. Despite failing health, he refused to retreat from political life. He allowed his name to go forward as a possible parliamentary candidate for the newly-created Socialist Alliance.

fields.bodyText: Rob Dawber, who was emerging as a writer after his years as a railwayman, has died aged 45. The cause was mesothelioma, a cancer contracted while working with asbestos on the railways. Last year, he won a significant victory in establishing his employers' culpability for his illness. Rob was educated at Wath-upon-Dearne grammar school in South Yorkshire, and read politics and English at Leicester University. He decided against the expected middle-class career, in place of which he took a job on the railways. This was partly because of his political commitment; Rob was of that generation of socialists who were inspired by the trade union struggles of the 1970s. Also, as he said, he wanted to work alongside people he liked. For 18 years, he was a rail worker and trade union activist. He became a branch secretary for the National Union of Railwaymen, and wrote for Socialist Organiser and Off The Rails, a bulletin for rail workers. His Fat Controller column mercilessly lampooned the rail managers who squandered the opportunities of the nationalised industries. During the miners' strike, Rob toured signal boxes run by rail workers who supported the strike, to maintain solidarity with the miners. Later, he stood as presidential candidate for the Rail, Maritime and Transport Union, to oppose privatisation and the consequent risks to health and safety. When privatisation finally came, Rob was made redundant. As a militant, his prospects in Sheffield, where so many jobs had disappeared, were not good. So he decided to write. His first script, which I was lucky enough to be sent, was full of life, characters and stories. It was about the break-up of the railways into private companies and sub-contractors. A week after he was commissioned to develop his original material, Rob was given the shattering news that he was terminally ill. He had fought all his life against the undermining of trade unions and the impact that had on health and safety. Ironically, he was to pay a higher price than most. With others, he had been given the job of breaking up troughs and other items, known by British Rail to contain asbestos, in a decrepit shed with an asbestos roof. Rob's reaction was to fight it to the end, and get on with what mattered to him. Furious with the medics for their lack of optimism, he decided "to outlive you all". He searched for treatments throughout the world, and prepared to try the most aggressive therapies that were still in their infancy. It was the first time that an employer was found liable for intermittent exposure out of doors, primarily to white asbestos. An internal memo revealed that, although workers were being routinely exposed to lethal asbestos, it would be too expensive to remove it all or educate them in ways of handling it. webTitle: Abuse rife in Indonesian Nike plants

fields.headline: Abuse rife in Indonesian Nike plants
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: Sexual and verbal harassment, limited access to medical care and compulsory overtime are commonplace in Indonesian factories making goods for the US clothing and footwear giant Nike, according to a report released yesterday.
fields.body:
Sexual and verbal harassment, limited access to medical care and compulsory overtime are commonplace in Indonesian factories making goods for the US clothing and footwear giant Nike, according to a report released yesterday.

Female workers in one factory told researchers from the Global Alliance for Workers and Communities that they were forced to trade sexual favours to gain employment.

Nearly 8% of those interviewed said they had been on the receiving end of unpleasant sexual comments, 2.5% reported unwanted sexual touching and 30% said they had witnessed or experienced abuse.

The vast majority of the approximately 4,400 people questioned in hour-long interviews at nine factories said they felt coerced to work overtime in order to meet production targets, even though overtime is voluntary under Indonesian law.

Among other incidents documented in the 104-page report, commissioned by Nike, were two deaths in separate factories which workers believed were related to the denial of medical attention.

Almost half of those questioned said clinic facilities were unsatisfactory, while many said their supervisors allowed them to visit clinics only after they had collapsed. Many women, who make up most of the labour force in the factories, said they were denied their two-day monthly menstrual leave allowed under Indonesian law.

One woman said a supervisor threw a book at her for working slowly while other staff were forced to run around the factory grounds or clean toilets if their pace of work was not fast enough.

Nike, which has been accused of condoning appalling labour practices in its Asian factories for years, described the claims as "troubling" but did not reject them in its response to the report.

It said it would seek independent verification as quickly as possible. A Nike spokesman admitted that the nine factories chosen for the survey from the 35 the company uses in Indonesia were among the most progressive in the country.

Dusty Kidd, the vice-president for corporate responsibility, said: "No worker should be subject to some of the working conditions reported in this assessment .. But we now have a baseline to work with."

He said the firm would start a "serious and reasonable remediation plan".

The company stressed that in two of the nine factories visited it is not the only buyer, making it much harder to ensure good labour practices.

The report was funded from Nike's £5.4m contribution to Global Alliance, a consortium of organisations and companies committed to improving the lives of factory workers, especially women, across Asia.

Indonesian labour leaders were not surprised by the findings and said that there were many other problems that were not raised in the report.

"Freedom of association and the minimum wage are two other big issues we are campaigning on," said Rudi Hartono, the head of the Association of Shoe Factory Workers. "People who are active in labour organisations are often not promoted while the workers' wages, while meeting the legal minimum standard, are inadequate to cover their needs."

He said research indicated that workers' wages would have to rise 75% in order to cover basic living needs. "Is that such a hardship considering that the cost of making a pair of shoes, including the labour, is only about 0.4% of what it is sold for in the shops?"

On the issue of overtime, local labour groups say that most workers do an average of at least two hours a day.

"Officially it's voluntary," said Yanti Mala, head of the Textile and Garment Workers' Association. "But the reality is that if workers do not want to do it they have to get special permission. If they do not do it without the special permission then it's standard to get a warning letter the next day."

Mr Hartono and Ms Mala accepted that conditions at factories used by Nike had improved in the last two years but said the company was not particularly proactive in its push to improve conditions. "They only really respond to pressure," Mr Hartono said.

He added that pressure was proving a double-edged sword. "Factory owners are telling us that Nike is threatening to relocate most of its production out of Indonesia because there are now so many new regulations to protect workers' rights."

No one from Nike was available to comment on the widespread rumour that the company plans to move its Indonesian operations to Vietnam or Cambodia, where the laws are much less strict.

fields.headline: Start-up seeks a pureplay solution
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: This summer will see the launch of a new online grocery business in Britain.
fields.body:
This summer will see the launch of a new online grocery business in Britain.

Last Minute Solutions, set up by three former Goldman Sachs bankers and two former heads of the M&S food business, appears to have chosen all the wrong business models. It is a "pureplay" - set up to be operated solely online - and the sort of business struggling to survive in the US.

But the business has won a £35m investment from the John Lewis partnership and will have the exclusive right to use the Waitrose brand and branded goods. John Lewis has installed directors at the firm and taken a 40% stake.

The grocery service, as yet unnamed, will start in the summer and LMS is building its first warehouse at an undisclosed location in the south east. The founders believe they can create a huge brand and are modelling themselves on companies like Orange and EasyJet.

"Orange gave the consumer something they wanted", says Jason Gissings, one of the former bankers. "They had an interesting brand and created interest in themselves."

"The LMS approach is based on a unique business model that incorporates the best from the incumbent delivery models - Tesco and Webvan - and combines them to create a model that surpasses both," says the company. LMS insists store picking is "unreliable and inefficient", and economies of scale are the ultimate solution.

It has signed up some big name consultants: Cap Gemini Ernst & Young for technology, Descartes for delivery software, Arthur Anderson for the business blueprint and Interbrand to help develop the LMS brand.

webTitle: Analysis: How to tackle world poverty

fields.headline: Taking charge of the drive against poverty
fields.standfirst:
Special report: globalisation
Fund to beat third world disease
fields.trailText: Will the cavalcade of international policy makers descending on London on Monday to discuss how to tackle child poverty come up with anything more durable than the millions of words spoken on behalf of noble causes at conferences from Rio to Tokyo in the past decade?
fields.body:
Will the cavalcade of international policy makers descending on London on Monday to discuss how to tackle child poverty come up with anything more durable than the millions of words spoken on behalf of noble causes at conferences from Rio to Tokyo in the past decade?

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, says the London meeting with be different.

The UN's social summit in Copenhagen in 1995 set three key goals to be achieved by 2015 - to halve the number of people living in absolute poverty, cut infant mortality by two-thirds and put every child in primary school.

On current trends, these things are not going to happen.

Some projections indicate that some targets might conceivably be met in a narrow numerical sense if India and China, the two most populous countries in the world, continue to enjoy robust economic growth. But in sub-Saharan Africa, the world's poorest region, there is no chance of the goals being met without intervention by local governments and western donors. The latest World Bank figures for the the region show incomes per head still falling and life expectancy plunging due to Aids.

Education, the key to better health and an ascent out of poverty, is likely to prove the acid test of the new initiatives.

In an interview with the Guardian the chancellor argued that responsibility for hitting the targets has for too long been shuffled between institutions such as the International Monetary Fund, World Bank, and the UN.

Now, he wants the real powerhouse of the global economy, the Group of Seven leading industrialised nations - the US, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada - to take charge.

This more activist approach is being urged on the G7 by Britain and Italy, which currently chairs the meetings of the group.

Many in the aid agencies have long said that real progress cannot come unless politicians force the slow-moving global organisations to act. Governments, they argue, should work harder to shape the global economy rather than leave it to market forces that mean, for example, that multinational drugs companies have little or no incentive to sell cheap generic drugs to combat the likes of TB, diarrhoea and malaria.

Second, they believe that the G7 collectively should nudge the IMF and World Bank away from focussing on narrow financial targets, such as low inflation and balanced budgets, and towards poverty reduction as a prime target.

One of the chancellor's specific goals is to make meeting the 2015 targets a central part of the IMF and World Bank programmes.

Jim Wolfensohn, the bank's president, and Horst Koehler, managing director of the IMF - both of whom will be at Monday's conference after a week touring Africa - are seen as key allies in development of the new approach.

There are hurdles to overcome before a new campaign based on achieving the 2015 targets can get off the ground, not least the unfinished business of debt relief for the world's poorest countries - the subject of an ongoing campaign led by the Jubilee 2000 group.

While 22 countries have begun receiving debt relief under the enhanced programme launched by the IMF and World Bank at Cologne in 1999, many more have yet to meet the criteria. Supporters are urging that this campaign not be allowed to run into the sand.

Another potential obstacle is the uncertain attitude of the new American administration. It will be difficult to persuade free marketeers such as George Bush to spend more US taxpayers' money on poverty reduction.

Also key to the success of an anti-poverty drive with children particularly in mind will be participation by the private sector, especially in tackling preventable diseases.

Mr Brown sees Monday's conference as the first step leading to September's UN special session on children.

A cast list that includes Nelson Mandela and the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, who will both address the London meeting by video link, is meant to give the issue a good kick-start.

But deeds are what will decide whether the conference is more than a feel-good session for policy makers which has no real impact on the ground.

fields.headline: On message
fields.trailText: Britain's Colt Telecom received a fillip yesterday after the company posted better than expected results.
fields.body:
 Results: Britain's Colt Telecom received a fillip yesterday after the company posted better than expected results. Revenues for the full year to December beat analyst forecasts by rising 60% to £640.8m; when infrastructure sales were added in revenues touched £687m. Pre-tax losses narrowed from £116m to £101m.

 Found and lost: US internet group Terra Lycos lost another senior executive yesterday when the company announced the departure of Abel Linares, who led the Spanish arm of the company in a huge merger last year. Terra Lycos shares were down 7.3% at the close of trading yesterday, eating into a more than 25% gain in the year so far after a poor 2000, when they fell 80%.

 Bangalore bull: Indian software firm Infosys Technologies said yesterday there were no changes to its plans despite fears that slowing US markets would hurt it. Infosys shares have fallen 7% this week amid market talk that the Bangalore-based powerhouse had stopped hiring staff.

webTitle: Navy sent to save Borneo victims

fields.headline: Navy sent to save Borneo victims
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: Ninety-seven people were confirmed dead yesterday after five successive days of ethnic clashes between locals and immigrants in the Indonesian half of the island of Borneo.
fields.body:
Ninety-seven people were confirmed dead yesterday after five successive days of ethnic clashes between locals and immigrants in the Indonesian half of the island of Borneo.

One journalist from the migrant community said he had heard the true figure could be more than 700. Police strongly disputed this.

Mobs of Dayaks, the indigenous people, armed with swords and machetes, burned houses, shops and hotels during the day in the town of Sampit, where the fighting is concentrated. More dead were also reported in other towns.

About 15,000 people, mostly migrants from the small island of Madura off the north-east coast of Java, were seeking refuge at police and government offices in Sampit, in central Kalimantan province. They are likely to be evacuated today on warships sent from Java. Extra police and soldiers are also on their way.

The Dayaks say the Madurans - many of whom arrived more than 30 years ago under Indonesia's programme to resettle people from densely populated areas - are unduly aggressive and do not respect local customs. The Madurans say the Dayaks are lazy and are jealous that the migrants control much of the economy.

A doctor at the hospital in Sampit said last night: "We've received more than 30 [bodies] today and many of them are missing limbs, the torsos are slashed and skulls battered," he said. Local media reported that more than 20 had been decapitated and Dayaks were seen parading the severed heads round the town.

"In many areas of the town the sky has turned black today with the smoke from all the burning buildings," said Achmad Badui, a Maduran journalist sheltering at a government office. "A group of community leaders has said that more than 700 Madurese have been killed since Sunday."

The unrest erupted early on Sunday morning after a group of Dayaks attacked a housing complex and killed five Madurans. The Madurans launched revenge attacks and the situation deteriorated. Three men, two of them government officials, are under arrest accused of inciting the initial attack.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Guerrillas deny kidnap attempt
fields.body:
Guerrillas deny kidnap attempt

Ethnic Albanian guerrillas yesterday dismissed claims by Serbian officials that they had attempted to kidnap the Serbian deputy prime minister, Nebojsa Covic.

A government-run press centre in the tense Presevo valley area bordering Kosovo claimed special police had thwarted the abduction attempt. Reuters, Bujanovac

Swedes to quiz Kurdish leader

Swedish police will go to Turkey to interrogate the jailed Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan about possible Kurdish involvement in the assassination of the Swedish prime minister Olof Palme, officials said yesterday.

Palme, whose government had declared Ocalan's Kurdistan Workers' party a terrorist organisation, was killed in Stockholm in 1986.

Ocalan has said rebels who broke away from his group may have had a hand in the killing. AP, Sweden

Farmers win support on BSE

German and French farmers hit by the BSE crisis have won support from two lawyers who say they will sue Germany and France.

US lawyer Ed Fagan and Michael Witti from Munich said the governments should carry more blame for the spread of BSE. Kate Connolly, Berlin

30 held over Sudan deal

More than 30 associates of Sudan's dissident Islamist leader, Hassan al-Turabi, have been arrested since he was taken into custody on Wednesday for striking a deal with southern rebels, an aide said yesterday.

No charges have been announced against Mr Turabi or members of his Popular National Congress over the memorandum of understanding with the Sudan People's Liberation Army. AFP, Khartoum

UK condemns detention

Britain protested to Israel yesterday over the detention without trial of a British-Lebanese citizen who was arrested on January 5.

Israel said yesterday that Jihad Letif Shuman, who according to his British passport is named Jehard Shuman, confessed he was sent by the Hizbullah guerrilla group to carry out attacks in Israel. Reuters, Jerusalem

Stolen statue returned to Italy

Italian police said yesterday they have recovered a first-century Greek marble statue which was stolen seven years ago.

The statue of Artemis, the Greek goddess of the moon, wild animals and hunting, is worth about £3.3m. It was found in Switzerland earlier this week. AP, Rome

Mission improbable

A German fighter plane attacked a Dutch air force control tower yesterday while on a routine training mission, firing seven rounds before realising it had the wrong target.

The three Dutch personnel in the tower were unhurt. AP, Amsterdam

webTitle: Opera diva storms Barcelona's male bastion

fields.headline: Opera equality fight
fields.standfirst: Diva storms Barcelona's male bastion
fields.trailText: The soprano Montserrat Caballé today leads an assault on one of the last bastions of male chauvinism in Spain - the 150-year-old all-male Cercle del Liceu club at Barcelona's Liceu opera house.
fields.body:
The soprano Montserrat Caballé today leads an assault on one of the last bastions of male chauvinism in Spain - the 150-year-old all-male Cercle del Liceu club at Barcelona's Liceu opera house.

The formidable Caballé, who has sung on the opera's stage on more than 100 occasions in the last 30 years, is facing fierce opposition from a hard core of traditionalists who have even gone to court in an attempt to prevent the diva from joining their ranks.

The Cercle's 1,000 members, who represent the cream of Barcelona society, will be filing through the doors of the opera house on the central Las Ramblas boulevard today and tomorrow to vote on Caballé's application.

Members must cast their vote by choosing between white balls and black balls, with a succesful application needing at least two thirds of the balls to be white. The result will be known tomorrow night. A nail-biting finish is guaranteed.

Three weeks ago the Cercle bowed to Spain's equal opportunities law and agreed to change its statutes so that women could, in theory, be admitted. But this was achieved only after an angry meeting of 300 members that began at 10pm and ended at 5am.

Forty percent of members, enough to blackball Caballe, voted against but failed to have the decision overturned in the courts. "We don't want this to become a club for female gossip," one opponent said.

Caballé, who donated £25,000 to help rebuild the Liceu after it burned down in 1994, has tried to tread delicately around the Spanish male ego. "Women should be bringers of peace, not the cause of discord," she proclaimed. "We do not wish to eclipse men, because we need them. I hope our presence will be a source of pleasure, not of problems."

But other women are much angrier at the attempts to keep them out.

"I want to be able to take guests in without having to ask my husband's permission," Adela Subirana, a businesswoman who is an important sponsor of the opera house, said. "I don't know why we have to listen to these machistas any more."

webTitle: Anger at adverts to recruit Ulster police

fields.headline: Anger at adverts to recruit Ulster police
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: A major television and newspaper advertising campaign to attract the first recruits for Northern Ireland's new police service was launched today despite a storm of protest from nationalist and republican politicians.
fields.body:
A major television and newspaper advertising campaign to attract the first recruits for Northern Ireland's new police service was launched today despite a storm of protest from nationalist and republican politicians.

They said it was too early for them to be able to endorse the reforms as concrete and wide-reaching enough to guarantee the fresh start they want to see, but security chiefs believe the search for 240 trainees had to go ahead because of the shortfall caused by reductions to achieve a 7,500-strong peacetime force.

Around 500 officers will have taken early retirement or redundancy by the end of March and a further 750 will have left by this time next year. The new recruits will start their training next autumn and be on the beat by next spring. Starting salary is £17,000 rising to £19,000 after training.

"If we didn't recruit now we would be left in a situation where there would be more soldiers on the streets, which is totally counter to normalisation aims," a security source said.

Policing, along with paramilitary decommissioning and demilitarisation, is at the centre of intense negotiations to try to salvage the faltering political process. The new Police Act means equal numbers of Protestants and Catholics must be appointed.

The "softly softly" television advert plays on the theme of the police reflecting the whole community in Northern Ireland, through a series of diverse people in plain clothes helping others in a shopping centre.

Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness, whose party has urged Catholics not to apply yet, blasted the advertising campaign as illegal because the police board was not in place, but the Northern Ireland Office has strongly denied this.

Les Rodgers, chairman of the Police Federation, which represents most rank and file officers, said morale in the service was at rock bottom.

"Every day, there is just more and more in-your-face criticism, plus all the uncertainty, which is very tough for men and women who are just trying to do their job," he said.

fields.headline: Kidnapped Briton weakens in jungle
fields.trailText: The Briton kidnapped in Bangladesh, Tim Selby, yesterday said that he and two Danes were growing increasingly weak after seven days in the jungle.
fields.body:
The Briton kidnapped in Bangladesh, Tim Selby, yesterday said that he and two Danes were growing increasingly weak after seven days in the jungle.

Mr Selby, 28, was seized by tribal bandits in the Chittagong hills on Friday in south-east Bangladesh.

In a letter delivered via intermediaries, he urged the authorities trying to negotiate his release to call off army patrols in the area. He wrote: "Our health is deteriorating rapidly and we are growing weak. It is vital [underlined] that you call off the army patrol and it is also vital [underlined] that you stop the army from interfering with tribal women. Signed Tim Selby."

British diplomats say the letter may have been written under duress. There are unconfirmed reports that one hostage has received "bruising" either from a fall or from the captors.

The report of poor health comes amid signs that negotiations are going nowhere.

The kidnappers flagged down Mr Selby's four-wheel drive vehicle while he and the Danes were surveying a Danish-financed road project near the hill station of Rangamati. Another Briton, David Weston, and the group's Bangladeshi driver, were also abducted but later released to convey a £1.2m ransom demand for the remaining three.

A team of trained hostage negotiators from the Metropolitan police is likely to fly to Bangladesh next week to assist with the operation. Its presence has become all the more urgent after a storm blew over the hills yesterday, drenching the jungle in hours of rain.

It is not clear whether Mr Selby is being kept under shelter or has been marched deep into the teak forests along the borders with Burma and India.

The army says it has trapped the kidnap gang within a 30 sq km area. But yesterday three armed men ambushed a local TV crew on the same road less than 5km (three miles) from where Mr Selby was captured; they let the crew go for 1,000 taka, or £12.

The area, with its high elephant grass and banana plants, is notorious for kidnapping, extortion and lawlessness. Mr Selby and his colleagues have been criticised by local officials for failing to take a police escort with them, as they had on the same road three days earlier.

Speaking from the Selby family home in Oldham, Greater Manchester, Mr Selby's brother, Jon, 30, said he had been warned that in hostage situations captors played cat and mouse. "I am sure the kidnappers will want to appear in control of the situation. It's something that we don't want to hear but it's something that we expect. We know things are not just going to happen."

The family had met hostage negotiation specialists, he said, who had built up a profile of his brother. It was standard procedure to refuse to pay the ransom demand. "We have not got any intention of going out there at the moment," he added. "At least while we are here we can be in contact and reached on the phone."
