fields.headline: Fin soup delicacy threatens sharks
fields.trailText: The movies may present sharks as fearsome predators who snack on swimmers, but in reality it is they who are at risk from human eating habits, an environmental group warned yesterday.
fields.body:
The movies may present sharks as fearsome predators who snack on swimmers, but in reality it is they who are at risk from human eating habits, an environmental group warned yesterday.

Rocketing demand for the delicacy shark fin soup is devastating populations, according to research from the WildAid organisation. It shows that the numbers of some species have fallen by up to 90% in less than two decades.

The value of fins is so much higher than that of the rest of the meat that often they are sliced off and the rest of the animal is dumped back into the ocean to die. WildAid wants governments worldwide to follow the lead of the United States and Australia in banning the controversial practice, known as finning.

Susie Watts, who carried out research in 12 countries over two years, said finning was devastating subsistence fishing communities in the developing world which relied on sharks as a part of their diet.

"In the past when sharks were caught up in nets they were thrown back because of the low value of shark meat in the developed world," she said. "But the fins are now cut off and the rest of the body thrown overboard. It's a very cruel practice as well as a huge waste of food."

Her colleague Victor Wu said that demand for shark fin soup, a delicacy dating from the second century BC, had doubled in the past decade because the expanding Asian middle class saw it as a status symbol. A bowl can cost up to $100 (£69) in parts of Asia.

"Shark fin is actually tasteless, but the attraction is there because it is considered a delicacy," he explained. "The trouble is that western consumerism has combined with an old tradition."

While soup is one of the biggest threats to sharks, it is not the only one. Consumers may not even know when they are eating shark; one species, the spiny dogfish, is sold in British fish and chip shops as rock salmon.

WildAid is calling for restrictions on all shark fishing and wants governments to control the numbers taken as "by-catch". It is thought that up to 50% of all sharks taken are caught unintentionally, and they are often dumped because they are less valuable than other fish.

Sharks have inhabited the oceans for around 400m years, but are vulnerable because they produce so few young. Overfished populations may take decades to recover, if they do so at all. They can also cause other stocks to collapse because secondary predators of species, such as tuna, are no longer kept under control.

fields.headline: Comet killed life before dinosaurs
fields.standfirst:
Impact wiped out two dominant species and humans could be next

Special report: space
exploration
fields.trailText: Impact wiped out two dominant species and humans could be next.
fields.body:
In a discovery with chilling implications for humans' dominance of the Earth, scientists have discovered that a massive comet or asteroid, similar to the one which killed off the dinosaurs, wiped out the giant reptiles' predecessors 200 million years earlier.

The finding suggests that regular collisions between our planet and large objects act as an evolutionary dice-shaker, sending dominant species back to the starting square and advancing obscure species to dominance. We could be next.

Students of the fossil record have long pondered the greatest catastrophe ever to strike life on Earth: the "Great Dying", 251m years ago, when suddenly, 90% of all marine animals and 70% of land vertebrates perished.

The impact of a comet or asteroid similar to that which brought doom to the dinosaurs 65m years ago was suspected, but the latest edition of the journal Science reports on the first evidence that such a collision actually happened.

Scientists at the universities of Washington and Rochester in the US have found that molecules of helium and argon gas, locked since the Great Dying in carbon, are present in proportions which could only have come from space. As in the later impact, the strike came from a body between six and 12 kilometres wide (four to eight miles).

Researcher Robert Poreda said yesterday the effect would have been to release energy 1m times greater than the biggest earthquake of the past century.

The crash coincided with volcanic activity on an unimaginable scale in what is now Siberia. Over a million years - a relatively short time in geological terms - 1.6m cubic kilometres of lava poured out of the ground, covering the entire planet in a layer 10 metres thick.

"It was the proverbial blast from the double-barrelled shotgun," said Dr Poreda. "We're not sure of all the environmental consequences, but with the impact and the volcanic activity, we do know that Earth was not a happy place.

"It may be that the combined effects of impact and volcanism are necessary to cause such a tremendous extinction."

The nemesis of the dinosaurs also coincided with a gush of lava from below the Earth's crust, in what is now India. In both cases, the impact of the comet or asteroid may have caused the eruption.

Alternatively, the coincidence of the two events could have meant the end for the dinosaurs and their predecessors.

"There has been lots of flood basalt volcanism over time, and many impacts, but these impact events caused major extinctions. Both coincided with periods of heavy volcanic activity," said Dr Poreda.

The dinosaur-killing impact has been tied to a crater on the Yucatan peninsula in Mexico, but it is not known where the earlier collision happened. At the time all Earth's land made up a single continent, Pangea.

The age immediately prior to the dinosaurs was called the Permian. Although there were amphibious reptiles, early versions of the dinosaurs, the dominant life form was the trilobite, visually somewhere between a wood louse and an armadillo.

In their heyday there were 15,000 kinds of trilobite. Around the time of the impact, they disappeared. Something similar happened to the dinosaurs 65m years ago. In the same way that the earlier impact seems to have cleared the way for them, the later crash made room for our ancestors, the mammals.

"The two extinctions are like bookends for the age of the dinosaurs," said Dr Poreda. "The first boundary helped usher in the age of the dinosaurs and the second snuffed it out."

Although it is likely to be millions of years before the next big asteroid or comet impact, there is a growing call for a defence system to be put in place.

webTitle: Human rights commissions in Africa 'are often a sham'

fields.headline: Human rights commissions in Africa 'are often a sham'
fields.standfirst: Watchdog says UN helps states use tribunals to deflect criticism
fields.trailText: An international human rights watchdog has denounced the proliferation of state-backed human rights and truth commissions in Africa as a sham.
fields.body:
An international human rights watchdog has denounced the proliferation of state-backed human rights and truth commissions in Africa as a sham.

Human Rights Watch believes that many are simply being used to cover up abuses by some of the world's most oppressive regimes.

In a 400-page report released yesterday, the group also criticised western governments and the UN for funding, and thereby lending unwarranted legitimacy to, such commissions which it claims have have little interest in curbing human rights abuses.

"By 2000, Africa was host to the largest number of government human rights commissions of any continent. Yet its human rights record, by and large, stands in stark contrast with this fact," said Human Rights Watch.

"For the most part [the commissions] have proved to be a disappointment. Many have indeed been formed by governments with dismal human rights records, weak state institutions, and no history of autonomous state bodies. Some appear largely designed to deflect international criticism of some serious human rights abuses."

A decade ago, there was just one state human rights commission in Africa - in Togo. Now there are 20, in almost half the countries on the continent. Four more commissions are on the way.

The watchdog accuses some African states of "jumping on the human rights bandwagon" without any real interest in genuinely respecting them.

Human rights are in vogue now in much the same way as elections were fashionable a decade ago, a time when, under pressure from western aid donors at the end of the cold war, African states staged elections with little real commitment to establishing genuinely democratic governments.

Similar plans to placate western donors are often behind the establishment of rights commissions, it said.

Some commissions - notably in South Africa, Ghana and Uganda - have genuinely exposed abuses and challenged government practices.

South Africa's commission criticised official inaction over rampant and sometimes violent xenophobia, and police torture. In Uganda, commissioners have used judicial powers to force the authorities to account for abuses.

But elsewhere - from Liberia to Kenya, Sudan to Malawi - commissions are being used to dress up the country's image overseas and deflect criticism of the government's inability to liberalise, the group said.

"Millions of Africans are being displaced, tortured or killed. Yet the sad truth is that human rights commissioners in Africa often turn a blind eye to these abuses," said the report's author, Binaifer Nowrojee. "Many commissioners fail to publicly denounce abuses, either from fear of retribution or out of hope of government favour."

The report says that Sudan's human rights body was set up seven years ago amid some of the worst political repression in the country and did nothing to curb such abuses.

Algeria and Tunisia formed commissions simply to ward off international criticism of the state crackdowns on Islamic political groups, the report said.

"In the late 1990s, the postwar governments of Liberia and Sierra Leone created human rights commissions after flawed peace accords granted an amnesty to the fighters responsible for the killings and torture of thousands of civilians," the report said.

"The question which remains is: can these institutions that are set up by governments with less than pure motives be transformed into independent and effective human rights bodies?"

Official human rights commissions sometimes work with truth commissions; one laying bare past abuses while the other examines present day human rights breaches. The truth commissions have sometimes proved more successful, in part because the present governments are not responsible for past abuses.

Nigerians were exasperated and amused to see army generals who once ruled the country with a rod of iron, and plundered much of its wealth, weeping before the country's truth commission. That, and revelations about the extent of the brutality that the military sank to during its last years in power, have probably done as much as any human rights commission to curb abuses in the future by the army.

webTitle: Dentist jailed for HIV risk and false claims

fields.headline: Jail for dentist who put patients at HIV risk and made false claims
fields.standfirst: Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: Health officials are trying to trace former patients of a dentist who was jailed for three years yesterday for using dirty equipment and making nearly £12,000 in false NHS claims.
fields.body:
Health officials are trying to trace former patients of a dentist who was jailed for three years yesterday for using dirty equipment and making nearly £12,000 in false NHS claims.

Doctors say William Duff, 39, may have exposed 4,500 patients to the risk of infection, including HIV and Hepatitis C, by using unsterilised needles and other equipment at his practice in Maryhill, Glasgow, between 1991 and 1994.

Greater Glasgow health board is trying to track patients of the practice before 1994. They will be offered blood tests and counselling.

Glasgow sheriff court heard how Duff, of Kilbarchan, Renfrewshire, became one of the highest paid dentists in Glasgow, at one point earning about £1m a year in fees. He arranged appointments around the clock, but cut corners, using unsterilised equipment. He carried out and claimed NHS funds for unnecessary work, extracting healthy teeth and fitting unnecessary crowns and fillings.

His three year scam came to light following patients' complaints which prompted a major fraud investigation. Duff was struck off by the General Dental Council in 1997.

Yesterday, Sheriff Susan Raeburn jailed Duff for three years and said he had harmed confidence in the dental profession. Duff had admitted culpable and reckless conduct and fraud at an earlier appearance.

Former patients said they were angry at the sentence and fearful for their health. Speaking after the verdict, Ellen Barclay, a 35-year-old mother from Glasgow, said she was awaiting the result of an HIV test. "Three years isn't good enough. He will be out in 15 months; I might not see my son grow up."

Mairi Patrick, 44, also from Glasgow, said:"[Dentists] are horrified at what he's done to me," she said. "I've suffered infections and my face has swollen up. I've had corrective surgery. He gave me 16 unnecessary crowns and I'm angry."

The court had heard that Duff knew that infection could be transmitted between patients if dental instruments were not sterilised, but failed to do so. The court also heard that Duff had submitted 74 false claims for work on patients totalling £11,800. The individual claims ranged from £9.60 to £275.

Duff's solicitor, Maurice Smyth, said his client had committed the offences because he was ill and suffering from depression. "He was in a black hole and now his career is in ruins. He has no normality in his life, he has no children and cannot adopt. He has justifiably been vilified in the press. Passing a custodial sentence would be wholly inappropriate," he said.

Sheriff Raeburn said imprisonment was the only sentence she could pass to restore confidence in the dental profession. More than 220 complaints were made by patients about Duff's work and 48 are pursuing compensation claims through the civil courts.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • The 11th of the dozen Turncoat of Turncoats contestants is selected. He is Reg Race, recently chosen, for his impeccable Blairite toadying, as Labour candidate for Chesterfield. Can it be that, for once, High Command has shown a little wit?
fields.body:
 The 11th of the dozen Turncoat of Turncoats contestants is selected. He is Reg Race, recently chosen, for his impeccable Blairite toadying, as Labour candidate for Chesterfield. Can it be that, for once, High Command has shown a little wit?

Chesterfield was once Tony Benn's seat, and it was as a Bennite that Reg first emerged in the 1980s, first as MP for Wood Green and then at the GLC. Not merely a Trot but "the most abusive, extremist, disruptive, posturing element in the whole Benn campaign", as one expert puts it.

Reg appeared in the Diary of October 7 1983 as a prolific writer of polemics against Neil Kinnock, taking space in Socialist Organiser, Labour Herald, Socialist Action and other satirical organs to rail against capitalism. And then, a few years ago, he resurfaced as a Blairite poodle. What a piece of turncoatery, and it earns him an instant quote of 8-1. Welcome, Reg. Now, just one more slot to fill.

 Such is Jack Straw's commitment to open government that the Home Office website devotes an area to the subject, with one section explaining the code of practice on access to government information. Here, the last of five key commitments is the solemn pledge to "respond to requests for information".

These requests are made on the request form helpfully provided, and you fill this in and email it back. What a splendid service. Some might point out that the absence of a "send" button at this point renders the whole thing transcendently pointless, but then what else would you expect of the sneerers anyway?

 Word that Skippy Hammond's Hinduja whitewash is even further behind schedule than we thought (yesterday, he lost four hours searching for his rubber) comes as a relief after a call about the kangaroo suit we are hiring for the volunteer to wear while delivering Skippy's jigsaw. "How funny," says Robert at costumier Angels & Bermans, "someone hired it out only this morning. It'll be out for the next week. It's strange that someone hired it just when you were after it - a bit of a one-off." Most singular.

But this mystery hirer, was he bewigged and carrying a set of colouring pencils? Or did he come in playing the bagpipes, and proceed to accuse all the mannequins of being barking mad? "I'm afraid I can't say who hired the suit," says Robert. A blow, then. But we're not finished yet.  We did promise to bring you the Rev Steve Chalke's views on the Hinduja affair, but frankly I don't have the strength. Maybe soon.

 A friend calls from Richmond, Surrey, to complain about the noise from the next office, where the last active Gestetner machine in the world is driving him mad. It does sound awful, even over the phone. But hasn't he thought of complaining to his MP?

Yes, he says, he has, partly because his MP is the one using the copier. We ring Lib Dem international development spokesperson Jenny Tonge to ask if the Gestetner is part of some "living village" of pre-industrial revolution life? "No, it's very sophisticated, and called a risograph. Who complained? If it's those people next door, I can tell you that, after some people found it disturbing, we relocated it to an office in Richmond ..." Poor show.

 I am surprised to see Diary pundit Steptoe mentioned in one of those media diaries Andrew Neil whines about. In one recent whinge, he made a typically sloppy mistake, wrongly denying that an ex-editor of Tatler owned a dog whose befoulment of the office floor provoked some sharp diary coverage.

Alerted to his howler, the Telegraph reports, Andrew then changed tack and began claiming that "the badly house trained dog" was - can you believe it? - Steptoe, who was working at Tatler at the time. Whether through malice or sheer idleness (one call to check, that's all it would have taken), he has ... well, apologise at once, pretty boy, that's my advice. Before it gets personal.

webTitle: New forces chief accepts women could die in battle

fields.headline: New forces chief accepts women could die in battle
fields.standfirst: Submarine or frontline infantry roles still opposed
fields.trailText: Admiral Sir Michael Boyce, the new chief of defence staff, said yesterday he had "no problem" with the prospect of women dying on the battlefield but was opposed to them working in submarines or fighting alongside men in frontline infantry roles.
fields.body:
Admiral Sir Michael Boyce, the new chief of defence staff, said yesterday he had "no problem" with the prospect of women dying on the battlefield but was opposed to them working in submarines or fighting alongside men in frontline infantry roles.

Distancing himself from his predecessor, general Sir Charles Guthrie, he said the armed forces had already accepted the possibility that women would be killed in battle or taken as prisoners of war.

Sir Michael said that women knew if they joined the forces, they could get in harm's way. But if society had problems with that, Sir Michael said he did not.

Women, he noted, were already engaged in frontline roles as pilots and could be posted in exposed forward gunnery positions where they were likely to be killed.

There are also women crew on naval ships - indeed, he said "women were good for the navy" - where conditions in war could be just as unpleasant as on a battlefield.

However, he said he was strongly against women fighting with men in the infantry, in small units of perhaps only four soldiers. Unlike on ships or other army and RAF units, infantry tasks could not be "portioned out", he said. Infantry, he added, deliberately placed themselves in positions where they would be engaged in hand-to-hand combat.

Sir Michael made it plain he would adopt a robust view if ministers, who are due to receive an internal army study on the issue, decided that all roles should be open to women and men alike.

"I will not do anything to diminish the operational capability [of the armed forces]," said Sir Michael. His mind was closed, he stressed, on the question of "maintaining operational effectiveness". That was the issue, he said, not whether women would be killed or not.

He said he was against women working in submarines because nuclear-powered submarines, sometimes submerged for a couple of months at a time, emitted gases which were potentially harmful to foetuses.

By the time women crew discovered they were pregnant the damage would already have been done, he said.

The Commons defence committee yesterday also addressed the role of women in the armed forces. Referring to Sir Charles's view that women should not be on the battlefield, it said it was unclear whether such exclusion was on the grounds of "physiological ability or moral distaste for women having to do such work". The MPs concluded: "If it is the latter, it is time it was abandoned."

Sir Michael said that women recruits on training exercises "broke" more often than men. However, he made clear that his main concern was that women infantry, wounded or killed in battle, would affect their male colleagues in a way that would disrupt military operations.

Women are able to serve in 70% of posts in the army, 73% in the navy, and 96% in the RAF. However, the defence committee said recruitment figures were disappointing - women account for less than 8% of all trained armed forces personnel.

Sir Michael yesterday echoed his predecessor's concern about the growth of equal rights and employment legislation, citing as an example the EU's working time directive which he implied was totally unsuitable for the armed forces.

He also conceded that operating no-fly zones over Iraq was a "difficult problem". He referred to the threat of an RAF aircraft being shot down.

Patrolling was becoming increasingly difficult, he added, because of "adverse comment from people who are supposed to be friends" - a thinly disguised reference to France.

Though he understood why the US wanted to go ahead with plans for a national missile defence system, he said that if Britain was to participate it would be expensive. The armed forces already had "barely enough money. You could argue not quite enough", he said.

Sir Michael said he backed the plan for joint EU military operations so long as it did not harm Nato. "The importance of the transatlantic link is paramount," he said.

fields.headline: Census is factor in choice of April 5 or May 3 poll day
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Is polling day May 3, as almost everyone assumes? Or will Tony Blair surprise everyone on March 12 by dashing to Buckingham Palace in time for a vote on April 5 ?
fields.body:
Is polling day May 3, as almost everyone assumes? Or will Tony Blair surprise everyone on March 12 by dashing to Buckingham Palace in time for a vote on April 5 ?

"Let's get it over with," murmer some voters. Either way, party canvassers will not be the only people knocking on front doors this spring. Census day looms. Thousands of officials, known as enumerators and carrying yellow bags full of yellow and pink forms, will be out throughout April and early May, cajoling 60m people into cooperating with the 10-yearly attempt to count the British population.

Sunday April 29 is the date. Census day was set by law two years ago - unlike the election, which, almost uniquely among advanced democracies, rests in the hands of the incumbent prime minister.

Most pundits, politicians and voters have long since assumed the general election will be May 3, since this is local election day and four years and two days since the landslide of 1997, a respectable gap. Yet Downing Street will not confirm that date, and cabinet ministers ocasionally try to persuade a lobby correspondent Mr Blair will decide to get it over with on April 5. The odds are only 60:40 on May 3, according to a BBC pundit.

Under election law 17 working days' notice is required; Monday March 12 is the last day to announce the April 5 option. That would be five days after Gordon Brown's fifth budget - one which will allow the chancellor to be prudently generous. "Budget lift-off," as one Labour official put it yesterday.

John Major did it in 1992, winning on April 9 against the odds after calling it on March 11, the day after Norman Lamont's budget had introduced a 20p tax band and shaken the City by doubling the projected debt burden. It is still being paid off.

Favouring the April 5 date is the widely sensed voter antipathy to the prospect of a campaign whose result is all but certain. It would also avoid the campaign being disrupted by Easter week, April 15-22, and mixed up with the census on April 29.

Charles Kennedy, the Lib Dem leader, has publicly told his troops to be ready for April 5. Labour's general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, told her staff "we must assume it is May 3" weeks ago, though, like the Tories, she must keep an eye on an earlier option.

A few Labour MPs are whispering: "Let's go while we're still so far ahead. You never know what might happen, look at the Mandelson affair, look at Lord Irvine." In reality both big party organisations would be aghast at an April 5 date, as would MPs. "We're just not ready; the posters aren't ready and not all the candidates have even been picked," one London suburban MP said yesterday.

So the weight of advice, and bookies takings, point to a dissolution on April 4 or 5, allowing a month long campaign.

webTitle: Right to roam plans leave farmers angry

fields.headline: Right to roam plans leave farmers angry and campaigners wary
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the countryside in crisis
Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: Proposals to open access to the countryside and give rural communities the right to buy surrounding land were yesterday unveiled by the Scottish executive to a chorus of criticism.
fields.body:
Proposals to open access to the countryside and give rural communities the right to buy surrounding land were yesterday unveiled by the Scottish executive to a chorus of criticism.

The draft bill outlaws Keep Out and No Trespassing signs, and enables communities to register their interest in land important to them. Farmers' leaders claimed it would open land to a rambling free for all, while ramblers said the bill would actually restrict access.

Land reform is an emotive issue. Scotland has 343 people or bodies owning more than half of private rural land, the highest concentration in the world. There has been anger at the sale of estates and beauty spots like the Cuillin mountain range, recently on the open market at £10m. There has also been confusion surrounding the law of access.

It is proposed to create a right of responsible access to land, including inland waters, for recreation. Access can be limited on grounds of health and safety, security or privacy, and when crops are growing, but landowners will have to take down any permanent signs barring entry and give reasons for any restriction.

The bill would also give rural communities a legal right to buy land when it goes on sale. They will be able to register an interest, and will have a 30 day space to decide whether to exercise the right-to-buy, which could be funded by a new Scottish land fund set up with nearly £11m of lottery funding.

Crofting communities will be able to buy the land on which they live and work at any time.

The proposals now go to pub lic consultation. The deputy first minister, Jim Wallace, said: "I believe this legislation will provide responsible enjoyment of the countryside and provide opportunities for rural and crofting communities."

Campaigners welcomed the proposals but Andy Wightman said: "It is not going to achieve a massive shake-up in ownership." Cameron McNeish, president of the Ramblers Association in Scotland said: "The legislation, rather than improving access opportunities, would restrict our cherished freedom to walk on land."

The National Farmers' Union has withdrawn from the forum to discuss the legislation.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Two die from meningitis
fields.body:
Two die from meningitis

Health officials yesterday issued fresh warnings against meningitis after a 22-year-old woman and a 19-year-old man who were not connected died in Barnsley, South Yorkshire.

Lord Cledwyn dies, 84

The former Welsh secretary Lord Cledwyn of Penrhos has died aged 84. Cledwyn Hughes was MP for Anglesey for 28 years. Obituary page 26

Dog doorbell invented

An amateur inventor has designed a doorbell for dogs. George Moore of Sharrington, near Melton Constable, Norfolk, used his dog Patch to test the four inch round platform which triggers a transmitter when stepped on.

Two charged with murder

Two men appeared before Milton Keynes magistrates yesterday charged with the murder of Rachel Manning, 19, a shop assistant, whose body was found in bushes at Woburn Golf and Country Club in December. Barri White, 21, unemployed of Bletchley, and Keith Hyatt, 48, a van driver, of Bedford, were remanded in custody.

Dalek sold for £2,500

A Dalek - one of Dr Who's feared enemies - which was part-exchanged for an E-type Jaguar has been bought for £2,500 by John Nutman, 32, of Iford, Dorset.

Troops find bomb launchers

Two improvised grenade launchers and 1,325 rounds of ammunition were found by troops in a field near Cookstown, Co Tyrone, yesterday. A follow-up operation uncovered two walkie-talkie radios.

Body found in wood

Police searching for Allan Matthews, 70, a recluse who disappeared more than two months ago, have found human remains near his woodland home in Lime Kiln Wood, in Telford, Shropshire.

Muggers attack high court judge

webTitle: Torch bomb blew off hand of TA cadet

fields.headline: Torch bomb blew off hand of TA cadet
fields.trailText: A boobytrap bomb hidden in a torch blew the hand off a 14-year-old cadet at a Territorial Army base in west London, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
A boobytrap bomb hidden in a torch, similar to devices used by agents in the second world war, blew the hand off a 14-year-old cadet at a Territorial Army base in west London, it emerged yesterday.

But officers from Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch were last night baffled over who planted it and why.

Although the TA base in White City would have been a likely target for the Real IRA, detectives are confident dissidents opposed to the peace process were not involved. The group has not used a torch bomb before and it appears the boy brought the device into the building from outside.

Drugs gangs and youths experimenting with DIY bomb-making equipment were being considered as possible explanations, the police said.

"Nothing can be ruled out but there is nothing to suggest that it was related to any terror group," said Metropolitan police commissioner Sir John Stevens. "There were no warning calls. The device was clearly designed to cause injury."

When forensic experts have identified the kind of explosive used, detectives will have a better idea whether the device was the work of experts or amateurs. The injured boy was named as Stephen Menary. He was in a stable condition and although officers have not spoken to him, sources said it was "very unlikely" he had made the device himself.

It exploded at 7pm Wednesday as he walked into the headquarters of the 4th Battalion Parachute Regiment 10 (London) company. The blast ripped a door off its hinges.

Torch bombs were used during the second world war by forces which coordinated sabotage behind enemy lines. The device was designed to explode when the torch was switched on.

fields.headline: Labourer held over 1968 murder of teenage boy
fields.trailText: Detectives investigating the murder more than 30 years ago of a teenage boy were yesterday questioning a man about his death.
fields.body:
Detectives investigating the murder more than 30 years ago of a teenage boy were yesterday questioning a man about his death.

A 64-year-old farm labourer was arrested at his home in Solihull, in the West Midlands, on Wednesday evening in connection with the abduction and killing of Roy Tutill, 14, in 1968. He was taken to a police station in Surrey where he was also interviewed about two attempted abductions in 1998 and 1999.

One incident involved a seven-year-old boy who had stopped at Heston service station on the M4, Greater London, with his parents. In the second, a 14-year-old boy managed to fight off a man who tried to grab him as he walked to school in Chertsey, Surrey.

The suspect, who has not been named, is believed to be a divorcee who moved away from the Surrey area weeks after Roy's death. He had travelled around the country for his work.

Roy disappeared on April 23 1968 while attempting to hitchhike to his home in Brockham Green, near Dorking, from Kingston grammar school. Three days later his fully-clothed body was found in a copse near press baron Lord Beaverbrook's estate at Mickleham, Surrey. He had been strangled and sexually assaulted.

Roy became known in the press as "the boy who never came home" and the case remains the only unsolved child murder in the county.

A huge team of officers interviewed more than 10,000 people and took 2,000 written statements in the months following the murder, but were unable to find the killer. Detectives continued to follow up leads over the years without success, arresting a suspect in 1991 but releasing him without charge. Police said he was not the man being questioned yesterday.

Last year Surrey police opened an incident room at Staines and put 22 officers on the case after a review identified potential new lines of inquiry. They hoped that new investigative techniques and scientific methods would help them to track down the killer.

In January this year they invited 60 officers involved in the original inquiry to pool their knowledge with those currently working on the case."This murder caused a tremendous amount of emotion in Surrey," said detective superintendent Dave Cook, who is leading the inquiry. "It was a very high profile case that was never solved. We re-opened it because methods of investigation have moved on, but the knowledge of the officers who worked on the original inquiry was invaluable.

"They were the vital bridge between the past and present. Their thoughts and memories proved a valuable tool in helping us understand what had taken place back then."

He added: "Roy Tutill's blazer and the books he was carrying have been carefully kept and it brought tears to the eyes just to look at them and think what that poor young boy went through."

Roy was last spotted thumbing a lift in Leatherhead Road, Hook. He was thought to have been picked up by a stocky, grey-haired man in an Austin Westminster grey saloon. There was speculation at the time that Roy had been murdered by a paedophile ring, but police refused to say whether they were seeking more than one person in connection with the death.

Roy's father died two years after the murder and his mother died in 1996. His brother Colin and sister Margaret are still alive and police are keeping them informed of developments.

fields.headline: Fire in the fingers
fields.standfirst: Andrew Clements  compares three interpreters of Schumann's piano music and hails a new master
fields.trailText: Andrew Clements compares three interpreters of Schumann's piano music and hails a new master
fields.body:
Schumann: Fantasy in C; Etudes Symphoniques; Piano Sonata no 2 Marc-André Hamelin
(Hyperion)
****
£12.99

Schumann: Piano Sonatas Nos 1 & 2; Waldszenen Eliso Virsaladze
(Live Classics)
****
£10.99

Schumann: Kinderszenen; Kreisleriana; Waldszenen Wilhelm Kempff
(Deutsche Grammophon Galleria)
**
£6.99

Schumann's piano music can be curiously elusive on disc. There are plenty of very fine performances around, but relatively few great ones, and fewer still of those have been made in the digital age. You have to go back two decades and more for the last genuinely outstanding discs - by Martha Argerich (who has not made any solo studio recordings since) and Maurizio Pollini (whose playing now never quite recaptures the spontaneity and personality it had in the 1970s). But Marc-André Hamelin's new recital unquestionably deserves a place right alongside them.

The Canadian-born Hamelin made his name with startlingly brilliant performances of Valentin Alkan's over-the-top 19th-century piano works, but in recital and on disc he has steadily broadened his range, and demonstrated that he is very much more than a fast-fingered technician. The clinching evidence of his completeness as an interpreter comes on this disc.

That all three works are immaculately played almost goes without saying - the closing second of the second movement of the C major Fantasy is a notoriously revealing test for any pianist, which even some of the greatest Schumann interpreters have failed, but Hamelin sails through it. His tempo seems unsustainable when he sets out, but he triumphantly vindicates it by the end.

But there really is much more to his performances here than just keyboard brilliance. Hamelin makes even the more tendentious of Schumann's formal schemes (that of the G minor Sonata, for instance) totally organic through his thoughtful dovetailing of sections, and by the way in which he relates the tempo of each section to that of the next. Every phrase is shaped by his easy, never self-conscious rubato. Each of the variations in the Etudes Symphoniques (Schumann's original version, without the "posthumous" numbers that some pianists interpolate) is deftly and instantly characterised, and the big-boned finale generates a thrilling head of steam.

Only at the very beginning of the Fantasy is there a suspicion that the expressiveness is a bit too generalised, and that the edges are softened more than is required by this most classically structured of all Schumann's piano works. But those reservations are quickly swept aside by the sheer magnificence of the playing that follows, in which the ebb and flow of the invention is plotted so vividly.

Hamelin's account of the G minor Sonata, with a genuinely searching slow movement and a dazzling dispatch of the final Presto, stands up proudly against any other on record - even Argerich's much more impulsive version from the early 1970s, and Horowitz's famous old account - and it makes a fascinating comparison with that by the much-respected Russian pianist and teacher Eliso Virsaladze, on one of the latest in the Live Classics series.

Virsaladze's performances of the G minor Sonata and Waldszenen were recorded at a recital in Moscow in 1973; the F sharp minor Sonata dates from Moscow in 1980. There is a great deal to admire in all three. The sleeve notes, which are otherwise pretty perfunctory, include a panegyric from Sviatoslav Richter about these very performances - "Can one imagine a more beautiful Schumann than Eliso offered us this evening?" - and it is easy to see how in the concert hall these would have been compellingly vivid.

Virsaladze attacks both sonatas with physical relish; she does not attempt the tonal refinement and clarity that Hamelin brings to the G minor, but ratchets up the excitement notch by notch. Subtlety isn't her objective, though in the miniatures of Waldszenen she captures the melodic essence of each with directness and much charm. As a document of one of the most important figures in recent Russian piano playing, it is all well worth hearing.

For good or bad, the reissue of Wilhelm Kempff's Schumann collection from 1973 and 1974 really does sound now like playing from another age. Kempff was then in his late 70s, and had lost the sense of freshness and simple directness that made him a favourite pianist of the early LP age. All three works here, even the simple lyrics of Kinderszenen and Waldszenen, get rather bumpy rides, with unaccountable lapses of continuity and laboured expressiveness, even though Kempff's clear, singing tone sometimes comes across. But the surging energy of Kreisleriana simply defeats him: this is one of Schumann's piano works whose sheer ebullience must be difficult to recapture in the tranquillity of old age. Kempff admirers will already have these performances from their earlier incarnations; those looking for authoritative accounts of these three works would do much better to look elsewhere.

fields.headline: Masked attackers beat Huntingdon boss
fields.trailText: The managing director of Huntingdon Life Sciences, the research laboratory which has  been targeted by animal rights campaigners, was attacked by three masked people wielding baseball bats last night.
fields.body:
The managing director of Huntingdon Life Sciences, the research laboratory which has been targeted by animal rights campaigners, was attacked by three masked people wielding baseball bats last night.

Cambridgeshire police say they are in no doubt the attack was linked to the animal experiments carried at HLS.

Detective Inspector Robbie Robertson said the "callous and cowardly" attack on Brian Cass, 53, happened as he arrived at his home in St Ives at around 7.50pm last night. Two members of the public who tried to help Mr Cass were sprayed with CS gas before the assailants, one of whom is believed to be a woman, fled.

Mr Cass was beaten about the head and upper body, and suffered an arm injury as he tried to defend himself.

He was taken to Hunchingbrooke Hospital, Huntingdon, where several stitches were put into a head wound. He has now been allowed home.

Mr Robertson said: "Last night's attack was callous and cowardly and we are in no doubt it is connected to Mr Cass's work at Huntingdon Life Sciences.

"In recent months we have witnessed an escalation in the nature of attacks on people and property associated with Huntingdon Life Sciences.

"Last night's events make us more determined to catch those who are responsible for these attacks."

Natasha Taylor of Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty, a campaign aimed at shutting HLS down, said: "We unreservedly condemn any act of violence be it against animals or humans."

Robin Webb of the Animal Liberation Front said: "Although we do not condone that kind of action we understand the kind of anger and frustration that moves lots of people to more radical paths when other avenues have failed."

Both organisations said they had nothing to do with last night's attack on Mr Cass.

A spokesman for HLS said: "Mr Cass will be going to work today but we cannot say when. Security at Huntingdon remains as tight as it has always been and no doubt we will be giving staff further information on how to improve safety at home."

webTitle: Spanish referee with a liking for thrillers

fields.headline: Spanish referee with a liking for thrillers
fields.trailText: Jose Maria Garcia-Aranda has a reputation as a disciplinarian - and Roma know all about him. At this stage of the Uefa Cup last season he sent off two of their players, Zago and Vincent Candela, when they went out 1-0 at Leeds.
fields.body:
Jose Maria Garcia-Aranda has a reputation as a disciplinarian - and Roma know all about him. At this stage of the Uefa Cup last season he sent off two of their players, Zago and Vincent Candela, when they went out 1-0 at Leeds.

But his most controversial red card came in the France-Croatia World Cup semi-final two years ago, when he cost Laurent Blanc a place in the final by sending him off after the French defender tangled with Slaven Bilic.

Bilic, the former West Ham and Everton central defender, said he thought Garcia-Aranda was "brilliant... I went to him after the game and told him he really impressed me". Blanc took a contrary view. The sending-off, he said, "was unfair and catastrophic for me".

Garcia-Aranda is a 44-year-old physical education professor from Madrid. The son of a referee, he has worked in the Primera Division for 12 years and been a Fifa referee since 1993.

According to his World Cup data sheet, his favourite movie is Alfred Hitchcock's Rear Window. This is the film, you may remember, where James Stewart becomes convinced that a woman has been murdered in a neighbouring apartment. It builds to a menacing climax, somewhat like last night's game. And in the end, of course, Stewart is proved right.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: The Invisible Circus
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: An intriguing tale with a broad temporal and physical sweep. And yet it ends up looking like a TV movie, or even, with its tangled and implausible pattern of character development, like a weirdly digressive daytime soap.
fields.body:
This is a curious film in many ways, with interests extending beyond the parochial horizons of most Hollywood fare. It's not without ambition or narrative interest and displays a distinctively thoughtful mien, deriving from its literary origins as a novel by Jennifer Egan.

Cameron Diaz plays Faith, a crinkly-haired middle-class San Francisco hippie who heads off to Europe in a camper-van in 1969 to get into the activist vibe. Mixed up in heavier and heavier scenes, she hangs with a kind of Baader-Meinhof group in West Germany and winds up dying a mysterious death. Seven years later, in 1976, her younger sister Phoebe, played by Jordana Brewster, goes on a personal odyssey to Europe to reconstruct her sister's life that fateful summer. To do this, she must ignore the barely suppressed rage of her fretful mother, played - perhaps inevitably - by Blythe Danner, who still has unresolved issues (as no one used to say in those days) relating to the death of her husband (Patrick Bergin).

Phoebe meets up with Wolf, her intense British boyfriend, played by Christopher Eccleston; they head off together; they incubate intense feelings for Faith and each other in various pensione and Faith herself appears in a cumbersome series of heavily signposted flashbacks.

On the face of it, it's an intriguing tale with a broad temporal and physical sweep. And yet it ends up looking like a TV movie, or even, with its tangled and implausible pattern of character development, like a weirdly digressive daytime soap. Cameron Diaz has already demonstrated in Being John Malkovich that she can play outside the conventional female-lead template, and the part of a beautiful idealistic flower-child who flirts with extremism should be ideal. Yet here she often just looks silly, never more so than romping with a bunch of counter-culture free spirits in the family kitchen: the "invisible circus" of the title.

A lot of Phoebe's Fodor-guide spiritual journey through Europe looks cliched as well, and like Cameron Crowe in Almost Famous, writer-director Adam Brooks thinks that a carefully modulated "acid trip" sequence wraps up the drugs issue.

The movie is furthermore naive about terrorism - the revolutionary anarchists are pretty squeamish about violence here and look like they would be better employed working for Anita Roddick. An oddity, undoubtedly headed for late-night cable.

It's not without ambition or narrative interest and displays a distinctively thoughtful mien, deriving from its literary origins as a novel by Jennifer Egan. Cameron Diaz plays Faith, a crinkly-haired middle-class San Francisco hippie who heads off to Europe in a camper-van in 1969 to get into the activist vibe. Mixed up in heavier and heavier scenes, she hangs with a kind of Baader-Meinhof group in West Germany and winds up dying a mysterious death. fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Shanghai Noon |  Earth | L'Humanité
fields.trailText: Shanghai Noon | Earth | L'Humanité
fields.body:
Shanghai Noon
Rental and DVD rental
Buena Vista Cert 12

A light-hearted buddy-buddy east-meets-west comedy that is hugely amiable and works a treat. It gives Jackie Chan a far better role than his other Hollywood vehicle, Rush Hour (now filming a sequel), and surely elevates Owen Wilson to a new level of celebrity. Already the co-writer of the eccentrically brilliant Rushmore, he looks a bit of a Sundance Kid here and pulls the same trick of playing a contemporary character in the old west, performed with superb timing and reams of laconic, drawled philosophy, charm and deviousness. Chan and Wilson makes a real team and the exuberance of their interplay suggests both actors were having a ball (compare and contrast particularly with Will Smith and Kevin Kline's disconnected duo in Wild Wild West, the last, disastrous attempt at frontier comedy). Debutant director Tom Dey makes the camera almost as acrobatic as Chan, whose English is clearly improving; and, like its title, Shanghai Noon pulls some neat twists on the old west. There's some sloppy plotting, but it's a small price to pay for such an engaging movie with some superb set-pieces.

Earth
Retail (£15.99)
Fox Pathé Cert 15

Part two of Deepa Mehta's controversial trilogy, Earth concentrates on the 1947 partition of India, when independence was combined with widespread carnage. In the foreground, the estimable Nandita Das (from Fire) is being wooed and considering a union. In the background, a country is breaking into warring tribal and religious groupings. A mood of foreboding sets in, despite the beautiful settings. There are moments of quiet contemplation and comedy, largely seen through a child's eyes, but it leads to a shocking ending.

L'Humanité
Retail (£15)
Artificial Eye Cert 18

A masterpiece, in some critics' views, but Bruno Dumont's film is like a parody of the European art movie at its longest, slowest and drabbest. Camera movement is non-existent, facial expression is largely absent from its non-professional actors. Shots are frequently held too long as if to say "and then, nothing happened". Kitano or Kaurismaki can get away with this in counterpoint to brief, memorable action but here, despite a plot about a detective trying to solve a little girl's murder, there isn't any. Just some graphic, joyless sex, and oodles of gloom.

fields.headline: The Legend of Bagger Vance
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Redford seems blithely uninterested in the politics of race, and his movie is narrated by an innocent 10-year-old boy, thus making these adult concerns conveniently inadmissible.
fields.body:
Watching this Robert Redford-directed movie, it's impossible not to think of Wilde's remark about all portraits being self-portraits. The camera lingers lovingly on the all-American young blond face of Matt Damon, and Mr Redford invites us to believe that these winsome chops can be quite unchanged through 15 years of story time, 1916 to 1931, during which period Damon is supposed to have gone through front-line service in the first world war, near-alcoholism and a virtual nervous breakdown - and his puppyishly pert good looks are not a whit diminished. Did Redford perhaps for a fleeting moment entertain the thought of playing the role himself, with a gallon of Vaseline for the lens?

Whatever its obscure origins in wish- fulfilment, this movie is an example of Redford's sweet tooth for heritage-shoppe Americana, taken here from the Jazz Age, with much picturesque Depression-era hardship, floppy caps and plus-fours familiar from The Sting, The Great Waldo Pepper, The Great Gatsby etc. Damon plays Rannulph Junuh, a superb golfer from Savannah, Georgia, who falls in love with the wealthy and beautiful Adele (Charlize Theron). He goes to war, and his experiences - on which Redford does not dwell - are enough to make him give up golf and Adele, develop designer stubble and take to the bottle in what is supposed to be squalor, but what looks mysteriously like a squat in a large and elegant mansion. Meanwhile, Adele needs him for a huge exhibition match she is organising on her late daddy's swanky golfing resort - so the old (or rather exquisitely young) clubslinger has to get his mashies and niblicks out for that last big comeback.

At which point, Matt Damon gets that accoutrement that no white star can afford to be without. The gift for the Wasp protagonist who has everything. The black guardian angel! Nic Cage had one in The Family Man, and now Matt does too. Will Smith plays the wise Bagger Vance, his caddy, the man who schools Matt in how to regain his all-important "swing". Golf is of course hardly famed for its friendliness to minorities; Bagger can't go any higher than caddy, and certainly not in good ol' Savannah. But Redford seems blithely uninterested in the politics of race, and his movie is narrated by an innocent 10-year-old boy, thus making these adult concerns conveniently inadmissible. Actually, the enigmatic Bagger doesn't have much of a "legend" or history of any sort: the legend is all Sunuh's, local hero and comeback kid - and what a boring legend it is. Golf fans might derive some interest, but it's very weak and a waste of that very watchable comic performer Will Smith.

fields.headline: Liam
fields.standfirst: Jimmy McGovern piles on the grim-up-north cliches in his script about Liverpool in the 1930s, says  Peter Bradshaw
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: There often seems to be a gap where the humanity and the humour are supposed to go.
fields.body:
Is it possible to make a film about a working-class 1930s childhood without the getting-the-strap scene in the schoolroom, or the seriocomic scene in confessional, or the rapturous cowboys-and-Indians scene in the cinema? Maybe not. Perhaps excluding these scenes would be just perverse, especially as the authoritarian schoolmaster and priest were figures with real power scarcely imaginable now, and regular attendance at Mass and the cinema were readily comparable experiences.

At any rate, Stephen Frears's new film - with its fiercely, almost belligerently grim screenplay by Jimmy McGovern - revisits familiar scenarios in its account of a Catholic boyhood in pre-war Liverpool, centring on Liam, a seven-year-old boy afflicted with a terrible stammer.

Frears and McGovern's movie unquestionably gives a platform to vivid, intelligent performances from Ian Hart as Liam's dad, the embittered, unemployed docker who joins Oswald Mosley's Blackshirts, Claire Hackett as his mam, and perhaps especially Megan Burns as Liam's elder sister Teresa, who goes into service in a wealthy, cultured Jewish household, and finds herself drawn into covering up her mistress's adulteries. Teresa becomes quietly light-headed with the unaccustomed atmosphere of comfort and tolerant gaiety, but then gets convulsed with a backwash of guilt about preferring them to her own family. Burns portrays all this with sympathy and emotional clarity.

Sin and shame are at the heart of this movie: bacilli fostered in the Petri dish of poverty and religious authoritarianism. When Scorsese had Harvey Keitel wincingly apply a candle-flame to his hand and ruminate about hell and atoning for your sins not in church but on the streets, he pulled off the remarkable achievement of persuading his audience to take sin seriously in a secular context. The horror and fascination of eternal damnation are present in McGovern's script too, only in a more diffuse, less articulate way. They brood over the Liverpool backstreets like filthy weather, and only become manifest in the film's terrible conclusion: Hart's grotesquely bungled attempt at an anti-semitic firebombing.

There is an awful lot of deja vu to be experienced in this movie. The poor pinched-faced mixed infants have to endure much bizarre haranguing from schoolmistress and cleric alike, and there is a gloomy sermon on the subject of hell's eternity that the priest has plagiarised from Joyce's Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man. These scenes, and many others, look a lot like sequences from Alan Parker's underrated Angela's Ashes. Both films are vulnerable to the charge of Hovis-commercial poverty, though Frears brings some of it off better than Parker. (Hart's closing-time drunkenness looks more convincing, for example, than Robert Carlyle's unhappy attempt at the same thing.)

As Liam, newcomer Anthony Borrows has a nice scene where he blurts out in confession that he has seen his mother naked, having been tormented by a Ruskin-type anxiety that her pubic hair makes her different from the "real" women he has seen in the Old Masters. But the comic confection of that moment is almost unique in the stern, salty porridge of gloom that Frears is serving up. And in Liam there often seems to be a gap where the humanity and the humour are supposed to go. No one should need or expect palliatives in a movie dealing with serious issues, but I couldn't help feeling that a director like Terence Davies would have dealt with them quite as unflinchingly, but found epiphanies and moments of redemptive meaning for which there seems to be no room in this film.

When fascism makes its unlovely appearance, Frears has a very adroit scene when Dad must reveal himself to his astonished family in his black shirt for the first time; and brazen out with ugly determination what is immediately apparent to his nearest and dearest - that he looks sinister and quite absurd. That must be a recurrent moment in the secret history of fascism that is unremarked by historians, but shrewdly captured here (there are similar instances in Cabaret and The Tin Drum).

His son turns against him, favouring the socialists, and for a while it looks as if there is going to be an important split between the two of them. But actually, despite some scenes at which Hart is shown shiftily turning up at rallies and trying on the outfit - and some coppers busting up a union meeting - politics itself doesn't play that big a part. When Hart is shown directing an arsonist blackshirt mob in the final reel, we are invited to assume that he has risen through the fascist ranks to some position of power; but slightly perplexingly, this development happens off camera. Frears's camera lingers in the kitchen, in church, in the street, but not in the meeting hall or smoke-filled room. Which is a shame - some exposition of this sort might have given the film more sinew.

Finally, we are left with a harrowing episode of violence, but it's not clear what exactly we can make of it all. In the end, I'm afraid, you'll leave the cinema battered, shocked and dispirited rather than moved or enlightened.

fields.headline: Finding Forrester
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: It is quite devoid of anything unexpected whatsoever.
fields.body:
Is Sean Connery wearing eyeliner? I only ask. His strongly defined eyes and dark eyebrows, under that silvery mane of a hairpiece, seem to be one of the few points of interest in this cloying mentoring-drama in which Connery is co-producer and star. It is quite devoid of anything unexpected whatsoever, and dismayingly similar to director Gus Van Sant's 1997 film Good Will Hunting - something which Van Sant appears coyly to concede by giving Matt Damon a cameo role.

Connery plays William Forrester, an ageing recluse of a writer, living like a hermit in his decaying apartment in the Bronx. He had one big hit in his youth, but now lives in a curmudgeonly semi-squalor of books and papers and is naturally waiting for a clear-eyed young person to discover his heart of gold and re-awaken his creative passion. (See also Michael Douglas in Wonder Boys.) The young person is Jamal Wallace (Rob Brown), a black 16-year-old with a genius for both basketball and literature, familiar with Coleridge, Kipling, Dickens and Conan Doyle. Jamal creeps into Forrester's apartment for a dare, but accidentally leaves his notebook behind. The impish Forrester scribbles pedagogic remarks all over Jamal's unformed jottings and a sparky, mutually nurturing relationship gets going.

Getting past the race thing is clearly supposed to be an important part of the film's worthy humanist message, but it is curious how both Jamal and Forrester are so totally uninterested in black literature. At any rate, Jamal's spirit is in danger of being crushed by a villainous teacher with a hint of bigotry, played by F Murray Abraham - this hateful mediocrity is, as good fortune would have it, an old enemy of Forrester's, whose publishing career Forrester had cheerfully crushed years ago, and ripe for another easy comeuppance. Thus are the racial issues of education and class triumphantly resolved. It's all very glib, with its attempt at representing tough street realities doused with treacly sentimentality.

webTitle: A Man Named Dave by Dave Pelzer

fields.headline: A Man Named Dave by Dave Pelzer
fields.standfirst:
Orion £12.99
Condensed in the style of the original
Buy it at a discount from BOL
fields.trailText: I've got so much life to live, I've got so much love to give, I will survive. I will survive
fields.body:
I want mommy but it's mother who answers. "So what does IT want?" she sneers, half-drunk. "You're nothing, you shit." I was 12 when I was put into care. I tried to put the stabbing and the beatings behind me, but the memories haunted me. I needed to prove I was a worthwhile person, but I still felt the shame. Somehow it was all my fault.

I worked day and night to get through college; I was determined to enlist in the air force and become a firefighter. My dad had been a fireman before he hit the bottle and left us.

"Congratulations. You're in," said the sergeant. At last I was worth something. "As a cook." I felt ashamed but I became the best cook I could, and saved every cent. I even sent some money to my dad, though he never thanked me.

"Your father's dying of cancer," said the officer.

I stood by his bed. Why hadn't mother got word to me sooner? Could she really hate me that much? My dad couldn't speak, but I told him I knew he had done his best for us as he passed away.

"Give me the insurance papers, IT, " said mother at his funeral. Suddenly I understood the source of her hatred; she had been abused by her mother.

"I understand," I said. "You understand nothing, IT ," she answered.

Several years later I graduated to the refuelling aircrew and met Patsy, my first proper girlfriend. We kind of got on, and even though my friends disliked her, we had a baby boy, Stephen, and got married.

"You've been using my credit card," I said one day. "Gad, don't you trust me?" She was right, I didn't. I was bad.

I visited mother before she died. She was drunk and desperate for forgiveness. I couldn't bring myself to give it.

"You're a loser," said Patsy. "You've left the air force to become a motivational speaker and you've been ripped off by your company. They haven't even printed any copies of your book." "You're right," I replied. "I've let you down. Everything's my fault. We should separate." Within days Patsy found a new man.

I struggled with my feelings of shame, before sending my manuscript to a publisher out east. "I feel like I want to spend the rest of my life with you," said my editor, Marsha, having known me for 10 seconds. "I feel the same way." And we all lived happily ever after.

And if you really are pressed, the digested read, digested: I've got so much life to live, I've got so much love to give, I will survive. I will survive

The English game's global appeal was made manifest yesterday when the Premier League sold the overseas television rights for £178m.

The three-year deal was announced at a meeting of league chairmen in London and is a significant increase on the previous £98m deal. From next season a consortium of four companies made up of Sport Plus, Rupert Murdoch's Newscorp, TWI and Octagon CSI will broadcast Premiership matches around the world. The £178m will be evenly divided between all 20 clubs.

Officials will now sit down with representatives of the four companies to work out a global marketing strategy for the league with the aim of increasing its popularity in markets such as the United States and Asia.

Richard Scudamore, the Premier League's chief executive, said: "This is an exceptionally good arrangement for all parties. After lengthy negotiations we have concluded a deal that recognises the enormous global strength of the FA Premier League. The exposure this gives us will enhance the reputation of the league and its member clubs throughout the world."

The club chairmen were told by Scudamore that two companies, who remain in talks about taking over sponsorship of the league from Carling, may be further persuaded by a clearer picture of the global exposure they will receive.

The league refuses to name either company until the end of April. A new sponsor is due to be announced by the start of next season.

During yesterday's meeting, club chairmen also backed Fifa and Uefa in its negotiations with the European Commission over the transfer system. Many spoke about the need for contractual stability and criticised Fifpro, the players' organisation, which wants to give footballers greater freedom to break contracts.

webTitle: Hull City saved by mystery buyer

fields.headline: Hull City saved by mystery buyer
fields.trailText: A buyer has been found for the troubled Third Division club Hull City. Details of the deal were revealed at the high court in Liverpool yesterday, when administrators were given until April 30 to secure the future of the club.
fields.body:
A buyer has been found for the troubled Third Division club Hull City. Details of the deal were revealed at the high court in Liverpool yesterday, when administrators were given until April 30 to secure the future of the club.

The court heard that the unnamed buyer would immediately put £85,000 into the club to keep it trading until a meeting scheduled for March 8. Then creditors and shareholders will be asked to vote on a creditors' voluntary arrangement that would see the Tigers sold for £360,000.

But during the half-hour hearing details emerged of a rival bid that had been forwarded directly to the court. The judge ordered that the terms of that and any further bids should be circulated to creditors before the March meeting in Hull.

Administrators were brought in this month after Hull survived a winding-up order issued by Customs and Excise and the Inland Revenue for unpaid debts.

fields.headline: Chesterfield charged over irregularities
fields.trailText: Chesterfield must wait between four and six weeks to find out whether they will be expelled from the Football League after being charged yesterday with serious financial irregularities.
fields.body:
Chesterfield must wait between four and six weeks to find out whether they will be expelled from the Football League after being charged yesterday with serious financial irregularities.

The Third Division leaders have been under investigation since a delegation from the league and the Football Association arrived unannounced at Saltergate last month to investigate a number of complaints about the club's business practices since their chairman, Darren Brown, took over from Norton Lea last May.

They have been charged with offences relating to breaches of transfer regulations, irregular payments and falsifying gate receipts.

Several charges have also been issued against Chesterfield officials and employees, although the league declined to specify the nature of the alleged offences.

"Chesterfield have 14 days to respond and we will be looking to get a date within the next month for a hearing," said the league's spokesman John Nagle. "If a club is found guilty of these charges they could be expelled from the league and then it would be up to the Conference whether or not to accept them. That is the top end of our powers but there are other options such as deducting league points and issuing fines."

fields.headline: Portsmouth turn to manager Rix
fields.trailText: The former Chelsea coach Graham Rix will today be named manager of Portsmouth, replacing Steve Claridge, who loses his job after 19 weeks in charge at Fratton Park.
fields.body:
The former Chelsea coach Graham Rix will today be named manager of Portsmouth, replacing Steve Claridge, who loses his job after 19 weeks in charge at Fratton Park.

Rix, 43, will be unveiled at a press conference today by Portsmouth's wealthy United States-based chairman Milan Mandaric. It will be Rix's first managerial job, having been sacked from his coaching role at Chelsea after Claudio Ranieri replaced Gianluca Vialli.

Claridge, 34, who took over as player-manager from Tony Pulis last October, faces the prospect of continuing as a player-coach under Rix or quitting the club he first joined as a 16-year-old apprentice.

Ipswich have signed the Celtic striker Mark Burchill on loan until the end of the season. Burchill goes straight into the squad for tomorrow's home game against Everton as Town will be without their strikers Marcus Stewart and Richard Naylor through suspension and injury respectively.

The manager George Burley said: "He's a young international player. I've been looking to add to the squad for a number of months and Mark comes at a good time with our injuries and suspensions."

Birmingham will open contract talks with Trevor Francis despite yesterday's warning from their owner David Sullivan, three days before the club's Worthington Cup final against Liverpool, that the manager could be sacked at the end of the season should City fail to make the play-offs.

Last night, in an apparently conciliatory move, the club's chief executive Karren Brady confirmed that she will be holding talks over a long-term contract with Francis, who has another season on his current deal, at the end of the season.

The Charlton goalkeeper Dean Kiely and Spurs' right-back Stephen Carr have pulled out of the Republic of Ireland's friendly against Denmark in Dublin on Wednesday because of injury. The Irish manager Mick McCarthy has not named a replacement for either, and has both Newcastle's Shay Given and Alan Kelly of Blackburn as goalkeeping cover.

webTitle: After 104 days, 47 matches and one Abba musical, Tord talks at last

fields.headline: After 104 days, 47 matches and one Abba musical, Tord talks at last
fields.trailText: Jon Brodkin meets the man who has done more than anyone to sort the maybes from the must-bes in Sven-Goran Eriksson's first England squad.
fields.body:
When English eyes focus on Sven-Goran Eriksson this afternoon, eagerly awaiting the Swede's first national team squad, the man who has done more than anyone to sort the maybes from the must-bes will be out of view.

Tord Grip has undertaken such a marathon tour of England since being dispatched from Lazio by Eriksson in November that he might have caused a petrol crisis. When he accompanied Eriksson to Anfield last night he took the number of matches he has seen in 3 months to 47, with 45 of them at the top level.

Just how familiar Grip's face is in executive boxes and service stations is a tribute to the esteem in which he is held by his boss. Asked recently to pinpoint his finest qualities as a coach, Eriksson replied: "Tord Grip".

The trust is plain in a relationship that dates back to the 70s and that has seen the Swedes nickname Grip "one half of Sven-Goran's brain". So close are the pair that they have been spotted together not just at matches but at Mamma Mia, the musical featuring the tunes of Sweden's finest, Abba. "A very good performance," Grip says, for once not referring to a wannabe for today's squad. "I like Abba's music; Benny Andersson is my favourite."

Men with attitude

Having watched every Premiership club, Grip will have plenty of sway in the selection of the squad to play Spain on Wednesday. As a former Norway coach who had two spells as Sweden's No2, assisting at the 1978 World Cup and helping the team to the semi-finals of Euro 92 and USA 94, he knows what to look for in an international player.

"Of course skill and technique," he says, "but also the attitude to the game. You need to be able to take a challenge or a tackle without arguing and without doing silly things afterwards because players will sometimes be more provoked in international games and, if you meet players from other countries who have another culture, you must be able to deal with that. You must be very steady."

Hence Grip, who won three Sweden caps, has been chatting as well as watching. At games he has been talking to managers and coaches, asking about players, picking up information. And he has made trips to training grounds as well, looking at facilities and coaching methods. He saw Bobby Robson put Newcastle through their paces and he has also visited Arsenal.

Not that his knowledge is restricted to such simple questions as the name of Sunderland's left-back. In December Grip saw England's Under-16s lose to France at White Hart Lane in the afternoon and the Under-17s win at the Valley in the evening. "The academies are growing and getting better," he says, "so there is a future in English football, no doubt."

Grip was hardly unfamiliar with Premiership football, having scouted Arsenal and Chelsea before their Champions League games against Lazio, but he sounds pleasantly surprised.

"What I hadn't seen was how many talented young players there are in England," he says. "They need to get experience of international opponents, of course; that is the main thing. It helps that some play in the Champions League and the Uefa Cup. But they aren't all playing in Europe, so they need to get experience in the Under-21 team or the full team. You have had a lot of success with the Under-21s in the last years, so it should be a good future. Then it is up to us."

By us he means the whole coaching team, including Peter Taylor, Steve McClaren and the goalkeeping specialist Ray Clemence. Yet there is a special bond between Eriksson and Grip. "I can read his mind and perhaps he can read mine," says Grip, whose day-to-day involvement in training at Lazio suggests he will be more than a super-scout.

Having first worked together at KB Karlskoga, where Grip was player-coach and Eriksson played behind him as right-back, Grip gave Eriksson his first coach ing job as his assistant at Degerfors. Since then they have worked in tandem with the Sweden Under-21s and at Lazio, and they talked regularly in the 18 years they were apart. "We speak openly to each other," Grip explains. He spotted something special in Eriksson from the start.

"I saw his ambition as a player and a coach," Grip explains. "He was not that talented a player when he started but with his ambition he went into the First Division club [KB Karlskoga] where I was manager and took a place in the team. He had the same ambition as a coach. He was determined to succeed."

Grip, like Eriksson, is an honest, likeable man. Raised in a small village in the north of Sweden where he spent six years working in the bakery, he describes his new job as "more than I could have dreamed of".

It says much for his unpretentiousness that to get to work at Soho Square he takes the bus or walks an hour and a quarter. "I prefer to walk," he says. "It's a lovely journey through Hyde Park and into Mayfair."

Finally, after thousands of miles and 47 matches, the journey is about to begin. England fans hope that it will take them through Japan and South Korea.

Marathon mission

Sven-Goran Eriksson's right-hand man has now seen every Premiership team in action. Liverpool, with their trio of England strikers, and West Ham, with their youthful midfield, have been watched the most - seven times - while prospects for Everton and Middlesbrough players look bleak with only one viewing apiece.
