webTitle: England repair work starts after Sven's crash course

fields.headline: England repair work starts after Sven's crash course
fields.standfirst: Jon Brodkin meets Tord Grip
fields.trailText: Sven-Goran Eriksson's squad to face Spain will be scanned anxiously for new or nearly new names and seldom has an England party been so eagerly awaited.
fields.body:
Today Sven-Goran Eriksson stops watching and starts working. The results of the England coach's crash course in Premiership football will at last be disclosed when he announces his first squad for next Wednesday's friendly against Spain at Villa Park.

Seldom has an England party been so eagerly awaited. As the first foreigner to be put in charge of the national squad he was bound to carry a certain air of mystique as he set about the business of restoring the modest fortunes of a team discomforted by Glenn Hoddle and deserted by Kevin Keegan.

Whoever succeeded Keegan, the pool of players would have been the same. Yet there is no denying the happiness of the coincidence which brings together the wide coaching experience of Eriksson and his assistant, Tord Grip, with the healthiest crop of young players England have had for ages.

But even with the best of crops the timing of the harvest is everything. Gather the corn too soon and its greenness becomes all too apparent; leave it too late and its value is limited.

Today's squad will be scanned anxiously for new or nearly new names. For Wes Brown, the 21-year-old Manchester United de fender capped once by Keegan, the full England story surely begins now. For West Ham's Joe Cole a regular squad place beckons and for Ashley Cole, Arsenal's fast-maturing 20-year-old left-back, England recognition cannot be far off.

Other fresh faces are jostling for attention: John Terry, another 20-year-old defender who at Chelsea does not look out of place alongside Marcel Desailly; Michael Carrick, only 19 but already reckoned by West Ham aficionados to have even greater potential as a midfielder than Joe Cole; and Richard Wright, the once-capped Ipswich goalkeeper who is putting some in mind of the young Gordon Banks.

Eriksson will want to examine some of his youthful options. But since the Spain game is the only chance he will have to watch England in action before the World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania at the end of next month he will not be repeating Peter Taylor's bold, if slightly bizarre, experiment in Italy by limiting his selection to players of 30 or under.

For Eriksson building the basis of a successful side will be a familiar matter of blending promising but untried talent with international experience. He may feel he needs Teddy Sheringham, 35 in April but still the country's leading scorer along with Andy Cole, as much as Emile Heskey.

Since Steven Gerrard, the 20-year-old quickly earmarked by Grip as a likely keystone in midfield, is again out of the Liverpool team with groin problems Eriksson could also turn in the short term to Paul Ince, in excellent form since Terry Venables took over the coaching at Middlesbrough, or even David Batty, by no means finished despite a long period of inactivity at Leeds.

Whatever happens Eriksson will be seeking to create the backbone of a team without which talk of formations and tactics is merely idle gossip. Hoddle did have one up to the point of England's departure from the 1998 World Cup but since then the team has suffered from a series of spinal disorders.

The retirements of Alan Shearer and Tony Adams have emphasised the need for players who will provide strong and enduring vertebrae around which the rest of a team skeleton can be formed. In this re spect Eriksson will be starting from scratch, since Keegan's sudden departure left England in a valley of dry bones.

Of the old spinal column only David Seaman remains and after the way he was beaten by Dietmar Hamann's speculative 35-yard shot when Germany won at Wembley in England's opening World Cup qualifier last October, the Arsenal goalkeeper's international career may already be over.

At centre-back Sol Campbell represents continuity and with Martin Keown and Gareth Southgate unfit, the Tottenham player will be a crucial figure on Wednesday and beyond. In midfield Eriksson will be looking to David Beckham and Paul Scholes for creativity and stability, although from now on Scholes's role could be more about playing off the front man, Heskey obviously.

Speculation about Eriksson's intended formation is unlikely to end at Villa Park; if anything the Spain match will pose more questions than it answers. However it does appear that the England coach will mostly operate with a back four while permutating his midfield and attack according to circumstances.

For the World Cup qualifier against Finland at Anfield on March 24, for instance, he might use two strikers, Heskey and Michael Owen, with Scholes, Sheringham, Steve McManaman, Nick Barmby or, at a pinch, Joe Cole, in support. For the matches in Albania and Greece he could play with one man up, Heskey say, supported by Barmby and Sheringham. Robbie Fowler, if he stays fit, could be a viable attacking option in any system.

The Football Association hopes that, under Eriksson, England can become a genuine international force in time for the 2006 World Cup. But for this to have a better chance of happening it is essential that England qualify for the tournaments in between: the 2002 World Cup in the Far East and the 2004 European Championship in Portugal. Eriksson, then, has to start winning qualifiers immediately.

Possible squad of 26: Goalkeepers: James (Aston Villa), Martyn (Leeds), Wright (Ipswich). fields.bodyText: Today Sven-Goran Eriksson stops watching and starts working. The results of the England coach's crash course in Premiership football will at last be disclosed when he announces his first squad for next Wednesday's friendly against Spain at Villa Park. Seldom has an England party been so eagerly awaited. As the first foreigner to be put in charge of the national squad he was bound to carry a certain air of mystique as he set about the business of restoring the modest fortunes of a team discomforted by Glenn Hoddle and deserted by Kevin Keegan. Whoever succeeded Keegan, the pool of players would have been the same. Yet there is no denying the happiness of the coincidence which brings together the wide coaching experience of Eriksson and his assistant, Tord Grip, with the healthiest crop of young players England have had for ages. But even with the best of crops the timing of the harvest is everything. Gather the corn too soon and its greenness becomes all too apparent; leave it too late and its value is limited. Today's squad will be scanned anxiously for new or nearly new names. For Wes Brown, the 21-year-old Manchester United de fender capped once by Keegan, the full England story surely begins now. For West Ham's Joe Cole a regular squad place beckons and for Ashley Cole, Arsenal's fast-maturing 20-year-old left-back, England recognition cannot be far off. Other fresh faces are jostling for attention: John Terry, another 20-year-old defender who at Chelsea does not look out of place alongside Marcel Desailly; Michael Carrick, only 19 but already reckoned by West Ham aficionados to have even greater potential as a midfielder than Joe Cole; and Richard Wright, the once-capped Ipswich goalkeeper who is putting some in mind of the young Gordon Banks. Eriksson will want to examine some of his youthful options. But since the Spain game is the only chance he will have to watch England in action before the World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania at the end of next month he will not be repeating Peter Taylor's bold, if slightly bizarre, experiment in Italy by limiting his selection to players of 30 or under. For Eriksson building the basis of a successful side will be a familiar matter of blending promising but untried talent with international experience. He may feel he needs Teddy Sheringham, 35 in April but still the country's leading scorer along with Andy Cole, as much as Emile Heskey. Since Steven Gerrard, the 20-year-old quickly earmarked by Grip as a likely keystone in midfield, is again out of the Liverpool team with groin problems Eriksson could also turn in the short term to Paul Ince, in excellent form since Terry Venables took over the coaching at Middlesbrough, or even David Batty, by no means finished despite a long period of inactivity at Leeds. Whatever happens Eriksson will be seeking to create the backbone of a team without which talk of formations and tactics is merely idle gossip. Hoddle did have one up to the point of England's departure from the 1998 World Cup but since then the team has suffered from a series of spinal disorders. The retirements of Alan Shearer and Tony Adams have emphasised the need for players who will provide strong and enduring vertebrae around which the rest of a team skeleton can be formed. In this re spect Eriksson will be starting from scratch, since Keegan's sudden departure left England in a valley of dry bones. Of the old spinal column only David Seaman remains and after the way he was beaten by Dietmar Hamann's speculative 35-yard shot when Germany won at Wembley in England's opening World Cup qualifier last October, the Arsenal goalkeeper's international career may already be over. At centre-back Sol Campbell represents continuity and with Martin Keown and Gareth Southgate unfit, the Tottenham player will be a crucial figure on Wednesday and beyond. In midfield Eriksson will be looking to David Beckham and Paul Scholes for creativity and stability, although from now on Scholes's role could be more about playing off the front man, Heskey obviously. Speculation about Eriksson's intended formation is unlikely to end at Villa Park; if anything the Spain match will pose more questions than it answers. However it does appear that the England coach will mostly operate with a back four while permutating his midfield and attack according to circumstances. For the World Cup qualifier against Finland at Anfield on March 24, for instance, he might use two strikers, Heskey and Michael Owen, with Scholes, Sheringham, Steve McManaman, Nick Barmby or, at a pinch, Joe Cole, in support. For the matches in Albania and Greece he could play with one man up, Heskey say, supported by Barmby and Sheringham. Robbie Fowler, if he stays fit, could be a viable attacking option in any system. The Football Association hopes that, under Eriksson, England can become a genuine international force in time for the 2006 World Cup. But for this to have a better chance of happening it is essential that England qualify for the tournaments in between: the 2002 World Cup in the Far East and the 2004 European Championship in Portugal. webTitle: Elton embraces Eminem in face of protests

fields.headline: Elton embraces Eminem in face of protests
fields.standfirst: Music industry draws around rapper at Grammys
fields.trailText: Eminem may not have won the top prize of album of the year at the Grammy awards ceremony in Los Angeles but he remained the focus of attention at the highly charged event because of protests against his violent and homophobic lyrics.
fields.body:
Eminem may not have won the top prize of album of the year at the Grammy awards ceremony in Los Angeles but he remained the focus of attention at the highly charged event because of protests against his violent and homophobic lyrics.

The rapper performed a much-anticipated duet with the gay rights campaigner Elton John and the two embraced on stage - an event described by a protester on the street outside as "like Barbra Streisand embracing Eva Braun".

Eminem won Grammys for best rap album and best rap solo performance but was beaten for the top award on Wednesday night by the veterans Steely Dan and their Two Against Nature. Bette Midler, who presented the award, said she had been so nervous about the controversy surrounding it and the possibility of protests that she had decided to come on stage with the most popular person in the business, Stevie Wonder.

Just before the award was made, the president of the Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, Michael Greene, made a plea to the packed Staples Centre and a wider television audience not to be too harsh in their judgment, saying: "It takes tolerance to teach tolerance." He likened protests against Eminem to earlier ones against Elvis Presley and the Beatles.

"The white teenagers from the suburbs buy a majority of the music in question," said Mr Greene, who has come under attack from gay and lesbian groups for not speaking out against the Eminem lyrics. "They live out their rebellion and delineate their rite of passage through this music. Most of the adults who pass judgment have never listened to or, more to the point, never even engaged their kids about the object of their contempt.

Mr Greene said "musicians, movie stars and athletes are not perfect" and could not always be relied on to be role models.

Protesters outside in the street had earlier criticised Mr Greene, Eminem and Elton John. One of the speakers at a small rally, the lesbian comedian Robin Tyler, who made the Streisand/Braun remark, accused Eminem of writing "neo-Nazi lyrics". As the limos arrived with the guests, Gwenn Baldwin of the LA Gay and Lesbian Centre said: "Find your edgy voice, Eminem, but don't carve it on the backs of gays and lesbians."

Lynette Sperber of Parents, Families and Friends of Lesbians and Gays said: "Elton John has been such a courageous warrior in our fight ... I wonder if he remembers what it was like for him before he came out."

A few Eminem supporters, including a group calling themselves Faggots 4 Eminem, counter-protested. One, Mike Watters from West Hollywood, said: "Censorship is a slippery slope." He believed that many gay performers had not joined the protests because they did not believe in censorship.

There was also a small contingent of Napster supporters carrying placards in support of the beleaguered music-swapping service.

Early in the proceedings Eminem was on his best behaviour as he won the rap album award and thanked those who voted for him for "seeing past the controversy and seeing the album for what it is and what it isn't". He used the occasion to tell his young daughter "daddy loves you".

Reaction was mixed. Electronic rocker Moby said that he was opposed to censorship and that Eminem was very good at what he did. "But he's also a misogynist and homophobic. I'm 33 and I can see through it but I can't imagine that an eight-year-old in Idaho sees it as just a joke."

Ed O'Brian, of Radiohead, who were also nominated for album of the year for Kid A, said: "We all feel he's made the most culturally significant album of the year and it's a terrific record."

The Irish band U2, always a favourite, picked up awards for the record of the year, song of the year and rock performance by a duo or group with vocal for Beautiful Day. Bono told the audience that he felt that Macy Gray should have got the award for her international hit I Try.

The number of awards has increased again this year to 100, prompting Beck to say before the show "so many categories - it's ridiculous".

There was an historic moment when the native American music album award was made for the first time, to Gathering of Nations Pow Wow, on which 16 drum groups had played. This prompted one of the few political moments of the night when Robbie Robertson, formerly of the Band, raised the case of Leonard Peltier, a native American jailed since 1976 for the killing of two FBI agents at Wounded Knee on what many believe was very flimsy evidence. Noting that Peltier, whose supporters had petitioned Bill Clinton for a pardon, was still not free, Robertson said: "Maybe he's not Mark Rich enough."

What seems to be now an annual award for most non-existent dress, won last year by Jennifer Lopez, went to Toni Braxton. Most unexpected guest went to a tattooed cowboy who dodged security and climbed on stage unannounced, mentioned an FM radio station and shook hands with the host, the comedian Jon Stewart.

The new artist award, often seen as a stepping stone to a big career, went to Shelby Lynne who remarked in accepting it that she had already made six albums.

In other respects, the show went according to tradition with a country singer, Faith Hill, making the most emotional acceptance speech, guests complaining about dreadful downtown traffic and God comfortably beating record companies and parents to the most thanked award.

Record of the year: Beautiful Day (U2).

Album of the year: Two Against Nature (Steely Dan).

Song of the year: Beautiful Day (U2).

Best new artist: Shelby Lynne.

Female pop vocal performance: I Try (Macy Gray).

Male pop vocal performance: She Walks This Earth (Sting).

Dance recording: Who Let the Dogs Out (Baha Men).

Pop vocal album: Two Against Nature (Steely Dan).

Traditional pop vocal album: Both Sides Now (Joni Mitchell).

Female rock vocal performance: There Goes the Neighbourhood (Sheryl Crow).

Male rock vocal performance: Again (Lenny Kravitz).

Hard rock performance: Guerrilla Radio (Rage Against the Machine).

Rock album: There Is Nothing Left to Lose (Foo Fighters).

Alternative music album: Kid A (Radiohead).

Female R&B vocal performance: He Wasn't Man Enough (Toni Braxton).

Male R&B vocal performance: How Does It Feel (D'Angelo).

R&B performance by duo/group with vocal: Say My Name (Destiny's Child).

R&B album: Voodoo (D'Angelo).

Rap solo performance: The Real Slim Shady (Eminem).

Rap performance by duo/group: Forgot About Dre (Dr Dre featuring Eminem).

Rap album: The Marshall Mathers LP (Eminem).

Native American music album: Gathering of Nations Pow Wow (Various artists).

webTitle: L&G in third deal to sell via high street banks

fields.headline: L&G in third deal to sell via high street banks
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Legal & General's umbrella logo is to appear in Alliance & Leicester branches following the third such deal struck by the insurance group with a high street bank.
fields.body:
Legal & General's umbrella logo is to appear in Alliance & Leicester branches following the third such deal struck by the insurance group with a high street bank.

The insurer, which once agreed to be taken over by NatWest in a deal which was never completed, also has similar agreements with Barclays and Northern Rock to sell its savings and insurance products to their customers.

Yesterday's announcement came as rival insurance group Prudential hinted that it too might be interested in clinching such agreements with leading banks.

The deals are being put in place ahead of the introduction of stakeholder pensions - which have low management fees and are expected to hurt insurer's profits - in April.

Revealing an 8% rise in operating profit to £840m, Jonathan Bloomer, Pru's chief executive, pointed to sales arrangements with Standard Chartered and Citigroup in Asia as an example of how it might look for other UK deals.

The Pru's profits figures showed the impact of the decision to cut its team of sales staff, which led to a drop of 24% in UK sales during the year. Profits in the UK insurance operation were 25% lower at £230m as sales of its Prudence Bond and unfashionable mortgage endowments fell.

Pru this week hired Mark Wood, the former chief executive of Axa, to run its European and UK business. While Mr Wood was closely associated with the release of Axa's so-called orphan assets and the ensuing payments to policyholders, Mr Bloomer played down any hopes of an early resolution to its vast estate of assets from dead and lost policyholders, estimated by some analysts to be £8bn.

The insurer tried to soften the impact of falling domestic sales by highlighting its "international development" during the year. Pru is to pay a dividend of 24.5p a share. Yesterday its shares fell 8p to 971p.

fields.headline: Piano Circus
fields.standfirst:
Brewery Arts Centre
Kendal
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Brewery Arts Centre
Kendal
Rating: ****
fields.body:
The six young pianists who comprise the Piano Circus sit with their pianos in an inwardly facing circle, yet still succeed in drawing us into a rarefied musical world.

They begin with Steve Reich's composition Six Pianos, a pivotal feature of their repertoire since the group's formation in 1989, and still the most perfect distillation of their brave and singular approach to live performance.

Reich's masterpiece, which has been known to drive audience members screaming from auditoriums with their hands over their ears, is a 20-minute exploration of repetition and time displacement. It works on the same principle as school clapping games, with subtle signals between participators resulting in small but significant changes of rhythm. The very simple individual lines intertwine to evoke a babbling brook of shimmering beauty - or a nightmarish chatter of unceasing angst, depending on your frame of mind.

Conlon Nancarrow's Studies Nos 5 and 26 are next, both arranged by the group's David Appleton. Crazy time signatures and crashing discords are a testament to the composer's jazz background, and the six pianists negotiate the troubled waters with poised serenity.

However, it's not until the African-flavoured Mazuzu Dream that they really start to look as if they're enjoying themselves. Based on a piece of township jive, the composition was written by Piano Circus's founding member Max Richter, and gives the six pianists a chance to break out.

The same goes for Miguel del Aguila's Conga Line in Hell (also arranged by Appleton) which begins with a restlessly modulating ragtime feel, progresses through a sequence of tempestuous glissandos, and winds up conjuring images of heroines tied to railway tracks.

Throughout the concert, the performers' concentration is absolute, their rapport rivetting to behold. Various members quietly count each other in, cue each other with almost imperceptible facial gestures, and sit silently throughout pages of music before striking one solitary chord.

None of the pieces requires titanic technical skills, but the effect of six musicians working together with such precision will hypnotise any lover of accomplished piano playing.

fields.headline: Carmen
fields.standfirst:
London Coliseum
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
London Coliseum
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Jonathan Miller's ENO production of Carmen was deemed by many to be an awkward effort when it first appeared in 1995. I missed it when it was new and can't say whether time has been kind to it, though it strikes me as still inherently flawed and dogged by a peculiar lack of focus.

Miller's decision to avoid the horrid trappings of tourist brochure Spain is admirable: the opera was, after all, deemed brutal and obscene rather than exotic and glitzy when premiered in 1875. What is worrying, however, is his transposition of the work to the grubby years surrounding the Spanish civil war, saddling it with a surface political gloss that it can't quite take and that isn't coherently thought through. José seemingly goes awol from Franco's army. The smugglers are got up as partisans. Carmen, kitted out in leather coat and beret, looks at one point like a resistance fighter.

The problem is compounded with a certain fussiness, and a level of dispassion that at times becomes dangerous. Bizet is, in many respects, opera's answer to Racine, sparse in utterance and employing a pared-down musico-dramatic language in which every note and gesture speaks volumes. Miller swamps the opera's unblinking clarity with overloaded detail, allotting each member of the chorus a sharply defined character, which frequently pulls your attention away from the principals. Miller also distances himself from the work's eroticism, seeing Carmen as an opera about sex rather than as genuinely sexy. It needs, of course, to be both to succeed.

This is a shame, for musically the evening is superb. The chief honours lie with the conductor, Vassily Sinaisky, who unleashes a torrent of emotion and lets the opera's terrible games of sex and death unfold with an outstanding, uncompromising vividness. His Carmen is Louise Winter, who has Ava Gardner looks and a superlatively voluptuous tone, though she occasionally overloads the innuendoes by forcing her voice in its lower registers. John Hudson is equally impressive as José, employing a formidable range of dynamics and vocal colouring to form a compelling portrait of emotional disintegration. Susannah Glanville's Micaela, lustrously sung, is the embodiment of the toughness of moral rectitude. Ashley Holland's Escamillo doesn't quite have the charisma, though vocally he's unfailingly exciting. The whole left me with very mixed feelings - though the best of it is unquestionably very impressive indeed.

 In rep until March 24. Box office: 020-7632 8300.

His Carmen is Louise Winter, who has Ava Gardner looks and a superlatively voluptuous tone, though she occasionally overloads the innuendoes by forcing her voice in its lower registers. John Hudson is equally impressive as José, employing a formidable range of dynamics and vocal colouring to form a compelling portrait of emotional disintegration. Susannah Glanville's Micaela, lustrously sung, is the embodiment of the toughness of moral rectitude. Ashley Holland's Escamillo doesn't quite have the charisma, though vocally he's unfailingly exciting. webTitle: Advisers battle to preserve independent advice

fields.headline: Advisers battle to preserve independent advice
fields.trailText: Planned changes by the government to the way financial products such as pensions, Isas and unit trusts are sold could mislead the public according to many smaller, independent advisers who are fearful of losing their livelihoods.
fields.body:
Planned changes by the government to the way financial products such as pensions, Isas and unit trusts are sold could mislead the public according to many smaller, independent advisers who are fearful of losing their livelihoods.

The move to end so-called polarisation has caused a storm in the independent financial adviser market (IFA), who fear they will be under threat if the changes are introduced, and that the benefits of impartial advice could be lost.

Currently, a choice of financial products from different providers can only be sold by IFAs, whereas banks and building societies must be tied to one lender.

The proposed changes mean that banks and building societies will be able to sell a range of products, typically from four or five providers. This will be known as a multi-tie arrangement and should bring more choice to people looking for financial help on the high street. IFAs are mainly seen by more affluent people.

But, the products offered are still likely to be less than that offered by most IFAs. And it is also likely the staff employed by bank and building societies will be less experienced and have few, if any, qualifications compared to IFAs.

The Financial Services Authority (FSA), the government backed regulator, has said it is currently looking at different options ranging from leaving the current situation unchanged, introducing it partially or scrapping polarisation altogether.

Polarisation was introduced 12 years ago, in a move to protect the public, but the FSA claims the market is now much better regulated and that the position adopted in the UK is out of touch with the rest of Europe. As a result, most experts believe that polarisation will be at least partially scrapped in particular as far as stakeholder pensions and some investment products such as CAT market ISAs are concerned.

CAT marked financial products - which stands for Cover, Access and Terms - are lower cost products aimed to help consumers find more standardised and clearer financial products at reasonable cost.

The real catalyst to end polarisation is stakeholder pensions. These are lower cost private plans aimed at the mass workforce. The government is desperate for them to succeed, as it does not believe there will be sufficient from National Insurance contributions to provide an acceptable level of state pensions.

It believes if it allows banks and building societies to sell a range of stakeholder pension products, there will be improved competition.

But, IFAs insist ending polarisation will simply confuse consumers more. Christine Hawkins, a partner with Horsham based Principles in Practice said: "There is just going to be major confusion. Many clients I see have no idea what is the difference between independent advice and tied agents. Multi-ties will make matters worse. You could also find banks just offer a range of poor products and staff will not be qualified to advise people."

Most IFAs fear they will lose business if the large banks win more business - they see it as similar to the corner shop versus the supermarket.

One IFA, Brian Lentz of Hatfield based firm Portfolio says: "This really is the thin end of the wedge. At present you either deal with one company or see someone who is independent. This whole business with multi-ties will leave people totally confused."

Another IFA, Alan Lakey of Highclere Financial Services based in Hemel Hempstead, says: "A lot of the financial products currently offered by banks are rubbish. But, once polarisation ends, they could be able to sell a range of bad products. Alternatively, they could offer the best products in the market and at competitive cost because of volume. This would mean it is impossible for IFAs to compete."

Although the Consumers' Association has spoken out in favour of retaining polarisation, Lakey believes the watchdog has not done enough. "I think they have their hands tied because of the government, we need a proper campaign to make sure the public understands what is happening."

fields.headline: Glasgow welcomes famous lovers
fields.standfirst:
Casanova
Tron Theatre
Glasgow
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Casanova
Tron Theatre
Glasgow
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Like any encounter with a real Casanova, Suspect Culture's new play involves equal measures of love and loathing. With the real, philandering thing, there's a veneer of love, just for a moment, an hour, one night, and then loathing - of yourself and of him - for believing those well-rehearsed lines.

In his new theatrical guise, the problem is more a tension between concept - the audacious presentation of Casanova as honest hero in a sea of deadening monogamy and women's self-delusion - and dramatic realisation. The concept is brave in this post-Aids, post-feminist world, and David Greig convincingly writes us a man who can say, after 3,267 sexual conquests, that "there has been no deceit".

He also writes perceptively on the games women play. Casanova's uptight PA swears she will never succumb to his charms and then does so in an aeroplane toilet ("The air hostess knocked on the door after an hour"); Mrs Tennant, an international art collector, keeps Casanova in her life as a reminder of her youthful self but doesn't want him when he finally says she is the one to tame him. "I like being married," she confesses, on her way home to a takeaway dinner and video, "It's comfortable."

But it is the way these moments of truth are theatrically reached that seriously dilutes the play's power. It is at least 45 minutes too long, and the structure - brief scenes in airports, coffee bars, toilets, galleries - involves far too much hoiking around of stage-set.

Casanova is supposed to be returning home to Glasgow to an exhibition commemorating his sexual life, but keeps meeting more irresistible women, played with a fine selection of accents and two wigs by Vicki Liddelle. This is all necessary, funny and sharp: after an encounter with a Russian gangster's moll, who speaks no English but mentions Milan, Casanova and his PA fly first class to Italy to find her. She isn't there, of course.

Less necessary is the sub-plot: the cabinet-maker's revenge after Casanova had a fling with his wife and she never came back. He hires a detective to impersonate his wife, lure Casanova into bed and then kill him.

We need some of this - the cabinet-maker and detective fall into a queasy, too easy relationship with each other, while she is still dressed as his wife, and they are the play's representation of the lies that can shape monogamy. But there is too much of him and his cabinets, too much of the plight of the cabinet-maker in the conceptual art world. Not something Casanova would ever think about, and not something this only fleetingly compelling drama should be dwelling on either.

 At the Tron (0141-552 4267) until March 3, Paisley Arts Centre (0141-887 1010) on March 6, Newcastle Playhouse (0191-230 5151) on March 9 and 10, then touring.

webTitle: Byers must take the City off tenterhooks

fields.headline: Byers must take the City off tenterhooks
fields.standfirst:
Decision day looms for Lloyds

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: The wait is almost over for Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, to tell us whether Lloyds TSB's £19bn bid for Abbey National should be subjected to the full scrutiny of a competition commission inquiry.
fields.body:
The wait is almost over for Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, to tell us whether Lloyds TSB's £19bn bid for Abbey National should be subjected to the full scrutiny of a competition commission inquiry.

The City must be put out of its misery by the end of today - the last day under the official timetable for Mr Byers to make his decision public.

It is not a moment too soon. It follows a week of frenzied speculation about what Mr Byers will do.

By leaving the publication of his decision until the very last opportunity, he has also fuelled the City's rumour mill.

For what it is worth, the "hot" word in the markets yesterday claimed that the office of fair trading had recommended that the takeover be given the all clear on competition grounds, but that Mr Byers - whether for reasons of consumer protection or mundane political expediency - would overrule the regulator and send the matter to the competition authorities regardless.

This will leave Mr Byers open to furious criticism - from Lloyds TSB at least - of engaging in precisely the kind of political interference he had promised to avoid, but there are good reasons to hope that the hot money is also smart.

While there has been some substantial evidence this week that the level of competition in retail banking is alive and growing, it is important to notice where it is being generated - outside the ranks of the "big four" in which Lloyds TSB is placed along with Barclays, HSBC and NatWest.

It was Halifax, Abbey National's closest competitor, which moved to slash a full percentage point off its regular mortgage rate.

That suggests the competition is not only alive but cutthroat. And, having shored up its competitive position on mortgages, Halifax is promising to train its guns on the current account market, at present still stitched up by the "big four".

Abbey is also trying to wrest control of the highly profitable current account market from the big four.

Like Halifax, it is trying to position itself as a real competitor for the accounts of customers who are traditionally more likely to get a divorce than switch their bank.

Combined with Abbey National, Lloyds would boost its already formidable position in current accounts to close to 30%. In the process, it would be taking out one of the banks which was doing its best to inject competition into the market.

Perhaps more crucially, it would also give a green light to any other the big banks to consider taking a swipe at the feisty Halifax, which would undoubtedly raise problems for any suitor as a result of its 19% share of the mortgage market. The eradication of these former building societies should be deterred. Woolwich, which launched the innovative all in one account Open Plan, has already been gobbled up by Barclays. Alliance & Leicester is likely to remain independent for only as long the protection it received against hostile takeovers when it converted exists.

These former building societies play a role in frustrating the dominance of the big four. Nobody is suggesting that their management should hide behind competition doubts to reject unwanted bids. But Mr Byer's first and overriding duty is to protect the consumer.

Frank nonsense

There was a refreshingly frank admission yesterday from Diageo's chief executive, Paul Walsh, who conceded that Burger King was upsetting its customers by selling them cold Whoppers with a stingy smear of mayo.

The remark, which conjured up memories of Gerald Ratner, was all the more startling as it slipped out after a dense flow of irony free marketing waffle: on Diageo's spirits business, Mr Walsh bemused his audience by declaring that "the sensuality of Bailey's opens you up to the pleasure of connecting with others".

Burger King's recent record is dismal - the introduction of "stealth fries", named after a special coating compared to the US army's stealth bomber, flopped two years ago. The chain's chief executives seem to last about as long as the average teenage burger flipper.

Just at the moment, the prospect of buying shares in Burger King's planned flotation looks as appetising as a soggy cheeseburger.

Mr Walsh, who took the helm at Diageo in September, at least appears to be doing something. In John Dasburg, he has recruited a heavy hitter to run the restaurant chain, and two new ad agencies should help put some fight back into the battle with McDonald's.

But his understanding of events on the ground is suspect. The real flaw with the flame-grilled Whopper is that it contains a large slice of tomato which falls out with a greasy glob of mush as soon as the discerning diner attempts to take a bite. The Big Mac's finely chopped ingredients, although unidentifiable, are infinitely more convenient.

fields.headline: Rien de Rien
fields.standfirst:
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
The world according to Les Ballets C de la B's Rien de Rien is a chaotic babel of languages in which we can either feel trapped within our own culture or free to go on a surfing spree of signs. The show's line-up - a 59-year-old former ballet dancer, a 15-year-old girl, a jazz singer and three men of Moroccan, Slovenian and Belgian origin - is itself a kind of postmodern, polyglot paradigm, brought together in a mosque, where cellist Roel Dieltiens plays a fabulously strange and discordant accompaniment to the performers' confessions, communications and party pieces. For 75 minutes the company speak and sing in English, French, Latin, Russian and Slovene, as well as dancing their way through tango, ballet, lindy hop, faux Isadora Duncan and modern dance.

There's no narrative driving the work other than the glimpses we get of the dancers' individual stories. But choreographer Sidi Larbi Cherkaoui, (familiar to London through his performance in Alain Platel's Iets Op Bach) doesn't serve up a lazy ragbag of theatrical scraps but an absorbing and clever meditation on public language and personal idiosyncrasy.

It opens with the three men dancing a sequence of meditative coiling movements - as fluid as the scrawl of Arabic script that crosses the back wall. Then the two younger women start to deliver, in perfect unison, an anecdote about Belgian travellers in a remote desert trying to accommodate their vegetarian sensibilities to the ritual slaughter and cooking of goat. The story is very funny - liberal westerners desperately trying to understand an alien world - but what's even funnier is the sharpness with which the women's gabby speech patterns and urban gestures have been foregrounded in the routine, their glib body language helplessly distancing them from their third world hosts and simultaneously marking a comic gender divide from the gravely dancing men on stage.

Whether these performers are dancing or talking, we see how style can either unite or separate, we see how individuals may strive for communality but become isolated by difference. Ballerina Marie-Louise Wilderijkx is blithely at ease dancing tango with one of the men but absurdly unapproachable when in diva Duncan mode; Cherkaoui's gorgeously powered dancing connects him with the other two men, but cuts him off as soon as he tries to outdo them. Little Laura Neyskens is absorbed into the grown-ups' world via her precocious technique but is left adolescently awkward when the material turns adult.

There are sections when the show's pace threatens to flag - where the material needs to be fleshed out with more activity, or where its intimacies need to be pursued to greater depth. Yet all of the performances are so expert, and Cherkaoui's eye for the singularity of body language is so witty and sharp, that we still end up feeling as if we know a startling amount about these people and the noisy, disjointed world we all inhabit.

fields.headline: Back to Methuselah
fields.standfirst:
Barbican
London
Rating: *
fields.trailText:
Barbican
London
Rating: *
fields.body:
Plenty of plays - no, the majority of plays written - are best left to moulder in peace after their first staging. Once is quite enough. Once is one time too many for Shaw's 1921 epic, which begins in 4004BC with Adam and Eve losing their innocence, and moves forward through time to AD31920, where babies are hatched out of eggs into a brave new world.

By the age of four, humans have got love, sex and fun out of the way and metamorphose into pure thought. This sterile, scary, loveless but presumably wise world where the ancients speak like Daleks and look like very pale Ancient Egyptians is called Arcadia. You are not entirely sure that Shaw is being ironic. He was not big on the merits of sensuality and emotional intelligence.

There may be something in the idea that we do not live long enough to achieve wisdom, but as is so often the case with Shaw, he makes a mountain out of a molehill. For all the flashes of wit, mockery of politicians and fantastical weirdness, the sheer number of words is out of all proportion to the message.

Shaw called his play a "metabiological pentateuch" and grandiosely likened it to Wagner's Ring cycle. In its original form it would last around 10 hours. Director David Fielding has done Shaw a huge favour by trimming it to four hours, although the Reduced Shakespeare version might be even more agreeable.

Fielding's intelligent, but sometimes irritatingly camp, production (Adam and Eve wear Barbie wigs), treats the play as if it were a sci-fi saga and sets it in a laboratory where white-coated technicians are conducting a series of experiments. The parade of intellectuals, puffed-up politicians, Chinese sages, Napoleon and ancients with beehive craniums are treated with a comic irreverence that makes Shaw's pontificating rather more bearable. The acting is commendable, as if the actors actually believe the hokum they are spouting.

If you were confident of living for 300 years, Shaw's play would be one way of filling the time, but as most of us are unlikely to reach treble figures, four hours of this is too much.

 Until April 5. Box office: 020-7638 8891.

fields.headline: With-profits policies condemned
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Insurance policies worth £400bn will today be condemned by financial services authority chairman Howard Davies as "opaque, obscure and high-charging".
fields.body:
Insurance policies worth £400bn will today be condemned by financial services authority chairman Howard Davies as "opaque, obscure and high-charging" as the chief City regulator presents plans to overhaul the with-profits industry.

In the wake of the closure of Equitable Life and court battles over the ownership of £45bn of "orphan assets" held by insurance firms, Mr Davies will say that with-profits funds have "serious disadvantages" and predict that their popularity will shrink markedly over the next 20 years.

With-profits funds, such as endowments, pensions and savings bonds, are held by 10m people, and contain a mix of shares, bonds and property.

But the FSA says that charges, averaging 3.5% per year for 10-year policies and 1.5% for 25-year policies, are significantly higher than other investment instruments.

Mr Davies also believes too much of the payouts on the policies comes in the form of a large terminal bonus, and that anybody cashing in early earns a return well below the market average. He will also call for an end to archaic terms in with-profits policies.

He will outline the principal areas for the FSA's review of with-profits policies, which will focus on the amount of discretion insurance firms can have over with-profits funds, clarity of information to policyholders and procedures for handling orphan asset cases.

The FSA's action on with-profits will be welcomed by the Consumer's Association, which only two weeks ago accused the with-profits industry of chronic underpayment of returns to investors and of skimming off billions of pounds in orphan asset cash to give to shareholders.

webTitle: Art review: Murillo: Scenes of Childhood

fields.headline: Murillo and the street children
fields.standfirst:
Murillo: Scenes of Childhood
Dulwich Picture Gallery
London
fields.trailText:
Murillo: Scenes of Childhood
Dulwich Picture Gallery
London
fields.body:
The only problem with this exhibition is its title. Scenes of Childhood suggests something sweet and unthreatening. Yet if the style of Bartolome Esteban Murillo (1617-1682) is as sugary as churros in chocolate bought from a Sevillian street vendor, the content of his paintings of children is anything but. These are not the royal princes painted by Velazquez, or the indulged middle-class children of Murillo's Dutch contemporaries. They are poor, parentless, uncared for, forced to work for a living or starve. They are fruitsellers, beggars, apprentice thieves.

There are not many paintings of the disinherited to set alongside the monarchs and prelates that fill Europe's art galleries. That is what makes Murillo's Urchin Hunting For Fleas (c1648) so arresting. This is a painting of a street boy sheltering in a rough, sparse hole of a place, the sunlight hits him through a big unglazed window, illuminating his skinny, rag-clothed body as he delouses himself. It's a hard, detailed painting: his feet are filthy, he's been eating a few shrimps and seems to be on a break from selling unpalatable apples.

This painting has been owned by the Louvre since the early 19th century and influenced the French realists; Manet copied it. It's one of Murillo's earliest street paintings and the style is not what we expect from a man who worked all his life in Seville and is known chiefly as a religious painter.

As he developed his sideline in "genre" paintings, Murillo turned his street scenes from harsh slices of life such as this, or Two Boys Eating Melon and Grapes (c1650), to whimsical images of shoeless, ragged children full of high jinks. His proletarians are seen through a fine lacy gauze.

It's possible to accuse these later paintings of softening poverty. Yet, surely, ignoring the dispossessed would be easier. Even at their gooiest, Murillo's paintings do not conceal the street children's calloused feet and rags. He was a pious man, and these paintings are full of charity. At their darkest, they are still upsetting to look at today. Most uncomfortable of all is Four Figures on a Step (c1655-60), in which we are in the position of the passerby accosted by two youths and an old woman wearing spectacles, who is delousing a boy.

The woman is Celestina, a traditional Spanish figure of the procuress. There's something very nasty under the honeyed surface. Who is the procuress offering to the sexual shopper - the young woman or the boy?

 Until May 13. Details: 020-8693 5254.

webTitle: Advisers battle to preserve independent advice

fields.headline: Advisers battle to preserve independent advice
fields.trailText: Planned changes by the government to the way financial products, such as pensions, Isas and unit trusts, are sold could mislead the public and mean the benefits of impartial advice could be lost according to many smaller, independent advisers who are fearful of losing their livelihoods.
fields.body:
Planned changes by the government to the way financial products, such as pensions, Isas and unit trusts, are sold could mislead the public and mean the benefits of impartial advice could be lost according to many smaller, independent advisers who are fearful of losing their livelihoods.

The move to end so-called polarisation has caused a storm in the independent financial adviser market who fear they will be under threat if the changes are introduced.

Currently, a choice of financial products from different providers can only be sold by IFAs, whereas banks and building societies must be tied to one lender.

The proposed changes mean that banks and building societies will be able to sell a range of products, typically from four or five providers. This will be known as a multi-tie arrangement and should bring more choice to people looking for financial help on the high street.

But the products offered are still likely to be less than that offered by most IFAs. And it is also likely the staff employed by bank and building societies will be less experienced and have few, if any, qualifications compared to IFAs.

The Financial Services Authority, the government backed regulator, has said it is currently looking at different options ranging from leaving the current situation unchanged, introducing change partially or scrapping polarisation altogether.

Polarisation was introduced 12 years ago, in a move to protect the public, but the FSA claims the market is now much better regulated and that the position adopted in the UK is out of touch with the rest of Europe. As a result, most experts believe that polarisation will be at least partially scrapped in particular as far as stakeholder pensions and some investment products such as CAT market ISAs are concerned.

CAT marked financial products Ð which stands for Cover, Access and Terms Ð are lower cost products aimed to help consumers find more standardised and clearer financial products at reasonable cost.

The real catalyst to end polarisation is stakeholder pensions. These are lower cost private plans aimed at the mass workforce. The government is desperate for them to succeed, as it does not believe there will be sufficient from national insurance contributions to provide an acceptable level of state pensions.

It believes if it allows banks and building societies to sell a range of stakeholder pension products, there will be improved competition.

But, IFAs insist ending polarisation will simply confuse consumers more. Christine Hawkins, a partner with Horsham based Principles in Practice said: "There is just going to be major confusion. Many clients I see have no idea what is the difference between independent advice and tied agents. Multi-ties will make matters worse. You could also find banks just offer a range of poor products and staff will not be qualified to advise people."

Most IFAs fear they will lose business if the large banks win more business Ð they see it as similar to the corner shop versus the supermarket.

One IFA, Brian Lentz of Hatfield based firm Portfolio says: "This really is the thin end of the wedge. At present you either deal with one company or see someone who is independent. This whole business with multi-ties will leave people totally confused."

Another IFA, Alan Lakey of Highclere Financial Services based in Hemel Hempstead, says: "A lot of the financial products currently offered by banks are rubbish. But, once polarisation ends, they could be able to sell a range of bad products. Alternatively, they could offer the best products in the market and at competitive cost because of volume. This would mean it is impossible for IFAs to compete."

Although the ConsumersÕ Association has spoken out in favour of retaining polarisation, Lakey believes the watchdog has not done enough. "I think they have their hands tied because of the government, we need a proper campaign to make sure the public understands what is happening."

fields.headline: Another day, another naked actress
fields.standfirst:
The Graduate
Gielgud Theatre
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
The Graduate
Gielgud Theatre
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Men of a certain age get Art; women get The Graduate. While the men tussle in a vaguely intellectual fashion over a white painting, the women fall out of a white towel and into white satin sheets. The West End is the land that time and feminism forgot, and The Graduate is its calling card, an appallingly conservative, thoroughly tedious male fantasy of lust sated and love gained. At least the object of lust is once again an actress, not a model, but you wouldn't know it from Amanda Donohoe's monochrome performance.

Donohoe's Mrs Robinson has two expressions: eyes open, chin flat; eyes slanted, chin jutting out. And her voice grows more angular to match, practically slicing out of her nostrils to give each cynical quip a metallic sheen. This is fine in doses, even delicious when she says of daughter Elaine "I think Peaches is rebelling", but her unrelenting archness is tiresome over the whole evening.

The real trouble, however, is that it is impossible to believe in her character. Through her bouts with Benjamin in the hotel, her drunken chat with Elaine, her exasperation with her husband at the wedding, she maintains the same air of boredom. Worse still is her shyness. Here is a supposedly sophisticated woman who drops her dress to titillate, yet clings to the bedsheets like a timid teen after she has sex. It is irritatingly dishonest, and symptomatic of adapter/director Terry Johnson's deference to the story's hypocritical coyness.

To Donohoe's credit, the play leaves no room for manoeuvre - it is populated by caricatures stuck in a groove. No matter how spirited Andres Williams's performance, his sulky sop Benjamin remains a whingeing ninny, not even happy when he gets his girl. Coral Beed has moments of real emotion as Elaine, and almost hints at character development, but she too ends the play as sappy as ever.

But as long as there are actresses willing to strip in a soft blue light, The Graduate will run and run. On press night, Cilla Black, Barbara Windsor and Tamara Beckwith were in the stalls. Let's hope they weren't taking notes for when Donohoe steps down.

 Booking until April 7. Box office: 020-7494 5065. This review appeared in later editions of yesterday's paper.
